webTitle: ICC to look at Malik match-fixing tapes

fields.headline: ICC to look at Malik match-fixing tapes
fields.trailText: Lord Griffiths, the chairman of the ICC's code-of-conduct commission is to study covert videotapes, which if genuine may provide some of the most devastating evidence in the match-fixing scandal.
fields.body:
For once the International Cricket Council has acted with alacrity in accepting the News of the World's offer of videotapes in which Salim Malik allegedly implicates a leading ICC official in match-fixing.

The covert tapes, which if genuine may provide some of the most devastating evidence in the match-fixing scandal, will be studied by Lord Griffiths, the chairman of the ICC's code-of-conduct commission.

The emergence of the tapes, only days after the England and Wales Cricket Board chairman Lord MacLaurin spoke of "mafia-type criminals" infiltrating the game, ensures that the ICC's meeting at Lord's on June 20 will be a deeply troubled one.

The newspaper alleged that Malik boasted of his match-fixing prowess to undercover reporters posing as wealthy gamblers. The Pakistan batsman allegedly said that, with the help of an ICC middleman, he could arrange for matches to be fixed during England's tour to Pakistan this winter.

More dithering from authorities initially seemed likely, with the ICC chairman Jagmohan Dalmiya busy firing off writs to protect his own reputation against claims that he was involved in corrupt TV deals. There was also little sign of pressure from the ECB when Tim Lamb, its chief executive, shied away from demanding that the ICC took immediate action on the dubious ground that it had not yet appointed its anti-corruption officer. "You cannot have a trial without a judge," he said.

As anyone using courtroom imagery should know, evidence needs to be assembled as soon as possible, and after yesterday's decision Lord Griffiths should be able to draft a full report in time for next month's meeting.

fields.headline: Hey, good-looking! Want a job?
fields.standfirst:
The way we work

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder - which is all very well when the beholder is someone you are trying to pick up in a club or over canapés. What about when they are a potential employer?
fields.body:
Beauty is in the eye of the beholder - which is all very well when the beholder is someone you are trying to pick up in a club or over canapés. What about when they are a potential employer? We all worry about polishing our cvs and preparing for tough interview questions, but it seems we might be better off buffing up in the gym or getting our eyebrows plucked - preparing ourselves for the aesthetic economy.

Chris Warhurst and Dennis Nickson, at Strathclyde University, have been researching the "style labour market" in Glasgow, finding that how people dress, look and conduct themselves is critical to their chances of landing a job in the city's booming service sector. As the economy shifts towards "high touch" jobs, the premium on presentation is rising. According to Cosmopolitan - and Cosmo knows - the number of women having plastic surgery for professional reasons has soared in recent years.

Of course, how people look has always had an effect on their employment chances, especially in the most visible professions. MPs and TV presenters are increasingly expected to have what programmers dub the "F-factor", but now the aesthetic imperative has reached the bottom of the labour market, too. Shop assistants, cafe workers, salespeople - all are seen as extensions of the firm and have to look the part.

In the service-crazy US, the reality of aesthetics has been accepted for decades. Charities exist to take cast-off clothes from professional women to help their jobless counterparts secure work. Us Brits are traditionally more squeamish about admitting that how you look, dress, talk - or even smell - might be as important as your GCSE results. But signs are the penny is dropping. One New Deal programme now has as its motto: Spray your pits and wash your bits.

In Glasgow, the Wise Group, a leading charity helping unemployed people into work, has piloted a course specifically targeted at self-image. Attendees visit certain stores and take notes on how the staff, customers and products look, and how they would present themselves for a job there. They are taught to recognise that there is a Gap look, a brand, that they should imitate in an interview. The students spend a day pretending to be someone else, have a make-over, get photographs taken.

The response is enthusiastic, according to Allan Watt, the group's director of development, and he thinks the approach will prove effective. "In a lot of workplaces, how you present yourself is vital now," he says. "A bar or hotel might have spent a fortune on their furniture, so they want their staff to look good, too."

What Warhurst and Nickson coyly call our "embedded capacities" count for everything. "You are now part of the product," Watt says. "We need to help unemployed people understand this."

All this is fine and dandy for those fortunate enough to be born with supermodel looks. But what about those with limited embedded capacities? Will ugliness equal unemployment? Not necessarily - call centres need people with a good voice and phone manner, not George Clooney looks. Watt reckons that while some employers will be lookist in their recruitment policies, for most it is "personality" and "self-esteem" that count.

A recognition of the importance of presentation is a welcome counter to the naive view held in some parts of government that if only people had enough qualifications, they would be OK, ignoring the realities of the hiring process. But it is a question of balance. We should admit that presentation is crucial and help people to look and sound and act as attractively - and employably - as possible. But we don't want a labour market of looks, where the unattractive and dull have no place but the dole queue.

Labour of love

According to Andrew Oswald, an economist who studies satisfaction, losing our job has a bigger impact on our happiness level than splitting up with our partner. How shocking! Or maybe not. It is strange that we insist on seeing work as an insignificant, or bad, part of our lives compared with that area of radiant happiness, our personal lives. There are plenty of people who have a better relationship with their job than with their partner.

But achingly trendy ad agency St Luke's may be taking things a bit far. We all know that meeting the parents is a rubicon for any relationship and the company is now holding "parents' evenings" to which staff bring their mum and dad. Now, that is a terrifying thought.
Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Bye bye Boos
fields.standfirst:
It was groovy, glamorous, going somewhere. And then a week ago, Boo.com became the first high-profile internet start-up to come to a grinding halt. Rumours about its future rumbled on until Monday, when 220 staff finally got their cards. John Cunningham finds out how they feel now

E-finance: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It was groovy, glamorous, going somewhere. And then a week ago, Boo.com became the first high-profile internet start-up to come to a grinding halt. Rumours about its future rumbled on until Monday, when 220 staff finally got their cards.  John Cunningham finds out how they feel now
fields.body:
As a group of mostly twentysomethings, the staff of online sportswear retailer Boo.com are very different from the usual casualties of a company crash - and so are their reactions. Bruised by the first collapse in Britain of a highflying dot.com retailer? Hard to find anyone who is. Bitter about their bosses? No way. Traumatised at being jobless? They're too busy following new leads.

This buzz is in stark contrast to the gloom that surrounds old-style layoffs in conventional firms. It's a world away from Longbridge, different from sackings in the City. The reason in part is that words like security, pensions and redundancy package are not in the vocabularies of young staff. Bonuses and share options are. Dismissal is for them a challenge, a career blip. But is their optimism justified?

Will Hutton, chief executive of the Industrial Society, points out: "In a tight labour market, there is a real demand for their skills and their confidence about getting a new job spills into a swashbuckling attitude." Nevertheless, he warns against being "seduced by the cult of the share option" - Boo went belly-up before there were any profits to share.

As for worker protection, unions have made some impact in e-finance but in dot.coms personal contracts are the norm. That gives individuals a feeling of power - but does the feeling last when a company has failed? Here, four former Boo workers reveal all.

Lisa Bradley, 23. European footwear buyer. Joined last year

It's quite a shock being 23 and losing your job,' Lisa Bradley says. "We all took it in our stride - some people even sounded excited - but on the retail team, we knew opportunities wouldn't be as wide for us." A psychology graduate, she has been "phoning all the agencies I know" but so far has seen only two jobs in merchandising or retailing. She didn't bother going in on Monday: "There wasn't any point as we weren't going to get our money." No good-news emails yesterday, either, just an interview with an agency and scouring the trade press for ads.

Bradley has no major financial commitments, but says she faces an uneasy time until she firms up her next position. She is chastened by Boo's demise and sad because, after all their efforts (long hours and a bad press were part of the package, she says ruefully), it was starting to work. Even so, the experience hasn't put her off. "I think e-commerce will happen, hopefully in two or three years' time."

Meanwhile, she is not one of those who would like to move on very quickly from job to job. "I'm looking for something long-term. Something for five or six years."

Emma Thomson, 26. Copywriter. Joined a year ago

When the crash came, Emma Thomson says, she was "worried for about two seconds. Everyone is helping everyone else. There were constant emails about new opportunities." The company's high profile, which helped attract investors and customers in the first place, also proved an asset when it crashed. Boo.com had a reputation for employing enthusiastic, talented people, hence the scramble to sign up its workers. "There were people from recruitment agencies handing out their cards on Thursday, by the door and in bars where we drink."

Thomson, who joined Boo a year ago from the publisher Quarto, decided not to wait to see if a buyer could be found. On Friday, she accepted a new job - paying 30% more. "It's with an internet company that designs other people's websites. I'll be a senior copywriter and content developer."

She is elated at how quickly good news sprang out of bad and says she feels no bitterness: "There were rumours for months." As for the founders' alleged profligacy, Thomson is diplomatic. "Getting through £91m in a year is quite lavish," she says simply.

Paul Kanareck, 25. Co-founder's assistant. Joined 18 months ago

On Monday, Paul Kanareck had his first early night for a week. Staff had crowded into the office at 10am to hear that all but 30 of them would lose their jobs - and to study the scores of offers that had been made to Boo in the past few days. A master list was compiled and constantly updated.

"A lot of senior managers were around, phoning colleagues to see if they could help," Kanareck says. At lunchtime, he noticed headhunters in a couple of Boo staff's favourite bars. Then it was back to check his messages. No new offers - he's taking his time over the two firm proposals he has so far had from media/ internet companies. He expects more.

The day the company finally died was an anticlimax, he says, after last week's drama. On Wednesday Kanareck, an Arsenal fan, was in Copenhagen for the game against Galatasaray when he got a mid-match call to say the plug was being pulled on Boo.com. On Thursday, he was back in the office to hear his boss, Ernst Malmsten, and co-founder Kajsa Leander address a packed staff meeting. The ovation they got shows the resilience of the Boo.com culture in the face of failure. "This is not a bring-out-the-violins kind of story. It's not 80s-style industrial mass redundancy," Kanareck says simply.

Having made the move from the City, he wants to "continue the momentum". E-commerce "is exactly right for my generation of bankers, lawyers, accountants, consultants who don't have a clear idea what to do with our careers - it gave us passion and commitment." The only thing it didn't give him was a holiday.

Megan Goodge, 25. Liaised with suppliers. Joined a year ago

It wasn't a bad start to Megan Goodge's first day of unemployment: "The phone started ringing at 8.30. There was a real mixture of offers: management consultants, media consultants, manufacturers in the industry. A lot of the calls were from contacts I've made in the last year. Now I've got a stack of interviews lined up."

When the redundancies were announced on Monday, "it was a sad day for me, a bit like the break-up of a family. I went to a couple of bars, mainly just to say goodbye." But Boo.commers, born networkers, will be staying in touch. Goodge made sure her name was on the list of ex-employees and she fully expects to work with colleagues again. A Cambridge graduate who spent two years as a consultant, she already has a plan in place: three months' freelancing, three months in Central America to learn Spanish, then back to Britain next year, to resume work or pursue a research thesis.

webTitle: Exporters win respite as pound drops

fields.headline: Exporters win respite as pound drops
fields.standfirst:
Outgoing MPC members clash over intervention in the market

Money Unlimited
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's hard-pressed exporters won a respite from the impact of the strong pound yesterday when sterling slumped to its lowest level this year on the foreign exchanges.
fields.body:
Britain's hard-pressed exporters won a respite from the impact of the strong pound yesterday when sterling slumped to its lowest level this year on the foreign exchanges.

With British interest rates thought to be at or near their peak and euroland borrowing costs expected to increase soon, the pound dropped sharply against the single currency and slid to a new six year low of just over $1.47 against the dollar.

Dealers said that there were signs that the euro may at last have reversed its 17-month slide on the foreign exchanges, amid growing nervousness on Wall Street over US share prices, particularly in over-valued hi-tech stocks.

In late afternoon, the euro had risen as far as 61.82p. Sterling was at its weakest level this year on a trade-weighted basis, down by 1.5%.

Philip Shaw, chief economist at Investec in London, said: "The euro got a boost against the dollar, from weakness in Nasdaq in particular, and has maintained its upward momentum as the market is still very nervous about volatility in US stocks. However it is too early to say that the dollar is on the downward path."

The pound's weakness against the euro was rein forced by comments from five members of the Bank of England's monetary policy.

Giving evidence to the treasury committee, they all agreed sterling was overvalued against the euro but there were sharp differences of opinion over whether intervention was an effective tool for weakening the pound.

Outgoing MPC member Willem Buiter said selling pounds for euros was an ineffective "water pistol" against the weight of financial markets, while fellow member Charles Goodhart said now was a good time to buy more foreign assets.

Mr Goodhart, who is also leaving the MPC, said that even though the impact of intervention on the sterling-euro exchange rate might be slight, it would be worthwhile because it would improve the diversity of Britain's holdings overseas.

It could also produce a profit if the euro, as expected, finally turned the corner and improved in value, he said.

Comparing intervention to shepherding, Sushil Wadhwani said a few sheepdogs could be effective against a herd of cows when they were stampeding. However, Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, told the committee that the markets were just as likely to be influenced by MPC members giving their views in speeches. He said:

"Intervention in terms of affecting the exchange rate for monetary policy purposes is only likely to be effective if the market is just about to come to the conclusion that it has got the rates wrong in the first place. The purpose of intervention is to pose the question to the markets: 'is this really where the exchange rate should be?' We can pose the question just as well by stating our opinion that the rate is not at a rational position as we can by intervening."

The Bank's deputy governor Mervyn King warned that the pound could fall sharply, with a 25% decline against the euro triggering a 2% or 3% point rise in inflation.

Departing duo at odds

Charles Goodhart

Born : 1949, The Netherlands.

Career : joins London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development next month as its new chief economist after three years on the MPC and distinguished academic ca reer, including posts at Princeton, LSE, Yale and Cambridge.

Strengths : capacity for free-thinking, good sense of humour.

Weaknesses : inconsistent, arrogant

Views on intervention : ineffective at best, like using a water pistol against the firepower of the global forex market.

Willem Buiter

Born : 1936, London.

Career : LSE professor, former chief adviser at Bank of England, now leaving the MPC after three-year stint which he combined with part-time academic work. Author of Goodhart's law, which states that when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.

Strengths : looks like a central banker.

Weaknesses : sounds like one.

Views on intervention : might not dramatically influence the euro-pound exchange rate, but unlikely to to the opposite. Could make the exchequer a few pounds if the euro recovers strongly.

fields.headline: British pay dear for francs
fields.standfirst:
EC report criticises currency charges in Europe

Money Unlimited

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: British tourists holidaying in Europe face extortionate bank charges when they buy local currency and France is by far the worst offender, a survey released yesterday by the European Commission reveals.
fields.body:
British tourists holidaying in Europe face extortionate bank charges when they buy local currency and France is by far the worst offender, a survey released yesterday by the European Commission reveals.

The survey shows that a tourist wanting to change £30 in a French bureau de change must pay out an average commission of over 13%, while the rate for changing £60 in a French bank is almost 8%. That compares to an average flat rate of just 2% in the UK.

Taking foreign currency out of a cash point abroad is definitely cheaper but the report warns that charges can vary drastically from card to card. "Eurocard and Mastercard holders sometimes pay twice the charges paid by Visa users," it says.

Exchanging money at a bureau de change abroad is, however, the most expensive option and other European countries where rates are high are listed as Austria (12.65%), Holland (8.53%) and Luxembourg (8.13%).

The report drew an angry response from Euro MPs and Labour MEP Peter Skinner said it was now time for the EC to force banks and bureaux de change to lower their charges. "Consumers have been ripped off for holiday cash for far too long. We need fair play on foreign exchange. If banks won't respond to consumers' demands then it's up to the EC to make sure they play ball," he urged.

The report also shows that the euro has not yet brought down transaction costs for consumers living in the 11 countries that have signed up to the single currency.

Consumers transferring £60 from one country in the euro area to another are still hit with an average fee of £10. Many are also charged twice for the same transaction by banks in either country which is in breach of EU law.

The European Commission has summoned the banks to a meeting next month to explain the situation and if it does not receive assurances that the matter is being resolved satisfactorily has said it will initiate legal action.

An investigation into a suspected cartel between European banks on foreign exchange charges and other transactions is ongoing.

fields.headline: Exchange merger survives German vote
fields.standfirst:
Length of meeting and number of abstentions nurture lingering doubts

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges last night survived its toughest test to date when members of the German stock market's supervisory board formally backed the deal.
fields.body:
The planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges last night survived its toughest test to date when members of the German stock market's supervisory board formally backed the deal.

But the decision, by 17 votes to nil with four abstentions, only came after a longer than expected meeting of the 21-strong body which lasted more than three hours.

Although the margin of the vote will provide a measure of relief for supporters of the merger, the length of the meeting and the number of abstentions will underline concerns about the merger.

More details of the plan emerged after the meeting, with Börse officials pledging that the hi-tech stock Neuer Markt would stay in Frankfurt. They said that while the merged exchange would have its headquarters in London there would be management based in both cities.

They also said the exchange would trade in different currencies but individual stocks could be traded only in one currency.

Earlier, plans for the merger received a double boost with the state of Hesse and the German stock market watchdog, the BAWe, offering guarded support.

Dieter Posch, head of the Hesse economics ministry which had tabled a series of questions about the merger, said he saw no fundamental flaws as long as the Neuer Markt remained in Frankfurt.

"The central question for us in the planned merger is the role which Frankfurt can play as a financial centre."

Chief regulator Georg Wittich said: "We are preparing for it [the merger] to go ahead."

But he warned that both the BAWe and its opposite number in Britain, the financial services authority, still wanted clarification on a number of issues, ranging from common admission and trading rules to insider dealing.

"Who would start investigations? BAWe or the FSA?" he asked.

Under the terms of the merger deal, the market for hi-tech stocks would be based in Frankfurt, while that for blue chip shares would be in London. The merged exchange - to be called iX - would use Frankfurt's Xetra trading system but be run from London.

Werner Seifert, chief executive of the Deutsche Börse, is chief executive designate of iX while the chairmanship will go to Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London exchange. He said details of the tie-up with the Nasdaq technology index would be worked out within "the next 120 days".

Although the principle of the merger has attracted little opposition, the detail of the deal has come under heavy fire. There are concerns in Frankfurt that, because iX will be run from London, Britain will become the power centre of the new operation with trading in the hi-tech stocks migrating to the City.

However, in London there are fears that the deal will mean the decision to locate hi-tech stocks trading in Frankfurt will bring a shift in the balance of power towards the German centre.

In addition there is concern about whether the shares of British companies listed on the merged exchange will be denominated in euros and whether dividends will be paid in the single currency.

fields.headline: Angels and Saints
fields.standfirst:
Be My Baby
***
Angels and Saints
***
Soho Theatre, London
fields.trailText:
Be My Baby
***
Angels and Saints
***
Soho Theatre, London
fields.body:
It is early days yet, but already Soho Theatre has established itself as a powerful force. The body of work it is creating ploughs a furrow of new writing that has been neglected by other theatres.

Artistic director Abigail Morris would probably hate the idea that you can define a Soho play, but out of seven plays this season five have been written by women, all have an immediate accessibility, and most have a kind of blatant honesty about them as they give voice to the lives of very ordinary people. If I had to pigeonhole Soho plays I would say that they often see the extraordinary in the ordinary, the diamonds in the dirt. None more so than these two plays that as a double bill make a long but rewarding evening. They are of such different emotional tenor, however, they might be better savoured on separate viewings.

Amanda Whittington's Be My Baby gives the lie to the idea of the swinging 60s with a story of four girls waiting out their pregnancies in a mother and baby home. It is an old story, but one worth repeating, not least as a reminder of the shame and secrets endured by our mothers' generation.

Whittington writes with a freshness about the innocence and ignorance of teenagers whose enthusiasm for the three-minute romantic dreams peddled by girl groups such as the Shangri-Las and the Ronettes is only matched by their naivety about their own bodies, men and the harsh realities of the world. There is a lovely, tiny moment in the play when middle-class Mary, forcibly sent to the home by her anxious mother, decides to run away. She puts on her gloves to do so, well brought up even in extremis.

There is something very simple and direct about this play. If it were a person you would say it had no side. If it were a person you would want to hold it and hug it.

Jessica Townsend's Angels and Saints is much more autumnal. Just when you think this is another one of those Irish plays about the frustrations of a middle-aged Catholic virgin caring for her elderly gran, it surprises you.

Coming back from the local Spar one day, 46-year-old Noreen has an ecstatic sexual experience in the church graveyard with a Scotsman with a drink problem. And that is about it. Except that Townsend writes with a matter of fact poetry so that the grimness of Noreen's life becomes a kind of benediction. Gabrielle Ready plays Noreen with such lumpy, luminous grace that the play makes you want to rush off to churchyards to find your own angel.

Till June 17. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

fields.headline: Terminally pleasant
fields.standfirst:
The Bluetones
Manchester Academy
***
fields.trailText:
The Bluetones
Manchester Academy
***
fields.body:
The Bluetones are fast becoming pop music's equivalent of the Liberal Democrats. Five years after a brief electoral challenge in the Britpop era, they still write moderate, pleasant tunes and have a reputation as moderate, pleasant chaps. The problem is that they're now only moderately successful. New single Autophilia dropped from 18 to number 40 after only one week, and Manchester Academy isn't full. Many bands, of course, would love the "quandary" of this sort of success, but the Bluetones have always aimed considerably higher. After all, their first - and best - album was called Expecting to Fly.

In attempting the leap, the Tones first attempted to beef-up their sound (with 1998's Return to the Last Chance Saloon) and have now radically altered their image with suits and shorter hair cuts. Neither has quite worked, and the suits - ghastly, it must be said - just don't suit them. The band seem desperate to outgrow their status of terminally indie purveyors of bittersweet adolescent love songs, when their gradually diminishing but devoted fanbase are perfectly happy to keep them that way.

Throughout the gig there are hints that this rather cruel catch-22 is getting to the Bluetones. In his new bespoke outfit, the almost too sincerely charming singer Mark Morris comes over, unfortunately, like an ironic Tommy Steele. "Of course I'm enjoying it!" he says at one point, before introducing a Neil Young cover, Mr Soul, with the words "Now here's one I do like."

The Bluetones may feel less affinity with the older, dewy-eyed songs - mostly written when the band were struggling, naive hopefuls with allergies to ties - but they contain an almost breathtakingly innocent rush that is lacking on their new album, Science & Nature. And when they do "adult" - the rock biz/drugs-scarred Basement Song - it's not exactly Sister Morphine. Closing proceedings with 1998's If, an uncharacteristic tale about a pop performer who becomes trapped by the demands of his own audience, seems curiously significant. It is their best song all night, and in cynical times for pop, is admirably honest.

 At the Town and Country, Leeds (0113-280 0100), tonight, and the Civic, Wolverhampton (01902 552121), tomorrow.

fields.headline: Stories From a Mean Street
fields.standfirst:
Stories From a Mean Street
****
New End Theatre, London
fields.trailText:
Stories From a Mean Street
****
New End Theatre, London
fields.body:
Stand-up Bob Boyton won a dedicated band of admirers with his class-war routines in the mid-80s, but when political cabaret fell from favour he was left high and dry. Other performers, such as Mark Thomas and Jeremy Hardy, found fresh outlets for their radical views, but Boyton was always too militant for the mainstream. Eventually he gave up and went to work with the homeless instead.

Now he's back, with a new 90-minute show, and instead of sniping at the ruling class, Boyton has written a series of tragicomic monologues about disenfranchised individuals at the edges of society. He has stayed true to the political ideas that inspired him originally, but the plight of these funny, desperate characters touches you far more than jokes about fire-bombing Conservative Central Office ever did.

Boyton delivers the opening item himself; the rest are divided between actor Cliff Parisi and Mark Thomas, who cites Boyton as a big influence. The quality of the acting varies, but all the pieces have a strong dramatic structure - often with a twist in the tale - and show a degree of compassion that would have been unthinkable in Boyton's previous incarnation. This is particularly the case with Carol, the story of a recovering junkie whose feckless partner sabotages all her efforts to save herself and to get her baby back from his foster parents.

More than any of the other pieces, this captures a sense of being trapped in a hopeless situation, but Carol eventually breaks free, telling her boyfriend: "I used to think I loved you but now it feels like I left all that behind me on the pavement with my sick."

The other stories concern a hard-up minicab driver, a knife-wielding ex-con and an extremely funny account of a reactionary blind comedian. These characters all inhabit a slightly cliched sawdust world of strippers, bent coppers and shady deals, but they react to the dilemmas they find themselves in with a much greater moral sophistication than such low-lifers would normally be given credit for - which, presumably, is Boyton's point.

fields.headline: Halifax drops cash machine surcharge
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The long-running dispute over cash-machine charging was revived yesterday when the Halifax said it would scrap all charges for withdrawals.
fields.body:
The long-running dispute over cash-machine charging was revived yesterday when the Halifax said it would scrap all charges for withdrawals.

In a move to win customers from its high street rivals, it became the first bank not to follow Barclays, Lloyds TSB and Abbey National in surcharging customers of other banks who who use its machines .

The charges will be dropped at the beginning of next year. Until then the Halifax will continue to collect the £1 disloyalty fee some of its current account and cash-card customers have faced since November when they use machines run by rival banks.

The surprise move by the Halifax, which has almost 3,000 cash machines, comes after the public outcry at Barclays' attempt to impose a £1 surcharge on customers of rival banks using its machines. Barclays' move, which almost tore apart the national Link cash-machine network, was intended to replace the disloyalty fee it charged its customers when they used rival machines.

Mike Ellis, chief operating officer of the Halifax, said he expected other banks to follow its example.

fields.headline: Egg reviews flotation plans
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Prudential last night risked becoming the highest profile victim of the dot.com fallout as it admitted it was reviewing the planned £2bn flotation of its Egg banking subsidiary on a daily basis.
fields.body:
Prudential last night risked becoming the highest profile victim of the dot.com fallout as it admitted it was reviewing the planned £2bn flotation of its Egg banking subsidiary on a daily basis.

It would join the list of flotations and initial public offerings (IPOs) dumped or postponed yesterday as internet and technology companies accepted investor interest was draining away fast.

With the prospectus due this week for the Egg flotation, already half the value estimated three months ago, speculation mounted that the timing of the sale of Egg shares to customers, employees and institutional investors would be delayed from the second week of June.

Amid rumours that the prospectus had been scheduled for publication yesterday, the Pru would only say last night: "No decision has been taken on the exact timing of that announcement. Market conditions are an important factor and the company will continue to examine the situation in light of this".

Among those putting their plans on ice in the teeth of stock market turbulence were Opal Telecom, the third generation telecoms provider, TeleCity, the net infrastructure company, and online games retailer Softwarefirst.com.

Video-on-demand company Video Networks Ltd said it would decide in two weeks whether a flotation will form part of its fundraising plans in the wake of rival Yes Television's abandoned IPO.

Shares in Project Telecom were meant to start trading yesterday but it extended the period for taking orders for its £35m IPO until Friday to win more support.

Opal Telecom said it had received an enthusiatic response from fund managers but had been warned it would be "crazy" to try and push ahead in the current climate of uncertainty.

David Goldie, Opal Telecom's founder, said it could be some months before the market was ready for such a float.

Television company Static 2358 has put its IPO scheme on ice as has Basildon-based Softwarefirst.com whose managing director William Flatau expressed disappointment at the decision to halt a float on Ofex.

"We released our prospectus just before the downturn that has paralysed our marketing and PR effort. Its extremely difficult to achieve a listing even on Ofex in today's market, even though our revenues are up 75% year on year," he explained.

Meanwhile Video Networks said it would take account of Yes's decision on Sunday to pull its initial public offering when it finalised plans for raising hundreds of millions of pounds.

"This and the general market situation has been put into the mix," said chief executive Simon Hochhauser. He believed the company was different from Yes TV, which had far fewer customers and different technology. He hoped the decision by Yes to scrap its IPO at the second attempt might help his own float.

The difficulty of raising money at present has also hit some of the biggest names in Europe. The placement of 10.7m shares in French software and consulting group Cap Gemini, to fund its acquisition of Ernst & Young's consulting arm, was understood to have hit problems yesterday.

Market talk was that the 90% slice of shares allotted to institutional investors was "only just" oversubscribed, by between 1.0 and 1.7 times.

fields.headline: Barclays budgets £325m for net
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Barclays increased the jockeying with rivals for internet customers yesterday, announcing a £325m budget this year for new projects and a pledge to keep making profits despite increased investment.
fields.body:
Barclays increased the jockeying with rivals for internet customers yesterday, announcing a £325m budget this year for new projects and a pledge to keep making profits despite increased investment.

Barclays, which refuses to follow some of its rivals by setting up a separately-branded bank for the internet, published a nine-page list of all its e-commerce initiatives across retail, overseas, Barclaycard, fund management and business banking operations.

The bank, which claims to be the country's biggest on the internet with 1m customers, tried to demonstrate the diversity of its cyberspace clientele by citing the example of a 99-year-old who registered for the online bank last month.

fields.headline: As Meninas/Candid Festival
fields.standfirst:
As Meninas/Candid Festival
****
Pizza Express, London
fields.trailText:
As Meninas/Candid Festival
****
Pizza Express, London
fields.body:
There's something weightless about the work of Monica Vasconcelos, the UK-resident singer from Sao Paulo who launched the Candid record label's week-long showcase. As Meninas (it means "the girls" but there are two honorary boys) is the quartet she leads as an alternative to her orchestral band Nois. The more exposed context highlighted the subtleties of her understated manner and also enhanced the sympathetic understanding Vasconcelos has with her regular saxophonist, Ingrid Laubrock.

Antonio Carlos Jobim often surfaced, but Vasconcelos has a profound grasp of Brazilian musical traditions that allows her to avoid a greatest hits of such superstar composers in favour of equally good, overlooked songs. On uptempo pieces, Vasconcelos would often play percussion in support of her drummer Chris Wells, but her voice has such a light, dancing quality (and a quick, clipped articulation like a string of vocalised punctuation marks) that she blends into the music's breezy shuffle as if she were a rhythm instrument herself.

Ingrid Laubrock shadowed Vasconcelos closely on saxophones, sounding like a confection of many contemporary jazz models on soprano, and at her most lyrical on alto. She plays exquisitely and with an atmospheric sense of space and delay reminiscent of Lee Konitz. That sound, and Ife Tolentino's lapping-waves guitar, allowed Vasconcelos's already airborne music to float all the more freely.

The festival continues with Stacey Kent (tonight), Olga Konkova and David Jean-Baptiste. Box office: 020-7439 8722.

fields.headline: Mikhail Pletnev/ Philharmonia/ Vladimir Conta
fields.standfirst:
Mikhail Pletnev/ Philharmonia/ Vladimir Conta
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Mikhail Pletnev/ Philharmonia/ Vladimir Conta
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
Mikhail Pletnev is a pianist of brilliance and insight, so why wasn't this concert - the second in a two-part retrospective of Tchaikovsky's works for piano and orchestra - the overwhelming experience one had expected? The evening's main focus was on the atrociously difficult Second Piano Concerto and the fragmentary Third. The latter is roughly contemporaneous with the Pathétique Symphony, and both Pletnev and his conductor, the Romanian Vladimir Conta, are anxious to stress the similarities: the baleful instrumentation, full of sardonic woodwind; the frenzied nervousness of its scherzando utterances. Pletnev adopts a dark tone, cumulatively weighting it through the cadenza so that the end of the concerto's single movement has a dense ferocity.

The Second Concerto was characterised by an unusual transparency and translucence. Conceived on a colossal scale, it's bravura stuff, requiring incredible technique and stamina. Most performers go at it hell-for-leather, as if they want to batter the piano into the floor. Pletnev's playing here is almost shocking in its delicacy, though he loses nothing in panache.

Conta zooms through it, avoiding the grandiosity which some bring to the work. He is unable to disguise the jolting transitions of the first movement - but the flaw here is Tchaikovsky's, not his.

However, Conta's conducting has a curious hit-and-miss quality. Capriccio Italien plodded in places where it should be buoyant; and Francesca da Rimini, though finely played, was a very uneven affair. Equating sex with damnation, it's a painful projection of Tchaikovsky's guilt complex about being gay, and it should be terrifying, erotic and excruciating by turns. Conta does some interesting things with the central love scene - opening in a mood of tremulous naivety and gradually building the pressure, rather than being explicitly sexy from the off - but the outer sections, depicting the lovers' hellish torment, misfire. The opening should freeze your marrow, and here it made little impact. The inferno that followed was the stuff of Gothic melodrama rather than genuine anguish.

Pletnev's genius remained untarnished by the evening, but Conta has a long way to go before he joins the ranks of the great.

fields.headline: Solitude and seascapes
fields.standfirst:
Alfred Wallis and James Dixon
Tate St Ives, Cornwall
****
fields.trailText:
Alfred Wallis and James Dixon
Tate St Ives, Cornwall
****
fields.body:
Alfred Wallis was 70, a penniless widower living a stone's throw from what is now Tate St Ives, when he first picked up a brush. That was in 1925. He went on to depict boats and harbours, streets and woods, on scraps of cardboard, in paint meant for walls or timber, with little regard for topography or perspective. The former sailor is now one of Britain's best-known naive painters.

James Dixon, fisherman and farmer, lived on Tory Island, 10 windswept miles off the coast of Donegal. He started painting seriously in his 60s, a quarter-century later: ships and storms and wrecks, friends and neighbours, the creep of mechanisation. He has a similar place in Ireland's heart.

This fascinating show, which comes to St Ives from the Irish Museum of Modern of Art, was prompted by the artists' similarities. What it highlights is the gulf between them.

Wallis and Dixon are best known for their seascapes, yet it seems to be the land that brings out their true characters. With the Cornishman you sense anxiety, even dread, whenever he strays from the water. His woodland scenes show houses squeezed between trees, edged out by roads. In Trees and Cottages, or The Forest, they are forced up like pips between fingers; in Cottages in a Wood, St Ives, they squat un der inky trunks that pour down like ash from a volcano.

Dixon, by contrast, seems happy to be able to put down roots. His bird's eye views of the east and west ends of Tory Island, hung on facing walls, are comforting and organic, the indents of the coast like the crinkles of an oak leaf. Works like Mary Driving Cattle Home Across the Sands of Dee, or Mr William Rogers Plowing in Dixon Farm, remind us that the land can be a place of growth and nourishment. And friendship, as in the teasing portrait of Derek Hill, the British painter who discovered Dixon.

You search in vain for such human connections in Wallis's works. A display by Alison Oldham, who is studying the links between painters and writers in St Ives, reminds visitors how Wallis influenced those who found inspiration in this beautiful town. But that seems to have done little to ease his heart. Ben Nicholson, one of the artists who brought Wallis to public attention, described him as a "lonely little man". It might have been guessed from so many pictures of objects - ships, houses - where a human presence is only inferred.

 Until October 29. Details: 01736 796226.

fields.headline: A freshness undimmed
fields.standfirst:
Jenufa
Glyndebourne Festival
*****
fields.trailText:
Jenufa
Glyndebourne Festival
*****
fields.body:
Nikolaus Lehnhoff's production of Jenufa is 11 years old now, but doesn't look it. Re vived at Glyndebourne for first time in the new theatre, it seems fresh-minted: Tobias Hoheisel's luminous sets, exquisitely lit by Wolfgang Goebbel, fill the bigger space as if they were tailor-made, while the staging has a visceral quality that is overpowering. Every detail is thought through, and the story is told directly; it's hard to imagine Janacek's greatest opera communicating more intensely than this. There isn't a single weakness in the cast either; there is a star performance from the astounding Anja Silja as the Kostelnicka, and it is an enormous tribute to Amanda Roocroft in the title role that she is never overshadowed by the magnetism of her colleague.

Everything Silja does is compelling. Her first entry, walking ramrod straight across the stage, eyes fixed straight ahead, says all you need to know about this character: her severity, her desperate sense of propriety, her anguish about the fate of her step-daughter are contained in that bearing. The tragedy seems unstoppable from that moment, and Silja's ability to claim compassion for the Kostelnicka at the same time as she shows how the character's manic sense of what is right drives her to killing Jenufa's baby is an extraordinary achievement, and she is singing (in her 60s) as well as she has done at any time in the last decade.

Roocroft, too, is in fine voice. Her Jenufa, frightened, desperate, and finally authoritative, is the best thing she has done in this country; her confrontations with Silja's Kostelnicka have tremendous electricity.

The two of them are supported wonderfully too. Jiri Belohlavek's conducting is always spacious, always looking out for the moments of lyrical calm in the score, yet unswervingly ratchets up the tension as the tragedy unwinds. The London Philharmonic plays its heart out for him. The two male leads are first class: Stefan Margita as Laca, clearly unhinged in the opening act, movingly compassionate in the last, and Paer Lindskog as Steva, feckless and selfish, without any obvious redeeming features. The rest of the cast, led by Susan Gorton's warm, caring Grandmother, matches them. Get a ticket if you possibly can - in Silja especially the show has a priceless asset, and there won't be many more opportunities to hear this greatest of singing actresses on stage in this country.

 Until July 9. Box office: 01273 813813.

fields.headline: Rebels raise takeover fear
fields.standfirst:
Standard Life carpetbaggers promise long battle

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers pushing for demutualisation of Standard Life yesterday held out the prospect of a long and bitter battle for control of the insurer if it fails to achieve a convincing victory in next month's vote on flotation.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers pushing for demutualisation of Standard Life yesterday held out the prospect of a long and bitter battle for control of the insurer if it fails to achieve a convincing victory in next month's vote on flotation.

The threat was made as the group of rebel members led by Fred Woollard, a Monaco-based investor, mounted a fresh attack on the insurer, accusing it of "misleading" policyholders over the size of potential windfalls and stoking fears that people would lose out as a result of conversion.

The rebels held a press conference at the offices of their public relations firm to give their response to Standard Life's defence document.

Mr Woollard conceded that obtaining the 75% majority necessary for demutualisation was a high hurdle. Some commentators are predicting a vote in favour of between 50% and 75%, which would leave the 175-year-old company "terribly vulnerable to someone making a takeover bid for it", Mr Woollard said.

In the event of such a result, it was likely his action group would mount a challenge to the board, which could mean a number of the dissident policyholders standing for election in an attempt to force a change of heart on the issue.

Among disputed points is the size of potential windfalls. The rebel members said the average handout to the 2.3m qualifying policyholders could be £5,000-£6,300 but Standard Life estimated that about half its members would receive less than £2,500, with fewer than 20% likely to get £6,000 or more.

Standard Life rejected Mr Woollard's claims that it was attempting to mislead members, and added he had "again failed to make a business case for demutualisation". It said that, if it were to float, those people with new policies and existing members who make an increase in their pension payments could end up worse off.

fields.headline: Party's over for dot.com IPOs
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Martha Lane-Fox looked like someone without a care in the world yesterday, sitting under the early summer Spanish sun, laughing and joking.
fields.byline: John Cassy in Barcelona and Terry Macalister
fields.body:
Martha Lane-Fox looked like someone without a care in the world yesterday, sitting under the early summer Spanish sun, laughing and joking.

The Lastminute.com co-founder was in Barcelona to address the Industry Standard's Global Internet Summit, apparently unfazed by the past two months' barrage of criticism caused by the company's flotation. Nor did she seem overly worried that back home demand from investors for new internet stocks continued to crumble.

The reason for her optimism? For perhaps the first time since the float, Ms Lane-Fox was attending an internet conference where her floundering share price was not the hot topic of gossip.

Instead, all the snipers were focusing on the collapse of e-tailer Boo.com and information provider Net Imperative, and which would be the next dot.com to run out of cash.

With £130m in the bank, Lastminute.com seems to have enough cash to make it through to break-even. "We have always said that the IPO [flotation] changed nothing about the day-to-day running of this business except that it gave us the funds to build it to the size we have always envisaged," Ms Lane-Fox said.

Elsewhere at the summit the mood was sombre, with an acceptance that the stock market party was over - at least for now and perhaps for ever for the more flimsy enterprises.

Rob Hersov, chief executive of Sportal, summed up the mood: "The IPO window has been closed. It's private placement time now. Investment banks are no longer pitching for floats. Everyone is rethinking their valuations."

Nick Denton, chief executive of Moreover.com, a news aggregator which is close to finalising a new round of fundraising, pointed out that traditional ways of valuing companies were coming back into fashion. "[It is a return to] revenue models, sustainability and technological advantage - the traditional things that define great technology companies.

"Six months ago venture capitalists were judging companies by the strength of their stories and the prospects of getting a quick flip at IPO."

Others were more bullish. John Palmer, chief executive of Letsbuyit.com, said his company still planned to list on the Neuer Markt on June 7. However, he admitted that when the company was finalising its last round of fundraising in March, which included a €16m (£9m) investment from BSkyB - investors were more demanding than previously.

British newsreel footage firm Newsplayer also pressed on with its flotation yesterday, setting out details of a listing that values the company at around £55m. Newsplayer, which operates through a video-on-demand model, set the price for its flotation on London's Alternative Investment Market at 84p per share.

Victor Basta, managing director in London of technology-focused investment bank Broadview, said a shake-out of the market was long overdue.

"Many of the companies were lucky to be funded in the first place. They were run by people who were underqualified and some of the deals violated the basic tenets of venture capitalism," he said.

The FTSE 100 blue chip index last night underlined the dramatic shift going on in the fortunes of new-economy stocks.

If the FTSE had been undergoing its quarterly reshuffle, many of the dot.com companies welcomed with such fanfare in March, such as Thus, Kingston Communications and Psion, would have been jettisoned.

In their place would come more familiar names: Hanson, Scottish & Newcastle and, perhaps, British American Tobacco and PowerGen.

fields.headline: Breaks for the England bandwagon
fields.standfirst: Five of the victorious test team are given time off for rest and practice
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey calls for a sense of perspective after victory against a Zimbabwe team that was technically deficient against the moving ball, devoid of application, mundane with the ball (Heath Streak excepted), overawed by the occasion and lacklustre in the field.
fields.body:
Now is the time for a sense of perspective. England's win was mighty efficient in all departments and particularly in bowling Zimbabwe out twice in a total of fewer than 70 overs. The seam bowling exhibited an overall ruthlessness - characterised by Andy Caddick's no-nonsense bouncer to Pommie Mbangwa that wound up proceedings - that it has often lacked in the past. When one bowler went off the boil another stepped into the breach and that is individualism within a team context.

But it is important to be clear about the quality of the opposition. Over the years Zimbabwe have given England a tough time in one-day cricket and held their own when the sides played tests in Africa. Just a couple of months ago in Port of Spain they had played themselves into a position to canter home against West Indies, even if they did freeze rigid and blow the game.

But their performance in this test was that of a middling county and no more. In this they were all too reminiscent of England over the years.

But it was not just luck Zimbabwe were short of. They were technically deficient against the moving ball, devoid of application, mundane with the ball (Heath Streak excepted), overawed by the occasion and lacklustre in the field - the one area in which they can compete with anyone in the world - with Andy Flower a disaster behind the stumps.

It is a matter of record that teams which suffer first up against England tend to come back stronger for the second Test (one reason for England's hitherto poor showing at Lord's, which normally comes later in the calendar) and Zimbabwe, surely, cannot play as poorly again now that the first one is out of the way.

With the exception of their failure to push on their innings on Saturday afternoon when they knew there might be rain around over the following two days, it was a first-rate effort that no doubt will be rewarded with an unchanged side for the second Test, which starts at Trent Bridge on Thursday week.

There was enough in Nick Knight's performance to keep him in a winning side. Such is fortune's fickle finger: the onus will be on Vaughan now to score runs for his county and for Knight (or someone else) to fail if the Yorkshire batsman is to regain the place that had seemed his once he had gained his contract.

The same goes for Chris Silverwood. Ed Giddins did all that was asked of him and more, although he was given prime conditions in which to bowl and ideal opposition against which to succeed.

He may not find such easy pickings again. However, his clever use of swing (the inswinger that deceived Brian Murphy into offering no shot was a cracker) balanced Caddick's seam and bounce and Darren Gough's robust pace and might well be a potent weapon in unsettling the West Indies' battery of left-handers later in the summer.

Although there is nothing to stop further players being placed under central contract, there are no plans to add Giddins or anyone else to the current list. David Graveney, the chairman of selectors, believes the system provides security for the chosen dozen while offering incentive for others.

This is also the first occasion on which the England management have had the option after a test of withdrawing contracted players from forthcoming county fixtures for rest, recuperation and practice while insisting that others play.

So Mark Ramprakash will be looking to gain some form at Northampton on Wednesday and Graeme Hick will be hoping to continue his at Bristol. Andy Flintoff and Chris Schofield will be at Southampton tomorrow (where one hopes the leg-spinner takes the opportunity to seek a masterclass from Shane Warne); Knight, together with Giddins, over whom Duncan Fletcher has no jurisdiction outside the tests, will be at Cardiff; and Craig White will be playing at Headingley against the Zimbabweans.

Others, though - Nasser Hussain, Mike Atherton, Alec Stewart, Gough and Caddick - will be taking a break.

Like the England captain, Atherton has already expressed his enthusiasm for the idea of spending a number of days in meaningful practice, and time out will limit the strain on his dicky back.

Likewise the fragile state of Stewart's hands demands that he stays out of the firing line, as does the imperative to keep the two fast bowlers fit and firing for the duration of an arduous summer of seven tests. If the contracts succeed only in this last respect, then they will have paid for themselves.

webTitle: Adams returns to scene of Law abuse

fields.headline: Adams returns to scene of Law abuse
fields.trailText: If there is a captain under more pressure than Zimbabwe's Andy Flower it is Chris Adams, who this morning leads his Sussex side against Essex at Chelmsford.
fields.body:
If there is a captain under more pressure than Zimbabwe's Andy Flower it is Chris Adams, who this morning leads his Sussex side against Essex at Chelmsford.

It is a poignant Second Division championship fixture. For here he will face the England captain Nasser Hussain, the man responsible for placing Adams in hot water with the England and Wales Cricket Board.

Adams will appear before an ECB disciplinary panel at Lord's on May 30 to defend himself against allegations that he physically and verbally abused the Essex all-rounder Danny Law in a Benson & Hedges Cup tie at Chelmsford a month ago.

It is not the first bit of bother Adams has had this season. Earlier this month, in the championship match against Warwickshire at Hove, Adams was twice disappointed to be given out lbw.

Adams later confronted the umpire David Constant after Warwickshire's spinner Ashley Giles, a friend during England's winter tour of South Africa, sympathised with what he also saw as two poor decisions.

Adams, his anger refreshed, then went to see Constant. It was ill-advised, and although Adams apologised to the umpire on three separate occasions - the matter is now closed - the official was clearly upset and in an emotional plea to the Warwickshire players explained that his job was already difficult enough without individuals placing him under greater pressure.

No one, however, is under greater pressure than Adams. For two years he has led Sussex with considerable success. He has scored heavily and been an inspirational captain. Last winter, though, he failed in South Africa and is coming to terms with the fact that his international career is probably over.

This season his form has been only moderate and Sussex, who are bottom of the Second Division, have won only two of their 10 games in all cricket.

Yesterday he was supported by the Sussex chief executive David Gilbert, who said: "I'd like to know what Chris has done to upset people. For two years since he joined Sussex he's been absolutely fantastic for this club. He's got us back on the rails because we were on the verge of extinction two years ago. People seem to have short memories."

Earlier, Hussain said: "Chris did something that seriously upset my team and I'm a firm believer in backing my team at all times. I've got nothing against Chris and enjoyed his company in the winter, but on this occasion I felt I had to act and let the ECB decide if they should take action."

Adams said: "I'm still in shock at the accusations. I haven't spoken to Nasser since the incident but as far as I'm concerned he remains a friend, a great leader and exactly the right man to lead his country at the moment.

"I felt there was very little wrong with my actions during the events that occurred. The match was a month ago but I only found out a week ago.

"I believe myself to be a nice bloke and a fair bloke. I play the game to win, have always done so and will never change that. I admit that at times I get pumped up and if that causes offence then so be it. I cannot change the way I am."

fields.headline: Footsore Razzaq digs deep
fields.trailText: An eighth-wicket partnership of 70 between Abdur Razzaq and Saqlain Mushtaq enabled Pakistan to set West Indies a target of 275 for victory yesterday with a minimum of 61 overs to play on the final day of the second test in Bridgetown.
fields.body:
An eighth-wicket partnership of 70 between Abdur Razzaq and Saqlain Mushtaq enabled Pakistan to set West Indies a target of 275 for victory yesterday with a minimum of 61 overs to play on the final day of the second test in Bridgetown.

Three early wickets for the visitors then put their hosts on the back foot as the possibility of victory gave way to the more realistic hope of a draw and the chance of moving on all square to the third and final test of the series, starting in Antigua on Thursday.

Saqlain and Razzaq, batting with a runner due to an injured right thigh, added only 10 runs from the day's first 14 overs but, once set, they managed 52 from the last 15 overs before lunch.

They came together late on the fourth afternoon in a spell in which Pakistan scored only six runs in the final 15 overs of the day for the loss of two wickets.

Razzaq, 32 overnight, brought up his second test fifty in his fifth test off 179 balls. He eventually made 72 and after Saqlain was out for 33 Pakistan declared on 419 for nine, an overall lead of 274.

The most successful West Indian bowler was Reon King, who finished with four for 82 from 29 overs. Courtney Walsh took one more wicket to take his test tally to 443.

Pakistan then made an encouraging start as West Indies began their second innings. Adrian Griffith was lbw for five playing across a Waqar Younis delivery; Sherwin Campbell was caught in the gully by Shahid Afridi off Wasim Akram for eight; and Shivnarine Chanderpaul was caught at short-leg by Mohammad Wasim off Mushtaq Ahmed to leave West Indies on 58 for three at tea.

webTitle: Barry fills England's void on the left

fields.headline: Barry fills England's void on the left
fields.trailText: Gareth Barry, who until yesterday was anticipating playing for England in the European Under-21 Championship in Slovakia, now looks set to join the senior squad for the European Championship proper. The 19-year-old Aston Villa defender has been called up by Kevin Keegan following the withdrawal of Jason Wilcox with a knee problem.
fields.body:
Gareth Barry, who until yesterday was anticipating playing for England in the European Under-21 Championship in Slovakia, now looks set to join the senior squad for the European Championship proper. The 19-year-old Aston Villa defender has been called up by Kevin Keegan following the withdrawal of Jason Wilcox with a knee problem.

Barry gets his chance because Keegan is so chronically short of naturally left-footed players. Wilcox was one of only two in the squad of 28 Keegan announced last week for the friendlies at Wembley against Brazil on Saturday and Ukraine tomorrow week, immediately after which he will announce his final 22 for Euro 2000. The other, Robbie Fowler, still has to prove to the England coach that he is fully match-fit following his ankle injuries.

Keegan looked at Nigel Winterburn and Jon Harley, as well as considering Steve Guppy and Steve Froggatt, before settling on Barry. "He has the talent to play anywhere,'' the England coach explained. "Of course he has played left centre-back for most of the time but he has played at left-back.''

For the unfortunate Wilcox a lone chance to appear in a major international tournament has come and gone. "I'm obviously bitterly disappointed,'' the Leeds United winger said yesterday."

Keegan and the England medical staff will monitor Fowler's progress in training. "At the moment he still has a real chance of being in the final 22," Keegan said yesterday.

Andy Cole, the striker most likely to be left behind if Fowler goes to the European Championship, is due to see a specialist about a toe injury for which he is having injections. Keegan will look at the Manchester United striker in training this week and then await the doctor's report.

webTitle: Fizzing Keegan savours the big stage

fields.headline: Fizzing Keegan savours the big stage
fields.trailText: Richard Williams reports from the heart of the England camp as Kevin Keegan is forced to shuffle his pack.
fields.body:
The first goal of England's Euro 2000 campaign was scored yesterday morning by Nick Barmby, whose name was an unexpected inclusion in the squad of 28 players named by Kevin Keegan last week. Sprinting in to meet Phil Neville's left-wing cross, Barmby smashed the ball past David Seaman as the Whites took a 1-0 lead over the Blues on the training pitch at Bisham Abbey.

The 26-year-old Everton forward, a former prodigy who won 10 international caps before drifting out of favour, was showing the kind of verve and confidence that he will need in order to ensure his place when Keegan cuts the squad to the required 22 in less than a fortnight's time.

Half a dozen absences meant that there were just enough players for an 11-a-side game. Apart from Jason Wilcox and his replacement, Gareth Barry, there was no sign of Gareth Southgate, Dennis Wise and David James, who had been allowed an extra day off in which to recover from Saturday's FA Cup final. Steve McManaman, who will play for Real Madrid in tomorrow's European Cup final in Paris, and Richard Wright, who will be in the Ipswich goal in the First Division promotion play-off against Barnsley next Monday, were also given special dispensation to report late.

At the end of a long and arduous domestic season the players did their best to look fresh yesterday. Their coach, who last saw his team in action three months ago, in a goalless draw against Argentina at Wembley, was vibrating with enthusiasm and nervous energy. "I am very excited," he said. "You realise what's at stake and what the nation is expecting. So naturally you feel nervous. And you need to feel that. So do the players. They need to feel the tension."

For some of them the tension is greater than for others. Before England face Portugal in Eindhoven on June 12 in the first of their Group A matches there are three friendlies in two of which the fringe players can make their bid for permanent inclusion in the squad. Brazil visit Wembley on Saturday, for a match which Keegan says he will use as an opportunity to experiment. The following Wednesday, when Ukraine are the visitors, he hopes to be able to select the XI that will face Portugal. A final warm-up fixture, against Malta in Valletta on June 3, should then be useful to test any lingering fitness doubts.

The strikers were looking particularly sprightly yesterday, four of them - Andy Cole, Emile Heskey, Michael Owen and Kevin Phillips - vying for the vacant position alongside Alan Shearer, who has the captaincy and, it must be assumed, Keegan's trust. Each of the quartet has a persuasive case, although Cole, the least favoured, was the one upon whom Keegan was keenest to bestow his blessings yesterday, presumably a measure aimed at boosting the Manchester United man's sense of well-being. The coach may invite Shearer to sit out the Brazil match, in order to have a look at two of the contenders.

But the best-laid plans of football coaches have a way of being overtaken by events and, although Keegan clearly has a good idea of his best line-up, he is also prepared for the sort of experience undergone by Alf Ramsey and Bobby Robson in the World Cups of 1966 and 1986, when their teams were spontaneously realigned once the tournament was under way, finding their truest and most efficient shape under the pressure of competition.

Keegan enters the tournament after 10 matches in charge of England. So far his record reads four wins (against Poland, Luxembourg, Belgium and Scotland), five draws (Hungary, Sweden, Bulgaria, Poland and Argentina), and a single defeat at the hands of Scotland in the second leg of the Euro 2000 play-off at Wembley last November. It is not a bad record, on paper, but his critics would point to the often lacklustre and tactically opaque performance behind the scorelines.

Not even his best friend would call Keegan a tactical genius and it remains to be seen how far the street wisdom he learnt as a player and the natural effervescence of his character will take him in a competition of this quality and intensity. Like Terry Venables he speaks the players' language and commands their liking and loyalty. He encourages his squad to enjoy the experience of a big occasion. Yet his own temperament is unpredictable and he will be watched in the coming weeks for signs of mental stress and for clues to the sort of abrupt exits that have marked his career.

Four years ago the hosting of Euro 96 was the catalyst for the rebirth of English football both as a family spectator sport and as a billion-pound commercial opportunity. Ever since Paul Gascoigne returned from the Flaming Lamborghini episode to score his delirious goal against the Scots the game's growth has been exponential, unhindered even by the disappointment of a controversial elimination from the 1998 World Cup.

If the manner of their recent performances has lowered the public's expectations this time around, then that may work to Keegan's benefit. "We've got the opportunity to make some people eat their words, which is always nice," he said yesterday. "And when I look at the players, I know the quality is there to win a major championship." At the moment, with Germany and Romania to come after Portugal, reaching the quarter-finals would do for a start. Dreams of greater glory had better wait a while.

webTitle: Veteran Hässler back in German squad

fields.headline: Veteran Hässler back in German squad
fields.trailText: The Germany coach Erich Ribbeck decided to put his faith in experience yesterday when he recalled Thomas Hässler, who will be 34 next week, after an absence of two years to a Euro 2000 squad which also includes the 39-year-old Lothar Matthäus. Both players were in the team who won the World Cup in Rome 10 years ago.
fields.body:
The Germany coach Erich Ribbeck decided to put his faith in experience yesterday when he recalled Thomas Hässler, who will be 34 next week, after an absence of two years to a Euro 2000 squad which also includes the 39-year-old Lothar Matthäus. Both players were in the team who won the World Cup in Rome 10 years ago.

Hässler's inclusion in the 22-man squad, who will make up a team to face England on June 17, is something of a surprise. Only last month Ribbeck said it was "unlikely" that the veteran creative midfielder, who won the last of his 97 caps at France 98, would be picked for the European Championship.

Last week he criticised the Milan forward Oliver Bierhoff for publicly telling the coach he should select Hässler, along with the midfielders Stefan Effenberg and Mario Basler. "We need players like [Hässler] who are so good at sending in crosses," said Bierhoff.

webTitle: England keep looking to the left

fields.headline: England keep looking to the left
fields.trailText: Jason Wilcox was the only left-footed player virtually guaranteed a place in Kevin Keegan's final party of 22, and now he has been ruled out. David Lacey looks at the alternatives for England's problem flank.
fields.body:
Still England are showing little sign of a swing to the left, quite the opposite in fact. Yesterday Jason Wilcox, the player most likely to give Kevin Keegan's team natural width on that side in the European Championship, was forced out of the tournament with damaged cruciate knee ligaments.

Wilcox was the only left-footed player virtually guaranteed a place in the final party of 22 that Keegan will announce after the friendly against Ukraine at Wembley tomorrow week. Robbie Fowler, while also left-footed, has yet to prove to the England coach that he is fully match fit.

To compensate in part for the loss of Wilcox Keegan has called up Gareth Barry, the 19-year-old Aston Villa central defender, from the England Under-21 squad. While it is hardly a case of replacing like with like, Keegan is confident that, if necessary, Barry could become the natural left-back missing from his original squad of 28 for Saturday's warm-up against Brazil, with Ukraine to follow.

"Gareth is a different player to Jason, no doubt about that," Keegan admitted, "but because he is different he gives you different options. He has the talent to play anywhere and, although he plays at centre-back most of the time, he has played at left-back."

It is unlikely that, when Keegan comes to pick his team for England's opening Euro 2000 game against Portugal in Eindhoven in three weeks' time, Barry will be first choice in any position. If Keegan opts for four at the back Phil Neville is more likely to play on the left even though he is right-footed. And, while Barry would be a more natural selection in a back three, he would still be only a cover for Sol Campbell.

The principal effect of Wilcox's withdrawal has been to make it even more likely that Steve McManaman, whose form for Real Madrid has left Keegan mightily impressed, will be on the left wing in Eindhoven. McManaman, who plays for Real Madrid against Valencia tomorrow night in the European Cup final in Paris, will be rested for the Brazil game but will probably appear against Ukraine.

An important side-effect of losing one of the two left-footed attackers in the squad will be that Keegan will be even more keen for Fowler to prove his fitness. The Liverpool striker, just recovered from two ankle operations, has played in two testimonial matches and Keegan remains optimistic.

"He has had these two games and he trained this morning," the England coach explained. "We will continue to look at him and monitor his sharpness and his fitness. When I name my 22 you will know whether I think he is fit or not."

Andy Cole still looks the striker most likely to be left at home should Fowler go to Euro 2000, not least because the Manchester United forward is suffering with an injured toe and is due to see a specialist in the next few days. "Andy has not played for three weeks and trained for the first time today," said Keegan.

At the moment, despite the loss of Wilcox and the doubts about Fowler and Cole, Keegan's squad is in a state of reasonable health. Past England squads have suffered worse setbacks before a major championship.

So Keegan was entitled to feel a little chipper yesterday. After all, no members of his squad have so far been pictured pouring tequila down their throats while sitting in a dentist's chair and as yet no jumbo jets have had their upper decks trashed.

True there have been reports of someone shaving off Fowler's eyebrows for a joke but, as Keegan observed: "If that is the worst thing that happens we will be all right. To my knowledge we have not had any problems with discipline."

England's performances against Brazil and Ukraine will go a long way to setting the level of public expectation. At the moment, after November's doleful 1-0 defeat by Scotland at Wembley in the second leg of the play-offs, over-optimism is not a problem.

Always professionally upbeat, Keegan is clearly trying to set a positive mood before his team meet Portugal. "I feel very privileged," he said yesterday. "I look at the way the players train and in particular their attitude, and I think, 'Yes, it is all there. It is just a case of me getting it right and the team helping me to get it right'.

"I know some people are sceptical but the quality is there to win a major championship. There is no doubt about that. I feel very, very excited."
