webTitle: Barmby back on a high and bound for the Low Countries

fields.headline: Barmby back on a high and bound for the Low Countries
fields.standfirst: Jason Wilcox's absence opens a door for the Everton midfielder
fields.trailText: The enforced absence of Jason Wilcox from next month's finals opens a door for Everton midfielder NIck Barmby.
fields.body:
The first question was the obvious one: "What did you do to Jason?" Nick Barmby may have been away from the England scene for four years but he knew how to milk the mood of yesterday's press conference. "Sneaked into his bedroom last night," he replied in a flash.

Poor Jason Wilcox, sent home injured on the first day of England's Euro 2000 get-together after being told the bruising news that he had no chance of making next month's finals.

One man's loss, though, is another's gain. In this case, the current shortage of left-sided players in Kevin Keegan's squad means that Barmby, a surprise inclusion in the 28 and largely predicted not to make the final cut, now has an improved chance of going to the Low Countries.

Not that the right-footed Barmby is a naturally left-sided player, but in the present crisis anyone who has ever veered over that side of the pitch will, it seems, be considered.

Barmby's excellent season for Everton - 10 goals are his best return during his four years at Goodison Park - has included stints playing on the left side.

And for obvious reasons Barmby is keen to play up this part of his game. He was not only eager to remind everyone that he played on the left side while at Tottenham under Gerry Francis, but stress how much he actually prefers that position.

"I think it brings more options," he insists. "That's what I found when I was at Tottenham. I'd come inside and Teddy [Sheringham] would be there, and you can play one-twos and things like that off him, and you can mix and run. It's just the same at Everton, with Kevin Campbell."

Apart from cutting inside, passing well and popping over some handy crosses, Barmby's other main strengths are his versatility and his inexhaustible running, both key Keegan qualities.

After some glum years in the wilderness, Barmby has made a vibrant contribution to the Everton team. His manager Walter Smith has been rightly pleased with the cherubic 26-year-old, singing his praises whenever possible.

Barmby started to be proclaimed as a player with international potential when he was at Tottenham and he won the first of his 10 caps in 1995. But he never seemed able to translate promise into performance at the highest level and moved to Middlesbrough.

In 1996 he made the switch to Everton - he is still their record signing at £5.75m - and won the 10th of his caps, scoring the first goal of Glenn Hoddle's ill-fated reign against Moldova.

But even at Everton he could find little immediate contentment and not surprisingly drifted out of international contention. "It was a lot of things really," he says. "Loss of form was one. I had a few injuries, double hernia, plus a battle with relegation. You can't play the way you can play. It's a battle every game and it was hard in the first two years.

"But in the last two years it's been a different story and I've been able to express myself more. Under Walter Smith we've played more of a passing game and it's benefitted me, and John Collins, more than most. I've enjoyed the last two years and it's a great boost getting in the England squad."

So will he go to the finals? "I have seen him play probably more than any other in the last month," revealed Keegan. "His training is generally very good. He's come in and picked up the pace. A very fit boy. And yes, he can play left side. Obviously what has happened to Jason may give him a boost as well."

There is one problem. Not expecting an England call-up, Barmby had already booked a family holiday. Now the family will go to Disneyland without him. But then again, if anyone had told Barmby a year ago that he would be in the Euro 2000 squad, he would have said they were living on fantasy island.

webTitle: Brazil face night of the long grass

fields.headline: Brazil face night of the long grass
fields.trailText: Mark Hughes might be new to management but he sounds a quick learner. The Wales coach's preparations for tonight's friendly against Brazil have gone far beyond practising corners or discussing Rivaldo's left boot.
fields.body:
Mark Hughes might be new to management but he sounds a quick learner. The Wales coach's preparations for tonight's friendly against Brazil have gone far beyond practising corners or discussing Rivaldo's left boot.

Calculating that a wide pitch and short grass would suit his visitors, Hughes has hauled the touchlines in and kept the lawnmowers locked up. The grass at the Millennium stadium could be high enough for Henry Wise to get lost in.

"I want it to be to our advantage, not to the opposition's advantage," Hughes said. "I have also looked up the regulations to see what the minimum width is and have asked for the pitch to be made smaller.

"It did look a very big pitch and with me asking the players to work hard and get about opponents all over the ground, that would make the job a little bit more difficult."

Ryan Giggs may be slightly miffed but the 72,500 capacity crowd will doubtless understand. Fifa's rankings suggest this is a mismatch even Don King might be wary of promoting. Brazil sit top of the pile; Wales are 101st, nestling between Vietnam and Barbados.

Yet Brazil have not won on their two previous visits to Cardiff. A draw in 1983 was followed by a 1-0 defeat in 1991 on - surprise, surprise - a small pitch with long grass.

Romario, who was injured playing for Vasco da Gama on Sunday, will not be striking at all. He will not feature against England on Saturday either.

"There's a school of thought that you should pick easier friendlies when you are building up to World Cup qualifiers, but I don't go along with that," Hughes said. "You can only progress if you test yourselves. Lesser matches produce a false sense of security."

Security is not readily associated with Brazil's coach Wanderley Luxemburgo right now. He is under pressure after starting the World Cup campaign with a 0-0 draw in Colombia and an unconvincing 3-2 home win over Ecuador. He must do without Real Madrid's Roberto Carlos, who is preparing for tomorrow's Champions League final.

Wales are missing the experience of Chris Coleman, Mark Pembridge, Nathan Blake and John Hartson, giving a chance for youngsters such as Matthew Jones and Mark Delaney to shine. Giggs will play, despite missing training yesterday to protect a minor thigh strain.

Hughes is hoping for positives rather than miracles. "Even in defeat you can feel you have done well," he said, "if you have done as much as you can."

Wales (possible 4-4-2): Crossley (Nottm For); Delaney (Aston Villa), Page (Watford), Melville (Fulham), Barnard (Barnsley); Robinson (Charlton), Savage (Leicester), Speed (Newcastle), M Jones (Leeds); Saunders (Bradford), Giggs (Manchester United).

Brazil (possible 3-5-2): Dida; Antonio Carlos, Aldair, Cafu; Emerson, Rivaldo, Ze Roberto, Cesar Sampaio, Silvinho; Franca, Elber.

fields.headline: A year in Kazakhstan
fields.standfirst: Andrew Sheehan was the British Council ELT consultant in Kazakhstan from 1995 to 1996, and discovered that, where friendliness and hospitality are concerned, Kazakhstan is unrivalled.
fields.trailText: Andrew Sheehan was the British Council ELT consultant in Kazakhstan from 1995 to 1996, and discovered that, where friendliness and hospitality are concerned, Kazakhstan is unrivalled.
fields.body:
Where on this planet would teachers travel for 40 hours - in each direction - just to attend a weekend ELT conference? Where does every ELT seminar or workshop, or even a visit to a classroom in a local school, end with a feast of home-prepared local specialities, entertainment in the form of a teacher or pupil playing the dombra, and the inevitable singing of the Beatles' 'Yesterday'?

Where could you fly for several thousand kilometres, land on a bumpy airfield, walk with your breath steaming in the minus 25 degree air across the runway and into the terminal, to be met by someone who was not sure if they would understand you, or if you would understand them, because although they had taught English for 30 years they had been totally isolated and had never spoken to a native speaker?

Where else, when they knew you were leaving, would the teachers serenade you with ballads they had written themselves, and cry unashamedly because you had done something to help them?

The same day I landed in Kazakhstan to take up my new post in Almaty, I was invited to one of the local schools where English was taught. The students proudly recited all the details of Britain's geography, history, culture (British English, definitely not American, was the preferred version). Thus I learned the height of Ben Nevis, the length of the Thames, and that "Manchester is the cotton capital of England", and "the east end of London is the poor end and the west end is the rich end". I discovered that the schools were using books printed, re-printed and re-printed yet again in Moscow, with little pretence at updating the information they contained. And the teachers spoke beautiful, delightful English, which often sounded quaintly Victorian.

The first thing I did was to introduce a program of weekly methodology and language development workshops for the Almaty English teachers. We began with a weekend seminar, each day beginning with a huge breakfast of dishes the teachers had prepared at home. I also realised that it was important to establish connections with English teachers throughout Kazakhstan, so I travelled extensively in that vast country, giving workshops in methodology centres, in universities, and to the teachers of English associations: the TEAs. Flying Kaz Air was an adventure; each time I flew my fingernails became shorter, and my faith in the pilots, not the planes, the mantra in my head.

My arrival always had something of the surreal about it. There would be a reception committee, and for a few awkward seconds, as we introduced ourselves, I could see (and they would confess, later) that they were wondering if I would understand them, for they had never spoken to a native speaker before.

The hospitality of the Kazakhs has to be experienced to be believed: even with the most severe deprivations - of resources, heat, power - or perhaps because of them, they remain the most generous, warm and exuberant people I have ever encountered. Wherever I went, every visit to a school, to a teachers' centre, or a university, became a festival of eating, drinking, laughing, of celebration.

When I organised the first national ELT conference (in co-operation with a colleague from the United States Information Service), and paid the travel and accommodation expenses of those who presented a seminar or workshop, teachers travelled by train from far-flung corners of Kazakhstan to be there. For many of them, the journey lasted longer than the conference.

This was followed by a national conference for the directors and heads of department of the teacher-training universities and methodology centres; over 50 participants attended, all full of enthusiasm and optimism. But they all said the same thing: they had no resources, not even a photocopier; they hand-wrote the handouts for their students; they had no audio cassettes (not to mention videos).The teachers had not been paid.

No wonder that when they came to the British Council's resource centre for the weekly methodology and language development seminars, they behaved like children in an expensive chocolate shop; it was too overwhelming - they had never seen so many up-to-date books and cassettes.

She and my translator talked in Kazakh; although Russian had dominated the country for many years, Kazakh was re-emerging from its hibernation. Although Kazakhstan is geographically isolated, and may still be outside the ELT mainstream, modern communication and the media are connecting it to the rest of the world. fields.trailText: Kazakhstan: a new destination for the EFL professional?
fields.body:
Kazakhstan: a new destination for the EFL professional?

Outline:
Introduction | Teaching in Kazakhstan (Sponsored Organisations) | Teaching in Kazakhstan (Private/Commercial Scene) | Contemporary Kazakhstan | Living in Almaty | Career prospects | Contacts

1. Introduction to the Country
Kazakhstan is not the first place that springs to mind when considering a career in TEFL. There are probably too many mental associations with some of the other more dangerous '-stans', such as Afghanistan or Tadjikistan. It is, however, a place for TEFL adventurers to consider, and is especially suitable for those with some experience and a taste for a 'frontier' lifestyle.

The country is located in Central Asia, between China and Russia, and covers more than a million square miles. Most of the country is steppe and desert, but with spectacular mountain ranges at its northern, southern and eastern edges. Although land-locked, it has access to the Caspian Sea, and also possesses a share of that great environmental nightmare, the remains of the Aral Sea. The climate tends to be a little on the extreme side, with winter temperatures regularly falling as low as -20C, while in summer the thermometer can reach a stifling 40C.

Almost all of its 16 million inhabitants speak Russian, although Kazakh (a member of the Turkic group of languages) is the 'official' language. Accordingly the population is composed of 42% Kazakhs and 37% Russians, with the remainder comprising Koreans, Ukrainians, Germans, and other central Asian races. Religious activity also claims an equal split between Muslims (47%) and Russian Orthodox (44%).

In short, the place is multi-cultural, in a Soviet sort of way, and multi ethnic. Moreover, it plays host to a whole range of attitudes and lifestyles that the average Westerner can only gaze at and puzzle over, far less even understand: a true melting pot of the typically Asian, the typically Russian; the old Soviet, the new capitalist. Respect for and deference towards authority is a way of getting by here - don't expect consultation or enlightened attitudes.

In economic terms, since the collapse of the USSR in 1991 Kazakhstan has been obliged to look for its own way in the world. Its acceptance of Western capitalism has been the strongest of all the central Asian states, and therefore its progress has been quite unique. Although this passage has been accompanied with a typically Eastern style of authoritarianism and corruption, the country's pro-business posture means that demand for skills in the international language of English is steadily increasing.

EFL provision here in the heart of Central Asia can be divided into two broad camps, the sponsored and the private. The sponsored sector was the first to try to satisfy the region's demand for English, so for this historical reason it tends to be the largest EFL provider here. Things are, however, changing rather quickly.

2. Teaching in Kazakhstan (Sponsored Organisations)
Louise Cowcher is ELT Project Manager for the British Council here in Almaty (the country's former capital). She outlined their approach as being one of strictly responding to demand. Indicative of that demand is the fact that they are the only UCLES centre for the whole of Central Asia, examining and providing tuition for the whole suite of Cambridge exams. Moreover, they are also providing an ever-widening program of teacher development for local English teachers, addressing such areas as methodology, language improvement, and materials evaluation, as well as business English and Young Learners. There is also a good level of demand from the state too, and BC is collaborating on English language projects with both the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Defence.

She sees the BC's role as one of ensuring quality ELT provision in what could be a huge market, and they are actively using the BC expertise gained in other FSU countries to help them in the challenge. In the near future they are hoping to set up a teaching centre, again in response to increasing demand. However, she is also keen to stress that their approach to ELT has been in collaboration with the other big players in the arena, namely US Peace Corps, the Soros Foundation, and USIS (United States Information Service). "We have shared objectives" she confirms, "and this has led us to collaborate on various projects, such as EFL conferences, seminars and textbooks". Currently the BC has 4 experienced teachers working in the Aksay gas fields, and these are earning money 'at the top of the range'.

Other sponsored EFL providers here include, of course, the US Peace Corps, who appear to be in an equally expansionist mood. Last year they had 43 EFL volunteers in Kazakhstan as a whole, and this year there are 54. Next year should see a further increase in numbers, too. Another major US player here is USIS, and they have typically supplied at least two teaching fellows and teacher trainers to local institutes that requested them.

Lisa Ponzetti, one of last year's cohort, points out that USIS go beyond just supplying teachers, and also make donations to local ELT associations and possess a resource centre and library for teachers and students of English. She also underlines that "the quality of the teaching experience in Kazakhstan would not be appropriate for a 'first-stepper'", and that "although it is a wonderful experience, the pay is not so good in some private places".

However, some ELT providers appear to be cutting back on some aspects of their English Language programmes. The Soros Organisation, for instance, which not so long ago had ten teaching fellows working in the country, now has none at all. Their spokesperson, Yulia Leonova, stated that the English Language programme in Kazakhstan is now effectively closed due to "a regression in the donors' outlook". But she did remain upbeat about the future, claiming that the current situation "will hopefully lead to a strong impulse to a new growth of ELT quality and the ELT community's activity".

International House also have a tentative presence here, through their co-operation with The Soros Foundation Language School. Its Director, Mira Khodjashova, is keen to stress the positive changes of recent years. Nowadays, she notes, good English language skills mean a good job with promising career prospects and a high salary, especially now that foreign interest in the country has 'exploded' due to Kazakhstan's virtually unlimited resources of oil and gas. She contrasts the current demand for 'communicative English' with the situation under Soviet times, when English was only needed for the 'academic' purposes of translation and reading. "When I was graduating" she smiles, "everybody thought I was crazy for having gone to the Institute of Languages. The specialisation of English teacher was one of the most unclaimed professions: now it is one of the most popular, and everybody is dying to learn English".

3. Teaching in Kazakhstan (Private/Commercial Scene)
Clearly, the economic changes of the past decade have had a tremendous impact on the ELT market, and as a result many clients now like to insist on a native speaker teacher. However, it is extremely difficult to attract NS teachers to the region. Despite this, many private schools have popped up to satisfy the locals' demand for English, although few of them offer NS teachers, and in most cases the quality of provision is sometimes questionable. Moreover, one informed observer told me that some private schools tend to treat their staff rather like 'bonded labour', while others fail to live up to the promises made in the teachers' contracts. Caveat Emptor!

A possible example of a decent private EFL school here is the Anglo-Kazakh centre, which has been providing tuition in general and business English for two years now. At present they employ 4 native speakers, all from England and CerTEFL qualified, with experience in working in such places as Taiwan, Kuwait, Russia, Turkey and Italy. Their remarks on the advantages and the drawbacks of working in the country noted that management styles are definitely not European, tending to be quite autocratic. Expect to be told what to do, rather than be consulted. The teaching load was 27 hours, for $800 per month, plus a possible $1000 bonus at the end of the contract, and this seemed to compare quite favourably with some other private schools in Almaty, which is where the great majority of the country's private sector EFL teaching goes on, being Kazakhstan's business centre.

Private teaching work appears to attract between $15 and $25 per hour, and is in rather plentiful supply, given the high level of demand. A final word from Andy Maunder, teacher at the Anglo-Kazakh centre, echoes a lot of the above: "If you want everything to run smoothly, Kazakhstan is not the place for you. But if you're ready to roll with the punches, you can get to like it here".

4. Contemporary Kazakhstan
Kazakhstan obviously experienced a great deal of social and political upheaval at the time of its 'divorce' from the USSR, and partly as a result of this their attempts at democracy became quite authoritarian. Parliament was dissolved by the President after the first two years of independence, and since then he has ruled virtually by decree. Modern critics point to the presence of what they see as 'crony capitalism', in which strong presidential power and patronism have led to the establishment of an elite ruling class with strong personal and kinship ties to the President.

At the other end of the scale, long term high levels of unemployment are dragging down one part of the nation into a poverty and indignity unseen during the Soviet period. Many of the people that can be seen around the city selling cigarettes and knick-knacks from grimy cardboard boxes are educated people, former doctors, engineers and teachers, who are unable to find work in the contracting state sector, and are without other skills to offer the new regime.

But there is oil and gas - a lot of it: and an allegedly pro-Western nation on the borders of China and close to the militant moslem hotspots of Afghanistan, Tadjikistan and Iran. Most governments can recognise an ally when they see one, so democratic European nations will probably continue to pump money in to try and 'democratise' a country that has neither experience nor traditions of democracy, and which probably never will. Observers point to a typically South East Asian style of government, as exists in Malaysia and even Indonesia, in which a facade of western-style democracy is apparent, but in which real power rests with an almost permanent ruling elite. Small wonder then, that many people see English as their passport to a new life outside the country - and several million have left since independence in 1991.

5. Living in Almaty
Let's cast aside the problems and see what sort of a lifestyle Almaty can offer the prospective EFL teacher. Long gone are the days of grey shops and restaurants doling out unappetising produce: now there are plenty of pubs and discos, even gay bars, where you can spend your money, but they are not cheap. Turkish restaurants also appear to be popping up at a gathering pace. Accommodation is freely available too, from dull one-roomed flats in the outskirts to wonderful refurbished apartments near the centre of town. But be prepared to spend from $100 to $600 for your living quarters, and don't be at all surprised to find yourself without heating, water or gas for anything up to a couple of days at a time. Such are the delights of living in a 'transition society'!

Travel is another problem. Given the country's enormous size, it seems to take a couple of days to get anywhere: and because of the country's antiquated transport system, those two days can be very uncomfortable! However, there is plenty to see and do near Almaty. If you're keen on mountaineering, rock-climbing, skiing or just gazing at spectacular scenery, this place will definitely keep you occupied. Equally, if you're a fan of drinking vodka and eating horsemeat, either before, after or even during a beautiful steam bath, you won't be left disappointed.

6. Career Prospects
So where does all this leave the average EFL professional? Well, take a look at the developing countries of South East Asia, and translate that into Kazakhstan 10 or 15 years into the future. Result? Plenty of jobs, hopefully. There are, however, certain drawbacks. Seamus Bennett is Director of the English Language Programme of the Kazakhstan Institute of Management, Economics and Research, where all tuition is given in English. He remarks that Central Asia is not perceived as an exciting destination by the average TEFL backpacker (unlike Poland or Hungary, for example), and that this has held back ELT provision in the region. Moreover, the region is quite isolated, physically, intellectually and politically, from even Eastern Europe, and this has resulted in the constrained development that has taken place so far. There's also the extreme climate to consider - around minus 15 in Winter here in Almaty, plus the occasional earth tremor. All of this will very probably deter future EFL professionals from considering working here.

However, the region does undoubtedly have its attractions, especially for an experienced teacher. The BC's Louise Cowcher explained that those with a background in teacher-training, plus other suitably 'mature' candidates, would find the place welcoming of their skills. "Others may find it difficult to adapt", she said, "although Almaty is by no means a 'hardship' area, and is comparable or even favourable to many current teaching locations in the former Soviet Union". According to her there is "an awful lot of demand" and "lots of potential" here.

However, don't dust off your passport and jump on that plane to Almaty just yet. The country is still 'closed', in that it's impossible to get here without a visa, and these are only obtainable as a tourist or an employee. In short, you'll need to find your job in Kazakhstan before you even set foot in the place, and for those of you who are adventurous enough to want to do so, the following list of contacts should be useful.

7. Contacts
Anyone interested in working in Kazakhstan is welcome to contact either Seamus Bennett or Jeff Bragg for an update on the current situation. Or you can email or telephone the following:

British Council
KIMEP
Soros Language Centre
Anglo-Kazakh Centre: 007-3272-639876

The BC's Louise Cowcher explained that those with a background in teacher-training, plus other suitably 'mature' candidates, would find the place welcoming of their skills. "Others may find it difficult to adapt", she said, "although Almaty is by no means a 'hardship' area, and is comparable or even favourable to many current teaching locations in the former Soviet Union". According to her there is "an awful lot of demand" and "lots of potential" here. However, don't dust off your passport and jump on that plane to Almaty just yet. The country is still 'closed', in that it's impossible to get here without a visa, and these are only obtainable as a tourist or an employee. In short, you'll need to find your job in Kazakhstan before you even set foot in the place, and for those of you who are adventurous enough to want to do so, the following list of contacts should be useful. 7. webTitle: Bush brings defence into presidential race

fields.headline: Bush brings defence into presidential race
fields.standfirst:
Martin Kettle in Washington
The issue explained
Audio: hear Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.trailText: George W Bush upped the stakes in the international arms race when he said  today that he will extend the US's controversial national missile  defence system (NMD) to cover Europe and Israel if he is elected president in  November.
fields.body:
George W Bush upped the stakes in the international arms race when he said today that he will extend the US's controversial national missile defence system (NMD) to cover Europe and Israel if he is elected president in November.

"A missile defence system should not only defend our country, it should defend our allies with whom I will consult as we develop our plans," the Republican presidential candidate said in a speech in Washington.

Asked at the end of his speech whom he had in mind when he talked about US allies, Mr Bush responded: "I mean people in Europe, for example, but I also mean Israel."

Mr Bush's comment represents a major shift in emphasis on missile defence from that of the Clinton administration, which is examining the feasability of a system designed to defend only the 50 US states from attacks from countries such as North Korea.

No European nation has so far asked for the US to do what Mr Bush now proposes, and all are in varying degrees opposed to the deployment of even the limited NMD system currently being examined by Mr Clinton.

Flanked by senior Republican foreign affairs and defence gurus including Henry Kissinger and General Colin Powell, Mr Bush made clear that he is strongly predisposed to introduce extensive missile defence systems whether or not the current testing phase is successful, and implied that he wants the system to guard against attack from Russia as well as from "rogue states" - another shift from Clinton administration policy.

"America must build effective missile defences based on the best available options at the earliest possible date," he said. The defences were needed against "rogue nations or accidental launches".

In the short term, the principal purpose of the speech was to make clear to Mr Clinton that the Republicans will not accept any deal involving missile defences that he may make during his visit to Moscow next month for talks with President Vladimir Putin.

"The administration is driving towards a hasty decision on a political timetable," Mr Bush warned. "No decision would be better than a flawed agreement that ties the hands of the next president and prevents America from defending itself."

The Clinton administration wants to persuade Russia to agree to changes in the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty - which bars both countries from developing anti-missile defences - to enable the US to go ahead with deployment of a limited NMD system consisting of 100 missiles based in Alaska to guard against attacks from "rogue states".

Mr Clinton is scheduled to take a decision on deployment later this year following the latest test of the US missile interceptor system. That test, originally due on June 26, has now been postponed until July after the discovery of faulty wiring in the anti-missile "kill vehicle".

fields.headline: No RAE of hope
fields.standfirst: Fury has erupted as plans to scrap the exercise are dumped
fields.trailText: Fury has erupted as plans to scrap the exercise are dumped
fields.body:
The heated debate over lecturers' preoccupation with academic publications and research ratings at the expense of teaching and practical work is set to erupt into a major row, after university funding chiefs aborted plans to scrap the research assessment exercise.

Only days after academic leaders concluded that the five yearly race for departmental research rankings should continue largely unchanged after 2001, the lecturers' union Natfhe added to calls for an end to the exercise.

Concerns that the assessment had become the be-all and end-all of academic life prompted the Higher Education Funding Council for England to embark last year on a "no-holds-barred" fundamental review of its research funding policies. The re-appraisal amassed and digested a wealth of evidence and views over the 12 months, including a consultation, detailed discussions by several commitees and a raft of academic studies. Yet next month the review's steering group will recommend that the funding council make only a few minor reforms to the assessment.

For opponents of the exercise, the conclusion will confirm what has long been suspected: that the academic elite will continue to use the competition to retain its iron grip on the council's £800 million research budget.

University lecturers were urged during last weekend's annual Natfhe conference to back a motion calling for an end to a "wasteful and bureaucratic system, which has particularly disadvantaged the new university sector". Conference delegates heard complaints that the quest for research kudos and money through the assessment was downgrading the status of teaching in academic departments and promoting divisive rivalries between institutions.

The union also reiterated concerns that the assessment was prejudiced against female academics taking maternity leave or career breaks. Meanwhile, among the government's research councils, which allocate specific research project grants to academics, the response was one of resignation.

"We were hoping that the 2001 exercise would be the last round, but there are tremendous conservative forces among vice-chancellors, making them stick with the devil they know," said one senior council official. "If you talk to anyone in universities all they want to talk about is minutiae of the research assessment exercise - not their own research."

Industry leaders had also hoped that the review would make way for a broader approach to the way academics are judged. They wanted work done for companies to be considered as well as papers in academic journals, which are now the central criterion used in the assessment.

Despite considering a number of radical options to the existing system, the reviewers could not come up with any plausible alternatives to the assessment. And support grew for the exercise as studies debunked many of the myths associated with it. There was little evidence, for example, of a frenetic transfer market in which star professors were hired by universities to boost ratings in the run-up to the last exercise. A comparison with universities in the US, meanwhile, revealed that research funds are not less skewed towards top academic departments in the the UK.

A few radical proposals survived until the later stages of the review, but now even these are likely to emerge in a watered-down form. Suggestions to allow top-rated departments to be assessed less frequently have now been replaced by proposals to use top-up grants to encourage the departments emerging highest in the research ratings to collaborate more. Instead of focusing resources for general postgraduate training to fewer departments, the reviewers are now proposing that departments will have to meet minimum training standards before receiving support.

The funding council is expected to consult universities on the proposals during the summer.

webTitle: Black month for Brown over GM farce

fields.headline: Black month for Brown over GM farce
fields.standfirst:
Special report: What's wrong with our food?
Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, is under siege again. He is carrying the can for the failure of the government's supposedly robust systems for monitoring the testing of genetically modified food and crops, the month-long delay in admitting the mistake of allowing contaminated seed to be planted, the alleged cover-up associated with it and the muted official announcement through a written Parliamentary answer last Wednesday.
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, is under siege again. He is carrying the can for the failure of the government's supposedly robust systems for monitoring the testing of genetically modified food and crops, the month-long delay in admitting the mistake of allowing contaminated seed to be planted, the alleged cover-up associated with it and the muted official announcement through a written Parliamentary answer last Wednesday.

Everyone loves to hate a scapegoat, particularly if it is the Ministry of Agriculture. It is easy to put the boot in too. After all, its complacency helped take the BSE crisis into the most expensive peacetime disaster in generations, its officials are routinely ridiculed in Whitehall for apparent slavish loyalty to intensive farming methods, and Mr Brown himself had a bad beef war politically and presentationally in the row with France over the resumption of British exports last year.

But the latest GM failure was a collective failure. After all, this is a government which prides itself on its joined-upness. Until a couple of weeks ago, the presentation of GM issues was a matter for a special unit within the Cabinet Office. All media inquiries were expected to go through it, including about the siting of trial sites for GM crops, even though Michael Meacher, the environment minister, was the man who announced the first batch of them back in March.

But then the going started getting tough. First, the number of trial sites was quite plainly going to be nowhere near the 80 first promised this year. Then a trial crop site was announced for Wales, when officials had earlier said the country would effectively be GM-free for three years of trials because it did not traditionally grow the crops which would have a GM alternative. This was plainly wrong, since Aventis, one of the companies involved in the trials, thought the borderlands of England and Wales ideal for such tests.

And then came the ultimate embarrassment. Farmers had planted two sowings of oil seed rape from seeds grown on the Canadian prairies and contaminated with GM material. Suddenly calls to the Cabinet Office were referred to the agriculture ministry, the Department for the Environment and the Food Standards Agency, although presumably the blessed Mo Mowlam's officials agreed the way the matter was finally made (sort of) public.

The Cabinet Office has the bare-faced cheek to say it was most appropriate for Nick Brown's team to handle the fall-out from this fiasco since "it is a story about seed purity". This, of course, is rubbish. The incident has undermined the government's whole GM policy, for which Ms Mowlam will still bear the overall strategic responsibility.

Her officials rather weakly point out that she did speak on the issue on the BBC's Today programme on Monday but the main reason for her appearance was to announce that the government was considering sweeping new powers to confiscate the ill-gotten gains of drug barons and other criminals, a recycled version of proposals a Home Office group came up with 18 months ago. It was however a time for a politically uplifting message to counter the Conservatives' apparent finger on the public pulse over crime.

No wonder voters are growing deeply cynical about politics. Mo is popular so she can obviously be in the driving seat - and it makes up for Mr Blair ignoring her recently. Mr Brown is not obviously popular. So when the wheels come off the wagon over GM issues, he, followed soon no doubt by Mr Meacher, an old lefty, will be the first to find the safety belts don't work.

webTitle: Marines to replace paras in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Marines to replace paras in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: Geoff Hoon's speech today
fields.trailText: British paratroopers will be pulled out of Sierra Leone and replaced by the Royal Marines, defence secretary Geoff Hoon announced today.
fields.body:
British paratroopers will be pulled out of Sierra Leone and replaced by the Royal Marines, defence secretary Geoff Hoon announced today.

The changeover is the first stage of the plan to withdraw the bulk of Britain's force deployed in Sierra Leone by mid-June, Mr Hoon told the Commons.

"It is a sensible military step which preserves our capability on the ground for the remainder of this mission, while allowing the parachute regiment to return to the UK."

The spearhead battalion had been outstandingly successful since arriving in the country this month, but conditions on the ground were difficult and the paratroopers needed to prepare for other duties later this year, he added. The changeover will begin this week.

An advance military training team will then arrive in Freetown after the marines to help the Sierra Leone government rebuild its defence forces, he said, adding Britain would be giving the Sierra Leone army access to stocks of light weapons and ammunition under the supervision of British army officers.

"Our commitment to promoting stability and security in Sierra Leone remains the same; our decision to enhance the capability of the Sierra Leone army is an essential element of that."

The longer-term aim was to have the rebel fighting forces demobilised and the Sierra Leone government in control of diamond production, he added.

webTitle: Multiculture awards honour Mandela, Ali G and Guardian

fields.headline: Multiculture awards honour Mandela, Ali G and Guardian
fields.standfirst: What is Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela was presented with a lifetime achievement award at a ceremony last night celebrating multiculturalism in the media.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela was presented with a lifetime achievement award at a ceremony last night celebrating multiculturalism in the media.

The former president of South Africa was honoured at the BT ethnic multicultural media awards (Emmas), which are supported by the Guardian. The award for best print journalist went to the paper's reporter Vikram Dodd.

Mr Mandela's award was given in recognition of his part in the struggle to defeat apartheid and establish a de mocratic free society in South Africa. Doreen Lawrence, mother of the murdered black teenager Stephen, accepted it on his behalf. In a statement from South Africa, Mr Mandela said he was thrilled to received the award. "But I do not accept it as an individual. I accept it on behalf of the people of South Africa who have contributed to the freedom of my people."

Sascha Baron-Cohen, the spoof comedian, won best television production for his Ali G Channel 4 show; Mel B was named public figure of the year for her role in promoting Aids awareness in young people and the journalist Yasmin Alibhai-Brown won media personality of the year.

The Sky News presenter Lisa Aziz and the comedian Junior Simpson were hosts for the third year of the awards at the Royal Lancaster hotel in London attended by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and Conservative leader, William Hague.

fields.headline: Ex-lover of black athlete charged
fields.standfirst:
Cotter accused of perverting course of justice over alleged race attack

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The white former boyfriend of black Olympic athlete Ashia Hansen has been remanded in custody on charges of staging a racist attack in order to sell the story.
fields.body:
The white former boyfriend of black Olympic athlete Ashia Hansen has been remanded in custody on charges of staging a racist attack in order to sell the story.

Chris Cotter, 28, a financial adviser, appeared before Birmingham magistrates with two other men charged with a range of offences connected to the alleged race attack.

Cotter, of Bromford, Birmingham, Surjit Singh Claire, 31, of Walsall, and Craig Wynn, 28, an engineer of Kingstanding, Birmingham, were charged with jointly perverting the cause of justice by maintaining that there had been a racist attack and reinforcing this by sending racist material when knowing this was false.

Cotter, a former British international long jumper, was stabbed several times outside Ms Hansen's house in Erdington, Birmingham, in March. He lost four pints of blood and needed 17 stitches.

The three were also charged with jointly sending racist material with intent to cause harassment, alarm or distress, and conspiracy to obtain financial gain by deception by selling stories to newspapers.

Claire and Wynn were also charged with conspiracy to inflict grievous bodily harm on Cotter. All three men were remanded in custody to reappear on May 31 after bail applications were refused.

Ms Hansen, a triple jumper, is a leading British gold medal hope for the Sydney Olympic Games this year.

She later issued a statement through her management company saying: "I am in a state of total shock at the news of Chris Cotter's arrest in what I believe was a racial attack on someone I trust and cared for.

"Despite the fact that we are no longer in a close relationship, I am still shocked at this turn of events.

"It has caused not only me but my family, friends and team-mates a great deal of stress over the past few months. There is also a danger of distracting attention from the legitimate racist issues we have in society.

"I now have to focus all my energies and thoughts on my preparation for the Olympic Games and would ask that the media allow me my privacy to do this."

fields.headline: Fjords, Flights and Fairytales
fields.trailText: YOU HEARD IT HERE FIRST
fields.body:
YOU HEARD IT HERE FIRST

When Joe Kinnear was told to fjord off by Wimbledon's Norwegian owners last summer, it wasn't just Mystic Fiver who saw the interaction of Mars as a sure sign that the most rotund man in football would soon be back managing a big club. But as the months ticked by, a few started expressing doubts. And those doubts turned to outright scepticism when Kinnear expressed interest in the Celtic, Blackburn and Fulham jobs - only to be cruelly rebuffed at every turn.

Where are the doubters now? In hiding probably - because according to Reuters, Kinnear will be named as manager of Sheffield Wednesday tomorrow. It doesn't get much bigger than that. Well, not as far as Jumping Joe Ashton MP is concerned. "I'd be delighted if he was appointed," Ashton, who notoriously called for Danny Wilson's dismissal earlier this year, told the Fiver exclusively. "He's got a track record of getting a lot from very little money. More importantly he has teams that fight. Wednesday were an absolutely bloody disgrace this season. Bradford fought with true Yorkshire grit while Wednesday laid down before Christmas."

The Fiver was ready to end it there but once Joe was off he wouldn't stop. "I met with Joe Kinnear at Wembley and he told me he was up for it," he continued. "And I suggested this to the board after the 8-0 defeat. I begged Dave Richards to appoint him but he wouldn't do it. The trouble was that Wednesday team were like a good horse without a jockey. If Joe Kinnear would have come in before Christmas they would have stayed up." At least he didn't say 'I told you so'.

THE SECRET TRANSFER DIARY OF BOBBY ROBSON, AGED 67

Yesterday

On club tour in balmy Trinidad & Tobago. Had depressing chat with Tecos Guadalajara about midfielder Roberto Palacios. Find out he plays for Peru. Cah! I'm not landing myself with another player like Nobby Solano who's always away on international duty. Flipping South America. Decide to leave for Europe.

Today

On plane to Paris for tomorrow's Big Cup final. Note that Atletico Madrid striker Kiko is available for £4.5m. Consider talking to representatives tomorrow and making bid. Doze off for a while, dreaming of a £3m offer for Benfica midfielder Calado, and the secret deal for a big-name European striker which people say I'm keeping under my hat. Wake up, tittering.

Today (later)

Still on plane. A bit bored, so speak to Portuguese FA on new-fangled jet phone. Push them on decision over defender Fernando Meira, who has walked out on Vitoria Guimaraes in a row over wages and may be a free agent. But if the Portuguese FA decide he's still under contract, he'll cost me £2.5m. They can whistle.

Today (even later)

Been on this plane far too long. Where's Paris? Become agitated when bids for Blackburn pair Damien Duff and Matt Jansen are turned down. Bah! That's it! Decide Fulham can go to hell if they want Didier Domi in exchange for Lee Clark. And as for this irritating Hugh Grant film they're showing... stewardess!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"You can't buy a player, moreover a forward, and then drop him if he doesn't score in two matches - especially when he cost as much as I did. Oh, the stupidity and the hypocrisy of people who change sides today" - Nicolas Anelka in L'Equipe. He was dropped by Real. That's all we can say, really.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LET'S HEAR IT FOR GALATASARAY!

We all love Galatasaray. Nobody who watched their progress to the Euro-Vase this season can fail to have been won over by the charm of their fans, the straight-talking nature of their officials, and the honesty of their players (even when spinning six feet in the air after a challenge). So who will begrudge this ground-breaking sporting organisation a reward of £17m from the Turkish government? Certainly not the Fiver, but a few Turks might.

The Fiver has been deluged - alright, slightly annoyed - by emails today complaining in finest Turklish about the multi-million bonus Gala are set to receive. "What about the earthquake victims?" they ask. "What about establishing a sound economic base upon which to secure entry into the European Union?" they also ask, rather long-windedly. Finally, and perhaps most pertinently, they wonder: "Why are Gala getting squillions when members of the Korac Cup-winning Efes Pilsen basketball team got a pen-and-tie combination set?"

If only the Fiver, sounding board for the world's football problems, could provide an answer. Particularly one that wasn't potentially libellous. Sadly, all we can do is observe another stroke of Gala good luck - a joint shirt-sponsorship deal with lowly neighbours Istanbulspor which should net the pair in the region of £16m. Coincidentally, the deal was signed last week, after which Gala surprisingly drew 1-1 with Istanbulspor in the final game of the season - a result which kept the smaller club in the top flight. It's a footballing fairytale!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bradford are believed to have made a £2m bid for Manchester United's Jonathan Greening. The 21-year-old has been on the fringes of the Old Trafford side this season, and fits into Bradford manager Paul Jewell's plans to rejuvenate his ageing side.

Everton have made Wimbledon captain Kenny Cunningham their top transfer target this summer. The Merseysiders are expected to ask the Dons to name their price for the Republic of Ireland full-back.

Dutch international defender Winston Bogarde is expected to leave Barcelona very shortly and his eventual destination is expected to be Chelsea. Similarly Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink is said to prefer a move to Chelsea if, as expected, he leaves Atletico Madrid this summer.

Both Milan and Lazio have made approaches to sign Luis Figo, according to the manager of the Portuguese national side, Jose Veiga. "We have received very good offers," Veiga said. "Figo is okay in Barcelona, but they offer much money."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Trevor Sinclair has confirmed that he is staying at West Ham. "There have been a lot of rumours but it doesn't bother me because as far as I'm concerned I want to stay here at least until the end of my contract," he told the Evening Standard. "The supporters have got nothing to worry about because I'm a Hammers man through and through.

Vicente del Bosque has been rewarded for guiding Real Madrid into the final of Big Cup with a one-year contract as permanent manager.

John Benson will step down as Wigan manager regardless of the Second Division play-off final result against Gillingham. Danny Wilson is favourite to succeed Benson, who may become the club's general manager.

Morton supporters are to petition the Scottish Parliament for support in their efforts to save the club. Morton chairman Hugh Scott has claimed that the future of the club will be decided by June 30 and has refused to rule out the prospect of it folding. Greenock and Inverclyde MSP Duncan McNeill said today: "The fans met last night and want their side of the story to be heard. The club is very important to the community."

Jim White tries to look excited as he reviews the SPL season. He looks totally defeated.

fields.bodyText: YOU HEARD IT HERE FIRST When Joe Kinnear was told to fjord off by Wimbledon's Norwegian owners last summer, it wasn't just Mystic Fiver who saw the interaction of Mars as a sure sign that the most rotund man in football would soon be back managing a big club. But as the months ticked by, a few started expressing doubts. And those doubts turned to outright scepticism when Kinnear expressed interest in the Celtic, Blackburn and Fulham jobs - only to be cruelly rebuffed at every turn. Where are the doubters now? In hiding probably - because according to Reuters, Kinnear will be named as manager of Sheffield Wednesday tomorrow. It doesn't get much bigger than that. Well, not as far as Jumping Joe Ashton MP is concerned. "I'd be delighted if he was appointed," Ashton, who notoriously called for Danny Wilson's dismissal earlier this year, told the Fiver exclusively. "He's got a track record of getting a lot from very little money. More importantly he has teams that fight. Wednesday were an absolutely bloody disgrace this season. Bradford fought with true Yorkshire grit while Wednesday laid down before Christmas." The Fiver was ready to end it there but once Joe was off he wouldn't stop. "I met with Joe Kinnear at Wembley and he told me he was up for it," he continued. "And I suggested this to the board after the 8-0 defeat. fields.headline: Ashton: Owls must appoint Kinnear
fields.trailText: Joe Ashton, the MP who notoriously called for Danny Wilson's head earlier this season, has told the Sheffield Wednesday board they must appoint Joe Kinnear as manager.
fields.body:
Joe Ashton, the MP who notoriously called for Danny Wilson's head earlier this season, has told the Sheffield Wednesday board they must appoint Joe Kinnear as manager.

"I'd be delighted if he was appointed," Ashton told Football Unlimited in an exclusive interview. "He's got a track record of getting a lot from very little money. More importantly he has teams that fight. Wednesday were an absolutely bloody disgrace this season. Bradford City fought with true Yorkshire grit while Wednesday laid down before Christmas."

"I actually met with Joe Kinnear at Wembley earlier this season and he told me he was up for it," he added. "And I told this to the board after the 8-0 defeat against Newcastle. I begged Dave Richards to appoint him but he wouldn't do it.

"The trouble was the Wednesday team were like a good horse without a jockey. We had no direction. If Joe Kinnear had come in before Christmas we would have stayed up."

Earlier today Wednesday chairman Howard Culley admitted the club they were focusing on "one individual" in their search for a new manager, but he refused to say whether Joe Kinnear is their prime target.

"We still have a number of candidates. We are looking down the road with one particular individual but there is no firm deal with anyone," he said. "We are not there. Until a deal is done we are not going to make any announcement."

But Reuters report that sources close to the club insist that Kinnear will be announced as the new Wednesday manager tomorrow.

fields.headline: My team
fields.standfirst: Kenneth Branagh on Tottenham Hotspur
fields.trailText: Kenneth Branagh on Tottenham Hotspur
fields.body:
I was brought up in Belfast and when I was old enough to start working out what football was - which was quite young I suppose, about six, seven, eight - you basically picked three teams, a Northern Irish team, a Scottish team and an English team.

It was just at the end of the Danny Blanchflower era, and with Blanchflower being from my neck of the woods, it had to be Tottenham for me - along with Linfield and Rangers as well. I'd define myself as an armchair fan, though. I've rarely been but I've always been a keen Spurs watcher.

For me the classic Spurs teams had the likes of Chivers and Gilzean and Martin Peters. And I always remember Ralph Coates with his Bobby Charlton hair. Pat Jennings was my idea of the complete sportsman just because he was such a gentleman and those non-flashy, one-handed catches were just incredible. Again, being from my neck of the woods, we were very, very proud of him. They were a great cup team back then, of course.

As for the team in recent years, I'm amazed by Les Ferdinand's relative lack of form with us, cos I used to go and watch him a lot at QPR - a friend of mine lived near the ground and that's where I used to watch a lot of teams play live - and he played his best football there. I hope we don't get rid of him as under the right circumstances he could come again. He's got such a strong physical presence.

All the same, we definitively need a real killer goalscorer. We need a nicker of goals, like Lineker used to do. Actually we've missed Teddy Sheringham.

Spurs fans won't forive me, but I'm afraid I don't find myself especially anti-Arsenal. I mean I think Arsenal have been entertaining. Christ, imagine if Spurs had Bergkamp or somebody like that.

I would be very, very excited to meet some of the people I admire, that's where I would feel I would get a bit tongue tied. I would be beside myself to meet Pat Jennings.

I met George Best once and it was one of the greatest events of my life. I was in a foyer in a hotel in Australia, I'd just done four months in a TV series. I was only 22 and I hadn't done much work but I had been in a couple of plays in Northern Ireland. I'm due to go home two days later having finished this job and I was sitting with a mate in the foyer having a drink when two blokes walked past.

I thought, 'Fuck, that's George Best.' He went with another bloke up to the reception desk and the guy that's with him looks around, looks at me and then walks over to me. He says, 'You're not the fellow from the Billy plays?'

I said, 'Yes I am actually.' He said, 'Oh George liked that...'

So I went to George, 'George pleased to meet you.'

He went, 'What happened to your accent then?'

I said, 'Well I've been away a long time.' But after that, when I talked to him, I just put the Irish accent on.

webTitle: Second dot.com collapse and rate fears hit shares

fields.headline: Second dot.com collapse and rate fears hit shares
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Fears of a full-scale bear market in technology stocks gathered momentum yesterday as the sector in both Europe and the US suffered fresh losses at the hands of nervous investors.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
Fears of a full-scale bear market in technology stocks gathered momentum yesterday as the sector in both Europe and the US suffered fresh losses at the hands of nervous investors.

Following a fall of almost 9% on Friday the FTSE Techmark index fell a further 4% as the collapse of a second dot.com venture, Net Imperative, intensified worries about further casualties among start-ups. The Techmark closed down 122 points at 2,929.

London's woes were reflected on Wall Street, where the prospects of higher interest rates from the US Federal Reserve next month dragged the technology driven Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level this year and triggered trading curbs on the New York stock exchange.

At lunchtime yesterday the Nasdaq was down 170 points, or almost 5%, at just above 3,200. The index closed at an annual low of 3,321 just over a month ago, and is down more than a third from an all time high reached in March.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell about 2% to 10,410 as inflationary fears continued to dog investors.

Some of the US's most highly valued firms were the hardest hit as investors worried that the higher cost of borrowing would hurt future earnings.

With US interest rates at their highest level in nine years after last week's increase, fund managers have grown wary of valuations based on a continuing consumer spending boom.

James Volk, a director at DA Davidson, the brokerage firm, said: "People are afraid that not only are higher interest rates going to slow down the economy but also the sales of all the Nokias, Ciscos and Qualcomms. They are trading on sales, not earnings."

Cisco, the biggest networking equipment company, and Oracle, the software firm, fell sharply yesterday morning on continued nervousness that an economic slowdown would prompt companies to spend less on technology.

Cisco, briefly the world's most highly valued company, has lost 25% of its market value since concerns over its price first surfaced a month ago.

Trading volumes have also fallen over the past few weeks. Industry figures suggest that there are far fewer day traders buying and selling shares in the US than there were at the beginning of this year.

Blue chips in the so-called old economy were also hit by the sell-off. The New York stock exchange implemented curbs little more than an hour after opening to prevent programme trades sending prices into free fall. General Motors suffered the sharpest declines, falling almost 10% in two hours after announcing the terms of a restructuring of Hughes electronics.

webTitle: US regulators seek law on online consumer privacy

fields.headline: US regulators seek law on online consumer privacy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: US regulators last night called for laws to protect consumer privacy on the internet after an official report found that only a fifth of the most popular websites complied with voluntary standards.
fields.body:
US regulators last night called for laws to protect consumer privacy on the internet after an official report found that only a fifth of the most popular websites complied with voluntary standards.

The report by the federal trade commission will come as a bitter blow to the online sector, which has fought off previous attempts at legislation by championing the effectiveness of self-regulation. The burgeoning use of the internet by consumers, combined with evidence that companies were not adequately protecting personal information, is understood to have prompted the FTC to review its stance on regulation.

Five FTC commissioners were expected to present a report and their recommendations to the senate last night after voting three to two in favour of legislation at a secret session on Friday. The report is understood to outline how self-regulation has proved largely inadequate in protecting consumer privacy.

Any bill is likely to face a struggle in Congress, with several high-profile politicians opposed to the idea. To win support, yesterday's report was expected to suggest a level of continued self-regulation as well as new legal powers. The US imposes fewer legal restrictions than European states on companies collecting personal information.

Analysts said yesterday that the announcement was likely to hurt online advertisers such as DoubleClick and 24/7, which aim to make money by collectuing personal data to target ads.

Henry Blodget, internet analyst for Merrill Lynch, the investment bank, said the government's new stance would affect the sector even before legislation was passed. He added: "We believe that stricter standards will emerge in the meantime, whether from self-regulation (with tougher penalties for non-compliance) or from government-imposed regulation of certain industries or types of information."

Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, said: "This is the first step down the slippery slope of government regulation of the internet. The market place has responded to the important privacy concerns of consumers and will continue to do so in practical ways."

Consumer and privacy advocates welcomed yesterday's recommendations. Jason Catlett, president of Junkbusters, an online watchdog, said: "The federal government has finally started to abandon the unsupportable fiction that companies will voluntarily protect consumer privacy."

Five FTC commissioners were expected to present a report and their recommendations to the senate last night after voting three to two in favour of legislation at a secret session on Friday. The report is understood to outline how self-regulation has proved largely inadequate in protecting consumer privacy. Any bill is likely to face a struggle in Congress, with several high-profile politicians opposed to the idea. To win support, yesterday's report was expected to suggest a level of continued self-regulation as well as new legal powers. The US imposes fewer legal restrictions than European states on companies collecting personal information. Analysts said yesterday that the announcement was likely to hurt online advertisers such as DoubleClick and 24/7, which aim to make money by collectuing personal data to target ads. Henry Blodget, internet analyst for Merrill Lynch, the investment bank, said the government's new stance would affect the sector even before legislation was passed. He added: "We believe that stricter standards will emerge in the meantime, whether from self-regulation (with tougher penalties for non-compliance) or from government-imposed regulation of certain industries or types of information." Harris Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, said: "This is the first step down the slippery slope of government regulation of the internet. The market place has responded to the important privacy concerns of consumers and will continue to do so in practical ways." Consumer and privacy advocates welcomed yesterday's recommendations. Jason Catlett, president of Junkbusters, an online watchdog, said: "The federal government has finally started to abandon the unsupportable fiction that companies will voluntarily protect consumer privacy."

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: The nagging, stitch-like pain in the lower back persists, and I suspect that the kidney tumour has now grown to the size of a mango.
fields.body:
Tuesday

The nagging, stitch-like pain in the lower back persists, and I suspect that the kidney tumour has now grown to the size of a mango. Dr Sarah Jarvis disagrees, and thinks it is nothing more than backache, but says that if I am concerned I should give a urine sample for analysis. Ha ha. Very droll.

Wednesday

This morning, Dr Jarvis is good-humoured when I call, but to the point. "I can't talk, I have a patient waiting," she says. "You know, 'patient'? One of those sick people?" When I mention the kidney, she sighs. "You don't have renal cancer." "Do." "You do not." "Do too. Do too? What am I now? Marsha Brady?" "You have backache," she says, " but if you are worried, come in and do a sample." She sounds translucently bored. "No, that's quite all right doctor," I reply, "no need for that." The thing about giving samples is, you have no idea what they might find.

Thursday

This morning, the doctor's heroic patience evaporates further. "If you are concerned about the kidney," she says, extremely slowly, like a traffic cop directing an au pair newly arrived from Helsinki to Carnaby Street, "come . . . in... and... do... a... urine... sample." A silence ensues. "What really gets to me is the boredom," says Dr Jarvis eventually. "This is the seventh time in a fortnight you've asked about the same thing. It's the repetitiveness. Can't you come up with something new? You haven't presented anything new for years. Literally, years."

Reflecting on this, I realise the doctor is right. In the nine years since she succeeded the excellent Fleur Navey as my doctor, I must have consulted her 300-400 times, but about so few things - deviated septum, ear infections (otitis media and externa), bronchitis, flu, cancers of the brain, testes, rectum, colon, stomach, blood and latterly kidney, arterial blockages, motor neurone disease, that persistent lump in the roof of my mouth... all the usual suspects, brought in for questioning time and again, and released without charge. I can see why she's bored.

Friday
Although for once my back is relatively free of pain, I am exhausted. A small boy in our house, we discover today, has a spiral fracture of his left leg from ankle to knee, and he appears to view this as an excuse for the entire family to stay up until 3am watching The Railway Children. Therefore I have had to postpone a trawl through my medical textbooks to find something recherche to revive Dr Jarvis's jaded palate.

Saturday

Interrupted in the middle of her emergency clinic, the doctor is to the point. "What now?" "Something new - a strange tingling in the extremities. Touching anything, however soft, puts my teeth on edge. I've never had that before." "Yes you have." "I don't think so." "Hang on..." Fingers click audibly on computer keyboard... "May 29 1998, complains of tingling in fingers and teeth being on edge." Now I think of it, it does ring a bell. "And I diagnosed eve of world cup over-excitability. Is there a big football tournament this summer?" "Right, goodbye then, doctor. Thank you very much."

Sunday

Tonight, finally, I spend time with my medical dictionaries, and eventually discover something new that I suffer from. Condylomata acuminata, it's called, and it needs prompt treatment. Poised to ring the doctor when, re-reading the entry more closely, I notice that condylomata acuminata is the technical term for vaginal warts.

Monday

I awake feeling nervy and unsettled, having passed a troubled night. In a dream, I am in the Hammersmith hospital's radiology department. "Yes, yes," says a young doctor, smugly, "your brain is fine. Absolutely fine." But on leaving the room, I become extremely confused - the result, I realise, of a mango-sized frontal lobe tumour of a type caused by brain cells becoming so bored with themselves that they change character in a quest for light relief.

I bump into a woman. "Excusing me, please, but I coming from Helsinki and know not where to go for to be becoming more and more interesting?" I say. "Go... that... way, yes," says Dr Jarvis, very slowly, "around... corner... and... straight... on." I follow the direction. Around the corner is a sign with an arrow pointing to one vast door at the end of the corridor. "Morgue," it says.
