fields.headline: Just a little snip...
fields.standfirst: A handful of British hospitals offer circumcision on religious rather than medical grounds. But is this really a job for the NHS?  Faisal Bodi, who will never forget his own op, reports
fields.trailText: A handful of British hospitals offer circumcision on religious rather than medical grounds. But is this really a job for the NHS? Faisal Bodi, who will never forget his own op, reports
fields.body:
Every other Friday, Bradford Royal Infirmary's neonatal unit is host to a clutch of swaddled babies, oblivious to the controversy they are creating. Today there are five suckling babes quietly waiting to go under the surgeon's knife. For the moment only a nervous silence suggests the serenity might be short-lived.

How things have changed. In my day there were no waiting rooms, no hospitals, no trained doctors, no anaesthetic, and certainly no aftercare. It's been more than 20 years since my own circumcision at the age of seven but the memory is as painful as if it had been etched in my mind yesterday.

My twin and I were taken to a GP's surgery in Blackburn. I think I went first, a conclusion reached some years later when I realised my inability to recall my brother's piercing cries, just my own, as a strange figure donned gloves while my father and his friend held me down. The rest is a blank, the effect, I would later discover, of passing out. I still hadn't come round by the time they'd pinned my brother down. I only regained consciousness at home hours later to discover my vital region bandaged up and sore.

I'd like to believe the days of the back-street circumcision are long gone. But horror stories still abound: of the occasional glans being excised, of other mutilations and avoidable infections. Many practitioners remain unqualified and the operation is just as likely to be performed on the dining table as in the operating theatre.

Thankfully, change is at hand. In 1996, Bradford NHS trust became the first medical authority to provide a circumcision service. Despite early opposition, a slow uptake and some teething problems, it has now grown to account for a fifth of all neonatal male circumcisions in the city. That however, is only one measure of its success. Perhaps a more telling indi cator is that babies are regularly brought in from as far afield as Newcastle and Hull. Another is that Bradford's model has been adopted by hospitals in Bolton, Bury, Sandwell, and Leicester.

Nafisa Hafeji is a Mancunian but has made the journey across the Pennines with Mustafa, her six-week-old son. The 27-year-old is horrified that her city's 35,000 Muslims still largely rely on untrained GPs to perform what can be a tricky procedure. "I feel much safer about having it performed in a hospital," she says, "you know everything is clean and sterile."

She eyes the clock as it approaches 12.40. At roughly half-hour intervals from now all the babies will be cradled away into the operating theatre. Mustafa is last in line. Nafisa's husband couldn't get the day off work but her mother is on hand to help. They disappear behind a curtain to be shown a video explaining the operation.

Dr Tariq Shah, consultant urologist at BRI and the pioneer of its circumcision service, is doing the explaining. Throughout the day he will be on hand to oversee his nurses perform the operations. Each one has undergone an intensive training programme. Bradford NHS trust makes no bones about its reasons for offering the procedure. Although claims of an overriding health benefit are often made, the medical case for routine male circumcision in the west is at least inconclusive. This service is primarily a religious one.

"Look," says Shah, "there are about 1,000 Muslim male babies born in BRI every year. They all need circumcising. Until now they have been performed privately by GPs but most of them have never had the training. Nor have they been trained to deal with complications. We in the NHS are having to pick up the pieces - and the cost - of these botched operations."

Critics of the service have accused Bradford of introducing circumcision through the back door. The NHS, they point out, is supposed to dispense treatment based on clinical not religious need.

Shah is sensitive to the charge. But for him the matter demands a commonsense approach based on pre-emption and prevention. "Muslims will demand circumcision for cultural and social reasons no matter what. But the NHS can only provide it if medically required. But that would be leaving room for back-street circumcisions, something that would also cost the NHS since it would have to repair the damage they do.

"That's not to say we don't have any complications. But because all our staff are properly trained they don't tend to be as serious. And if there are any problems we can dealwith them swiftly on site."

Circumcisions are not free, but parents pay no more than the cost of materials used in the procedure. At £60 the fee compares favourably with private practitioners. The nurses provide their services for no extra pay.

Our conversation is interrupted by the sound of a baby crying. Next door, Dr Mohammed Ajmal is part-way through an operation. It's uncomfortable viewing but by no-means x-rated stuff. As one nurse comforts the bawling patient and another tugs down his anaesthesised foreskin, Dr Ajmal, a trainee from Manchester, cleans underneath. He then fits a Plastibell, an upturned protective plastic hood, over the head of the penis. The prepuce is drawn over and a cord tightly tied around the foreskin to fit snugly into a groove on the Plastibell underneath.

With the blood supply to the foreskin now cut off, Ajmal makes an inch-long vertical incision in the foreskin and cuts around it in a loop until the skin has been removed. Blood seeps from the cut, but not in the copious quantities I'd imagined. Time for a quick clean, a fresh nappy and the operation is complete. The bell and cord stay in place. Within seven days the part of the prepuce that cannot be cut off will drop off on its own as dead skin.

How much pain is involved is hard to quantify but the medical consensus is that it increases with age. Bradford will only accept patients aged between four and 12 weeks. Older patients, I am told, need greater restraint because the nerve fibres in the foreskin are more sensitive. Younger ones are just too small and fidgety.

Shah concedes the surgery is not pain free but says it is not as bad as people assume. "Babies do not feel that much pain, just some tugging and pressure. They cry as much because they are tied down and detached from their mother."

This is where he is on vulnerable ground. While circumcision does have demonstrable health benefits, the clinical case is far from proven. Opponents see the suffering as unjustified. They call circumcision a "euphemism for genital reduction surgery or genital mutilation performed on children who, by definition are not able to give informed consent". Led by a group called Norm UK, the anti-circumcision lobby says the operation, performed on 20,000-30,000 British infants each year, also causes lasting trauma and feelings of shame and violation.

For Muslims and Jews, the centuries-old rite has traditionally served as a symbol of group identity and a means of ensuring personal hygiene. But this is not, according to Norm UK, sufficient reason for lopping off a part of the anatomy they say is vital to sexual sensation. "We approach the problem from a strictly medical perspective," says secretary David Smith. "It is now acknowledged that it is a damaging operation."

The staff are acutely aware of the ethical debate. Ironically, most, like enrolled nurse Ann Coatsworth, oppose circumcision unless it is clinically necessary. "My son had it done, but for medical reasons," she says. "With any surgical procedure there are risks and you've got to weigh them up. But I understand why other people have different views."

Back in the waiting room the moral controversy could not be further from Nafisa's mind. Her immediate priority is to be reunited with Mustafa, who has been away now for some 20 minutes. Her nerves are on edge. "I'm glad I don't have to go in," she says with a sideways glance at her mother. "I told her she's going to have to change his nappy for the next week. I don't want to see it."

Mustafa returns as quietly as he left. But tears are rolling down his cheeks. Ann lifts up his nappy to rub some petroleum jelly on the treated area, providing the clearly upset Nafisa with her first glimpse of the newly constituted penis.

There's a flurry of activity as Shah enters the room to inspect the other remaining infant. For a moment it seems as though something might be amiss: 40 minutes after his operation, six-week-old Bilal Rehman is still oozing. Ann is instructed to put on a gauze to staunch the flow. The same is recommended for Mustafa. But there are reassuring words from Shah. "It's just precautionary. There will be a bit of clotting, it never gets completely clear."

If there are any unwelcome reactions, the babies will be transferred to the children's ward. Should they still be bleeding half an hour later they will be detained overnight. Tomorrow morning, and again a week later, the parents will be telephoned to check if all is well.

But today is not a day for aberrations. At 3.30, some three hours after he came in, Mustafa is ready to be discharged. His mother greets the news with a sigh of relief. As for the star of the show, his eyes are now dry and he is fast asleep once more.

fields.headline: Feel the force
fields.standfirst: On the new generation of rollercoasters, thrillseekers are subjected to the kind of pressures that only astronauts and fighter pilots would normally be expected to endure. Now a series of reports of brain damage has raised serious questions about their safety.  Oliver Burkeman reports
fields.trailText: On the new generation of rollercoasters, thrillseekers are subjected to the kind of pressures that only astronauts and fighter pilots would normally be expected to endure. Now a series of reports of brain damage has raised serious questions about their safety. Oliver Burkeman reports
fields.body:
As the car trundles slowly towards the summit, the thoughts of the foolhardy thrillseeker ascending the Oblivion rollercoaster at Alton Towers in Staffordshire tend to dwell on the more fundamental questions of life: its transience, its fragility - and how, under the wrong circumstances, a vertical drop at high speed from a very great height can bring it rather swiftly to an end. Once the car has reached the precipice, though, there's no time to think: screaming participants are plunged face-first into a black hole at 70mph, their bodies withstanding forces reaching four-and-a-half times that of gravity. It takes several moments, at the end, before paralysing terror is replaced with a surge of relief, exhilaration and an overpowering smugness towards those who opted to wait on the ground instead.

In recent months, though, a hand ful of riders on some of the world's most stomach-churning rollercoasters in the US and Japan have been reporting some more disturbing sensations: persistent headaches, symptoms of blood clots in the brain which, if left untreated, can cause brain damage, seizures, and even death. This month, America's consumer product safety commission put at 16 the number of reported cases of brain damage believed to be related to the extreme g-forces experienced on white-knuckle rides. In one of the most serious incidents, Japanese researchers reported that a 24- year-old woman had been diagnosed as suffering from subdural haematomas - ruptured veins on the brain's surface, better known as a key symptom of shaken baby syndrome - after taking a 70m plunge on the giant Fujiyama rollercoaster.

The thought that one's safety might be in immediate and serious danger is, of course, as crucial to the thrill of a good rollercoaster ride as is the underlying faith that death won't actually result from the experience. And, by and large, the industry has an excellent safety record: 500m rides are purchased in Britain each year, but the nightmare mechanical failures - the loose screw, the insecure harness, the heart-stopping mid-loop halt - are so rare as to prompt just 400 accident reports to the health and safety executive in total. Theme parks enjoy reminding critics that the chances of having an accident while driving to an attraction are seven times greater than when riding on it; equivalent US figures show that fishing is 17 times more dangerous.

But the new generation of giant rollercoasters are raising a different kind of safety fear, as parks race to outdo each other in speed, altitude and nerve-shattering terror. This is not a field in which records remain standing for very long, but the current leaders - according to the Rollercoaster Club of Great Britain - give a sense of the territory: Millennium Force at Cedar Point, Ohio, is the tallest conventional rollercoaster at 95m; and Superman - The Escape, at the Magic Mountain park in California, the fastest, firing riders down its 377m of track at 100mph, exposing them to forces approaching those previously only experienced by astronauts and jet-fighter pilots.

"We suspect that many cases have been overlooked," warned Toshio Fukutake, a neurologist at Chiba University in Japan, who wrote the Fujiyama study. He acknowledged that the problem was rare, but added: "Giant rollercoasters that are higher and faster than typical roller coasters may be more dangerous_ the woman's subdural haematomas and resulting headaches may have been caused by the up-and down, back-and-forth motions of the rollercoaster, or the acceleration force may have been strong enough to rupture veins on the surface of her brain."

Haematomas - usually encountered in older men suffering from alcoholism, hypertension or diabetes - are extremely rare in younger women, but eminently treatable: eight weeks after presenting her symptoms, the woman made a full recovery. But her case adds weight to earlier studies of "rollercoaster headache", including a paper published in the New England Journal of Medicine in 1995 in which the effects were likened to whiplash injuries."The swooping ride induces marked rotatory and other positional changes in a deformable brain that is moving within a relatively rigid skull, thus causing tensile and shearing stresses," the authors observed.

The forces experienced while hurtling down hundreds of metres of steel tracks demand years of professional training in other contexts: astronauts reach a g-force of 3 during the launch of the Space Shuttle; Blackpool Pleasure Beach's £12m Pepsi Max Big One - so tall it requires aircraft warning beacons from the Civil Aviation Authority - subjects riders to 3.5g; Alton Towers' Oblivion reaches 4.5. Only jet-fighter pilots experience a greater hammering - and they wear anti-gravity suits to pump air around their lower bodies, compressing blood vessels to prevent the rapid drain of blood from the head as g-forces spiral towards 9 and 10.

The British Association of Leisure Parks, Piers and Attractions is adamant that no British rides have ever been linked to these risks. "We are aware that there are a number of rides in this country that exert moderate g-forces, and there is no evidence that this is known to affect people's health, providing that passengers follow the operators' safety warnings and advice," says a spokesman for the group.

In any case, much as theme parks crow about them - "Some TV Gladiators were actually sick after sampling the world's ultimate white-knuckle ride," says Alton Towers of its 4g Nemesis attraction - high forces are not all they seem. "You can't compare absolute figures," says Volker Damman, head of medical operations at the European Space Agency and an expert on the effects of space travel on the human body. "It depends on how long you're exposed to high forces for. On a rollercoaster you're talking about milliseconds and you can experience that turning a sharp bend in a car.

"It also matters how your body is positioned: the worst is vertical force, pushing blood away from the head. Russian astronauts on the Soyuz withstood 5g for much longer, but they were lying on their backs. It was much, much harder for them to breathe, but the blood was drawn from their chest to their back, which is less of a problem."

fields.headline: Routine ultrasound in pregnancy
fields.body:
Pregnant women in Britain routinely undergo at least one ultrasound scan. Most women are excited at the prospect of seeing their baby for the first time, and being reassured all is well. Some hospitals also offer a chance to find out the sex of the baby. Scans give useful information but they may also miss or exaggerate problems. Some midwives argue women should be given more informed choice over whether to have a scan.

What a scan shows

There are four main medical reasons for having a scan in early pregnancy. A scan gives a more accurate estimate of expected delivery date than calculating the date from the last period. Where a later date is predicted this can avoid unnecessary induction of labour. More accurate dating is also important in interpreting Down's syndrome tests. The scan will show whether the mother is carrying twins or more babies, although this is almost always detected before delivery anyway and there are usually no health benefits to early detection. Scans can show a low-lying placenta, which could cause problems in labour. But the placenta moves of its own accord in 19 out of 20 pregnancies and no further action should be needed unless other symptoms develop. Finally, the scan can indicate an abnormality with the baby. Checking this normally requires more tests. As with all screening, scans are not foolproof. Studies show that scans detect up to 80% of severe abnormalities but on rare occasions foetuses are aborted that are healthy or have insignificant problems.

Safety
There is no evidence scans cause harm to the baby but more research is needed to prove this beyond doubt.

Choice

Some midwives are concerned that scans are presented as routine rather than an option and that counselling, pointing out that abnormalities may be found, is rarely given.

Information

A leaflet, Ultrasound scans - should you have one?, published by the Midwives Information and Resource Service, is available from some midwives.

 What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York university (01904 433 634) and verified by experts.

webTitle: Microsoft boss opens the University Gates

fields.headline: Microsoft boss opens the University Gates
fields.standfirst: The software mogul's £130m Cambridge scholarship fund is a well-intentioned but misguided gesture, says higher education editor Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 4pm: The software mogul's £130m Cambridge scholarship fund is a well-intentioned but misguided gesture, says higher education editor Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Whether or not the Microsoft empire wields a monopolising power over the world's computer markets, one has to admire the philanthropic side of its founder Bill Gates. The richest man in the world has said that he plans to give almost all of his $100bn (£62bn) fortune away.

Earlier this year he and his wife Melinda gave a further $5bn to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, making it the biggest charitable foundation in the world, with assets now totalling more than $21bn. The aims are laudable: to improve the lives of people from disadvantaged backgrounds, primarily through health and learning. Yet today's news that Gates is now set to donate £130m of his fortune to launch a new international scholarship fund at the University of Cambridge represents a well-intentioned but ultimately misguided gesture.

The scheme will finance 230 scholarships in Cambridge, where a Bill Gates House will be established as a students' centre. Scholars of any nationality will able to study any subject offered at Cambridge, but are likely to be recruited for science and technology degrees.

It will be the biggest scholarship scheme for international students in the UK, creating a strong rival to the University of Oxford's Rhodes Scholarships, which awards grants only to overseas "English-speaking peoples".

The move highlights an unfathomable irony among some successful Americans, who extol the virtues of a society where success is based on talent not background, and yet who retain a strong fascination with Oxbridge, the very embodiment of the old school tie elite. In an interview last week President Bill Clinton, himself a former Rhodes scholar, revealed that he was considering a return to Oxford as a college tutor.

There are of course many other UK universities, with much less money than the Oxbridge institutions, that have strong records in attracting large numbers of overseas students as well as students from poor backgrounds. A Gates scholarship scheme should not operate just at Cambridge but should open the doors to all the country's universities.

fields.headline: Fallen angels
fields.standfirst: Ever heard of Hayden Christensen? Well, don't worry, you will. He's been cast as Anakin Skywalker in the next instalment of the Star Wars trilogy.  George Mountford  explains why it's the worst career move he'll ever make
fields.trailText: Ever heard of Hayden Christensen? Well, don't worry, you will. He's been cast as Anakin Skywalker in the next instalment of the Star Wars trilogy. George Mountford explains why it's the worst career move he'll ever make
fields.body:
Who wouldn't want to be plucked from obscurity, made into a star by one of the world's leading directors and given, apparently, the world at their feet?

Anyone who's smart, that's who.

What does it mean, for example, for Hayden Christensen, who was last week announted by George Lucas as the star of the next Star Wars movie in the prized role of Anakin Skywalker?

A good clue to the next Anakin's future career prospects can be gained by looking at the most recent Anakin's current movie activities. Now, granted, he's still a kid, and his parents, lawyer, agent and personal masseuse have doubtless encouraged him to concentrate on his education. And his apparent lack of acting skills probably have as much to do with the fact that half of his co-stars only ever existed inside a computer (not to mention George Lucas's legendary reluctance to give his actors any guidance). But, face facts, fans of Jake: his only announced role this year is in Madison, "A story about a man's personal struggle to victory in the 1971, Madison, Indiana hydroplane regatta."

The original Skywalker, Mark Hamill himself, was plucked by George from obscurity (well, Fred Flintstone And Friends and Sarah T - Portrait Of A Teenage Alcoholic) to become the most famous farm boy since John-Boy Walton. The work since then has been plentiful (Flash II: The Revenge Of The Trickster) but, I assume, less than fulfilling. Hamill at least starred in all three original movies, so that by the end he was able to command the sort of pay packet likely to banish sleepless nights for the rest of his life.

It's always miserable to be a child, but to become a child star in a big, big film must be like having the biggest party of your life and then never getting to leave your room again. Steven Spielberg has inadvertently screwed up more minors than any other non-lawbreaker in history. Henry Thomas in ET was the first big casualty. Henry's still working, but his CV bears all the hallmarks of the past-their-prime: sequels to movies they weren't in the original of (Psycho IV: The Beginning) and based-on-a-true-story TV movies (Indictment: The McMartin Trial.)

There was Jonathan Ke Quan from the second Indiana Jones movie. There was Joseph Mazzello and Ariana Richards from Jurassic Park, who went on to Stories From My Childhood (presumably featuring "The Day My Agent Didn't Call") and Born Free: A New Adventure. And our own Christian Bale only just managed to escape from Spielberg's shadow. You might notice a simple rule here: nobody, young or old, becomes a star from a Spielberg movie - you either already are, or you never will be.

There's always scope for this sort of tragedy whenever either the main star, director or source material is so strong they could cast anyone (Natasha Henstridge/Anne Widdecombe/Fergie) in the other big roles and it wouldn't matter. And for those others, if they don't remember that they are there solely for Arnold to rescue, a painful dose of reality lies somewhere ahead.

The work won't dry up: some producer somewhere still believes that people went to see Terminator II because of Robert Patrick, so he'll never go hungry. But the quality quantity takes a dive, and that must be tough to take.

But it must be hardest for the kids: Anna Paquin went from nowhere to ubiquity in The Piano, but other than that goose movie (Fly Away Home) must have been working more on an education recently. Of course, she made the extra mistake of winning an Oscar for her breakthrough role, earning the bitter and undying hatred of every other young actress in the English-speaking film world.

Linda Blair went from the Exorcist to Sarah T - Portrait Of A Teenage Alcoholic (where she hopefully gave some good tips to Mark Hamill) and Temptress II (plus episodes of MacGyver and The Love Boat) but, while it's good to be working it can't be quite the same, can it?

Not all child stars are doomed to fail. Haley Joel Osment from the Sixth Sense will probably do well, mainly because he'd done a lot of work before he met Bruce Willis and displays some or all of the characteristics of acting ability.

My advice to Hayden is this: enjoy the ride, keep a close eye on the money, do one more big movie for as much cash as possible and then go back to the real world. Otherwise, in a couple of years, you'll be in The Sixth Sense II: The Seventh Sense.

fields.headline: The Lars dance
fields.standfirst: Guardian film critic  Peter Bradshaw found much to admire at this year's Cannes film festival - even if Von Trier's Palme d'Or winner was rubbish
fields.trailText: Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw found much to admire at this year's Cannes film festival - even if Von Trier's Palme d'Or winner was rubbish
fields.body:
The Cannes jury (pictured) has awarded the Palme d'Or to Lars Von Trier's Potter-esque musical fantasy Dancer in the Dark - with the best actress award presented to Björk for good measure - and in so doing has fulfilled the worst nightmares and wildest dreams of the 2000 Cannes film festival.

Opinions about the film have been bitterly divided. Some critics and delegates thought it an almost insupportably harrowing study of a young woman and the indomitable spirit with which she copes with life's injustice, this spirit deepened and made gloriously vivid by her fantasy musical life. Others thought Björk's childlike performance trod a fine line between touching serenity and naff, unintentional absurdity, but that this riskiness and edginess were all part of the flash and crash of Von Trier's experimentalism.

I belonged to the third contingent, which thought it was rubbish. For all the style and brio, there was something crudely manipulative about the story, and something facetious and shallow about the whole enterprise. Just as in The Idiots, where the suspicion persisted that the subject of the sexual existence and identity of those suffering from mental handicap was simply a joke, Dancer in the Dark looked like a sprightly Dogme movie with MTV videos dropped in for the song and dance numbers. Von Trier clearly had no serious love of musicals; they were just a gimmick.

Von Trier's movie-making is an event, a happening. With its audacity and provocation, Dancer in the Dark demanded a response, and it got one. Amid the stately parade of high art cinema, it made a splash. But that was all it made. The final anguish of Björk's death is just ridiculous - and self-important. Nothing in the film is deeply felt, or deeply considered, and the euphoria soon wears off, leaving only the conviction that this is a middlebrow film, for people with posters of Björk on their bedroom wall.

But there you are. Cannes is definitely under threat from those who feel it isn't where the action is: the Hollywood and Anglophone movie-makers stay away, leaving the festival with uncommercial art movies, some of questionable quality, and whose failings are apparent when exposed to the glare of the festival audience. Von Trier is news; he makes people sit up; his film is in English and it has got a pop star in it. Maybe that is what the Cannes festival thinks it needs.

Elsewhere, the much vaunted far eastern content of the festival received consolation prizes. Edward Yang got the director's prize for Yi Yi, a beautifully crafted, engaging film about an unhappy family in Taiwan. Guizi Lai Le, or Devils on the Doorstep, Jiang Wen's film about the wartime Japanese occupation of China, got the Grand Prize, and the critics' prize went to Shinji Aoyama's epic Eureka. The best actor award went to Tony Leung for his excellent performance as the unhappy, cuckolded husband in Wong Kar-Wei's In the Mood for Love, set in 1962 Hong Kong. Leung is a marvellous performer and this elegant, sad film deserves UK distribution.

The really good news from Cannes is that a bauble went to one of the best films of the festival: Songs from the Second Floor, by Roy Andersson, which delivered the mega-voltage jolt that Dancer in the Dark promised but failed to provide, won the Jury Prize. A deeply disturbing and yet unaccountably hilarious film, it was presented in a series of surreal, painterly tableaux that play fast and loose with the perspectives and contours of reality.

Andersson's film is set at the end of the millennium, with life in a northern European city on the verge of breakdown. A traffic jam has paralysed the city and a torpid miasma of despair and anxiety convulses society, to the extent that only a human sacrifice will exorcise these fin-de-siècle demons. Alongside this ghastly sense of the end of the world, there are minor, farcical disasters: a magician's act going wrong, an insurance-arson job covering the perpetrator in giveaway soot.

Andersson's anti-narrative is vividly and agonisingly realised: it has something of Ingmar Bergman, Terry Gilliam and Woody Allen, but is very distinctive. In Songs from the Second Floor, he has created a secret cabaret of existential anxiety, and his movie was one of the joys of Cannes.

Once again, the on dit is that Cannes is finished and other festivals, like Toronto, are more important: a theory often airily put about by people who wouldn't dream of actually going to Toronto. Cannes has certainly got a problem attracting US movies: the big fish don't see the advantage in entering their expensive babies for competition. But where Cannes can and must score is getting the indie breakthroughs, such as the Palme d'Or winners of yesteryear: sex, lies and videotape or Pulp Fiction. Increasingly, movies like these are getting their festival plaudits at Sundance or Telluride.

One of the shrewdest things about Cannes has often been its mixture of big stars and highbrow academics on the juries. As Philip French wrote in the Observer, this has the happy effect of making the stars feel like intellectuals and the intellectuals feel like stars. And it makes everyone feel that world cinema is a coherent, intelligible concept that can be judged by a jury of open-minded professionals. Cannes used to have that broad mix in its films: now it is losing it. This year, it needed more lively US films, but also lighter films, more comedies, love stories and populist dramas. Even the Asian films, some of them excellent, are mostly destined for the festival circuit; and a European festival audience may have difficulty distinguishing a great Chinese film from something posterity may dismiss as a Far East Merchant Ivory. Tellingly, Ang Lee's thrilling martial arts/action movie, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, was shown out of competition.

In the end, the Cannes festival will have to promote the aspect of the movies which is difficult to acknowledge: their sexiness - which has nothing to do with sex or box office appeal, but currency and contemporary charge; it is the sense of what gets movies talked about. This is probably what appealed with Dancer in the Dark, and to some extent Von Trier's award is valuable, as his film will indeed be talked about. But it is unfortunate that the big prizewinner is this negligible and faintly embarrassing film, when pictures like Yang's Yi Yi, Andersson's Songs from the Second Floor and James Gray's The Yards will surely outlast it.

Von Trier clearly had no serious love of musicals; they were just a gimmick. Von Trier's movie-making is an event, a happening. With its audacity and provocation, Dancer in the Dark demanded a response, and it got one. Amid the stately parade of high art cinema, it made a splash. But that was all it made. The final anguish of Björk's death is just ridiculous - and self-important. Nothing in the film is deeply felt, or deeply considered, and the euphoria soon wears off, leaving only the conviction that this is a middlebrow film, for people with posters of Björk on their bedroom wall. But there you are. Cannes is definitely under threat from those who feel it isn't where the action is: the Hollywood and Anglophone movie-makers stay away, leaving the festival with uncommercial art movies, some of questionable quality, and whose failings are apparent when exposed to the glare of the festival audience. Von Trier is news; he makes people sit up; his film is in English and it has got a pop star in it. Maybe that is what the Cannes festival thinks it needs. Elsewhere, the much vaunted far eastern content of the festival received consolation prizes. Edward Yang got the director's prize for Yi Yi, a beautifully crafted, engaging film about an unhappy family in Taiwan. Guizi Lai Le, or Devils on the Doorstep, Jiang Wen's film about the wartime Japanese occupation of China, got the Grand Prize, and the critics' prize went to Shinji Aoyama's epic Eureka. The best actor award went to Tony Leung for his excellent performance as the unhappy, cuckolded husband in Wong Kar-Wei's In the Mood for Love, set in 1962 Hong Kong. Leung is a marvellous performer and this elegant, sad film deserves UK distribution. The really good news from Cannes is that a bauble went to one of the best films of the festival: Songs from the Second Floor, by Roy Andersson, which delivered the mega-voltage jolt that Dancer in the Dark promised but failed to provide, won the Jury Prize. A deeply disturbing and yet unaccountably hilarious film, it was presented in a series of surreal, painterly tableaux that play fast and loose with the perspectives and contours of reality. Andersson's film is set at the end of the millennium, with life in a northern European city on the verge of breakdown. A traffic jam has paralysed the city and a torpid miasma of despair and anxiety convulses society, to the extent that only a human sacrifice will exorcise these fin-de-siècle demons. Alongside this ghastly sense of the end of the world, there are minor, farcical disasters: a magician's act going wrong, an insurance-arson job covering the perpetrator in giveaway soot. Andersson's anti-narrative is vividly and agonisingly realised: it has something of Ingmar Bergman, Terry Gilliam and Woody Allen, but is very distinctive. In Songs from the Second Floor, he has created a secret cabaret of existential anxiety, and his movie was one of the joys of Cannes. Once again, the on dit is that Cannes is finished and other festivals, like Toronto, are more important: a theory often airily put about by people who wouldn't dream of actually going to Toronto. Cannes has certainly got a problem attracting US movies: the big fish don't see the advantage in entering their expensive babies for competition. But where Cannes can and must score is getting the indie breakthroughs, such as the Palme d'Or winners of yesteryear: sex, lies and videotape or Pulp Fiction. Increasingly, movies like these are getting their festival plaudits at Sundance or Telluride. One of the shrewdest things about Cannes has often been its mixture of big stars and highbrow academics on the juries. As Philip French wrote in the Observer, this has the happy effect of making the stars feel like intellectuals and the intellectuals feel like stars. And it makes everyone feel that world cinema is a coherent, intelligible concept that can be judged by a jury of open-minded professionals. Cannes used to have that broad mix in its films: now it is losing it. This year, it needed more lively US films, but also lighter films, more comedies, love stories and populist dramas. Even the Asian films, some of them excellent, are mostly destined for the festival circuit; and a European festival audience may have difficulty distinguishing a great Chinese film from something posterity may dismiss as a Far East Merchant Ivory. Tellingly, Ang Lee's thrilling martial arts/action movie, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, was shown out of competition. In the end, the Cannes festival will have to promote the aspect of the movies which is difficult to acknowledge: their sexiness - which has nothing to do with sex or box office appeal, but currency and contemporary charge; it is the sense of what gets movies talked about. This is probably what appealed with Dancer in the Dark, and to some extent Von Trier's award is valuable, as his film will indeed be talked about. But it is unfortunate that the big prizewinner is this negligible and faintly embarrassing film, when pictures like Yang's Yi Yi, Andersson's Songs from the Second Floor and James Gray's The Yards will surely outlast it.

fields.headline: Corporate killing
fields.standfirst: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today unveils proposals to make big corporations accountable for deaths that result from gross negligence. We explain the old and new laws
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today unveils proposals to make big corporations accountable for deaths that result from gross negligence. We explain the old and new laws
fields.body:
What is the current law on corporate killing?
The current law states that charges of corporate manslaughter can be brought against named individuals in companies only if the prosecution can prove they have "controlling" responsibility. That has led to executives escaping charges in a string of high-profile disasters ranging from the King's Cross tube station fire that killed 31 people in 1987 to last year's Paddington rail crash. The current legislation hinges on a 1987 court of appeal ruling on the Herald of Free Enterprise disaster, in which more than 190 people died after the ferry's bow doors were left open as it left Zeebrugge harbour.

Why is the government proposing new legislation?
The proposals are intended to make it easier to prosecute company bosses over fatal accidents, in response to mounting accusations that executives from large corporations regularly escape charges after major accidents. Recent attempts to prosecute large companies for manslaughter by gross negligence have failed because it proved impossible to identify named individuals and prove them personally guilty of manslaughter. In the Southall train crash case, the crown prosecution service failed to persuade the courts that the commonlaw offence of manslaughter could be applied to corporations, in this case Great Western Trains. After the Paddington crash, in which 31 people died, the CPS announced it would take no further action.

Have there been successful prosecutions under the present law?
There have been only two successful prosecutions in Britain for corporate manslaughter. The first involved OLL, the activity centre responsible for the deaths of four schoolchildren in a canoeing disaster in Lyme Bay, Dorset. Its managing director was jailed for three years in 1994. In the second case, the managing director of Jackson Transport (Ossett) Ltd was sent to prison for a year in 1996 after the death of an employee who inhaled chemicals.

How far would the new law go?
For the first time directors of rail and shipping companies could be convicted if it is shown that transport disasters are the direct result of corporate conduct of a standard far below what can reasonably be expected. Whereas the present law requires proof that a director or other "senior controlling" officer was grossly negligent, in future it will be enough to show that there was a management failure for a company to be held responsible, even if the immediate cause of the deaths was an act of an individual member of staff.

What are the limitations of the new law?
The new offences will be limited to areas where the English courts have jurisdiction and relatives of those who die will be able to bring private prosecutions.

How does Britain compare to the US?
Under US corporate manslaughter laws people get sent to prison, companies get put out of business and juries award massive punitive damages. Companies and executives can face fines of millions of dollars in addition to compensation claims. In the UK companies currently face only a fine for breaching safety regulations. After the Southall rail crash, Great Western Trains was fined £1.5m - a tiny fraction of the company's profits.

Transport companies face new law of corporate killing

fields.headline: Fish
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about man's other best friend on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about man's other best friend on the net
fields.body:
1. Evolution is in danger of going into reverse unless people eat more oily fish, a nutritionist claimed today.

2. Salmon, trout and other fish such as herring and sardine are essential brain food according to Professor Michael Crawford, and rising rates of mental illness and depression maybe linked to the fact that we eat less of them.

3. He says that the omega-3 fatty acids found in oily fish in the lakes of east Africa gave our ancestors the celebral boost they needed to become wise Homo sapiens.

4. It is worrying news then that according to the British Trout Association, the average Brit eats 145.89g of fish a week compared with 282.15 in 1948.

5. To be fair, there are other theories: some say that language and communication expanded our brains.

6. Nevertheless, the department of health recommends that people eat one to two portions of oil-rich fish a week for more prosaic reasons.

7. Oily fish may decrease the risk of heart disease and increase fat tolerance. Cod liver oil itself can prevent arthritis.

8. As with all foodstuffs, there are health scares. Last year, government experts warned that high levels of PCBs and dioxins (both harmful toxins) had been found in oily fish sold in London's Billingsgate market and Aberdeen.

9. Fish evolved 530m years ago in the Cambrian explosion - an unparalleled period of change on earth.

10. Today, their stocks are in decline the world over.

webTitle: Plunge in profits for Britain's 'flagship' companies

fields.headline: Plunge in profits for Britain's 'flagship' companies
fields.standfirst: Annual pre-tax figures give BA and M&S cause for concern
fields.trailText: British Airways and ailing retailer Marks & Spencer have both revealed sharp falls in their profits today.
fields.body:
British Airways and ailing retailer Marks & Spencer have both revealed sharp falls in their profits today.

The airline reported a 98 per cent plunge in its annual pre-tax profit, which this year was £5m, compared with last year's £225m. However, this year's figures include £249m in one-off gains from selling parts of its business and, excluding this windfall, BA made a loss for the first time since it was privatised in 1987. It blamed the fall on steeper fuel bills, the strong pound and corporate restructuring.

M&S saw its profits over the same period - the 12 months to the end of March - fall to £417.5m, down from £546.1m. The shareholders' dividend was also cut for the first time, from 14.4p to 9p per share.

Both companies have recently appointed new chief executives in an attempt to turn their fortunes around. BA enlisted Rod Eddington just over a month ago to replace Bob Ayling. Mr Eddington, previously at Australian airline Ansett, said he had been "impressed" by the enthusiasm and determination of BA's staff, customers and investors and said the airline would be "developing frequency, network and customer service" in an attempt to win back customers.

Meanwhile, newly-installed chairman Luc Vandevelde was equally sanguine about M&S's results. "After three months in the job, I am convinced that M&S will have a future as successful as its past," he told shareholders. Mr Vandevelde described the dividend cut as "essential" if the company wanted to maintain its investment capacity, saving the company £140m.

Last year, sales fell by 7.2% despite a small increase in food purchases. However, in the eight weeks since the end of the financial year, home furnishing sales had increased by 35.6% and overall sales were up 2.1%. The City was cheered by the news and shares in M&S rose 10% to 242p in the first hour of trading.

M&S spent £63.3m last year on rebranding and restructuring its business, abandoning the St Michael label and adding mobile phones and baby clothing to its range. The company is recruiting another 4000 staff and 178 stores have been refurbished. Cost-cutting measures have included the decision to source more products from outside Britain and redundancies among middle-management.

The GMB union, which represents many M&S suppliers, said the profits should be used to help some of the 50,000 textile workers made redundant since 1990 by firms that had supplied M&S. "Now is the time for M&S to cough up what it owes. We want to see some of these massive profits used to help out redundant workers and get them back on their feet."

fields.headline: The rules
fields.trailText: 1. Entry into the competition implies acceptance of these rules.
fields.body:
1. Entry into the competition implies acceptance of these rules.

2. Everyone is eligible to enter except employees and close associates of John Wisden and Co., Wisden Cricket Magazines, John Brown Publishing, MMC Ltd and their close relatives.

3. No more than one entry per person. Each entry from a UK address must be accompanied by a cheque for £2.50, payable to "Wisden". Each entry from overseas must include five international reply coupons. Families and friends may send entries in the same envelope, but each entry must be accompanied by the £2.50 entry fee. Forms received without the entry fee will be discarded.

4. All entries must be received by close of business on Friday, May 12, 2000. Entries once received cannot be altered. Proof of posting does not constitute proof of delivery. However, competitors will receive through the post a copy of their entry, as recorded on our computer, and a unique PIN number. Competitors are advised to retain a record of their answers and to check them against the answers we have recorded. An entry will be changed in the event of an error on our part. Otherwise, the original answer as written on the entry form must stand. If there is an error or if you have not received your copy, write to the address below. Your letter MUST be received by close of business on June 30, 2000, or it will not be considered under any circumstances.

5. All entries and appeals must be posted to Reality Cricket, Octagon House, White Hart Meadows, Ripley, Surrey GU23 6HR. No phone or fax enquiries can be handled.

6. Entries must be on the official form. Photocopies are acceptable, provided the answers are clearly legible. Further entry forms are also obtainable by sending an SAE to the above address - but please remember only one entry is allowed per person. All invalid or incomplete entries will be discarded without notification.

7. There is no cash alternative to the prizes. Prizes will be as stated, and if winners are unable to take up the prize no alternative will be offered. In order to be eligible for a prize, entrants aged under 16 must have their entry form signed by a parent or guardian. In the event of a tie for the overall prize, those involved will be notified and Wisden will set a tiebreak question or questions until a winner emerges. In the event of a tie for the monthly prizes, the entrant with the highest overall standing will be the winner. If there is still a tie, the entrant closest to the answer to Question 6, 12, 23, or 36 (whichever is relevant) will be the winner.

8. Dates and venues are given for guidance only. The questions remain valid if the same match is played at another time or place before the end of the 2000 season.

9. Where alternative answers are suggested, entrants must choose one of these options. Other answers (e.g. a no-result in a one-day match) will be marked as wrong. If a match does not take place, or if a one-day match where a result is requested does not finish, the question will be treated as void. In questions involving individuals, anyone not taking part in the match will be treated as a wrong answer.

10. If two answers are equally correct, dead-heat rules apply, e.g. if a match is tied, those predicting a draw will be marked wrong and those predicting a win for either side will get half the available points. Ties in other questions will be treated similarly. However, decimal places will be excluded and rounded down to the nearest whole number (e.g. if there is a tie between three of the players in question 15, all those who predicted any one of the three will receive three points).

11. Competitors are responsible for ensuring that their entries are clear and unambiguous. Answers which cannot be read clearly will be treated as wrong.

12. The decision of the editor-in-chief of John Wisden & Co. Ltd is final in all cases. Rulings to cover unforeseen eventualities will be made by Wisden if necessary.

Return to Phase One

webTitle: Walking a tightrope to great acting

fields.headline: Walking a tightrope to great acting
fields.standfirst: Beneath Gielgud's style and splendour lay a radical vision that changed the theatre's trajectory
fields.trailText: Beneath Gielgud's style and splendour lay a radical vision that changed the theatre's trajectory, writes Michael Billington
fields.body:
Everyone acknowledges John Gielgud was a great actor. But his contribution to modern British theatre has been seriously underrated. As a producer, he was a radical visionary who, long before the era of subsidy, saw the need for semi-permanent classical companies.

And as an actor, although his reputation was for vocal splendour and stylish conservatism, he allied himself with adventurous directors such as Peter Brook and Alain Resnais and with living writers such as Harold Pinter, Edward Bond, Alan Bennett and David Storey. Even though he once turned down Endgame, it seems fitting that his final job, completed only a month ago, was a film of Beckett's Catastrophe directed by David Mamet.

But Gielgud's greatest legacy was his now largely forgotten work as an actor-manager in the 1930s and 1940s. At a time when West End theatre was relentlessly frivolous and ephemeral, Gielgud had the vision and foresight to create classical companies. At the New Theatre in 1935, where he and Olivier famously alternated as Romeo and Mercutio, at the Queen's Theatre in 1937-8 and at the Haymarket in 1944, he laid the foundations for post-war British theatre.

Gielgud presented a classical repertory comprising Shakespeare, Congreve, Sheridan and Chekhov. He engaged the design team of Motley to give the productions visual coherence. And he surrounded himself with the rising generation of actors, including Peggy Ashcroft, Alec Guinness, George Devine, Anthony Quayle, and Glen Byam Shaw. Significantly, Devine went on to found the English Stage Company in 1956 and Quayle and Byam Shaw to revolutionise standards at Stratford in the 1950s.

But it was Gielgud who erected a signpost to the future: one that led to the founding of the RSC and the National Theatre. As "Percy" Harris, part of the Motley design team who herself died only a week ago, once told me: "I think he single-handedly put English theatre back on the map. Larry [Olivier] gets all the credit and John doesn't, which I think is a sign of John's innate modesty."

Gielgud and Olivier were, of course, legendary opposites both as actors and as men. As Kenneth Tynan once wrote: "Between good and great acting is fixed an inexorable gulf which may be crossed only by the elect whose visas are in order. Gielgud, seizing a parasol, crosses by tightrope; Olivier polevaults over, hair-raisingly, in a single animal leap." That accurately captures Gielgud's lightness and grace as opposed to Olivier's muscular athleticism. But although the two men were temperamental and stylistic opposites there was, on Gielgud's side at least, no personal animosity.

It was he who gave Olivier his big classical break as Romeo and Mercutio in 1935. And it was Gielgud who donated the sword once used by Kean as Richard III to Olivier to mark the latter's conquest of the role. But although Gielgud was always seen as the high priest of British acting and Olivier as the heretical pathfinder, I believe that does Gielgud a grave disservice. His willingness to take hair-raising risks was astonishing.

Peter Brook, who worked closely with Gielgud at Stratford in the 1950s, talks of his "unique and endlessly inventive mind, always open to change". Gielgud's Stratford Lear was also the tortured centre of a radically experimental production with Oriental designs by the Japanese-American sculptor, Isamu Noguchi. And even though Gielgud initially remained aloof from the new movement in British drama, he soon joined what he could not beat. He was unforgettable at the Royal Court as a lachrymose asylum inmate in David Storey's Home, as a self-parodying theatrical knight in Charles Wood's Veterans, and as a despairing, isolated Shakespeare in Edward Bond's Bingo.

But it was his famous performance as the demob-suited, sandal-shoed Spooner in Pinter's No Man's Land at the National that crowned his work in modern drama.

If, as David Hare always claims, acting is a judgment of character, Gielgud's career tells us a lot about the man: the quicksilver mind, the questing intelligence, the endless curiosity. And all those qualities were confirmed by his remarkable work in his later years in film and television: his raging, dying writer in Resnais's Providence, his acidulous patriarch in Brideshead Revisited, his supercilious valet in Arthur.

But my abiding impression of Gielgud was of his irrepressible youthfulness. He would talk, if pressed, about the past. But his racing mind was more interested in the present and future: he never ceased dreaming of making a movie of The Tempest, directed by Ingmar Bergman, though in the end he had to settle for Peter Greenaway's Prospero's Books.

Gielgud was often seen as the aristocratic figurehead of British acting embodying traditional values: in my view his greatness, as both actor and manager, lay in his radically restless temperament, his visionary belief in companies, and his astonishing ability to recreate himself from one generation to the next.

Pinnacles of his art

King Lear (Stratford-on-Avon 1955) Gielgud once claimed that Isamu Noguchi's experimental Japanese costumes killed the cast's efforts to act in them. Not so: Lear's tyranny, madness and climactic pathos were superbly captured by that infinitely pliable voice.

The Tempest (Stratford-on-Avon 1957) A classic example of Gielgud's ability to redefine a role. In place of the usual pontificating Prospero, four times as old as his brother, we got an irascible, moody, half-naked figure who delayed, until the last possible moment, the acccess of benevolence and charity.

fields.bodyText: Everyone acknowledges John Gielgud was a great actor. But his contribution to modern British theatre has been seriously underrated. As a producer, he was a radical visionary who, long before the era of subsidy, saw the need for semi-permanent classical companies. And as an actor, although his reputation was for vocal splendour and stylish conservatism, he allied himself with adventurous directors such as Peter Brook and Alain Resnais and with living writers such as Harold Pinter, Edward Bond, Alan Bennett and David Storey. Even though he once turned down Endgame, it seems fitting that his final job, completed only a month ago, was a film of Beckett's Catastrophe directed by David Mamet. But Gielgud's greatest legacy was his now largely forgotten work as an actor-manager in the 1930s and 1940s. At a time when West End theatre was relentlessly frivolous and ephemeral, Gielgud had the vision and foresight to create classical companies. At the New Theatre in 1935, where he and Olivier famously alternated as Romeo and Mercutio, at the Queen's Theatre in 1937-8 and at the Haymarket in 1944, he laid the foundations for post-war British theatre. Gielgud presented a classical repertory comprising Shakespeare, Congreve, Sheridan and Chekhov. He engaged the design team of Motley to give the productions visual coherence. And he surrounded himself with the rising generation of actors, including Peggy Ashcroft, Alec Guinness, George Devine, Anthony Quayle, and Glen Byam Shaw. Significantly, Devine went on to found the English Stage Company in 1956 and Quayle and Byam Shaw to revolutionise standards at Stratford in the 1950s. But it was Gielgud who erected a signpost to the future: one that led to the founding of the RSC and the National Theatre. As "Percy" Harris, part of the Motley design team who herself died only a week ago, once told me: "I think he single-handedly put English theatre back on the map. Larry [Olivier] gets all the credit and John doesn't, which I think is a sign of John's innate modesty." Gielgud and Olivier were, of course, legendary opposites both as actors and as men. As Kenneth Tynan once wrote: "Between good and great acting is fixed an inexorable gulf which may be crossed only by the elect whose visas are in order. Gielgud, seizing a parasol, crosses by tightrope; Olivier polevaults over, hair-raisingly, in a single animal leap." That accurately captures Gielgud's lightness and grace as opposed to Olivier's muscular athleticism. But although the two men were temperamental and stylistic opposites there was, on Gielgud's side at least, no personal animosity. It was he who gave Olivier his big classical break as Romeo and Mercutio in 1935. And it was Gielgud who donated the sword once used by Kean as Richard III to Olivier to mark the latter's conquest of the role. But although Gielgud was always seen as the high priest of British acting and Olivier as the heretical pathfinder, I believe that does Gielgud a grave disservice. His willingness to take hair-raising risks was astonishing. Peter Brook, who worked closely with Gielgud at Stratford in the 1950s, talks of his "unique and endlessly inventive mind, always open to change". Gielgud's Stratford Lear was also the tortured centre of a radically experimental production with Oriental designs by the Japanese-American sculptor, Isamu Noguchi. And even though Gielgud initially remained aloof from the new movement in British drama, he soon joined what he could not beat. He was unforgettable at the Royal Court as a lachrymose asylum inmate in David Storey's Home, as a self-parodying theatrical knight in Charles Wood's Veterans, and as a despairing, isolated Shakespeare in Edward Bond's Bingo. But it was his famous performance as the demob-suited, sandal-shoed Spooner in Pinter's No Man's Land at the National that crowned his work in modern drama. If, as David Hare always claims, acting is a judgment of character, Gielgud's career tells us a lot about the man: the quicksilver mind, the questing intelligence, the endless curiosity. And all those qualities were confirmed by his remarkable work in his later years in film and television: his raging, dying writer in Resnais's Providence, his acidulous patriarch in Brideshead Revisited, his supercilious valet in Arthur. But his racing mind was more interested in the present and future: he never ceased dreaming of making a movie of The Tempest, directed by Ingmar Bergman, though in the end he had to settle for Peter Greenaway's Prospero's Books. Gielgud was often seen as the aristocratic figurehead of British acting embodying traditional values: in my view his greatness, as both actor and manager, lay in his radically restless temperament, his visionary belief in companies, and his astonishing ability to recreate himself from one generation to the next. fields.headline: The end of Lebanon's occupation
fields.standfirst: Beyond the mayhem caused by the withdrawal of the Israeli army from southern Lebanon, former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown sees Israel's move as key to securing peace in the region
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 1pm: Beyond the mayhem caused by the withdrawal of the Israeli army from southern Lebanon, former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown sees Israel's move as key to securing peace in the region
fields.body:
In military terms, one man's rout is another man's planned withdrawal. The Israelis would have us believe that what is happening in south Lebanon is the latter; a disciplined and orderly movement of troops to prepared positions.

And so it is, so far as the Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) are concerned. Their disciplined, well-trained units are following the orders of their government as well as their commanders. They have homes to go to in their own country.

The same cannot be said of the Lebanese militias and the civilian population of the bloodstained region. They have been plunged into a new and terrifying phase of violent uncertainty.

A human wave is flowing south. Jubilant Lebanese, refugees in their own land, are marching back to their long-abandoned homes in the crumbling occupation zone. Ahead of them, soldiers of the South Lebanese Army (SLA), Israel's client militia, are abandoning their weapons and positions, and clamouring to seek refuge over the border in Galilee.

Israelis too are on the move, pouring south from the rocket-threatened border settlements. Those left in towns like Qiryat Sh'mona are obliged to take to their bunkers at night, as the guerrillas of Hizbullah and Amal close in on the frontier.

The Israeli government and top army brass are making out that they could see this all along; that none of it is surprising. But they must be horrified by the sudden evaporation of the SLA, and its implications.

The Lebanese government must be rattled too. Its fragile army is in no fit state to fill the vacuum in south Lebanon. Nor is the United Nations an option: the UN Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) has nearly 5,000 troops in the region, but no mandate to do more than observe the unfolding drama.

The danger is that in the first flush of triumph, the wild men of Hizbullah, Amal or the various Palestinian guerrilla groups will chance their arm on a rocket strike into Israel. That would certainly provoke massive retaliation and more mayhem.

Israel had hoped that the SLA would hold its ground in the short term, before handing over control to the Beirut government. That hope is now shattered. But it is hard to imagine that the Israelis had no back-up strategy. Their withdrawal, after all, has been telegraphed for the best part of a year.

The pullout is wildly popular in Israel, which long ago wearied of the 22-year occupation. South Lebanon was supposed to be a "security zone". In reality, it was nothing of the kind. IDF conscripts have been killed at the rate of more than 20 a year there, and the constant flaring of guerrilla warfare has led to massively expensive retaliatory raids and air strikes.

Popular it may be, but Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak - a former army chief - is not a man who takes strategic decisions in isolation. Now that his hopes of a dignified and orderly withdrawal have disintegrated, he must be looking elsewhere. Almost certainly, to Damascus.

Israel's evacuation from Lebanon is not just a tactical recognition that the occupation was militarily useless, as well as morally outrageous. It is part of Barak's great scheme to make peace with Syria, and thus complete the so-called circle of peace.

Israel has already signed treaties with Egypt and Jordan. Another one with Syria would secure the Zionist state's external borders, and allow the government to dictate a final settlement with the Palestinians in their pathetic enclaves in Gaza and the occupied West Bank.

There is little doubt that Damascus, which has long believed Lebanon to be part of Greater Syria, has the muscle to impose order in the evacuated occupation zone - if Israel allows it to. Hizbullah is armed and supplied largely by Iran, but those supplies only reach it courtesy of the Syrians.

In the days and weeks ahead, Syrian diplomatic and military moves will be closely monitored by Middle East watchers. If Damascus orders the pacification of south Lebanon - and thus ensures the security of Israel's northern border - the quid pro quo could well be an Israeli-Syrian peace pact.

That will certainly involve an even more momentous Israeli withdrawal, from all or most of the Golan Heights, captured in the Six-Day War of 1967. If that happens, the Middle East peace process will take a giant step forward. The almost certain losers, predictably, will be the Palestinians.

fields.trailText: "He was a wonderul man and I was very privileged that he was in my play No Man's Land. It leaves a great gap." Harold Pinter, writer and actor

"He was a wonderul man and I was very privileged that he was in my play No Man's Land. It leaves a great gap." Harold Pinter, writer and actor

"John Gielgud to me was mercury - quicksilver in his wit, always ahead of the audience, always reassessing his performance." Sir Peter Hall, theatre director

"He was a great actor. It is a great loss, it feels like the end of an era. We will all remember him with love, admiration and gratitude." Joan Plowright, actor

fields.headline: Bob Ayling's fall from grace
fields.standfirst: Transport editor Keith Harper looks at the latest twist in the former dome chief's career
fields.trailText:
Tuesday, 11.30am: Transport editor Keith Harper looks at the latest twist in the former dome chief's career.
Special report
fields.body:
Bob Ayling's fall from grace has been the fastest and most ignominious of any senior executive in recent business history. Until two months ago, he was still heading British Airways, somewhat precariously it must be admitted, but it seemed he had survived several crises and been given the benefit of the doubt by his reluctant board.

But within 24 hours of opening the London Eye, his only success story, he was peremptorily sacked. Now, as the Millennium Dome begins to sink into the waters of the Thames, Tony Blair's favourite businessman has been dealt another body blow and sacked as chairman of the Millennium Dome's operating company.

It could not have happened to a nicer guy, though nice guys are probably not very good at running multimillion pound businesses and making them successful. Ayling did not see this last dagger being drawn, even at the last minute. A few days ago, he was at the dome generously hosting a lunch as chairman of the organisation, blythely telling his audience that the dome was one of the most popular attractions in the world and that it was going from strength to strength. Had he any inkling of what was in store, he would almost certainly have said nothing.

Ticking off the Munros, those Scottish mountains which are higher than 3,000ft, and buying a new boat have became his main preoccupations since his enforced redundancy in March, from which he will collect more than £1m as a final payoff because he was on a rolling two-year contract.

Ayling's problem is that he has not been tough enough. He admits that he inherited BA post-privatisation when it was still partly behaving like a nationalised company. He would like to have cut a larger swath through BA but drew back from the dastardly deed. Now his successor, the Australian Bob Eddington, will have to carry through considerable pruning of staff, whose numbers have expanded excessively since privatisation.

At the dome, Mr Ayling must be regarded as the sacrificial victim. A very public Londoner, he was proud to do the job but it was a titular appointment. He ran a grandiose project designed by the Conservatives and then taken over enthusiastically by the prime minister. Ayling might have cavilled at the lack of coherent ideas which have dogged the project, but it was effectively in the hands of ministers and out of his.

Ayling is the kind of person who remains unruffled by events around him. If a house collapsed on him he would still be able to get up, dust himself down and walk away. But don't expect him to turn up running a business again. Chairman of the Countryside Commission or the National Trust perhaps.

webTitle: At last: female voices at the Test match

fields.headline: At last: female voices at the Test match
fields.trailText: There is a simple cricketing equation. Cricket (or the cricket which the media cares about) equals men in whites, which in turn equals men talking about men in whites.
fields.body:
There is a simple cricketing equation. Cricket (or the cricket which the media cares about) equals men in whites, which in turn equals men talking about men in whites.

But this year - goddammit, there goes the chance for a good rant - that equation doesn't really work any more. Women are suddenly audible both on TV and radio cricket programmes. We're not talking parity here - though we can assume financial equality in 2000, can't we? - but the female cricketing voice is no longer extraordinary, and nor is it just that of the long-suffering Rachael Heyhoe-Flint.

Eleanor Oldroyd, an experienced radio broadcaster, is the most high-profile newcomer. She made her Test Match Special debut during the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's last week.

She is a roving reporter providing the bits of information, like pitch reports, and interviews with umpires, that TV viewers have had access to for years. It was a dream start for Oldroyd, despite the fact that she was caught out in a thunderstorm wearing headphones which had a radio aerial sticking out of them. "I had to pinch myself once or twice to make sure that I really was at Lord's working on TMS, a programme that I've lived with for so many years," she says. "It is great to know that you are part of an institution, but an institution that is changing."

She isn't the only woman who will be gateauing with Aggers and Blowers this summer. Donna Symmonds, who made her TMS debut on the England tour of the Caribbean in 1997-98 will rejoin the team for the West Indian summer, and Karen Smithies, England's World Cup-winning captain has also been signed up. And if you get your cricket-fix over the internet you can hear journalist Kate Laven interview players on the ECB's website.

TV, too, is changing. Sybil Ruscoe, who made her debut for Channel 4 last season, is back again but in a different role. She has become Mark Nicholas's co-presenter on C4's Cricket Roadshow, shown every Saturday morning, and already looks more relaxed than she did in her ground-breaking, but hybrid, roving-reporter role of last year.

As yet, no woman has done ball-by-ball TV commentary for the men's game though Sarah Potter, the ex-England international and correspondent for The Times, has covered England women's matches for Sky. Sky would be wise to get her on board for their one live Test of the summer, England v Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge, because in the present climate their cricket coverage, unlike their football, looks very male.

What is definitely missing from any cricket coverage on television is what the less politically correct might call an old boiler: a commentator who is more Billie Jean-King than Billie Piper. It would be nice if we were able to see a competent, funny, intelligent but only average-looking woman tell us what was going on at a Test. But that's a different battle altogether.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every Tuesday.

fields.headline: Israel speeds up Lebanon retreat
fields.standfirst: Barak brings forward 'humiliating' withdrawal of troops as Hizbullah guerrillas move in to south Lebanon
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak said today that his country's withdrawal from south Lebanon could be completed within 10 days in what amounts to a humiliating retreat for Israeli forces after a 22-year occupation.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak said today that his country's withdrawal from south Lebanon could be completed within 10 days in what amounts to a humiliating retreat for Israeli forces after a 22-year occupation.

After an emergency meeting of his security cabinet last night, Mr Barak decided to speed up the withdrawal - bringing it forward more than a month ahead of Israel's self-imposed deadline - as Hizbullah guerrillas moved into villages abandoned by the South Lebanese Army,

As they evacuated the south Lebanon territories occupied by Israel since 1978, homeward-bound Israeli soldiers honked the horns of jeeps, waved brigade banners and kissed Israeli soil after crossing the frontier.

Hundreds of Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen and their families, fleeing from the advancing Hizbullah, were given refuge in a tent camp on the Sea of Galilee. Refugees carrying small bags clambered off Israeli buses and were taken to the large white tents which had housed pilgrims accompanying Pope John Paul II earlier this spring.

Israel stepped up its withdrawal, originally scheduled for completion by July 7, after the abrupt disintegration of the South Lebanon Army. Hizbullah took over villages and positions abandoned by the SLA, seizing control of about a quarter of the buffer zone Israel set up in 1985, after a three-year occupation of larger parts of Lebanon. In chaotic fighting yesterday, several Lebanese civilians were killed and Israelis living in border towns were ordered to go into underground bomb shelters.

In today's fighting, a driver working with a BBC crew covering the Israeli withdrawal was hit by artillery fire and is believed to have been killed. A cameraman with BBC correspondent Jeremy Bowen said the driver, Abed Takoush, had been caught in the car which was engulfed in flames.

Many border residents and political commentators strongly criticised the government, saying it had mishandled the withdrawal and had not foreseen the collapse of the SLA. "Humiliation permeates the air," wrote commentator Hemi Shalev in the Maariv daily newspaper. "Our allies are toppling and begging for help. The enemy is celebrating in the main streets and along the border, and the Israeli Defence Forces are looking for escape routes."

Ilana Aderi, 58, a Kiryat Shemona resident, said she was fed up with living with the threat of guerrilla shellings. "This whole city should be evacuated and turned into an army base," she said.

Mr Barak gave extensive radio interviews today to reassure a confused public. "When we solve the problem from its roots - the withdrawal of the army from Lebanon will take a few days, maybe a week or maybe 10 days - we should not be alarmed," he said, confirming for the first time that the withdrawal would be moved up considerably. Israel was in the decisive stage, and needed its civilians to remain steadfast, he said, adding that "the ongoing tragedy" of Israel's military presence in Lebanon had reached its end and the buffer zone no longer has a purpose.

But the leader of Hizbullah guerrillas said his men would continue their war against Israel if it kept troops in the disputed Shebaa Farms area and refused to release all Lebanese prisoners.

"If the Israelis stay in Shebaa Farms and keeps any Lebanese prisoner...we at Hizbullah will deal with the withdrawal as if it did not happen, and we have to fight to liberate (our country)," Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah said.

Israel has indicated it will not withdraw from the farms, at the foot of the Golan Heights, saying the land is Syrian and not Lebanese.

Syria, which has its own dispute with Israel over the Golan Heights, gloated over Israel's reversal. A Syrian official said: "Israel's accelerated withdrawal from south Lebanon proves that its occupation of the area during the last 22 years was a total failure and a disaster (for Israel). Israel will achieve no gains out of its occupation of any Arab lands. It will not enjoy any security until it ends its occupation of Arab lands."
