fields.headline: Adiós al guerrero
fields.standfirst: The body of a black warrior is being returned to Africa after long years on show in Spain. Some people want him to stay
fields.trailText: The body of a black warrior is being returned to Africa after long years on show in Spain. Some people want him to stay
fields.body:
En las próximas semanas un avión devolverá a Africa el cuerpo disecado de un guerrero negro. Durante casi cien años ha estado en una vitrina del Museo Darder de Banyoles (Girona). En 1991 Alphonse Arcelin, un médico de Haití residente en España, pidió que el guerrero fuera devuelto a Africa. Denunció que su cuerpo estaba expuesto en el museo como si fuera un animal exótico. Desde entonces la polémica no ha cesado. Desde 1997 el guerrero espera en el almacén del museo una decisión sobre su futuro. Finalmente su destino será Botswana.

El cuerpo del bosquimano fue extraído de su tumba y disecado la misma noche de su entierro. Parece ser el cadáver de un guerrero de la tribu bosquimana, procedente de una zona hoy situada al norte de Sudáfrica. Se expuso en París a partir de 1831 y el doctor Darder lo compró en 1916.

Crees que el cuerpo disecado del guerrero bosquimano debería volver a la vitrina del Museo Darder de Banyoles? Por qué?

Dani Planes (vive en Banyoles y tiene13 años): Sí. El bosquimano hace muchos años que está en Banyoles y debería quedarse aquí. Debería volver a la vitrina. Darder lo compró para su colección y ahora nos lo quieren quitar. Creen que va contra las personas negras. Nos preguntan por qué no tenemos personas blancas disecadas en el museo. Pero entonces los museos británicos también deberían devolver sus momias a Egipto.

Alba Vilaseca (vive en Banyoles y tiene14 años): No. No lo devolvería a la vitrina del museo. Desde que empezó la polémica mucha gente viene a Banyoles sólo para ver al bosquimano. Hacían cola en la calle para entrar al museo. Se convirtió en un atractivo turístico y Banyoles tiene muchos más atractivos. Por ejemplo, el lago es más importante. El bosquimano quizás tenía antes interés cultural y científico, pero ahora no.

Ana Archer (vive en Barcelona y tiene 18 años): No. Tener una persona disecada en una vitrina no tiene interés ni cultural, ni científico ni museístico. Ni ahora ni nunca. Es una situación muy grave.

Crees que una persona de raza negra puede ofenderse al ver al bosquimano expuesto?

Dani: Sí, creo que se puede ofender.

Alba: Sí, quizás sí. Es como si nosotros vamos a Africa y vemos a una persona de raza blanca disecada. Queda mal y crea mal ambi ente. Ahora en Banyoles viven bastantes personas de raza negra. Los que yo conozco no se pronuncian sobre el tema. Dicen que nos las arreglemos nosotros.

Ana: Depende de la persona. Yo no lo he visto. En todo caso si fuera un blanco no estaría en una vitrina. Quizás es una actitud racista por parte de algunos.

La decisión final del Ayuntamiento de Banyoles es devolverlo a Botswana. Qué piensas de esta decisión?

Alba: Me parece bien. Lo mejor es devolverlo a su pueblo. Y sino que siga en el almacén. En todo caso no volver a exponerlo, ni en Banyoles ni en Botswana. Espero que allí lo entierren o lo quemen, por ejemplo.

Dani: No me gusta. Allí lo quemarán o harán algo raro. Aquí no va contra nadie, no está en el museo para ofender a nadie.

Ana: Lo mejor es que vuelva a Botswana. Pero ahora lo peor ya está hecho. El pobre hombre ya está disecado y ha estado expuesto.

Crees que otros museos europeos que tienen restos humanos expoliados deberían también devolverlos a su país?

Dani: No, excepto si tienen muchísimo valor y su país los reclama.

Alba: Sólo si sus países insisten mucho en reclamarlos. Otros países tienen momias egipcias. Yo las devolvería si hay polémica sobre el tema. Una persona muerta no debería ser el atractivo de un museo. De todos modos el bosquimano disecado y las momias egipcias son casos distintos. En las momias la persona está tapada y no se reconoce. Al negro de Banyoles se reconocen las facciones y se ve todo el cuerpo.

Ana: Aunque el mal ya está hecho al menos no deberían estar expuestos. Lo mejor es devolverlos, aunque el mal ya no tiene solución.

Y con otros bienes expoliados?

Dani: Sólo si son muy valiosos. Si no no acabaríamos nunca de devolver objetos de un país para otro. Todos los museos tienen cosas de otros sitios. Si no los museos no existirían. Si vas a un museo es para ver cosas diferentes. Y así no tienes que viajar para aprender cosas de otros sitios.

Alba: Devolverlos a su país. Ahora la gente viaja más que antes. Quien quiera verlos que vaya a su país de origen. Es más real ver las cosas en su país.

Ana: Deberían ser devueltos a su país. Forma parte de su cultura y de su historia.

el attractivo attraction

el bosquimano bushman

webTitle: 23 May: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 23 May: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText:
In brief and the latest casting news

Dana Carvey sues surgeon, Drew Barrymore's mum makes more mischief, Perry in Porsche palaver, and Katie Holmes and David Cronenberg on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Wayne's World star Dana Carvey is suing LA surgeon Elias Hanna for allegedly botching the heart operation that the actor underwent in March 1998. It is alleged that Hanna operated to unblock a healthy artery and that Carvey required a subsequent angioplasty to clear the affected vein. Upon learning of the mistake, Carvey says he was miserable. "I can remember lying on my bed sobbing," he told the jury. The actor is also alleging that he missed months of lucrative work as a result of the error.

 One week after she was arrested for criminal mischief and possession of an unlicensed hand-gun, Jaid Barrymore is causing still more headaches for her estranged daughter Drew. The 53-year-old mum is currently touting a tell-all memoir, entitled Confidential, around the publishers of America. According to the New York Daily News, the book lists Jaid's ex-lovers (which include Jim Morrison and Kiefer Sutherland, for those interested) and claims that Warren Beatty once demanded a mother-daughter threesome with both Jaid and Drew. "It's Jaid's attempt to set the record straight," says Barrymore's agent Sheree Bykofsky of the book. Oh, well that's all right then.

 Matthew Perry ploughed his bottle-green Porsche into a Beverly Hills house-front over the weekend, at a time when concerned well-wishers were still assuming that the Friends' star was in hospital suffering from a particularly virulent strain of flu. Perry was admitted at the start of the month, and had reportedly been there ever since. Police investigating the accident pointed out that the actor - currently doing the rounds in The Whole Nine Yards - was not under the influence of drugs or alcohol.

Casting couch

 Katie Holmes is in talks to star as Rene Russo's daughter in Big Trouble, a drama backed by Disney and based on the bestseller by newspaper columnist Dave Barry. Best known as James Van der Beek's muckle-mouthed co-star in TV's Dawson's Creek, Holmes made a rewarding foray into cinema last year in acclaimed comedy-thriller Go.

 Lofty director David Cronenberg is to go determinedly trashy when he takes a role in the tenth instalment of the Friday 13th saga. Entitled Jason X, the film will be set in the year 2455 and will star the Crash director as a bespectacled professor who uncovers and thaws out a frozen 20th-century psychopath. Cronenberg made the most of a vibrant support slot as a saintly gas-board worker in last year's elegiac Last Night, but Jason X provides an altogether less taxing role. "I basically play a stupid doctor who deserves to die," Cronenberg told the Hollywood Reporter, at once giving away the film's denouement and writing off all chance of an Oscar nomination.

webTitle: Pacino down and out in Beverly Hills project

fields.headline: Pacino down and out in Beverly Hills project
fields.trailText: Al Pacino is in final negotiations to play a skid-row movie producer in the new film by writer-director Andrew Niccol. With a working title of The Hollywood Project, the film is being backed by a joint venture between New Line Cinema and Jersey Films, which is run by Danny DeVito.
fields.body:
Al Pacino is in final negotiations to play a skid-row movie producer in the new film by writer-director Andrew Niccol. With a working title of The Hollywood Project, the film is being backed by a joint venture between New Line Cinema and Jersey Films, which is run by Danny DeVito.

The exact content remains tightly under wraps, but industry insiders have described it as a cool dissection of the Hollywood dream factory that is a blend between Robert Altman's The Player and the Nathanael West novel The Day of the Locust.

New Zealand born Niccol's only previous writing-directing offering was the 1997 genetics-themed sci-fi drama Gattaca, starring Uma Thurman, Ethan Hawke and Jude Law, though he won plaudits for his script for The Truman Show, directed by Peter Weir.

The 35-year-old film-maker's next project had been widely expected to be a directing stint on the fish-out-of-water drama River Road, from his own script, but the film has now been shelved in favour of The Hollywood Project. Assuming Pacino confirms his involvement, the film is likely to be put on a fast track with a view to commence shooting before the end of the summer.

fields.headline: They think it's Moldova...
fields.standfirst:
He'd already hitchhiked around Ireland with a fridge for a
£100 bet, so why not take on the entire Moldova national
football team at tennis? Tony Hawks took up the challenge
fields.trailText: He'd already hitchhiked around Ireland with a fridge for a £100 bet, so why not take on the entire Moldova national football team at tennis? Tony Hawks took up the challenge
fields.body:
Although to this day he denies it, I maintain that my friend, the writer and comedian Arthur Smith, knew exactly what he was doing. He was fully aware that I had a history of being a sucker for these things. After all, in May 1997 I had hitch-hiked around Ireland with a fridge to win a £100 bet. So, after having argued with me for some time about how good I was at tennis during a boring televised game of football between England and Moldova, I think he felt confident that he'd lure me into it.

"Hawks," he said, "I bet you're not a good enough player to beat the entire Moldovan national football team at tennis, one by one."

I was a fool to have shaken on the bet after having agreed that the loser would have to perform the forfeit of standing stark naked on Balham High Road while singing the Moldovan national anthem. The challenge lay ahead to ensure that it would not be me.

I knew nothing about Moldova, its tennis facilities, its political situation, its visa requirements, its currency, its language, its ethnic make-up or whether its people would take kindly to a decadent bourgeois westerner swanning around waving a tennis racket in front of its footballers. All I knew about the place were the names of 11 men, printed on the inside back page of my newspaper: Romanenco, Fistican, Spynu, Testimitanu, Culibaba, Stroenco, Rebeja, Curtianu, Sischin, Miterev and Rogaciov. "Well," I thought, "none of them sound to me like they're any good at tennis."

I flew to Moldova's, which is sandwiched between Romania and Ukraine, and took up lodgings in the capital, Chisinau, with a family of four. I hired an interpreter (who turned out to be the world's biggest pessimist), and quickly learned that Moldovans get on with life's struggle without asking too many questions or displaying too much emotion. Rather naively I had expected that an Englishman turning up with a bizarre quest might create a little interest and perhaps even a modicum of enthusiasm, but this was far from the case.I began turning up at football clubs with my bemused translator Iulian. He would go up to a club official, say something in Russian or Romanian, and I would await his translation of the ensuing rebuff.

These guys just didn't want to know. Their players were too busy training, I was told, to contemplate any games of tennis with any Englishmen, and they seemed unmoved by the consequence of compulsory nudity that their intransigence would necessitate. In fact, it was a full two weeks before I got one Moldovan footballer anywhere near a tennis court, and this was only accomplished after having gained the confidence of a vain football manager by pretending to be a BBC TV sports journalist, keen to make a profile of him and his club.

It was the Monday of my third week before I found myself facing Iurie Miterev across a clay tennis court. I shook hands with the object of my fear, a fine physical specimen wearing a red top and green shorts. He looked unsettlingly eager as he waited at the opposing baseline.

I hit him the first ball. A high, gentle, looping one aimed at his forehand. I watched keenly as he shaped up to it, taking a big and hugely worrying back-swing. This guy was about to strike the ball very hard indeed.

His face, a picture of concentration, was almost grimacing as his racket head made contact with the ball, and... bang!... he hit it clean over the back fence. I let out a huge sigh of relief, while Iulian scurried off to retrieve the ball. Iurie's next attempt was no better. This second shot bounced several times before it reached the net. He needed to find some kind of middle ground between the two shots, but I knew this was something he'd be unlikely to achieve in the course of an afternoon. Thank God.

In the coming days I was to discover that Iurie was no exception to the rule - the rule being that Moldovan footballers are crap at tennis. By the Thursday of my third week I had beaten seven Moldovan footballers and the family with whom I was staying had begun to delight in my success. Despite their initial reticence (or it could have been fear) they had begun to show a keen interest in my exploits and now each victory was greeted with cheers, a new bottle of Moldovan wine and a celebratory meal. Consequently they were quite taken aback when on the Friday I told them the bad news.

"It's all over folks," I said rather sheepishly at the dinner table. "The bet is lost. I've tried everything but no matter what I try I just can't get two of the managers to allow me to play their players. I'm afraid I'm four short and that's that!"

The family looked shocked. As shocked as they'd looked on my arrival when I'd first told them what I was intending to do. I'd been so relentlessly positive throughout my stay that seeing me so resigned to defeat was difficult for them to comprehend. Eyebrows were raised and little shrugs of the shoulders were accompanied by short bursts of Romanian which remained untranslated. The mood was sombre.

"I'm sorry," I said as I got to my feet at the end of the meal.

"It's OK," said Adrian, the eldest son and the most accomplished at English, "I think that it is not your fault."

It probably wasn't, but that didn't make it easier for any of us to bear.

The following morning at breakfast, however, I discovered the family in buoyant mood. The mother had been in a car with the mother in law of one of the national team players, who had mentioned a European championship qualifying game coming up against Northern Ireland in Belfast.Why didn't I play them over there?

"What a fantastic idea!" I cried out, almost overwhelmed. "Thank you so much. Thanks to all of you." And we drank a lot of Moldovan champagne

Four days in Belfast only brought me three more victories but I still needed to beat Marin Spynu, who'd been dropped by the national team and was now playing his football just outside Nazareth in Israel. Somehow it seemed appropriate that my epic struggle should now take on biblical proportions. I do not wish to tell you what happened on a small tennis court just outside Nazareth (for fear of ruining your enjoyment of my splendid book on this subject). Suffice to say that it resulted in a writer and comedian removing all his clothes, standing on a box outside Woolworths on Balham High Road, and singing a sketchy version of the Moldovan national anthem through a megaphone. A crowd of around 70 well-wishers looked on, all of them in paroxysms of laughter. Up until this point I'd had no idea that male nudity could be this universally funny. It was a ludicrous sight and yet, paradoxically, not without dignity. After all, someone was keeping their word here. A bet was being honoured.

So, after having argued with me for some time about how good I was at tennis during a boring televised game of football between England and Moldova, I think he felt confident that he'd lure me into it. I was a fool to have shaken on the bet after having agreed that the loser would have to perform the forfeit of standing stark naked on Balham High Road while singing the Moldovan national anthem. fields.headline: Larry Elliott
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist Larry Elliott was live online on Wednesday 21 March 2000 to respond to questions on the Budget. He explained the consequences of the strong pound and the IR35, and gave his views on the dot.com bubble. This is an edited transcript of the live discussion, but you can click here to read the full debate and have your say.
fields.trailText: Larry Elliott: Before taking specific questions, here's my overall take. The centrepiece of the Budget was obviously the big increase in health spending, triggered by the problems in the NHS this winter. The increases in spending are large and appear to be genuine. They should make a difference to the NHS over the next year. The rest of the budget was quite intricate, with lots of small measures designed to improve the way the economy works - either by stimulating enterprise or by getting people off welfare and into work. Finally, it was quite a political Budget, the first stage of the government's blueprint for re-election next year. The next stage will be further increases in spending in the summer, followed by next year's Budget. Expect bigger tax cuts then to be the starting gun for an election in May/June 2001.

The next stage will be further increases in spending in the summer, followed by next year's Budget. Expect bigger tax cuts then to be the starting gun for an election in May/June 2001.


sgcc2: What's IR35, and why is it so damaging to the self-employed and small businesses?

LE: Unless I've missed something in all the small print, there were no concessions on IR35 in the budget. From April, experts say it will triple the tax burden on self-employed people.

desconocid Yes, in fact, IR35 is a way of overtaxing middle income people while preserving exemptions for the rich (note especially the exemptions for senior partners of "large" accountancy and legal firms). The tone of malice and exultation from the Inland Revenue didn't go down too well either. It seems that people who work are to be taxed heavily while people who just sell other people's work just pay 10% on their profit.

LE: As you say, the rich can always find ways to get round paying tax. It's called tax avoidance, whereas when it's the poor earning a few pounds in the cash economy it's called evasion.

sgcc2 I'm sorry: I don't get why IR35 will triple people's tax burden... How has it changed? <.p>

LE: I'm not an expert on IR35, but as I understand it, self-employed people will be saddled with national insurance payments from April, which will increase the amount of money they hand over to the taxman.


fred5: I find it incredible that we have to start paying tax at such low earnings levels in this country. If dear Gordon really wanted to improve the lot of working people, then why not raise the general tax threshold to something like £10,000 before tax is deducted. This would enable more people to live with a reasonable standard of living without having to rely on the state for benefits to top up the short fall. We are a very wealthy nation, but it seems to me that more and more of our earnings are being taxed either directly or by stealth.

LE: All tax experts say the best way of helping poor people is to take them out of the tax system altogether by raising tax thresholds. That is a more progressive measure than cutting tax rates, which gives disproportionate help to those earning most. Unfortunately, governments of both left and right are now fixated by tax rates. So I agree, raising thresholds would be an excellent idea.


Mpotter: How crucial is the strength of the pound to the good health of the British economy, and how worrying is it that measures to counter it seem to have been left out of the Budget altogether?

LE: Overall, the economy is doing pretty well. The strong pound is good for inflation, because it means the cost of imports into Britain are kept low. But for those parts of the economy that rely on exports - mainly but not exclusively manufacturing - the strong pound is proving to be a real headache. Some companies are operating on quite thin margins, so the 30% increase in the value of the pound makes life very difficult for them.

Brown doesn't believe there is much that he can do about the state of the pound, believing that it is really caused by the unexpected weakness of the euro. He is hoping that the euro will strengthen. Keeping fiscal policy relatively tight should help by taking pressure off the Bank of England to raise rates, but in the end what would really help would be lower interest rates. That is not really on the cards.


DeVise: How much of the NHS cash injection is funded by the 25p on a pack of cigarettes?

LE: The 25 pence on cigs raises £235 million in 2000-01 and £405 million the following year


DeVise: If there is a sudden plunge in dot.com stocks, do you think this will have a knock-on effect on the rest of the economy (given the existing weakness of the manufacturing sector), or will it merely cool off the NASDAQ excesses? It would be interesting, by the way, to know what percentage of the workforce are currently employed in new media and dot.com operations. Do you happen to know?

LE: My belief is that the stock market - and particularly the dot.com sector - is massively over-valued and a bubble waiting to burst. When it does, the impact on the economy could be quite serious unless governments act speedily to prevent knock-on effects to growth. Even in the US, employment in the dot.com sector is very small - only 1-2%.

DeVise: Thanks for those answers, Mr Elliott.


EvitaW: What effect will the Budget 2000 have on possible entrance to EMU and five economic criteria set out by Chancellor Brown, especially with regard to budget surplus, inflation, exchange and interest rates?

LE: On EMU entry: in each of his three previous budgets, Gordon Brown made a point of saying that the UK's public finances were healthy enough to meet the Maastricht convergence criteria for monetary union. He made no such mention this time - an indication that the chancellor is cooling off the idea of a referendum shortly after the election. At the moment, Britain would not meet the five tests laid down by the government in October 1997, which are supposed to test the impact on jobs, investment, the City and whether our economy is in synch with those in euroland. With public opinion hostile the idea, I get the impression that the government will decide that the five tests have not been met.

EvitaW: Thanks... thatÇll give a wholly new flavour to my paper on Labour Gov't and the euro...


TomB3: What definition is being used for "an international bond" in the withholding tax change? When will this be implemented?

LE: On the withholding tax: the definition of an international bond is one that is traded offshore. For example, a eurodollar bond is one that is denominated in dollars but traded in Europe. The City has developed a lucrative market in eurobonds since the 60's and is opposed to EU plans for a 20% levy - the so-called withholding tax - that would affect holders of eurobonds.


LE: I've got to go and write for tomorrow's paper now, but I'll try to round up some of the questions I've not answered. I've no idea why the 5% rate for sanitary products does not come into force until Jan. Perhaps because it is a VAT cut rather than a change in excise duty? All EU countries have two rates of VAT, some have much higher rates than our 17.5%. I wish GB was more honest about redistribution, since analysis by the IFS shows that the biggest gainers from the Budget were people in the poorest tenth of the population. That seems to me a good thing.

The big omission from the budget: action to improve public transport and justice for pensioners.

Thank you.

See you again next year.

webTitle: Parental leave challenge taken to European court

fields.headline: Parental leave challenge taken to European court
fields.trailText: More than 2.5 million working parents excluded from the government's new parental leave scheme face a long wait to learn the outcome of a legal challenge launched on their behalf by the TUC.
fields.body:
More than 2.5 million working parents excluded from the government's new parental leave scheme face a long wait to learn the outcome of a legal challenge launched on their behalf by the TUC.

The high court today referred the case to the European Court of Justice for a ruling on the meaning of part of the European parental leave directive and agreement on which the scheme is based, which could take up to two years.

The high court refused the TUC's plea for an order that, in the meantime, the excluded parents could take leave, even though they might eventually lose the case.

But Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, and Mr Justice Morison urged the European court to deal with the case as a matter of urgency.

They said that if, "as we think", trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers may have acted unlawfully in the way he introduced the scheme, "the sooner this is made clear the better".

The TUC's argument that the government broke European law by excluding 2.7 million employees from the right to take unpaid parental leave was presented last week by Cherie Booth QC in her last court appearance before the birth of her son, Leo.

Under the parental leave regulations, introduced on December 15 last year, parents of children born or adopted on or after that date are entitled to 13 weeks' leave spread over the years up to a child's fifth birthday.

The prime minister's wife, seeking judicial review in a case against Mr Byers, contended that the cut-off date wrongly shut out parents of children under five born before December 15.

Today the TUC was given leave to appeal against the judges' refusal to grant an interim order allowing the parents to take leave while Europe decides.

The court heard that if the European court took two years to make a ruling, around one million of the parents would have lost their leave entitlement forever because their children would by then be more than five.

TUC general secretary John Monks claimed a "clear moral victory" after today's judgement.

"Ministers should now extend parental leave to the nearly 3 million working parents who have missed out, without the need for a lengthy European court case," he said.

"Fighting what looks like a doomed case in the European court simply to delay parental leave for those parents with children born before the December deadline sends all the wrong signals from a government that says it wants a better work/life balance," he said. "It is sad to see the UK government take such a family-unfriendly position."

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said: "It is right that this question should be resolved in European courts. This is what we requested."

The TUC

Related story

fields.headline: The F word
fields.standfirst: Last week, the nation was asked to pick its favourite words.  Michèle Roberts points a finger at one we all love to hate
fields.trailText: Last week, the nation was asked to pick its favourite words.  Michèle Roberts points a finger at one we all love to hate
fields.body:
So Bob Geldof wants to discover the nation's favourite word. Last week, launching the London International Literature Festival's millennium project, he announced that the hunt is on. Will he conduct polls and interviews? Are we talking oral or written language here? And aren't we all egotists whose favourite word is I?

There are moments, of course, when the ego dissolves. It is well known that people about to die, in extremis, often shout for Mum. So that's it then. Mum's the word. She sums up birth and death. We begin with her body, bawling for the breast, and in fantasy, in longing, we end there, too.

Freud certainly associated the image of the mother with the child's acquisition of speech. One of his stories concerns a small boy playing with a cotton reel on a length of string during his mother's temporary absence from the room. The child invented a push-pull game of gone-away and come-back. Mastering the cotton reel, the child simultaneously mastered words along with loss; loss is the mother of invention.

If Mum seems too obvious, too easy, how about fucking? That's the one you'll hear in the street, used for decoration and emphasis, for rhythm, for weighing and pacing sentences, repeated like a mantra until it becomes almost abstract, emptied of content. Perhaps men use this word more than women do, so let's hope Geldof's sample is equally composed of males and females.

But not only do men use words differently; different words are applied to men and to women. Let's stay with the letter F. Such lovely words begin with F - fantasy, furbelows, Flaubert, flow, flourish, feminism, flan. F is certainly for fashion. Favourite formats flicker, fast-forward and frequently fade following fickle fashion.

But there is another F word that is as ubiquitous as it is loathed: feisty. Feisty inhabits the worlds of journalism and novel-blurbs. You will not hear it applied to men. Only females are feisty. More specifically, feistiness belongs to heroines. Feisty is not witchy or bitchy. Like charity, it envieth not.

If you slung it in a poem and looked for half-rhymes, you might team feisty with fists, yeast, busty, fast. Feisty isn't really poetic, though. Feisty belongs and capers in prose. In gushy, romantic, deceiving prose. It is ostensibly praising, complimentary. It invokes a certain kind of womanly strength. It does what lusty or gutsy used to do for gels. Think Wife of Bath and Merry Wives of Windsor. Think pantomime dame with arms akimbo and ballooning crinoline. Think Angela Carter's mockery of thigh-slapping baroque.

You start to get a sense of ambiguity, ambivalence, of a put-down lurking just underneath the surface. A whiff of fakery or monstrosity. So why do people use the word so much? Perhaps it hints at the dilemmas of heroines in what is supposed to be a post-feminist world. Since we are constantly instructed that we must not be victims and must not whinge, we accept that we must be cheerful and brave at all times, like Girl Guides. Feisty. Not being over-sensitive and bursting into tears, but not turning into harridans, either.

Perhaps feistiness is the required condition of modern woman. An impossible balancing act. Damned if you do and damned if you don't. Battling against the odds, trying to bend the rules, or even to discover what these are in the first place, are we just tilting at windmills? Do we look faintly comic to observers?

Then feisty becomes also, perhaps, a term for a woman who doesn't know how to be properly feminine. Feisty is not fragrant. Fragrant is the opposite of smelly and, as we've learned from the law courts, of promiscuous. Whores, as long as they are golden-hearted and in the right kind of romantic or historical novel, might aspire, at the most, to become feisty. Virtuous wives, we know from a judge's immortal words, are simply fragrant. Cleanliness is godliness in this view, whereas sex stinks. But opposites attract and fragrance is drawn ineluctably towards stinkiness. Think of all those lavatory sprays fragranced with lemon and lavender. If forced to choose between fragrant and feisty, I'll plump for female every time.

 The Looking Glass by Michèle Roberts is published by Little, Brown on May 25 at £15.99.

One of his stories concerns a small boy playing with a cotton reel on a length of string during his mother's temporary absence from the room. The child invented a push-pull game of gone-away and come-back. Mastering the cotton reel, the child simultaneously mastered words along with loss; loss is the mother of invention. If Mum seems too obvious, too easy, how about fucking? That's the one you'll hear in the street, used for decoration and emphasis, for rhythm, for weighing and pacing sentences, repeated like a mantra until it becomes almost abstract, emptied of content. Perhaps men use this word more than women do, so let's hope Geldof's sample is equally composed of males and females. But not only do men use words differently; different words are applied to men and to women. Let's stay with the letter F. Such lovely words begin with F - fantasy, furbelows, Flaubert, flow, flourish, feminism, flan. F is certainly for fashion. Favourite formats flicker, fast-forward and frequently fade following fickle fashion. But there is another F word that is as ubiquitous as it is loathed: feisty. Feisty inhabits the worlds of journalism and novel-blurbs. You will not hear it applied to men. Only females are feisty. More specifically, feistiness belongs to heroines. Feisty is not witchy or bitchy. Like charity, it envieth not. If you slung it in a poem and looked for half-rhymes, you might team feisty with fists, yeast, busty, fast. Feisty isn't really poetic, though. Feisty belongs and capers in prose. In gushy, romantic, deceiving prose. It is ostensibly praising, complimentary. It invokes a certain kind of womanly strength. It does what lusty or gutsy used to do for gels. Think Wife of Bath and Merry Wives of Windsor. Think pantomime dame with arms akimbo and ballooning crinoline. Think Angela Carter's mockery of thigh-slapping baroque. You start to get a sense of ambiguity, ambivalence, of a put-down lurking just underneath the surface. A whiff of fakery or monstrosity. So why do people use the word so much? Perhaps it hints at the dilemmas of heroines in what is supposed to be a post-feminist world. Since we are constantly instructed that we must not be victims and must not whinge, we accept that we must be cheerful and brave at all times, like Girl Guides. Feisty. Not being over-sensitive and bursting into tears, but not turning into harridans, either. Perhaps feistiness is the required condition of modern woman. An impossible balancing act. Damned if you do and damned if you don't. Battling against the odds, trying to bend the rules, or even to discover what these are in the first place, are we just tilting at windmills? Do we look faintly comic to observers? Then feisty becomes also, perhaps, a term for a woman who doesn't know how to be properly feminine. Feisty is not fragrant. Fragrant is the opposite of smelly and, as we've learned from the law courts, of promiscuous. Whores, as long as they are golden-hearted and in the right kind of romantic or historical novel, might aspire, at the most, to become feisty. Virtuous wives, we know from a judge's immortal words, are simply fragrant. Cleanliness is godliness in this view, whereas sex stinks. But opposites attract and fragrance is drawn ineluctably towards stinkiness. Think of all those lavatory sprays fragranced with lemon and lavender. If forced to choose between fragrant and feisty, I'll plump for female every time.  The Looking Glass by Michèle Roberts is published by Little, Brown on May 25 at £15.99.

fields.headline: Andrew Smith MP
fields.standfirst: Chief secretary to the Treasury Andrew Smith MP responded to your questions on the Budget on Wednesday 21 March 2000. He explained his views on wealth redistribution and defended Budget decisions, from petrol duty VAT on feminine protection. This is an edited transcript, but you can click here to read the entire live debate and have your say.
fields.trailText: Morcheeba: Did the Treasury encourage (false) speculation that income tax would be cut further in this Budget simply to allow Gordon Brown to be portrayed in a more purposefully prudent light than would otherwise have been the case?
fields.body:
Morcheeba: Did the Treasury encourage (false) speculation that income tax would be cut further in this Budget simply to allow Gordon Brown to be portrayed in a more purposefully prudent light than would otherwise have been the case?

Andrew Smith: Morcheeba, no.


DeVise: Congratulations on an inspired Budget... I was sad to see the middle England tabloids decrying Gordon this morning. It doesn't do anything for me, but then it shouldn't. I earn plenty of money and there's no reason why I should get tax cuts. It's good to thatsee Labour really is redistributing wealth.

AS: DeVise, thank you. This is a budget to unite the whole country. Economic strength, rebuilding public services and tackling child poverty are in everybody's interests. This isn't about taking from some to give to others; it's about setting economic policy and managing public finances so that the country as a whole is better off, and we are able to give particular help to those in greatest need.


ABC123: Why do you find it so difficult to admit that you are redistributing wealth? Wouldn't such an admission excite the Labour heartlands more than any NHS cash boost, however welcome the new money may be?

AS: ABC123. I don't accept the distinctions between the "heartlands" and the rest of the country. Surely everyone will benefit from good quality health services, investment in education, helping more people into jobs and improving support for pensioners. This is a budget to unite the whole country.


Meatloaf: Hallo. Can you explain what this (I think) I35 thing is that William Hague was talking about in the House yesterday? He claims it knackers ebusiness and stuff.

AS: Meatloaf. IR35 is about ending the situation where some people can set themselves up as service company workers in a way which allows them to choose how much tax and national insurance they pay. It's about fairness and a level playing field. This will not damage e-business; in fact yesterday we announced new measures like 100% capital allowances for small firms buying IT equipment and reformed capital gains tax in ways which will encourage the growth of the knowledge economy.


Poquelin: Is it really possible to "lock in" economic stability, as Gordon Brown liked to repeat yesterday? Surely the British economy is subject to European and worldwide influences which make it impossible for even the prudent Chancellor to make such a claim?

AS: Poquelin. Of course no economy can insulate itself from the global economy, but we are building a platform of stability by sticking to our fiscal rules, supporting the monetary framework we put in place and sensible planning of public spending. It's because we are prudent with the economy that we can take action for a fairer society. With sound public finances, lower debt payments and social security under control, we are able to help hardworking families, tackle child poverty, help pensioners as well as build our public services, with the huge boost to NHS resources.


Barkhamp: The zero real increase in petrol duty means that John Prescott gets nothing for a transport infrastructure fund that Gordon Brown promised him last November, and environmentalists are upset about the increase in lorry weight (though they would say that, wouldn't they?). Has the government given up on solving the transport logjam?

AS: Barkhamp, not the case - even though because of the sharp old price rise, we decided not to increase fuel duty above inflation. Gordon Brown did allocate an additional £280m for transport, available for spending in a couple of weeks' time. We also brought in an incentive to use a low sulphur fuel, and continued our commitment through new aggregates levy matched by cuts in employers' national insurance contributions, to help the environment whilst generating jobs.


RubenRuben: Why was Gordon so reluctant to mention sanitary towels in the Commons yesterday? Were you too embarrassed to make this (very welcome) announcement?

AS: RubenRuben, Dawn Primarolo worked very hard on this and Gordon decided that it was right for her to get the credit.

I'm afraid I have to go to another meeting now but thank you for your questions.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours chased over a moor by a clever dog and crammed into a pen
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will become the first part of Gianluca Vialli's summer shake-up this summer, according to the Mirror, which reports that Chelsea have opened preliminary negotiations with Atletico Madrid to pave the way for a £13m move.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will become the first part of Gianluca Vialli's summer shake-up this summer, according to the Mirror, which reports that Chelsea have opened preliminary negotiations with Atletico Madrid to pave the way for a £13m move.

Planet Football claims that another Dutchman, Winston Bogarde, "seems certain to agree a switch to Stamford Bridge" despite interest from Middlesbrough.

Teamtalk reckons that Bryan Robson is instead targeting Lens strikers Joseph Desire-Job and Pascal Nourma. Cameroonian international Desire-Job scored nine goals in the French First Division last season, while his striking partner Nourma managed fourteen.

Meanwhile, their north-eastern rivals Newcastle are also after a striker, Atletico Madrid star Kiko. The Mail reports that the 28-year-old Spanish international is mulling over the details of £4.5m deal which would pay him £25,000 a week.

The Mail also claims that Alex Ferguson is trying to lure Mark Schwarzer to Old Trafford. The Boro keeper was the man Peter Schmeichel recommended as his successor last year and Ferguson, having tried once to sign him, has decided on a second attempt for the 27-year-old.

Bradford have made a £2m bid to sign Manchester United's reserve team forward Jonathan Greening, reports Teamtalk. The Bantams are also said to be interested in Liverpool defender Steve Staunton.

Liverpool are close to signing Dynamo Kiev midfielder Kakha Kaladze in an £8m deal, according to the Mail, which also reports that Gary McAllister is on the verge of moving to Anfield after being promised a further 12 months if he helps Liverpool reach the Champions League.

Pegguy Arphexad has agreed a three-year contract to become Liverpool's number two goalkeeper behind Sander Westerveld, claims the Express, who also say that Charlton are eyeing Bolton striker Dean Holdsworth.

Sheffield Wednesday have given Joe Kinnear until midday today to decide whether he wants to be their new manager, reports the Star.

According to Teamtalk, Celta Vigo and Espanyol have joined the race to sign Everton midfielder Don Hutchison, who is out of contract at Goodison Park next summer. Meanwhile Walter Smith has said he will listen to offers for Norwegian international goalkeeper Thomas Myhre.

Coventry are after Honduran U-23 captain Ivan Guerrero, according to Planet Football. But the left-sided player is uncertain whether to play in the Olympics or move to Highfield Road. "Coventry need Guerrero," revealed his agent. "Therefore, it is he who must decide if he wants to play soccer in England or with the national team of Honduras."

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Brigitte Tailliez talks about her trip to Jerusalem during the Pope's Holy Land tour
fields.trailText: Brigitte Tailliez talks about her trip to Jerusalem during the Pope's Holy Land tour
fields.body:
J'appartiens à l'Ordre religieux des Vierges Consacrées. Ce voyage en Terre Sainte était prévu depuis l'été 95. Nous souhaitions mettre en uvre ce projet pour le grand Jubilé.

C'était la 23ème fois que je me rendais en Terre Sainte. Comme vous pouvez le constater, cet endroit m'attire beaucoup ! Chaque fois que je fais un pèlerinage en Terre Sainte, c'est pour moi connatre davantage le Christ en mettant mes pas dans ses pas. Jamais je ne me lasserai de cette forme de découverte.

J'ai vu le Saint-Père, d'un peu loin certes mais je l'ai, disons, aperçu, lorsque j'ai participé à la messe sur le Mont des Béatitudes. Cela constituait, pour moi comme pour tous ceux qui ont eu la chance d'être présents, une grande joie et un grand moment de communion de pensée et de prière avec le Pape.

Tous les chrétiens locaux étaient là, et le Pape, de par sa présence sur le sol qu'avait foulé le Christ 2000 ans auparavant, leur apportait beaucoup dans leur reconnaissance en tant que Palestiniens chrétiens. Les discours et homélies prononcés par le Pape confortaient ce sentiment. C'était pour lui quelque chose d'absolument essentiel de prier en Terre Sainte, et par ricochet, c'était important pour tout chrétien de pouvoir faire cette démarche au moins une fois dans sa vie. L'atmosphère était très joyeuse, en raison de la présence de nombreux groupes de jeunes.

J'avais déjà eu l'occasion de voir le Saint-Père au cours d'autres pèlerinages. Je l'ai vu à Paris, lors des Journées Mondiales de la Jeunesse en 1997.

Mon prochain pèlerinage ? En octobre, à Rome.

Glossaire/Glossary

conforter to reinforce
fouler le sol to tread the ground
une homélie a homily
mettre en uvre to bring sthg about
par ricochet indirectly
un pèlerinage a pilgrimage
le Saint-Père the Holy Father
la Terre Sainte the Holy Land

 Brigitte Tailliez, 53, a researcher at the Louvre, was speaking to Karine Vandenhove.

fields.headline: Island of tolerance in Fiji
fields.trailText: Another coup in a small and divided developing country, but there is another story to be told in Fiji - the story of how a country's democratic institutions, its armed forces, civil service and civil society, challenged by a small group of racial opportunists, have withstood that threat and endorsed the values of tolerance and pluralism.
fields.body:
Another coup in a small and divided developing country, but there is another story to be told in Fiji - the story of how a country's democratic institutions, its armed forces, civil service and civil society, challenged by a small group of racial opportunists, have withstood that threat and endorsed the values of tolerance and pluralism. I was appalled to read in a reference to how Fiji's prime minister had "packed" his cabinet with ethnic Indians (Fiji's leaders held hostage in 'ethnic' coup, May 20). Would we hear of how Tony Blair has "packed" his cabinet with Jews, women or perhaps homosexuals? (How many ministers in a pack, anyway?).

In fact, the People's Coalition government has more ethnic Fijians in it than Indo-Fijians, but that is not particularly relevant. This attempted coup is not about indigenous rights - it is a simple and selfish bid for power. And while Fiji is not yet a nation at ease with itself, Britain should be so fortunate as to have such a courageous and conciliatory executive authority as President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. The coup is untenable, but huge damage is done, which cannot be measured in dollars. If it all seems so far away - remember that chances are the sugar in your tea was grown and harvested by the hands of Fiji islanders - Indians and Fijians alike. We too have a stake in the survival of their liberties. The quality of our democracy is diminished by this threat to theirs.
Andy Carl
Conciliation Resources
a.carl@c-r.org

webTitle: Heston re-elected as US rifle association chief

fields.headline: Heston re-elected as US rifle association chief
fields.trailText: In his time, Charlton Heston has played the likes of Michelangelo, Moses and John the Baptist. But when the Almighty finally calls in his chips, the 75-year-old actor may well be best remembered for his long-standing role as the president of America's National Rifle Association (NRA). Yesterday, Heston was re-elected as the organisation's president for an unprecedented third term in office.
fields.body:
In his time, Charlton Heston has played the likes of Michelangelo, Moses and John the Baptist. But when the Almighty finally calls in his chips, the 75-year-old actor may well be best remembered for his long-standing role as the president of America's National Rifle Association (NRA). Yesterday, Heston was re-elected as the organisation's president for an unprecedented third term in office.

He has played presidents before of course (he was Andrew Jackson in The President's Lady and Franklin Delano Roosevelt in a TV mini-series), but the NRA gig is shaping up as his most durable and high-profile.

Clearly it is also a role that Heston can put his heart and soul in. With Hollywood dominated by liberals, he has provided some much needed glamour to one of America's most criticised institutions, defending what he terms the nation's right to bear arms in the dark days following the Columbine high-school massacre.

Accepting the post, Heston promised that he would be campaigning for the NRA-friendly George W Bush at this autumn's presidential elections, and poured scorn on Bill Clinton's anti-gun policies which, he said, were directly responsible for boosting NRA membership to its current record number of 3.6m.

fields.headline: Labour MP joins Livingstone's cabinet
fields.standfirst: John McDonnell, a long-time supporter of Ken Livingstone, has agreed to become the London mayor's adviser on local government. Patrick Barkham reports
fields.trailText: John McDonnell, a long-time supporter of Ken Livingstone, has agreed to become the London mayor's adviser on local government. Patrick Barkham reports
fields.body:
The removal of Ken Livingstone's status as Labour party pariah continued today when the first MP signed up to join his London mayoral administration.

John McDonnell, a long-time Livingstone supporter and Labour MP for Hayes and Harlington, announced he had accepted a position in Mr Livingstone's cabinet as an adviser on local government.

Although he did not consult the party headquarters in Millbank before accepting the job, he told the Today programme that "the prime minister made it very, very clear to Ken that he wanted to work together in the best interests of London. That is what we all need to do, put the election behind us and just do our best for London."

Pointing to Nicky Gavron and Lord Harris - the Labour members of the assembly Mr Livingstone has persuaded to join his administration, along with his Conservative business adviser Judith Mayhew - Mr McDonnell said: "There is a spirit now of working together. This is a new politics."

Mr McDonnell is an obvious choice for Mr Livingstone's cabinet. He served as his deputy at the Greater London Council in the 1980s, consistently defended Mr Livingstone's record, and was one of the few Labour MPs to vote for him in the Labour party's mayoral ballot.

Mr Livingstone announced that the first meeting of his cabinet will take place on June 20, two weeks before the formal transfer of powers to the mayor and London assembly on July 3. It will continue to meet every Tuesday.

His cabinet will not be based, Mr Livingstone has stressed, be based on the "Whitehall" model, in which all members are bound by collective responsibility to speak with one voice. Instead, the mayor "will expect members of the cabinet to present him with the most honest advice about the tasks facing him."

Mr Livingstone's cabinet members

Deputy
Nicky Gavron, Labour assembly member

City and business adviser
Judith Mayhew, chairman of the Corporation of London's policy and resources committee

Local government adviser
John McDonnell, Labour MP

Environment
Darren Johnson, Green party assembly member

Chairman, Metropolitan police committee
Lord Harris, Labour assembly member

webTitle: Censorship to be eased in sex films

fields.headline: Censorship to be eased in sex films
fields.trailText: Real life sex scenes are expected to be allowed in films and videos after the British Board of Film Classification decided yesterday not to appeal against a high court ruling on obscenity.
fields.body:
Real life sex scenes are expected to be allowed in films and videos after the British Board of Film Classification decided yesterday not to appeal against a high court ruling on obscenity.

The BBFC said it would be rewriting its guidelines for R18 films and videos which are distributed solely through the 80 licensed sex shops for sale to adults. They are expected to allow scenes of sexual penetration to be sold legally for the first time.

The board also announced that it is to lift the ban on the seven videos in the case. The titles include Horny Catbabe and Nympho Nurse Nancy

The high court ruled last week that the risk to children from the sale of videos in adult only shops was insignificant. But the home secretary, Jack Straw, has warned that he is willing to change the law to ensure that children are protected.

When the BBFC first launched its judicial review action last summer, its president, Andreas Whittam Smith, warned that failure would mean changing its approach to all films and videos, including the way it censored extreme violence.

fields.headline: Hollywood lives
fields.standfirst: The sexism, the old boys' network, the insults endured:  Sharon Krum lifts the cover on a book that reveals how women have really been treated in Tinsel Town
fields.trailText: The sexism, the old boys' network, the insults endured: Sharon Krum lifts the cover on a book that reveals how women have really been treated in Tinsel Town
fields.body:
'Take off your clothes.' For the first wave of executive women in Hollywood, that line was often the opening shot in a humiliating job interview. Nor did the situation improve once a position at a studio was secured. There were bosses who began each day with a call announcing: "I am holding my big veiny dick in my hand", who told tales of their sexual conquests, who asked their assistants to track down the numbers of cute girls they spotted on Wilshire Boulevard.

"Discussing sexism, indeed sexual harassment, in Hollywood was a little like discussing the fact that the sea was blue," says writer Rachel Abramowitz of those first years for women in a town run by men who saw them as objects, arm candy, anything but peers. "It was accepted as the cost of doing business."

Yet until now, 25 years after the first wave of women began trying to climb the corporate ladder in Tinsel Town, that cost has been quietly bemoaned, paid, but never examined. Putting Hollywood's power women under the microscope seemed too painful to contemplate. The sexism, the old boys' network, the insults endured. This is the town, remember, where Jodie Foster was initially vetoed for The Accused because she "wasn't rapeable enough".

There have, of course, always been women in Hollywood: secretaries, story editors, costume designers, actresses. But as power players behind the scenes, they were nonexistent. Back-room Hollywood was like a treehouse with a sign nailed to the door: No Girls Allowed. But as Abramowitz points out in her piercing new book, Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? Women's Experience of Power in Hollywood, in the mid 70s a select few women began jockeying for a place at the corporate table. "And for every woman who made it came a pejorative story. It was always the same: they slept their way to the top."

Abramowitz's book, which took seven years to write and is published in the US this month, is all the buzz in Hollywood right now. Encompassing 150 interviews with women at every level, including actress turned producer and now Paramount chief Sherry Lansing, Meryl Streep and director Penny Marshall, it is the first dissection of women, power and their push for leverage in the entertainment industry. "I was surprised how much it took to stay in the game and that women took it all," Abramowitz says. "They just hung in there, even though they were telling me stories that made your eyes roll back in your head. I think they survived because they chose to wear blinkers."

But while the rise of the feminist movement coincided with the breakdown of the studio system, few women initially beat a path to Hollywood. Part of the reason was the primacy of the male auteur in the 70s, leaving women to guess, correctly, that Hollywood wasn't interested in their contribution; part was that women still felt uncomfortable with the idea of becoming powerbrokers. "Seizing power in Hollywood, it's like gladiators," Abramowitz says. "You have to grab it and wrestle people down - it's not enough to do a job well. Women, socialised to be team players, didn't feel comfortable acting like that."

The few who did come, alone or as wives of successful male directors, moved up from lower-level producing jobs through a combination of tenacity, strategic alliances with powerful men and the adoption of a new personality. "They were the ball-buster or the geisha," Abramowitz says. Dawn Steel, marketing whiz turned production head of Columbia Pictures (who died in 1997), was an abrasive, tough-talking broad whose apeing of male behaviour won the "boys" over. Sherry Lansing, known for her diplomacy and sweetness (though she is said to be hard as nails underneath), played the "girlie girl", the people pleaser.

"Women had to do two things. They had to adopt one of those two personas to negotiate the inner circle and they had to produce hits. Hits put them on the map." (For Lansing it was Fatal Attraction, for Steel, Top Gun.) But when these women began to make strides, it was always accompanied by a push to dismiss them. When California magazine put Steel on the cover as one of the worst bosses in Los Angeles (her screaming was legend), she was chosen over a man who killed two of his migrant workers, then tried to flush them down the toilet. Steel was furious and demanded an explanation. What she discovered was an editor who thought a woman would play on anti-women fears and sell better. He was right.

But while Lansing and Steel were climbing the ranks, many women were not so lucky. "You had the supreme dominance of male adolescent audiences at that time," Abramowitz points out. "The studios could always justify not promoting a woman by saying, oh, she can't make a Porky's or produce a testosterone-charged action movie. There was always an excuse."

For actresses, the situation was not much better. They were relegated to girlfriend/bimbo/mother roles unless they purchased and produced properties themselves. Meryl Streep summed it up perfectly when talking about the dearth of intelligent roles for women: "One would assume the chief occupation of women on earth was hooking, and I don't mean rugs."

The pioneer women who populate Abramowitz's book are in turns angry at the sexist behaviour they endured and mournful at the price they paid. Having to work twice as hard to prove themselves, many didn't have children or successful marriages. But in the 90s, Abramowitz says, things started to turn. With Lansing and Steel running studios, the next generation now had role models: "Women coming in their wake are less angry and more confident."

Movies like Thelma & Louise and When Harry Met Sally, both championed by women executives, opened the door further as they proved to the male hierarchy that female executives have a nose for money. "But they still have a way to go. There are still no female studio owners and no dominant female directors. As soon as women achieve a certain level, the ceiling gets raised again."

webTitle: Classic Oz memorabilia goes under the hammer

fields.headline: Classic Oz memorabilia goes under the hammer
fields.trailText: They're not made of precious stone and are some 60 years past their prime. But Christie's still expect the legendary ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz to fetch a sum "in the high six figures" when they are auctioned in a movie memorabilia sale in New York on Wednesday.
fields.body:
They're not made of precious stone and are some 60 years past their prime. But Christie's still expect the legendary ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz to fetch a sum "in the high six figures" when they are auctioned in a movie memorabilia sale in New York on Wednesday.

Other blasts from the past scheduled to go under the hammer include Bert Lahr's Cowardly Lion costume (made of genuine lion hide), Christopher Reeve's Superman outfit from the 1980 film Superman and the yellow and black Rolls Royce that featured in the classic 1964 Bond movie, Goldfinger.

Inevitably, though, it is the ruby slippers that are expected to draw the most attention. The pair are reported to be in good knick, are sized 6-B (having been made to measure for Garland) and are made of red satin, covered in scarlet sequins. Sad to say, however, that the slippers are not unique. They are one of four pairs that was made specifically for the 1939 MGM film and were raffled off in a competition to promote the picture the following year. This is how the ruby slippers fell into the possession of lucky winner Roberta Baumann, who kept them for nearly half a century before auctioning them off in 1988.

On this occasion, the slippers set a record for movie memorabilia by fetching a price of $150,000 from Disney's MGM Studio theme park, but they are expected to at least treble that figure tomorrow. The current record auction is currently held by the Best Picture Oscar statuette for Gone With the Wind, which was sold for a whopping $1,542,500. The buyer was none other than a certain Michael Jackson.

webTitle: High flyer brought down to earth

fields.headline: High flyer brought down to earth
fields.standfirst: New Labour favourite loses top jobs at British Airways and Millennium Dome in three disastrous months
fields.trailText: When Bob Ayling, the then BA chief executive and chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company, took an inaugural spin on the London Eye at its belated launch in March this year, he admitted: "Life is full of risks - and some of them pay off in a big way."
fields.body:
When Bob Ayling, the then BA chief executive and chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company, took an inaugural spin on the London Eye at its belated launch in March this year, he admitted: "Life is full of risks - and some of them pay off in a big way."

Less than three months on, New Labour's favourite businessman is no doubt questioning just which risks have paid off for him.

That very week he was sacked from the top job at Britain's favourite airline, and late last night it emerged he is to lose out a second time. His dismissal or resignation is a "non-negotiable" part of a £29m package to save the crisis-hit dome, the millennium commission has decreed.

Four years ago, it all looked so different for the shopkeeper's son who grew up to become a fully paid-up member of New Labour - and the epitome of the champagne socialist. Then at the pinnacle of a 15-year career at BA, he became chief executive of a flourishing company still deemed a national institution.

A few months after the former lawyer and civil servant succeeded Sir (now Lord) Colin Marshall at the helm, the airline announced record pre-tax profits of £474m. A lucrative alliance with American Airlines was in the offing and the new chief executive was swift to embark upon an ambitious £1bn cost-cutting programme.

But, in those short years, staff morale hit rock bottom with his inept handling of a cabin crew strike, the proposed tie-up with American Airlines became bogged down in regulatory disputes, and a radical redesign of BA's tailfins - part of a £60m corporate revamp - prompted such derision that the airline was forced into an embarrassing climbdown.

Attempts to cut staff failed and, in February 1999, BA recorded its first loss since it was privatised in 1987, falling £75m into the red.

The chief executive blamed the east Asian economic downturn and increased competition, but the excuses failed to wash. The writing was on the wall, when the graffiti at BA headquarters compared him unfavourably with his predecessors: "First we had King, then we had Marshall - now we are just Ayling," it read.

The naturally resilient 54-year-old braved the storm a little longer, however, and, last October, claimed he planned to confound his critics by seeing out the remaining seven years of his £500,000-a-year post.

At the same time, he remained loyal to his government contacts, building on ties cemented when he held a joint 50th birthday party with Jack Straw. When the Millennium Dome had few friends and even fewer financial backers, BA was persuaded to help bail it out, and became a £6m co-sponsor.

But the failure of the London Eye to open on time because of "safety reasons" inevitably reflected badly on him and his company, and in January he faced heavy criticism over the way in which he dismissed Jennie Page, the dome's chief executive, and then chose an obscure Disneyland Paris middle manager as her replacement.

While the London Eye has been generally received with acclaim, the same could not be said for the dome and, last night, it was the turn of the man once perceived as its saviour to pay the price.

webTitle: Euro campaign turns up the heat

fields.headline: Euro campaign turns up the heat
fields.standfirst:
Relaunch for euro campaign

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Euro enthusiasts are to step up their campaign for the single currency in a move that threatens to increase cabinet tensions over how to handle the issue.
fields.body:
Euro enthusiasts are to step up their campaign for the single currency in a move that threatens to increase cabinet tensions over how to handle the issue.

The Britain in Europe group is to exploit public concern about the high pound's impact on manufacturing jobs to put the case for merging sterling into the new money. Next month's initiative was described by one senior BiE member as a "shift in gear" to bolster support for the euro in anticipation of an early referendum if Labour wins a second term.

The plan risks deepening the government rift ahead of the election, with Tony Blair's senior lieutenants at odds over how to deal with the euro. BiE's move is believed to have the blessing of Peter Mandelson but is certain to irritate Gordon Brown who wants to play down the decision until after the election.

Another key BiE figure admitted ministers were pulling in different directions over the future of sterling. "In the end it is for the prime minister to sort out the competing pressures," the figure said.

BiE's decision represents a switch in tactics from last October when it came under pressure from No 10 to put the case for staying in Europe, rather than joining the single currency, to build a broad cross-party alliance. Mr Blair accepted an invitiation to join a major "patriotic alliance" launch in London's new Imax cinema at Waterloo, attended by Tories Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine, only after the emphasis was switched from the euro to Europe.

BiE is proposing to publish a pamphlet putting the case for entry, followed by a speech by the former Tory chancellor Mr Clarke the following day, June 13. Mr Clarke's involvement will also highlight Conservative divisions despite William Hague's hopes of making the euro one of the main Labour-Tory battlegrounds at the polls.

Mr Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, drew a rebuke from Downing Street last week when he appeared to challenge the gov ernment's official wait-and-see line by warning that fluctuating exchange rates would damage Britain as long as the pound was outside the euro. Mr Brown, the chancellor, let it be known that he felt his co-chairman of Labour's election team had stepped out of line.

Simon Buckby, BiE's director, who is close to Mr Mandelson, yesterday played down next month's initiative and stressed that Mr Mandelson was not involved. "We are drawing the legitimate conclusion that by staying out of the single currency the high pound is costing jobs in manufacturing," he said.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, are understood to have applied discreet pressure to step up the campaign for the euro.

Britain faces further exclusion from EU decision-making as the 11 countries in the euro zone draw up a common strategy for the weakened currency. The move will downgrade the importance of the EU council of finance ministers (Ecofin), on which Mr Brown sits and retains an indirect influence over the direction of the euro.

webTitle: Why single currency will be a hard sell for PM

fields.headline: Why single currency will be a hard sell for PM
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister has a dilemma: what to do about the euro? The polls show two-thirds of public opinion is against signing up. And yet, according to weekend reports, he believes he can persuade the nation of the merits of the single currency. Today, in the first of a three-part series on Britain and the euro, Guardian writers look at the political problems facing the prime minister.

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: It wasn't meant to be like this. When New Labour swept to power 18 months ahead of the scheduled launch of the EU's single currency, it assumed that the euro would quickly become strong and successful and that the British public would gradually be won over.
fields.body:
It wasn't meant to be like this. When New Labour swept to power 18 months ahead of the scheduled launch of the EU's single currency, it assumed that the euro would quickly become strong and successful and that the British public would gradually be won over.

Instead, voter opposition to the UK joining monetary union has hardened as the euro has become the weakling of the foreign exchanges. The government, which declared three years ago that there were no constitutional barriers to joining the single currency, only economic issues to consider, now finds itself in a tight spot.

The government's problem is straightforward. Unlike some countries that have already joined monetary union, Britain will hold a referendum first, and public opposition is running against the single currency by around 3 to 1. Meanwhile, the rest of Europe is losing patience with Britain's wait-and-see approach, with stories emerging from Paris and Berlin of how countries committed to closer ties should be allowed to go it alone.

To supporters of UK membership of the euro, this is a familiar story, with Britain losing not just influence but the right to shape European institutions. Some cabinet members - together with leading Conservative euro supporters such as Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine - say the battle to win over public opinion can be successful, but only if the government adopts a more positive approach.

Tony Blair seems to agree with at least part of this assessment. Weekend reports said the prime minister believed a strong government line in favour of the euro would have a significant impact in a referendum, as it did in 1975 when voters decided by a 2 to 1 majority to stay in the EEC.

Political analysts believe this would certainly have been true in the summer of 1997. At that time, just after Labour's landslide victory, Mr Blair was the undisputed master of British politics, and like a latter-day Moses could have parted the waters of euro-scepticism and led his people into the promised land. But Labour is less popular than it was in 1997, and scepticism - not just about the euro but about Europe more generally - has grown.

Like all UK governments, Labour has had its run-ins with Europe, with Gordon Brown defending the interests of the City over the withholding tax, Clare Short saying last week that the EU was the world's worst development agency and Nick Brown exasperated by the French government's refusal to lift the ban on British beef. The sleaze allegations at the heart of the commission have not helped the cause of the euro enthusiasts either.

Pivotal issue

The prime minister believes that before a campaign to join the single currency can be fought and won, the case first has to be made for Britain to stay a member of the EU. This is a far cry from the summer of 1997 and, with the Conservatives eager to make the single currency a pivotal issue in the next election campaign, the government has opted for a cautious approach. Hindsight may one day conclude that this was Mr Blair's great strategic error, like Harold Wilson's refusal to discuss devaluation after winning office in 1964 - until it was forced on him in 1967, too late to save his industrial strategy or prevent defeat in 1970.

By 1997, the party battle over Europe had been won. A small rump of Old Labour MPs (and peers), not all on the left, remained hostile on either economic or political grounds - or both. But some on the left - Ken Livingstone was typical - who had once opposed the "capitalist club" now swung to support the big EU federalist project.

For New Labour MPs three years ago, the single currency was barely worth discussing. It was obviously a "moderniser's" perspective. Europe good, petty nationalism bad. Devolution for Scotland and Wales, regional government for England too, could easily be fitted into that framework. Unlike more self-deluding Tories, Labour knew the euro would happen on January 1 1999 and said they wanted it to succeed.

Even so, the referendum rapidly became an event most likely to occur after Blair had won a second term - probably in late 2001. That was the theory. In the meantime, Labour developed a mantra for dealing with the question of the euro and stuck to it. The government has no objection to joining the single currency in principle, but five economic tests will have to be met first to ensure that the UK has converged with the euro zone.

Whether those tests have been met will be considered early in the next parliament, when the government will decide either to hold a referendum or announce that Britain is not yet ready to join.

To some euro supporters, this all seems like a colossal loss of nerve. The prime minister and the chancellor see it differently. Firstly, they wanted the first Labour government in almost 20 years to show that it was managerially competent rather than be fixated by Europe. New Labour decided not to jeopardise its honeymoon with the voters, let alone with the Murdoch press, the Mail and Telegraph, by steamrollering the referendum through in autumn 1997.

Secondly, it is by no means certain that winning a referendum will be a breeze. British voters are notoriously conservative, and unlike 1975 - when the radical option was to come out of the EEC - the government will have to persuade the electorate to adopt change.

Moreover, almost the entire British political, business and media establishment backed the yes campaign in 1975; this time one of the main political parties, more than half the press and a good chunk of business is against.

Significant barriers

Thirdly, the economics do matter. Although the question of economic convergence is routinely batted away as irrelevant by supporters of British membership of the euro, there were - and are - significant barriers standing in the way of early entry.

For all these reasons, Mr Blair felt vulnerable in 1997, and still does. Though instinctively more pro-euro than Mr Brown (not initially realised) he was reluctant to fight the Tory tabloids until he had to.

Instead, he urged pro-euro papers, including the FT, Independent, Guardian, Observer and Mirror to fight the cause for him - and berated their caution as they berated his. Only Stephen Byers and Peter Mandelson - who have both listened to the pro-euro lobbying of big business during their spells as trade and industry secretary - have come out with a stronger line.

The strengths and weaknesses of the government's line have become apparent over the past three years. Mr Blair's reluctance to fight only when the time is right looks smart in the light of what has happened to the euro. Good generals do not throw their forces into the fray when there is no hope of victory. Governments do not call elections they expect to lose.

On the other hand, if Labour was not prepared to hold a referendum in the aftermath of 1997, what guarantee is there that it will be any more willing to take the plunge in 2001? There is likely to be only a small window of opportunity before the onset of mid-term blues makes holding a plebiscite fraught with danger, and some Labour insiders now believe that a vote may be put off to a third term, or even indefinitely.

What Britain's movers and shakers say to the euro

Yes

Peter Mandelson Cabinet outrider for the euro, wanted a referendum held after the last election and is pushing for one very soon after the next

Stephen Byers Caught in a pincer movement between big business and organised labour, the trade secretary believes joining swiftly is the only way to stop sterling destroying jobs

Robin Cook Once a sceptic who now has the zeal of the convert, the foreign secretary believes Britain will have little influence in the EU without the euro

Ken Livingstone London's mayor fears staying out will do as much damage to his beloved city as the great fire of London

John Monks TUC general secretary heads posse of union leaders convinced only the euro can save manufacturing

Charles Kennedy Political and economic union remains the Liberal Democrat leader's dream

Ken Clarke After fighting to keep Tory options open, the ex-chancellor wants Tony Blair to make up Labour's mind

Michael Heseltine Another Tory at odds with his party leadership, the former deputy PM believes joining swiftly makes good political and economic sense

Lord Marshall As chairman of British Airways, he is eager to end damaging currency fluctuations

Yes, in principle

Tony Blair Joining the euro would write his name in British history but he is eager not to bet the ranch on the move this side of an election

Mo Mowlam Instinctively in favour, Labour's most popular minister believes the government should set out its stall

Digby Jones He's rowed the CBI back a little to keep it together but the pro-euro body's director general wants Tony Blair to engage the enemy

Maybe

Gordon Brown Cooling slightly on his earlier enthusiasm, his plan is to keep options open and mention euro as rarely as possible to kill it as election issue

David Blunkett In some ways a touchstone, the education secretary thinks now is not the time to pick a fight

Margaret Beckett Pragmatic former trade secretary, she knows the pound is hurting industry yet thinks there might be an easier road to salvation

Bill Morris The T&G transport union leader, put on the Bank of England's court by Gordon Brown, remains to be convinced
