Michael Portillo Retaining sterling is a point of principle rather than practical politics for the shadow chancellor

Alastair Campbell Blair's spin doctor fears a pro-euro Labour offensive might produce "Vote Tory" editorials in a Europhobic Sun

Ed Balls Still to be convinced the single currency will be a strong currency, Brown's chief economic adviser genuinely wants to "wait and see"

John Prescott Few people are talking about it in Hull so why bother tearing the country apart?

Eddie George Deeply sceptical, the governor of the Bank of England wants to hang on to his pounds

Jack Straw The home secretary is against losing the political sovereignty that would inevitably follow from giving up economic sovereignty

William Hague Saving the pound is one of his few popular policies but he knows it may not be possible to keep it for ever

Never

Ruth Lea The Institute of Directors' guru believes it would be economic suicide to adopt the euro and enjoys telling you so

Sir Stanley Kalms Never, ever, says the man from Dixons who is gaining from cheaper imports

fields.headline: We reject the Labour view
fields.standfirst:
Only our party is brave enough to break the silence on joining the euro

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Only our party is brave enough to break the silence on joining the euro.
fields.body:
A bold Liberal Democrat agenda is emerging: a type of politics that challenges the focus groupies, not seeking a careful midpoint in the narrowing space between the left of the Conservatives and the right of Labour, but breaking into new ground, robust, radical and risking controversy - a distinctively Liberal Democrat agenda.

High on that agenda are those issues where the two larger parties maintain deliberate silence: issues vitally important to large sections of our national community, where neither Conservatives nor Labour will risk taking a position for fear of losing votes. Timidity is the characteristic they share.

One issue where Omerta, the Mafia rule of silence, seems to be binding on both parties is the euro. Conservatives remain divided and cannot get together to suggest a sensible and realistic policy. The Labour government waits rather grandly, as if its collective horoscope predicted a miracle, for the British economy to converge on the Maastricht criteria, meeting all five of Gordon Brown's tests. But there is no reason to believe that this will happen by itself. Those governments that joined the euro last year, with only a few well-placed exceptions, took heroic measures to meet the Maastricht rules; almost no one in Britain believed they would succeed.

Italy, Spain, Portugal and others adopted policies that tackled domestic inflation, budget deficits and national debt head on. The political and economic price in the short term was high. But today, they have all converged, and are now enjoying a very respectable growth rate and a decline in unemployment. Not surprisingly, Sweden, Denmark and even Greece have announced their intention to join soon.

In Britain, however, the issue of when, how and at what rate we might join the euro goes undiscussed. The Eurosceptics launch sporadic passionate and even hysterical attacks, but make no constructive contribution. The government, now even more scared of losing votes, has suppressed any all-party public campaign to explain what is at stake.

Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, doing what the government should have done, has convened a highly qualified commission under Christopher Huhne, a leading economist and MEP, to consider practical steps required for British membership of the euro zone. This action too was denounced by some. Not, however, by manufacturers, haemorrhaging from the effects of a hugely overvalued pound. Nor by people now losing good jobs in car factories, farms, textile and steel mills.

Six years ago, Liberal Democrats passed a modest conference motion calling for stronger action against hard drugs. As part of the campaign to target such life-destroying drugs, members proposed a royal commission to investigate whether decriminalisation of cannabis would help concentrate resources for this purpose. Predictably, the roof fell in. Liberal Democrats were accused of promoting drug addiction. Nobody bothered to read what the motion actually said.

Now a more expert group has echoed that advice. Those who have read the Runciman Commission report applaud its restraint, common sense and careful argument. No matter. The home secretary dismissed it. The only sound was the muffled applause of the Conservative ranks. Abetted by much of the media, the subject has been buried again.

Liberal Democrats, however, believe an issue of such importance to our young people, many of whom use soft drugs from primary school age, cannot be concealed. It must be debated, considered, and acted upon. We don't argue that decriminalisation is necessarily the right answer. But we do say discussion, not dumbness, is the proper response of a concerned society.

The other part of the new agenda is the traditionally liberal part. Here again, we will not muffle criticism, nor abandon our alternative policies. The liberal agenda ranges from policies on crime and punishment, and asylum, to freedom of information, where we oppose both the larger parties.

Despite copying notably harsh Conservative policies, New Labour is now seeing a rise in the crime rate. The prison population in England and Wales in 1998 was the highest per capita in western Europe (apart from Portugal). Yet the very crimes that often incur sentences of imprisonment - assault, robbery and theft - have not been discouraged by the longer sentences our courts hand out compared to the rest of Europe. England and Wales had well above their 1998 average levels of both property and contact crime.

It is strange that the much more effective criminal justice policies of our European neighbours attract little attention here. Ministers are obsessed by the US, despite its high levels of violent crime, and faithfully emulate its policies, three strikes and you're out and all the rest, as if they felt they had to seem macho. Perhaps they watch too many American crime movies.

Next there's asylum policy, where Britain has come very close to abandoning the Geneva Convention on Refugees. It is next to impossible for a genuine refugee to reach Britain legally. If fleeing for good reason, they will almost certainly be fleeing a dictatorship which will not provide travel papers. They will have to be smuggled in, to be labelled illegal, or bogus. If the truck driver or ship's captain discovers them, he will try to get rid of them before arriving because of the huge penalties that will now be incurred. And if they get through all that, they will find it extremely difficult to get the legal advice they need before they are fast-tracked back whence they came. It is feasible to divide the economic migrant goats from the tortured and persecuted sheep, but the government has not even tried to move towards a system that would make that possible.

And then there is freedom of information, where the government bill, unless radically amended, is likely to be more restrictive and certainly more bureaucratic than the present regime. Liberal Democrats will not just seek to amend the bill. They will use their position as junior partners in the devolved government of Scotland to ensure that there is a legislative model of how freedom of information should empower the ordinary citizen.

These contemporary issues are challenging, controversial, difficult. Postponing them, running away from them, or following the vagaries of public opinion polls will not make them easier to resolve. And maybe an encouragingly large number of our fellow citizens actually want to address them. If so, the new Liberal Democrat agenda offers them the means.

 Baroness Williams in the Liberal Democrat deputy leader in the Lords

fields.headline: Liberalism, c'est moi
fields.standfirst:
What Tony Blair really said about Europe and the Lib Dems

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: What Tony Blair  really said about Europe and the Lib Dems
fields.body:
Extracts from the unpublished parts of an interview with Robert Harris which appeared in the US in Talk magazine earlier this year:

"The modern media is immensely powerful. It is omnipresent. It makes decision-making often very difficult... There is just a massive and often completely factually inaccurate campaign against Europe run by a very large part of the press that literally suppresses any news that would reflect well on Europe.

"I don't doubt its power and its impact. But I think on Europe Britain will do what is sensible despite media power... They do respond to political leaders who know what they want to do...

"We've made it clear in principle we're in favour of Britain joining the single currency. The reason we say it has to be conditional is because it is an economic union... People ignore this sometimes in a slightly bizarre way. It is an economic union in which you give up control of your exchange rate and your interest rates in the interest of having transparency of costs and of being able to participate more easily in the single market of Europe.

"That economic construction has to be right for Britain. And the truth is that Britain's economy for some time has been slightly more in line really with the US economy than the mainstream continental economics of Europe. So the economics have got to be right.

"But when people say we are hesitant about it - we're not hesitant about it. We've resolved all the issues of principle.

"But the issue of the economic conditions being right and the economic benefits being clear and unambiguous for Britain: that is a real issue. And remember we entered the exchange rate mechanism for political reasons, when Mrs Thatcher was finally pushed for political reasons against her will into the exchange rate mechanism. We joined as a consequence at the wrong rate and at the wrong time - and we paid an enormously heavy penalty for it. And indeed as a result of that harmed the case of Britain in Europe...

"If we decided to make a recommendation to people, the whole dynamics of the argument would change, because the circumstances would have changed. And when people are asked now whether they want to go into the euro, they're asked as of now. Well, the government's position as of now, is not to go into the euro, so it's hardly surprising people say. 'Well, no'.

"But I think when you get underneath it people want to keep the option open. They understand that we live in a different world today. The world's moving closer together. From January 1, 2002 the euro notes and coins are going to be in circulation. So they'll make up their mind on sensible British grounds. They always do.

[And would you consider it a great achievement of your premiership if Britain does go in?]

"Well, it is important for us, and it is a goal, an objective of mine for Britain to be a key and leading player in Europe. And I've no doubt at all that the future destiny of Britain lies with Europe. So to that extent I'm anxious that Britain occupies that position in Europe.

"We've got a very close relationship with the US. It's fantastic that we have, but I've always thought that Britain is stronger with the US if it's stronger in Europe, and vice versa - and our job is to be the bridge between the two...

"It has been taboo in the Labour party ever to talk about the American Democrats. You could talk about the Swedish social democrats or the French socialists, but this was taboo. It struck me when I was reading the speeches of people like Bill Clinton that what they were saying was precisely what I felt the Labour party should be about.

"When it was formed, out of its dissent from the Liberal party... the Labour party suffered as a result. It was more narrow in its base, it was more doctrinaire in its views, and it lost an essential Liberal strand of radical thought. And the truth of the matter is that people like myself in the Labour party today and people like Charles Kennedy and the Liberal Democrats, we basically are driven by the same value systems. There may be differences of policy but that's... almost the accident of being inside different political parties than some great division of ideas. So I think it's important that we move closer together. I've never given up on that goal."

webTitle: British Library offers books for adoption

fields.headline: British Library offers books for adoption
fields.trailText: The British Library yesterday launched an appeal to the public to adopt the mouldiest, wormiest books among the 150m in its collection to plug a hole in its conservation budget.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The British Library yesterday launched an appeal to the public to adopt the mouldiest, wormiest books among the 150m in its collection to plug a hole in its conservation budget.

Thousands of books are in danger of falling to pieces, with acid from the ink or paper eating away the pages, and decay, insects or sheer old age disintegrating bindings.

The library wants members of the public to commemorate a person's birth year or celebrate a birth, wedding anniversary or retirement by adopting a tome.

The expertise of Helen Shenton, director of conservation, and her team of 70 is internationally recognised, and they are frequently consulted on delicate book restorations. But they cannot afford to apply their skills fast enough to save many books in their own care.

"The job is expanding constantly beyond our means," Ms Shenton said. "The forecast death of the paper book with the coming of information technology was completely wrong. There have never been so many books being printed."

In the 1990s, in the scramble to get the library out of the British Museum and into the St Pancras building, all other budgets were slashed.

Under the adoption scheme, a donor's name will be inscribed in a book, the donor will receive a certificate and once a year will be invited to "meet your book" events.

The Blairs could have Leo's name inscribed on a book plate for £15. For £150 he could have the book plate to himself and for £1,000 choose the book to sponsor.

Messages of support were sent yesterday by the author Hanif Kureishi, biographer Amanda Foreman and actress Kathleen Turner, who said reading was a source of "company, comfort, challenges, joy".

fields.headline: Maths Year 2000
fields.trailText: "Maths is fun" is the message of Maths Year 2000, and books with maths themes and storylines, like money, time and solving problems, are a great way to explore and investigate mathematical ideas.
fields.body:
"Maths is fun" is the message of Maths Year 2000, and books with maths themes and storylines, like money, time and solving problems, are a great way to explore and investigate mathematical ideas. You can also take a trip to Numberland and download a celebrity screensaver while you are there.

Bunny Money
Rosemary Wells
(Picture Corgi Books, £4.99, age 5-8)

Max and Ruby set off to town with a handful of money to buy granny a present. But money soon goes if you don't keep tabs on it! Count the notes in the wallet and subtract the amounts as Max and Ruby spend their way through the story. You can photocopy the notes or cut them out from the back pages so your child can handle them. How much would they have saved if they had taken sandwiches instead of buying lunch? All good fun!

The Great Pet Sale
Mick Inkpen
(Hodder Children's Books, £5.99, age 5-8)

Have great fun listening to rat try to sell himself as the best bargain from the pet shop window for 1p as he takes us on a tour of the shop. All the animals have their price, and in the end they are all bought up for a pound. Have coins at the ready and count up the cost of the animals as you approach the magic 100 pennies.

Mrs Armitage on Wheels
Quentin Blake
(Red Fox, £4.99, age 5-8)

Having an eye to solving problems is an important maths skill, and Mrs Armitage knows how to solve a problem when it arises - or thinks she does. She adds a new contraption to her bicycle for every thought that comes in to her head, with predictable consequences. This is what happens when you're not a mathematician!

A Bargain for Frances
Russell Hoban
(Mammoth "I Can Read" series, £4.99, age 5-8)

Frances learns a painful lesson about her friendship with Thelma in this delightful book, but at the same time she learns about costs, value, trading and how to make the best of a bad bargain. Have some coins at the ready and ask your child to identify the coins for the one pound and nine pennies that are key to Frances' bargain. Discuss how much Frances paid out to get the blue china set. How much was Thelma left with? What things are worth one pound and nine pennies to your child? And what is a bargain?

Tick-Tock
Eileen Browne
(Walker Books, £4.99, age 5-8)

Mum Squirrel loves listening to her cuckoo clock. One afternoon she has to go out, but she warns her offspring Skip Squirrel not to bounce on the bouncy chairs next to her beloved clock. But Skip's pals come by and, guess what? Bounce, bounce, boing! The clock is broken. Thus starts a race against time to get it fixed before mum comes home at four o'clock. Find the clocks on each page and show your child how to tell the time as the deadline approaches.

Maths Curse
Jon Scieszka and Lane Smith
(Puffin paperback, £4.99, age 5-8)

Mrs Fibonacci, the maths teacher, says one morning: "You can think of almost everything as a maths problem." Our child hero then panics and can't sort out the difference between a genuine maths problem, an idle muse and a chaotic jumble of illogical questions. A beautifully designed book, it is also very American in content (and thus fully metric), but it does raise interesting and challenging maths questions.

fields.headline: Sir John Gielgud
fields.standfirst: A colossus of English theatre, he bestrode the stage with originality, wit and a voice 'like a silver trumpet muffled in silk'
fields.trailText: Sir John Gielgud, who has died aged 96, blazed a glorious trail through the English theatre of the 20th century and left an indelible imprint upon it. He was the first classical actor of his generation to discard antique modes of Shakespearean interpretation and performance. His Hamlet, Richard II, Leontes, Angelo, Lear and Prospero were acclaimed as thrilling recoveries and discoveries of roles on which the dreariness of convention had long since settled. "You have to spin it out of yourself, like a spider. It is the only way," he said in 1961, and not until extreme old age did he lose that air of effortless spider-like facility.
fields.body:
Sir John Gielgud, who has died aged 96, blazed a glorious trail through the English theatre of the 20th century and left an indelible imprint upon it. He was the first classical actor of his generation to discard antique modes of Shakespearean interpretation and performance. His Hamlet, Richard II, Leontes, Angelo, Lear and Prospero were acclaimed as thrilling recoveries and discoveries of roles on which the dreariness of convention had long since settled. "You have to spin it out of yourself, like a spider. It is the only way," he said in 1961, and not until extreme old age did he lose that air of effortless spider-like facility.

After hesitations and doubts, he rode the surges of the new wave theatre, and revealed himself a remarkable character actor in the plays of Harold Pinter, Alan Bennett and Charles Wood. In 1970, his desolate inmate of a mental institution in David Storey's Home, tears coursing down his face while he maintained a stiff-lipped facade, marked the full flowering of his theatrical Indian summer.

He was not, however, just the starriest actor for high strung, tragic heroes half in love with painful suffering, deploying that famous tenor voice which Alec Guinness once apostrophised as being "like a silver trumpet muffled in silk". He set new standards in the playing of the artificial high comedy of Congreve, Wilde and Sheridan, to which he brought the breath of naturalness. He revelled in suave villainy and hauteur, in the drawn-out repartee of these periods, sometimes deliciously parodying aspect of his tragic demeanour and voice. He was in his glorious element playing doomed heroes and dandies, neurotics and aesthetes.

As a source of inspiration and influence on his profession, he was unrivalled by any actor in his time except for Laurence Olivier. For, in youth and middle age alike, Gielgud was a modern pioneer seeking to fulfil the actor's dream of working in a permanent ensemble, performing classic plays of high quality, where profit was neither motive nor stimulus. The famous companies he assembled in his historic seasons in the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s became blueprints for the RSC and National Theatre decades later.

The other astonishing aspect of Gielgud's career, which spanned more than 75 years, lay in his ability to recreate and extend himself as fashion and circumstance demanded. He was socially and politically conservative. As a raconteur and conversationalist, scattering his indiscretions and gossip with gay abandon, he may have been the acme of unconventionality. But, theatrically speaking, the shock of the new often shocked him. Since he was also a restless seeker, he learned to rise above the prejudice of his first impressions and to cast aside hidebound convictions.

In the 1950s, when the new wave of dramatists broke excitedly upon the London theatre, when Brecht and theatre of the absurd threatened the hold of the upper middle-class drawing-room comedy and the regimen of the well-made play, Gielgud was, at first, left bothered and bewildered, though his astonishing, oriental King Lear, at Stratford for George Devine in 1955, in which the Japanese sculptor and designer, Isamu Noguchi, enveloped him in a mane and head of horses' hair, proved he did not lack the spirit of wild adventure.

Yet, unlike Peggy Ashcroft and Olivier, he did not join the avant-garde at the Royal Court in the 1950s and, by the early 1960s, he was beginning to look a thoroughly traditional figure.

This isolation from the new did not, however, last that long. Gielgud adjusted, adapted and learned. Critics have suggested he discovered an ideal point of mediation between the old theatre and the new with Alan Bennett's Forty Years On (1968), a revue-like play which regards the totems of England's early 20th-century society with a mixture of mockery and nostalgia. But, in fact, his Broadway performance four years earlier, as a lay brother laid low after being persuaded to marry the richest man in the world, in Edward Albee's mystifyingly symbolic Tiny Alice, marked the point at which he threw in his lot with the nouvelle vague.

From then on, Gielgud's career revived. He began to disprove the old slur that he was only able to give a single performance in one voice. In No Man's Land, his sly literary vagrant in search of a billet - the model of bohemian seediness with a cigarette forever between his lips - cast off the familiar Gielgud persona as thoroughly as he did for his 1936 Merchant Of Venice and the 1961 Othello.

When his ability to memorise parts for the theatre began to falter in his mid-70s, while playing an archaeologist disturbed by excavations into his own past, in Julian Mitchell's Half Life, Gielgud turned to the world of film. He adapted and fashioned a late career - notably as the conductor-hero of Alain Resnais's Providence (1977), and an ancient, naked Prospero in Peter Greenaway's astonishing version of The Tempest, Prospero's Books (1991).

He delighted in the suave malice of the narrator's father in the television version of Bridehead Revisited (1981). He won an Oscar for his performance as Dudley Moore's butler in the Hollywood comedy Arthur (1980). There was even a last stage performance. At the age of 84, he took on the role of Sir Sydney Cokerell, the museum curator in Hugh Whitemore's Best Of Friends, and had a field day with the character's mellow urbanity. Even in his 90s, he capered nimbly through the musical reaches of Shine (1996).

The essential Gielgud did not greatly change from first maturity to old age - he was all quick-silver and mercurial intelligence. In rehearsals and life alike, he was impulsive and master of the never-made-up mind. His tongue and ideas for altering performances often ran away with him. His capacity for speaking his mind at the wrong time in the wrong way was a life-long joy - for all except those who suffered the cold blast of truth.

Gielgud may have been born into the heart of the conventional upper middle classes of Edwardian England, but this third child of an Edwardian stockbroker had the theatre in his blood. Ellen Terry, Irving's leading lady, was a great aunt. His grandmother, Kate, played Cordelia at 14 and became an instant star. His great uncle, Fred Terry, made his name with the Scarlet Pimpernel.

Some have argued that his acting and looks bore no trace of his Terry ancestors. They suggest that his style bears the imprint of his father's Lithuanian forbears, and of his thespian Polish great-grandparents, who were renowned for their Shakespearian acting. Even in his 30s - and remarkable for his great, domed forehead and aquiline nose - he did not look English. Ronald Harwood has suggested that "the fusion of the Anglo-Saxon and the Slav to be one of the clues to understanding Gielgud's qualities, both as an actor and as a man."

Educated at Westminster school, Gielgud was stage-struck in childhood, during which the adjectives "nervous, frail and sensitive" were attached to him. He became a willowy young man - quick and sharp, with a butterfly mind, who liked to dress in silk socks and broadband black hats, and with fluffy hair which barbers used to wave. He played no school games and walked in stiff self-consciousness - "like a cat with rickets," said one of his first drama teachers. In a theatre which celebrated bluff maleness and matter-of-fact understatement in its leading actors, he seemed the man least likely to take the West End theatre at all, let alone by storm.

When Gielgud played his first leading role in London, as Romeo to Gwen Ffrancgon Davies's Juliet in 1924, the critics were loud in their scorn. "Scant of virility," accused Ivor Brown, "with the most meaningless legs imaginable." But perhaps the "orange" make-up or coal-black, centre-parted wig and white tights did not help much.

It may have been his Slavic heritage that saved him from sinking after this. For it was in the then almost unknown Anton Chekhov that Gielgud made his name. "Perfection itself," said James Agate, the most influential critic of the period, about his Trofimov, the young revolutionary in The Cherry Orchard. His Kontantin in The Seagull, and the doomed Tusenbach in the first English production of The Three Sisters, were almost as eye-catching.

So it was that the 25-year-old Gielgud arrived at the Old Vic at the end of the 1920s as leading man - and walked almost straight into theatrical history. In the next 19 months, he took on more Shakespeare leads than any subsequent actor has attempted in twice the time. He was all ages and all types - Romeo and Lear, Orlando and Prospero, Macbeth and Malvolio, Antony and Benedick. One of these roles, his Richard II - "A tall willowy figure in black velvet . . . the pale agonised face set beneath a glittering crown" - was the making of him.

Critics had already commented on Gielgud's voice, that fabulous piece of machinery which a few detractors have claimed to be capable of making flamboyant music with elongated vowels and little more. The old records of his stage roles disprove that charge. They reveal Gielgud as master architect, building and shaping character minutely. In Shakespeare, he composed a serious intellectual music. His grief-struck Richard, seething with hauteur, anger, self-pity and vulnerability, displayed both his Slavic and Anglo-Saxon aspects - his doomed king exuded emotion that he struggled to keep in check.

The Hamlet that followed was more remarkable still - a prince for all seasons, contemporary in its sense of disgust and outrage, instead of traditional ponderous nobility, fresh in its Oedipal stresses and strains. For an age accustomed to mature 40-something Hamlets, it was disconcertingly young; for an age familiar with understatement, it was riven with emotion, "hysteria and self- lacerating sensitivity." James Agate called it "the highwater mark of English Shakespearian acting in our time."

Four years later, Gielgud's second prince - bringing Shakespeare daringly into the West End - was less hysterical, more thoughtful and prone to flashes of humour. It was even more feted. The critic JC Trewin said it was the best of the 70 princes he had seen, and, even when Gielgud played the role in his 40s, the likes of the youthful John Mortimer were bowled over all over again.

It was, however, in a new, slight costume piece about Richard II - Gordon Daviot's Richard of Bordeaux - that Gielgud really became a star. "Yes, I know it's vulgar, but I can't resist," he said to a friend, as he sat signing picture postcards of himself after a performance. But it was a mark of Gielgud's essential seriousness that he did not succumb to the frippery and shallowness of the 1930s West End. Instead, supported by the impresario Bronson Albery, he set about creating his own company of players in classical drama in St Martin's Lane.

It was typical of his eagerness to encourage the new that he cast the young Olivier to alternate with him the roles of Romeo and Mercutio to Peggy Ashcroft's Juliet. It was not supposed to be a theatrical contest. But so it proved, and Olivier, unsurprisingly perhaps, was a love-possessed Romeo from the finger tips to the heart, while Gielgud's Romeo was all surface and no sensuality. When it came to Mercutio, however, Olivier was second-bested. "John's extraordinary darting imagination made him the better," Ashcroft said.

Gielgud may have felt pangs of jealousy but they never loomed large - he was always far more of a team player than Olivier, and far more willing to test himself against his best contemporaries.

His famous 1937 season at the Queen's, with Peggy Ashcroft as his leading lady, and a repertoire of Richard II, The Merchant Of Venice, The School For Scandal and The Three Sisters, directed by Michel Denis, marked his first attempt to create an ensemble of classical players. But then, tiring of the producer's role, Gielgud was diverted by Binkie Beaumont, who was about to become the most powerful of London impresarios, into a Dodie Smith drawing-room romance.

Beaumont, the canniest of producers, was a conservative influence in Gielgud's theatrical life, ranged against the likes of Komisarjevsky, St Denis, Guthrie and Peter Brook, who inspired him to new challenges and to new styles of performance.

At least under Beaumont's aegis he was given the chance of launching a bold 1945 season at the Haymarket, which might have been designed to show the ease with which he scaled both the heights of tragedy and comedy. There was his fourth Hamlet, and the abominably cruel Ferdinand in The Duchess Of Malfi, ranged with what the fledgling critic Kenneth Tynan delightedly called his "tongue-in-cheek and hand-on-heart Valentine in Love For Love." In 1953, Beaumont gave him another chance - at the Lyric, Hammersmith - to run his own classical company again. Astutely choosing Paul Scofield as his co-star, Gielgud resuscitated Thomas Otway's tremendous Restoration tragedy, Venice Preserv'd, playing the role of the wracked Jaffier in a dazzle of torment and nobility.

In the 1940s, Gielgud consolidated more than he advanced. He was more larch than oak when he played an admired, too youthful Lear, an unwarrior-like Macbeth and a new Italianate Prospero. But there were people who criticised what someone called his "divine coldness" - it was as if there were something remote and aloof about his acting.

These reservations were set aside in his annus mirabilis at Stratford-upon-Avon in 1950, when he seemed to shed a sense of inhibition and restraint. His Angelo in Measure For Measure, for Peter Brook, marked a new immersion in wickedness. He discovered "a dark and chilling urgency that froze the blood." He was no longer courting sympathy or exuding an easy romanticism. He and Peggy Ashcroft turned Much Ado About Nothing into an exquisite war of words.

Anthony Quayle, directing him as Cassius in Julius Caesar, persuaded him to do away with lyricism and softness, and Gielgud achieved a pugilistic fury that astonished the critics. His Leontes, in Peter Brook's A Winter's Tale, confirmed his new-found confidence in playing unsympathetic roles. "Dressed in hectic red, tall and tortured and rigid, he commands the bare black stage like a fury," John Barber wrote.

A year later, in the Coronation honours, Gielgud was awarded a long-delayed knighthood, for which Olivier and Richardson had had to lobby the prime minister, Winston Churchill; Gielgud's homosexuality had been the bar to this honour. Then irony and disaster struck in a double action. Just a few months later, when the government was in the midst of a witchhunt against homosexuality, Sir John was charged with persistently importuning for immoral purposes. He admitted his guilt and was fined.

The repercussions were great and awful for a man of Gielgud's temperament and character. It was said that he briefly contemplated suicide. "You can't imagine what it was like," he said to me years later. But in his weeks of stress and humiliation, much of the generosity and kindness that he had shown to his fellow actors was returned in full measure. Sybil Thorndike, who was acting with him in A Day By The Sea, led those determined to give support. fields.bodyText: Sir John Gielgud, who has died aged 96, blazed a glorious trail through the English theatre of the 20th century and left an indelible imprint upon it. He was the first classical actor of his generation to discard antique modes of Shakespearean interpretation and performance. His Hamlet, Richard II, Leontes, Angelo, Lear and Prospero were acclaimed as thrilling recoveries and discoveries of roles on which the dreariness of convention had long since settled. "You have to spin it out of yourself, like a spider. It is the only way," he said in 1961, and not until extreme old age did he lose that air of effortless spider-like facility. After hesitations and doubts, he rode the surges of the new wave theatre, and revealed himself a remarkable character actor in the plays of Harold Pinter, Alan Bennett and Charles Wood. In 1970, his desolate inmate of a mental institution in David Storey's Home, tears coursing down his face while he maintained a stiff-lipped facade, marked the full flowering of his theatrical Indian summer. He was not, however, just the starriest actor for high strung, tragic heroes half in love with painful suffering, deploying that famous tenor voice which Alec Guinness once apostrophised as being "like a silver trumpet muffled in silk". He set new standards in the playing of the artificial high comedy of Congreve, Wilde and Sheridan, to which he brought the breath of naturalness. He revelled in suave villainy and hauteur, in the drawn-out repartee of these periods, sometimes deliciously parodying aspect of his tragic demeanour and voice. He was in his glorious element playing doomed heroes and dandies, neurotics and aesthetes. As a source of inspiration and influence on his profession, he was unrivalled by any actor in his time except for Laurence Olivier. For, in youth and middle age alike, Gielgud was a modern pioneer seeking to fulfil the actor's dream of working in a permanent ensemble, performing classic plays of high quality, where profit was neither motive nor stimulus. The famous companies he assembled in his historic seasons in the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s became blueprints for the RSC and National Theatre decades later. The other astonishing aspect of Gielgud's career, which spanned more than 75 years, lay in his ability to recreate and extend himself as fashion and circumstance demanded. He was socially and politically conservative. As a raconteur and conversationalist, scattering his indiscretions and gossip with gay abandon, he may have been the acme of unconventionality. But, theatrically speaking, the shock of the new often shocked him. Since he was also a restless seeker, he learned to rise above the prejudice of his first impressions and to cast aside hidebound convictions. In the 1950s, when the new wave of dramatists broke excitedly upon the London theatre, when Brecht and theatre of the absurd threatened the hold of the upper middle-class drawing-room comedy and the regimen of the well-made play, Gielgud was, at first, left bothered and bewildered, though his astonishing, oriental King Lear, at Stratford for George Devine in 1955, in which the Japanese sculptor and designer, Isamu Noguchi, enveloped him in a mane and head of horses' hair, proved he did not lack the spirit of wild adventure. Yet, unlike Peggy Ashcroft and Olivier, he did not join the avant-garde at the Royal Court in the 1950s and, by the early 1960s, he was beginning to look a thoroughly traditional figure. This isolation from the new did not, however, last that long. Gielgud adjusted, adapted and learned. Critics have suggested he discovered an ideal point of mediation between the old theatre and the new with Alan Bennett's Forty Years On (1968), a revue-like play which regards the totems of England's early 20th-century society with a mixture of mockery and nostalgia. But, in fact, his Broadway performance four years earlier, as a lay brother laid low after being persuaded to marry the richest man in the world, in Edward Albee's mystifyingly symbolic Tiny Alice, marked the point at which he threw in his lot with the nouvelle vague. From then on, Gielgud's career revived. He began to disprove the old slur that he was only able to give a single performance in one voice. In No Man's Land, his sly literary vagrant in search of a billet - the model of bohemian seediness with a cigarette forever between his lips - cast off the familiar Gielgud persona as thoroughly as he did for his 1936 Merchant Of Venice and the 1961 Othello. When his ability to memorise parts for the theatre began to falter in his mid-70s, while playing an archaeologist disturbed by excavations into his own past, in Julian Mitchell's Half Life, Gielgud turned to the world of film. He adapted and fashioned a late career - notably as the conductor-hero of Alain Resnais's Providence (1977), and an ancient, naked Prospero in Peter Greenaway's astonishing version of The Tempest, Prospero's Books (1991). He delighted in the suave malice of the narrator's father in the television version of Bridehead Revisited (1981). He won an Oscar for his performance as Dudley Moore's butler in the Hollywood comedy Arthur (1980). There was even a last stage performance. At the age of 84, he took on the role of Sir Sydney Cokerell, the museum curator in Hugh Whitemore's Best Of Friends, and had a field day with the character's mellow urbanity. Even in his 90s, he capered nimbly through the musical reaches of Shine (1996). The essential Gielgud did not greatly change from first maturity to old age - he was all quick-silver and mercurial intelligence. In rehearsals and life alike, he was impulsive and master of the never-made-up mind. His tongue and ideas for altering performances often ran away with him. His capacity for speaking his mind at the wrong time in the wrong way was a life-long joy - for all except those who suffered the cold blast of truth. Gielgud may have been born into the heart of the conventional upper middle classes of Edwardian England, but this third child of an Edwardian stockbroker had the theatre in his blood. Ellen Terry, Irving's leading lady, was a great aunt. His grandmother, Kate, played Cordelia at 14 and became an instant star. His great uncle, Fred Terry, made his name with the Scarlet Pimpernel. Some have argued that his acting and looks bore no trace of his Terry ancestors. They suggest that his style bears the imprint of his father's Lithuanian forbears, and of his thespian Polish great-grandparents, who were renowned for their Shakespearian acting. Even in his 30s - and remarkable for his great, domed forehead and aquiline nose - he did not look English. Ronald Harwood has suggested that "the fusion of the Anglo-Saxon and the Slav to be one of the clues to understanding Gielgud's qualities, both as an actor and as a man." Educated at Westminster school, Gielgud was stage-struck in childhood, during which the adjectives "nervous, frail and sensitive" were attached to him. He became a willowy young man - quick and sharp, with a butterfly mind, who liked to dress in silk socks and broadband black hats, and with fluffy hair which barbers used to wave. He played no school games and walked in stiff self-consciousness - "like a cat with rickets," said one of his first drama teachers. In a theatre which celebrated bluff maleness and matter-of-fact understatement in its leading actors, he seemed the man least likely to take the West End theatre at all, let alone by storm. When Gielgud played his first leading role in London, as Romeo to Gwen Ffrancgon Davies's Juliet in 1924, the critics were loud in their scorn. "Scant of virility," accused Ivor Brown, "with the most meaningless legs imaginable." But perhaps the "orange" make-up or coal-black, centre-parted wig and white tights did not help much. It may have been his Slavic heritage that saved him from sinking after this. For it was in the then almost unknown Anton Chekhov that Gielgud made his name. "Perfection itself," said James Agate, the most influential critic of the period, about his Trofimov, the young revolutionary in The Cherry Orchard. His Kontantin in The Seagull, and the doomed Tusenbach in the first English production of The Three Sisters, were almost as eye-catching. So it was that the 25-year-old Gielgud arrived at the Old Vic at the end of the 1920s as leading man - and walked almost straight into theatrical history. In the next 19 months, he took on more Shakespeare leads than any subsequent actor has attempted in twice the time. He was all ages and all types - Romeo and Lear, Orlando and Prospero, Macbeth and Malvolio, Antony and Benedick. One of these roles, his Richard II - "A tall willowy figure in black velvet . . . the pale agonised face set beneath a glittering crown" - was the making of him. Critics had already commented on Gielgud's voice, that fabulous piece of machinery which a few detractors have claimed to be capable of making flamboyant music with elongated vowels and little more. The old records of his stage roles disprove that charge. They reveal Gielgud as master architect, building and shaping character minutely. In Shakespeare, he composed a serious intellectual music. His grief-struck Richard, seething with hauteur, anger, self-pity and vulnerability, displayed both his Slavic and Anglo-Saxon aspects - his doomed king exuded emotion that he struggled to keep in check. The Hamlet that followed was more remarkable still - a prince for all seasons, contemporary in its sense of disgust and outrage, instead of traditional ponderous nobility, fresh in its Oedipal stresses and strains. For an age accustomed to mature 40-something Hamlets, it was disconcertingly young; for an age familiar with understatement, it was riven with emotion, "hysteria and self- lacerating sensitivity." James Agate called it "the highwater mark of English Shakespearian acting in our time." Four years later, Gielgud's second prince - bringing Shakespeare daringly into the West End - was less hysterical, more thoughtful and prone to flashes of humour. It was even more feted. The critic JC Trewin said it was the best of the 70 princes he had seen, and, even when Gielgud played the role in his 40s, the likes of the youthful John Mortimer were bowled over all over again. It was, however, in a new, slight costume piece about Richard II - Gordon Daviot's Richard of Bordeaux - that Gielgud really became a star. "Yes, I know it's vulgar, but I can't resist," he said to a friend, as he sat signing picture postcards of himself after a performance. But it was a mark of Gielgud's essential seriousness that he did not succumb to the frippery and shallowness of the 1930s West End. Instead, supported by the impresario Bronson Albery, he set about creating his own company of players in classical drama in St Martin's Lane. It was typical of his eagerness to encourage the new that he cast the young Olivier to alternate with him the roles of Romeo and Mercutio to Peggy Ashcroft's Juliet. It was not supposed to be a theatrical contest. But so it proved, and Olivier, unsurprisingly perhaps, was a love-possessed Romeo from the finger tips to the heart, while Gielgud's Romeo was all surface and no sensuality. When it came to Mercutio, however, Olivier was second-bested. "John's extraordinary darting imagination made him the better," Ashcroft said. Gielgud may have felt pangs of jealousy but they never loomed large - he was always far more of a team player than Olivier, and far more willing to test himself against his best contemporaries. His famous 1937 season at the Queen's, with Peggy Ashcroft as his leading lady, and a repertoire of Richard II, The Merchant Of Venice, The School For Scandal and The Three Sisters, directed by Michel Denis, marked his first attempt to create an ensemble of classical players. But then, tiring of the producer's role, Gielgud was diverted by Binkie Beaumont, who was about to become the most powerful of London impresarios, into a Dodie Smith drawing-room romance. Beaumont, the canniest of producers, was a conservative influence in Gielgud's theatrical life, ranged against the likes of Komisarjevsky, St Denis, Guthrie and Peter Brook, who inspired him to new challenges and to new styles of performance. At least under Beaumont's aegis he was given the chance of launching a bold 1945 season at the Haymarket, which might have been designed to show the ease with which he scaled both the heights of tragedy and comedy. There was his fourth Hamlet, and the abominably cruel Ferdinand in The Duchess Of Malfi, ranged with what the fledgling critic Kenneth Tynan delightedly called his "tongue-in-cheek and hand-on-heart Valentine in Love For Love." In 1953, Beaumont gave him another chance - at the Lyric, Hammersmith - to run his own classical company again. Astutely choosing Paul Scofield as his co-star, Gielgud resuscitated Thomas Otway's tremendous Restoration tragedy, Venice Preserv'd, playing the role of the wracked Jaffier in a dazzle of torment and nobility. In the 1940s, Gielgud consolidated more than he advanced. He was more larch than oak when he played an admired, too youthful Lear, an unwarrior-like Macbeth and a new Italianate Prospero. But there were people who criticised what someone called his "divine coldness" - it was as if there were something remote and aloof about his acting. These reservations were set aside in his annus mirabilis at Stratford-upon-Avon in 1950, when he seemed to shed a sense of inhibition and restraint. Then irony and disaster struck in a double action. Just a few months later, when the government was in the midst of a witchhunt against homosexuality, Sir John was charged with persistently importuning for immoral purposes. webTitle: Concessions put IRA arms offer at risk

fields.headline: Concessions put IRA arms offer at risk
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein yesterday piled the pressure on Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble with a warning that the IRA's unprecedented offer to put arms beyond use was at risk because of government concessions over reforms to the RUC.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein yesterday piled the pressure on Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble with a warning that the IRA's unprecedented offer to put arms beyond use was at risk because of government concessions over reforms to the RUC.

A Sinn Fein source also rejected arguments on flags and the IRA initiative which Mr Trimble is using to sell a return to government to his sceptical Ulster Unionist council. It will vote on Saturday and the outcome is in the balance.

Sinn Fein's move, at an official briefing in west Belfast, appeared aimed at reassuring its own supporters. It indicated deepening division over a speedy return to Stormont.

It was also designed to force the government to reconsider further concessions on the policing bill, with speculation rife a new attempt would be made later this week to bring John Taylor, deputy leader of the UUP, back behind Mr Trimble.

Sinn Fein was worried Mr Trimble might secure only conditional backing for going back into the power-sharing executive, as he did in November. It warned that too would have serious implications for the IRA's move.

But, with his critics ready to pounce, Sinn Fein's briefing will hit Mr Trimble hard. His career will be finished if he loses on Saturday.

The IRA is offering to allow outside weapons inspectors, Cyril Ramaphosa and Martti Ahtisaari, examine some of its secure dumps. An army council member, Brian Keenan, will again act as interlocutor to John de Chastelain's international commission.

Its move was in the context of the full implementation of the Good Friday agreement and the British and Irish governments' statement issued on May 5. Republicans say concessions on policing change that.

Mr Trimble has won an indication from Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, that he will accept an amendment to the bill to make sure the RUC name lives on even though it will not be part of the day-to-day title.

Mr Trimble is insisting the IRA still has to decommission its weapons after allowing the inspectors to visit.

The Sinn Fein source believed weapons would never be destroyed, saying decommissioning would only be resolved on the IRA's terms.

He said: "With trust, luck, and good discussions between the IRA representative and de Chastelain, you are going to get some way to sort this out which upholds public confidence and can be verifiable."

The Sinn Fein source also ridiculed Mr Trimble's claim at his press conference yesterday that a government concession on the controversial flags issue would prevent a repeat of Sinn Fein action in banning the union flag for its two ministries on appointed days. Mr Mandelson is to decide where the parties are unable to agree.

The Sinn Fein source said it was obvious Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun would refuse to allow the union flag above their departmental buildings.

He believed the Good Friday agreement would be finished if Ulster Unionists failed to back Mr Trimble. He said the two governments would become increasingly important, a theme Mr Trimble emphasised as he warned about imposition of joint authority between Dublin and London.

Mr Trimble said of Saturday's vote: "The choice we face is a simple one: we can either put the IRA to the test, or we can take the seemingly easier route and let them off the hook. Saying No to this will only serve to consign unionism to the political wilderness.

"The way will be clear for a return to direct rule, only this time it won't be as before. It will be direct rule with a heavy green pinned to it, with Dublin taking an even bigger say in our affairs, with unionists left with no say at all."

webTitle: TV woman jailed for cancer deception

fields.headline: TV woman jailed for cancer deception
fields.trailText: A BBC presenter who conned friends and television colleagues out of £55,000 by claiming she was dying of cancer, was jailed for a year yesterday.
fields.body:
A BBC presenter who conned friends and television colleagues out of £55,000 by claiming she was dying of cancer, was jailed for a year yesterday.

Elizabeth Wagstaff, the makeover expert on Changing Rooms, spent the money on clothes to impress her boyfriend and expensive food.

Inner London crown court heard that she promised to repay the money when a trust fund matured. But when that cash failed to materialise she told further lies about her health when all she had was a minor thyroid condition and a water retention problem.

The biggest loser was her boyfriend Mark Thurgood, who gave her £12,000 when she said her only hope was treatment in the US.

Judge Quentin Campbell told Wagstaff, 38: "The nature of your deceptions was particularly cruel and unpleasant. There cannot be anyone in this court who has not had a friend or relative who truly does suffer from cancer or had died from that disease.

The judge said three medical reports spoke of relationship difficulties and various health problems, including anorexia and bulimia. But they relied solely on the information she had given. She had not consulted her doctor.

He said: "The answer to the question that the court posed, 'Why does a person like you, of unblemished character, commit cruel offences?' appears to have two answers. Firstly your need to be the centre of attention, and secondly, greed."

Wagstaff, of Stevenage, Hertfordshire, pleaded guilty to 14 counts of obtaining a money transfer by deception and four of obtaining property by deception between July 1998 and last August.

Mark Aldred, prosecuting, said Wagstaff had painted a picture of cancer inexorably spreading throughout her body. Her claims became more extravagant until she began pretending she had stomach cancer and did not have long to live. "On one occasion she wore a plaster on her neck and told him [Mr Thurgood] she had had a thyroid gland removed."

She told a similar tale to a close friend, Mia Sampietro, who told Wagstaff's friends and colleagues, many of whom dug deep into their savings.

Mr Aldred said Wagstaff claimed that altogether she needed £200,000. Her victims included production staff Michael Jewitt and Caroline Officer, who lost £500 and £5,000, TV producers Helen Leven-Thompson (£1,000) and Amanda Eyles (£2,500). The landscape gardener Peter Beech, who also worked on Changing Rooms, gave her £6,000 while Scott Georgiades, a close friend of Mr Thurgood, gave £9,000.

Mr Aldred said when there was no sign of the money being repaid, she tried to fob them off with various excuses, but when the police were finally called in she made a full confession.

Andrew Shaw, for Wagstaff, said that she had been desperate to retain the affections of her boyfriend, "who liked his women to dress well".

Mr Shaw read from her statement which said: "Everyone was convinced I was doing so well and successfully and being so brave about my operation." She needed their respect because she was so "very depressed" about her looks.

Mr Shaw contended that much of Wagstaff's problems were to do with the fact that while she "had a talent for the job she didn't have the character".

Mr Aldred said when there was no sign of the money being repaid, she tried to fob them off with various excuses, but when the police were finally called in she made a full confession. Andrew Shaw, for Wagstaff, said that she had been desperate to retain the affections of her boyfriend, "who liked his women to dress well". Mr Shaw read from her statement which said: "Everyone was convinced I was doing so well and successfully and being so brave about my operation." She needed their respect because she was so "very depressed" about her looks. Mr Shaw contended that much of Wagstaff's problems were to do with the fact that while she "had a talent for the job she didn't have the character". Press Association

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText:
Local Heroes
7.30pm, BBC2

Is Adam Hart-Davis related to Jarvis Cocker? Cycling around the south coast dressed in a lurid pink and yellow shirt, Hart-Davis certainly shares the Pulp frontman's air of wilfully uncool cool. Moreover, as he explores the work of such scientific luminaries as hovercraft inventor Christopher Cockerell, Hart-Davis also has the knack of making his obsession with weird and wonderful British scientists seem the most natural thing in the world. Entertaining.

Entertaining.

Reputations
9pm, BBC2
"I can't believe Liberace was gay", noted Mike Myers in his guise as Austin Powers. An obvious joke now. Yet, throughout a career that brought fame, fabulous wealth, but precious little critical credibility, Liberace kept his homosexuality a secret, successfully suing the Daily Mirror in 1956 when its columnist William Connor (cruelly) described him as a "fruit-flavoured, mincing heap of mother love". The man who was "camp in an era when no one knew what camp was" stayed in the closet until his death from an AIDS-related illness in 1987, when he was posthumously outed by a coroner who insisted upon an autopsy.

Fish
10pm, BBC1
Simon is still playing up, Trevor's burger van has been closed by the Health and Safety, and Fish's absent partner is incurring the wrath of her family (via telephone). As the legal drama continues, Fish (Paul McGann) has more to worry about than merely doing his day job and representing a Labour campaign manager dubiously sacked by an MP. It's all eminently watchable, but it's difficult not to reflect that the plot is pushing our hero dangerously close to dull martyrdom.

Michael Moore: The Awful Truth

11.35pm, Channel 4

Michael takes another sideways swipe at US political culture, looking at the sibling rivalry between Governors George and Jeb Bush to see who can execute the most prisoners, and examining the phenomenon of Compassionate Conservatism - via a game show format.

fields.headline: Dinosaurs revisited
fields.standfirst:
BBC seeks ratings triumph with Conan Doyle epic combining technology and costume drama

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC aims to repeat the ratings bonanza reaped by the acclaimed Walking With Dinosaurs series by bringing together the technology that brought prehistory to life and the creative brains behind the corporation's successful costume dramas.
fields.body:
The BBC aims to repeat the ratings bonanza reaped by the acclaimed Walking With Dinosaurs series by bringing together the technology that brought prehistory to life and the creative brains behind the corporation's successful costume dramas.

Producers are working on a £5m project to dramatise the Arthur Conan Doyle epic novel The Lost World, which charts the adventures of a group of scientists and writers who travel into the South American rainforests in search of a location where dinosaurs are reputed to survive.

The Lost World is thought to be one of the most ambitious adaptations the BBC has undertaken. The series of two 75-minute episodes will not be screened until Christmas next year.

Already, however, BBC chiefs are hoping it will be a ratings winner that will silence criticism that the corporation is failing to generate "big hits". Chris Smith, the culture secretary, said this year that it needed more high profile successes such as Walking With Dinosaurs.

Peter Salmon, controller of BBC1, is backing the project. A number of stars have been earmarked to play the lead roles, and a script is in preparation.

Tim Haines, responsible for Walking With Dinosaurs, and Jane Tranter, head of drama serials, who was executive producer of last year's Christmas hit David Copperfield, will co-produce The Lost World. Mr Haines said yesterday that the Conan Doyle novel, while not a classic, was a "rollicking good story". It is ideal for the dinosaur technology developed by the Bristol animations firm Framestore.

The BBC hopes the new series will attract viewers who watched Walking With Dinosaurs and many more who like costume drama. "If there is anything that Walking With Dinosaurs didn't get it was people who watch television purely for entertainment and drama," Mr Haines said.

As viewers get fed up with docusoaps and home improvement shows, programme makers are desperate to find the next "big thing", and Mr Salmon hopes that The Lost World will bring a new genre to television. While the £5m budget appears to be large, the technology is far more affordable for broadcasters than it was a few years ago.

The location filming for The Lost World will be in either Australia or New Zealand from January to March next year, with some scenes shot in London. Ms Tranter said the adaptation would be largely faithful to the book, but a new female character had been introduced to spice up the plot. "A load of sweaty men would be a bit dull," she said. The character would be a "plucky lass", and "love does eventually blossom".

"One of the dramatic challenges is to ensure that the piece exists as a drama and doesn't just become about the wonderful effects."

fields.headline: Great white hoax
fields.trailText: The Natural World | Animal Airport | I Saw You
fields.body:
I have a confession. I'm a shark obsessive. I've seen more than 40 shark documentaries (34 on tape). When I was 12, I asked my mum and dad for a Great White (I planned to keep it in the back garden in a doughnut-shaped pool, so it would never get bored).

So you can believe me when I tell you this. If ever you hear the words: "The shark's reputation (as a man-eating machine) is far more fearsome than the reality...", it's a lie.

The Natural World (BBC2) was subtitled "Dangerous Australians", and uttered this fallacy within a minute. Within two, it was using 999-style shark-attack reconstructions to hook the passing viewer, casually trawling the mid-evening waters for the scent of blood.

But the film had a more sinister agenda. In actual fact, it was an attempt by the BBC to destroy the Australian tourist industry.

In order to achieve this bold aim, narrator "Jono" set out his chilling thesis: "Australian animals are armed with an impressive array of weapons. They bite better, sting better, their venom is unrivalled anywhere else in the world."

Swiftly, Jono moved on to Stage Two of The Plan: in Australia we don't just have sharks and snakes and spiders, but... flower urchins.

Flower urchins may look innocent enough to a small child playing in a rock-pool, but they can cause muscular paralysis.

Soon, Jono was claiming that casual visitors to Australia could be fatally attacked by "venomous trees", maybe even badly laid concrete slabs. "There's danger everywhere", he said.

Eventually, a real event was found to be recon structed. "This is a reconstruction of a true event that happened to Val Plumwood", Jono explained helpfully over footage of a woman canoeing through a swamp.

Val was fantastically factual about the true event: canoeing in her big hat, "it seemed (suddenly) that my canoe was adjacent to a crocodile". The beast capsized Val and bit her in half. "It had me in its jaws... and then it seemed to relax and let me go", presumably aware that it was being filmed by the BBC.

In the 70s, I dimly recollect pandas called Chi Chi and Cha Cha passing through customs at Heathrow on an annual basis. Nowadays smaller animals - frogs and spiders - join us on every flight (they travel cattle class just below the toilets). Animal Airport> (C5) bothered to make a film about this.

With cameras shoved just about everywhere bar the back-passage of a drug-smugger in preceding Heathrow series, it was inevitable that the "Animal Reception Centre" would be last in line for more of TV's internal examinations.

Sadly for C5, there was no camp Jeremy "character" waiting to be discovered, just a lot of men in overalls, cleaning up elephant dung.

The director even set up a shot with a heron (supposed to appear spontaneously from a box as the voice-over said: "All sorts of things pop up.") After the 18th take, the keeper looks up as if to say: "Did I do that right?" blissfully unaware that the crew are tearing their hair out.

I Saw You (ITV) was just as contrived, but far more cynical. Basically, it was Nick Hornby-Lite. One of those dreaded romantic comedies (Rom-Coms, probably prefixed in certain circles with the abbrev: Brit).

Here it is: the night Ben sprays MARRY ME in shaving foam all over the sitting room, his girlfriend dumps him. Ben's champagne cork does one of those limp comedy-ejaculations last seen on The Vicar Of Dibley.

So Ben embarks on his mumbly, self-deprecating Hornby-quest. There's a single mum, of course, essential for any true test of nice bloke-ism. Then there's a break-up, a mix-up, a slapstick finale and the make-up.

We are supposed to know what happens, even down to every lame gag and last colon on the easy-like-Sunday-morning script. Women must fall for this rubbish all the time, I think, but then I look round the room and realise I'm the only one watching.

webTitle: MPs back restoration of sheep dip

fields.headline: MPs back restoration of sheep dip
fields.trailText: Organophosphate sheep dip should go back on sale, in marked containers, "as soon as possible," the Commons agriculture select committee says today.
fields.body:
Organophosphate sheep dip should go back on sale, in marked containers, "as soon as possible," the Commons agriculture select committee says today.

The chemicals, which have been linked to skin disorders among farmers, were withdrawn in December last year by the agriculture minister, Lady Hayman, until containers that minimised exposure to OP were available.

The MPs say in a report that they are concerned that users are without the preferred means of combating sheep disease for the foreseeable future and that there are likely to be "severe economic, environmental and animal welfare implications".

The MPs criticised the government's lack of consultation before the ban was announced. "The culture of secrecy proved most unhelpful." Press Association

fields.headline: Getting personal with Stephen Jones (Babybird)
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Full Name: Stephen Michael Jones

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and if so why? Whatsisname out of that band.

Have you ever lied about your age? The first thing an A&R man ever told me in this business was to lie about my age. So that's why I always tell the truth.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? I don't need to. I have a girlfriend.

What was the last illegal thing you did? I recorded a CD onto a cassette.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I recorded a CD onto a cassette.

Who is the nicest person you've ever worked with? The nicest person was a guy called Scott Piering. He died recently, very sadly missed.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant per son you've ever worked with? G.O.D. Because he's an arse and never turns up on time.

Has a critic ever made you cry? No, but if I was one I would cry every day.

What would you advertise without a fee? Imperial Cancer.

What would you never advertise? My own funeral.

What wakes you up screaming at 4am? Lager.

What takes you to a happy place? A plane.

 Babybird's single Out of Sight is out now on Echo.

webTitle: Guides look to update their image

fields.headline: Guides look to update their image
fields.trailText: The Guide Association is aiming to update its image and assert its position as the biggest female youth organisation in the country.
fields.body:
The Guide Association is aiming to update its image and assert its position as the biggest female youth organisation in the country.

As the movement celebrates its 90th anniversary this month, its executives recognise that the image of the Guides and sister organisations - Brownies, Rainbow Guides and Rangers - has become old-fashioned and out-of-touch. Guides membership has fallen from a high of 900,000 in 1980 to 700,000 today, with a huge exodus among those aged 14.

Today the association publishes a wide-ranging survey, by Opinion Leader Research, of girls aged 11 to 17, providing a picture of who today's girls are, what they do in their spare time, their views on sex, boys, education and the future.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Antz
(Eric Darnell, Tim Johnson, 1998) 12.10pm, 8pm, Sky Premier
The animated blockbuster that took on A Bug's Life in the insect war, this starts hilariously, with the Woody Allen-voiced Z-4195 ("the middle child in a family of five million") on the psychiatrist's leaf, wondering if there's more to life than being a worker ant. There is. Romance with Princess Bala (Sharon Stone) and war with the termites is just around the corner. With Sly Stallone as a soldier ant, this is inspired fun, even if the screen is at times stodgy with subterranean hues.

The Last Detail
(Hal Ashby, 1973) 9pm, Carlton Cinema
Forget As Good As It Gets; this is Jack Nicholson at his best as a grizzled veteran navy man, with Otis Young escorting dopey young rating Randy Quaid to military prison. At first they just want to get the job done, but gradually grow fond of the lad and treat him to manly delights - prostitute, beers, hotdog in a freezing park.

He Got Game
(Spike Lee, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Renowned NY Knicks fan Lee takes on basketball with this accomplished sports film. Focusing on the strained relationship between a father (Denzel Washington) released from jail to convince his son (Ray Allen) to take a basketball scholarship, Lee attacks the commercialisation of the game, without losing sight of its beauty.

Le Bossu
(Philippe de Broca, 1998) 12.15am, Sky Premier
De Broca stages one of those beautiful swashbucklers the French do so well (La Reine Margot, Horseman on the Roof and all). The ubiquitous Daniel Auteuil plays Lagardère, a 17th-century swordsman; when his friend, the heroic, doltish Duc de Nevers (Vincent Perez), is betrayed by his scheming cousin, Gonzague (Fabrice Luchini), Lagardère is left to bring up the Duc's orphaned daughter, and seek revenge.

webTitle: The nuclear option comes in from cold

fields.headline: The nuclear option comes in from cold
fields.standfirst:
Cost cuts and Kyoto set scene for a comeback

Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Cost cuts and Kyoto set scene for a comeback
fields.body:
Is nuclear energy poised to make a comeback? The question may seem naive given the hammering the industry has taken in recent weeks: British Nuclear Fuels' debacle over its Japanese reprocessing contracts; British Energy's sagging profits and collapsing share price - and safety worries caused by its staff cuts.

But there are grounds, most paradoxically environmental reasons, why ministers and the market might view the nuclear option more favourably in years to come and objections to building new power plants may be overcome.

Britain's existing nuclear power plants face decommissioning and closure over the next 20 years, starting soon with the Magnox stations owned and managed by BNFL and moving on, from around 2015, to the AGR (advanced gas-cooled reactor) stations belonging to BE.

A combination of factors has produced a rapprochement between the industry and the green movement. First, the end is in sight for the most blatant cause of objection: reprocessing of spent fuel rods and the toxic waste that leaves. Japan and Germany want to exit their reprocessing contracts with BNFL, while BE has signalled it wants to rescind its £300m annual deal with BNFL and switch to dry storage.

Energy experts at Friends of the Earth have cautiously welcomed the latter move, with Mark Johnston saying it is "the least worst option" and seeing an end to reprocessing here within the decade, probably much sooner.

Helen Wallace, a scientist at Greenpeace, is more sceptical, arguing, correctly, that BE's policy shift has been determined by cost-cutting. "Stopping reprocessing would not make nuclear power acceptable to us because it's still producing waste and there's still a risk of accidents. But we think this move is very significant and definitely a move in the right direction."

A second reason for revival of the nuclear option is price. Peter Hollins, BE's chief executive, says the government's drive to bring new players into the industry and reduce the market share of National Power and PowerGen has brought wholesale prices down more steeply than anybody envisaged.

That and the immediate prospect of new trading arrangements based on a commodity market have propelled prices down 15% already this year and are likely to push them down further; Mr Hollins had expected a fall of 25% would take three years.

In the short run this will not benefit nuclear power but coal, according to Tony Cooper, leader of the Engineers & Managers Association, with some 4,000 members in the nuclear industry.

With its new £100m government subsidy, the coal industry is in a better position to compete with alternative fuels such as gas and, though the subsidy means the moratorium on new gas-fired power stations will be lifted, Mr Cooper believes price pressures will inhibit investment in in new plant.

The third and most compelling reason for what even Mr Johnston concedes could be "the slim chance of a come-back" for nuclear power is environmental. Britain is committed by the Kyoto accord to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions by 12.5% by 2010 but has opted to raise this to 20%. Mr Cooper says all the recent cuts in greenhouse gases from Britain have been caused by the switch from coal to gas and nuclear.

Both Greenpeace and FoE insist that the next leap in reducing greenhouse gases must come from a switch to renewable energy sources and energy efficiency, effectively controlling demand.

Helen Liddell, energy minister, wants renewables to provide 10% of Britain's energy mix within 10 years but there is considerable scepticism whether this target can be met. "Unless the government can do something about transport it's difficult to see how the rate of CO 2 reduction can be maintained without nuclear," Mr Cooper says.

"Not everybody is prepared to stand up and say so but we believe there's an increasing understanding of the role of nuclear in dealing with the greenhouse effect. The only way the UK can meet its Kyoto commitment is because of our increasing output," adds Mr Hollins.

Mr Johnston says gas remains a better option. But he admits that if CO2 emissions continue to hit the roof in, say, five years, nuclear could make a comeback.

Greenpeace wants all existing plants shut and views any suggestion of new ones as an expensive folly. "Not only on environmental grounds is nuclear unacceptable but because it would be investing in old technology which has failed economically," Ms Wallace says.

The industry concedes many of these points. But, says Mr Cooper, there are two factors which could favour a nuclear revival. First, if other forms of generation, notably coal, had to be bear the full cost of environmental impact and a market-driven system came into being, the economics of the nuclear power industry would improve.

Second, nuclear technology is changing so it can become intrinsically safe. "Safety is now based on human and computerised controls but there are designs being worked on in which, if the reactor core started to heat up, the physics of it alone would slow that process and you'd get negative feedback."
