The question may seem naive given the hammering the industry has taken in recent weeks: British Nuclear Fuels' debacle over its Japanese reprocessing contracts; British Energy's sagging profits and collapsing share price - and safety worries caused by its staff cuts. But there are grounds, most paradoxically environmental reasons, why ministers and the market might view the nuclear option more favourably in years to come and objections to building new power plants may be overcome. Britain's existing nuclear power plants face decommissioning and closure over the next 20 years, starting soon with the Magnox stations owned and managed by BNFL and moving on, from around 2015, to the AGR (advanced gas-cooled reactor) stations belonging to BE. A combination of factors has produced a rapprochement between the industry and the green movement. First, the end is in sight for the most blatant cause of objection: reprocessing of spent fuel rods and the toxic waste that leaves. Japan and Germany want to exit their reprocessing contracts with BNFL, while BE has signalled it wants to rescind its £300m annual deal with BNFL and switch to dry storage. Energy experts at Friends of the Earth have cautiously welcomed the latter move, with Mark Johnston saying it is "the least worst option" and seeing an end to reprocessing here within the decade, probably much sooner. Helen Wallace, a scientist at Greenpeace, is more sceptical, arguing, correctly, that BE's policy shift has been determined by cost-cutting. "Stopping reprocessing would not make nuclear power acceptable to us because it's still producing waste and there's still a risk of accidents. But we think this move is very significant and definitely a move in the right direction." A second reason for revival of the nuclear option is price. Peter Hollins, BE's chief executive, says the government's drive to bring new players into the industry and reduce the market share of National Power and PowerGen has brought wholesale prices down more steeply than anybody envisaged. That and the immediate prospect of new trading arrangements based on a commodity market have propelled prices down 15% already this year and are likely to push them down further; Mr Hollins had expected a fall of 25% would take three years. In the short run this will not benefit nuclear power but coal, according to Tony Cooper, leader of the Engineers & Managers Association, with some 4,000 members in the nuclear industry. With its new £100m government subsidy, the coal industry is in a better position to compete with alternative fuels such as gas and, though the subsidy means the moratorium on new gas-fired power stations will be lifted, Mr Cooper believes price pressures will inhibit investment in in new plant. The third and most compelling reason for what even Mr Johnston concedes could be "the slim chance of a come-back" for nuclear power is environmental. Britain is committed by the Kyoto accord to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions by 12.5% by 2010 but has opted to raise this to 20%. Mr Cooper says all the recent cuts in greenhouse gases from Britain have been caused by the switch from coal to gas and nuclear. Both Greenpeace and FoE insist that the next leap in reducing greenhouse gases must come from a switch to renewable energy sources and energy efficiency, effectively controlling demand. Helen Liddell, energy minister, wants renewables to provide 10% of Britain's energy mix within 10 years but there is considerable scepticism whether this target can be met. "Unless the government can do something about transport it's difficult to see how the rate of CO 2 reduction can be maintained without nuclear," Mr Cooper says. "Not everybody is prepared to stand up and say so but we believe there's an increasing understanding of the role of nuclear in dealing with the greenhouse effect. The only way the UK can meet its Kyoto commitment is because of our increasing output," adds Mr Hollins. Mr Johnston says gas remains a better option. But he admits that if CO2 emissions continue to hit the roof in, say, five years, nuclear could make a comeback. Greenpeace wants all existing plants shut and views any suggestion of new ones as an expensive folly. "Not only on environmental grounds is nuclear unacceptable but because it would be investing in old technology which has failed economically," Ms Wallace says. The industry concedes many of these points. But, says Mr Cooper, there are two factors which could favour a nuclear revival. First, if other forms of generation, notably coal, had to be bear the full cost of environmental impact and a market-driven system came into being, the economics of the nuclear power industry would improve. Second, nuclear technology is changing so it can become intrinsically safe. "Safety is now based on human and computerised controls but there are designs being worked on in which, if the reactor core started to heat up, the physics of it alone would slow that process and you'd get negative feedback."

fields.headline: Dome chief forced to quit
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Bob Ayling is being forced to quit as chairman of the  Millennium Dome company as the price of a further  £29m emergency bail-out from the national lottery to  prevent the crisis-hit project closing early.
fields.body:
Bob Ayling is being forced to quit as chairman of the Millennium Dome company as the price of a further £29m emergency bail-out from the national lottery to prevent the crisis-hit project closing early.

The millennium commission demanded the sacking or resignation of Mr Ayling, who was sacked two months ago as the chief executive of British Airways, as a "non-negotiable part" of the rescue package, a commission spokesman said last night.

"The chairman is the only person who has been required to depart, but we have also requested a strengthening of the finance team," he added.

The commission refused to grant the £38.6m requested by the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC), on top of £509m already received. It said it had "serious reservations" about providing further funds without "substantial change in the governance" of the company.

It demanded that three conditions were met in exchange for the money, including "the strengthening and restructuring of NMEC's management and governance".

The dome's chief executive, PY Gerbeau, promised this would be the project's last appeal for handouts: "I want to draw a line in the sand," he said last night.

He said there would be no redundancies of frontline staff among the 5,000 workers at the site, in Greenwich, south-east London, but the management is likely to face a shake-up and some contracts will not be renewed. Evening openings would be scrapped, and 350 people who would have been hired over the summer to cover those hours would not now be taken on, saving £1m.

Downing Street indicated yesterday that, with the latest grant, plus further reforms, the dome would now stay open as scheduled until the end of the year despite rumours that it could close early.

Commissioners, who include Chris Smith, the culture secretary, the Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam and the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, expressed "full confidence" in Mr Gerbeau, but the statement was described by one observer as "by far the toughest ever".

The grant is being made only two months after the commission handed over a £60m loan, supposedly to be paid back by NMEC, to cover "cash flow problems" caused by visitor numbers that have been far lower than forecast. The company yesterday admitted visitor forecasts made in 1997 and revised last January were wrong, and said a figure of 7m was nearer the mark than the dome's original target of 12m.

The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats last night condemned the latest cash injection, both claiming the government was "throwing good money after bad".

The Department of Culture, Media and Sport yesterday strongly denied suggestions that, because the millennium commission has allocated its full £2bn lottery allocation, the extra grant would be drawn from the new opportunities fund (NOF), the pot of lottery money which funds small community projects around the country.

However, while existing and promised NOF projects will not be affected, if the £29m is not paid back, it will not feed into the NOF, inevitably reducing the schemes which could have been funded.

The Guardian has learned that the national audit office is to examine whether decisions to award additional grants were carried out appropriately and based on a genuine business case made by NMEC.

Mr Gerbeau said: "I am pleased with the vote of confidence from the commission in terms of their support for our improvements to date. However, I obviously have concerns that the application for funding has not been approved in full, but I will be discussing the matter further with my board.

"I am running a lean and mean operation but if I can get some more support with the finance operation that is good. We have been delivering drastic cost savings and we will continue to do more."

fields.headline: Secrets and lies
fields.standfirst:
Exactly what happened in a County Armagh hay shed one winter's day in 1982 has remained one of the most enduring and controversial mysteries of the conflict in Northern Ireland. So why did MI5 destroy a secret recording that would have revealed the truth about the incident? Peter Taylor exposes a very British cover-up

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Exactly what happened in a County Armagh hay shed one winter's day in 1982 has remained one of the most enduring and controversial mysteries of the conflict in Northern Ireland. So why did MI5 destroy a secret recording that would have revealed the truth about the incident?  Peter Taylor  exposes a very British cover-up
fields.body:
In the dead of a cold October night in 1982, a technical officer from MI5, and an undercover "operator" from the army's secret surveillance unit, 14 Intelligence Company (known as 14 Int), covertly entered a hay shed in Ballyneery Road North, a few miles from Lurgan, County Armagh. Inside were 1,000lbs of "blowie", fertiliser-based explosives packed in black plastic bags and covered with hay bales. They had been stored there by the IRA. The MI5 officer carefully planted a listening device in one of the rafters, expertly crafted to fit in with its surroundings, and started to run tests apparently by reciting nursery rhymes. The 14 Int technical operator fixed his own wiring device to the hay bales. It was designed to trigger a signal when the IRA moved the bales to get to the explosives.

The listening post at which the signals were received was a few miles away, manned by an RUC officer and soldiers from the army's Special Collation Team (SCT). They would record on tape the sounds - and, hopefully, voices - emitted from MI5's device.

There were similar operations in place all over the province, primarily designed to gather intelligence. The tapes would be transcribed and routinely destroyed. Normally the hay shed would have been placed under "eyes on" surveillance either by 14 Int or its RUC counterpart, E4A, but given the exposed nature of the location in a strong republican area and the high risk of detection by local people or their dogs, a decision was made to rely on MI5's technical expertise and the trigger wire.

The decision caused resentment in some quarters of 14 Int, among those who felt they were capable of doing the job and regarded MI5 as "the pin-stripe brigade in green wellies". Special Branch was not happy either at leaving everything to MI5. What subsequently happened might have shaken the Security Service to its foundations - had the full story been revealed.

The IRA had brought the explosives across the border from Dundalk at the end of September 1982 and stashed them away in the hay shed. The RUC's Special Branch had identified the IRA's main supply route from the south through a highly placed informer within the IRA. Apparently he had been recruited by the army, taken over by Special Branch and put on MI5's payroll. The "mole" was gold dust, a source graded "A". The plan had been to let the consignment run and catch the IRA's North Armagh unit redhanded, thus putting an end to the mayhem it had caused in the district. Because the intelligence also indicated that the explosives were to be used to pull off a "spectacular", the surrounding area was placed out of bounds to the police and army so that there was no danger that they would present themselves as a target. The hay shed and its deadly contents remained under surveillance for several weeks.

On October 27 1982, the RUC received a telephone call about a theft in the vicinity of the Kinnego embankment, which was part of the off-limits area. A call was made to see if police could investigate and word came back via Special Branch that they could, a check having been made to ascertain that the explosives were still in the hay shed. Three police officers, Sergeant Sean Quinn and Constables Alan McCloy and Paul Hamilton, were given the green light to proceed along the embankment in an armoured Cortina. At 2.19pm it was blown 70ft in the air by a 1,000lb bomb planted under the road and triggered by remote control, leaving a crater 40ft wide and 15ft deep. The three RUC officers died instantly. The explosives had not been in the hay shed.

MI5's listening device had failed and the IRA had removed them under the noses of British intelligence. It appears there had been a signal from the 14 Int technician's trigger on the hay bales but it had been dismissed by the SCT monitors as possibly a dog chasing a chicken, since there had been no corroborating noise from MI5's bug. Had there been human surveillance on the hay shed, three policemen would not have died.

That night, Special Branch handlers are thought to have met the "mole" and told him to name names. A fortnight later, three local IRA men - Sean Burns, Eugene Toman and Gervaise McKerr - were shot dead by the RUC's SAS-trained anti-terrorist unit in highly controversial circumstances. None of the IRA men was armed. Intelligence reports linked Toman and Burns to the Kinnego bomb. Their deaths fuelled allegations of a "shoot to kill" policy.

When the covert units searched the hay shed in the wake of the Kinnego explosion, they found the explosives gone and three old German Mauser rifles, without ammunition, left behind. They had not been there when the devices were originally planted. It was assumed that the IRA would return. MI5 installed a second device and the 14 Int operator re-set his trigger, this time under the weapons. The SCT team waited, tape recorders ready, and the RUC's anti-terrorist unit on standby.

A fortnight after Toman, Burns and McKerr had, in the words of Lord Justice Gibson been brought "to the final court of justice" by the police, there were sounds of movement in the hay shed. This time, MI5's bug was working. The anti-terrorist unit moved in and shot dead 17-year-old Michael Tighe, who had no IRA connections, and seriously wounded his friend, 19-year-old Martin McCauley.

McCauley was charged with possession of the weapons. At his trial he said they had entered the hay shed out of curiosity and claimed that the police opened fire without warning and then discussed finishing him off on the ground. The police told a different story. They said that when they heard the sound of a rifle being cocked and "muffled voices", they shouted: "Police. Throw out your weapons." They said they repeated it before firing the first shots, after being confronted by two men aiming rifles.

The critical question is, who was telling the truth? Was a warning given or was this another example of so-called "shoot to kill"? The controversy was intensified the following month when the RUC's anti-terrorist unit shot dead two INLA members in Armagh: Seamus Grew and Roddie Carroll. Again, the circumstances were controversial. Again, neither was armed. Suspicions over "shoot to kill" were confirmed when it transpired that the Special Branch officers involved in all three incidents had been instructed to tell lies and fabricate cover stories to protect the "mole" and another informer who had provided the vital intelligence.

In May 1984, as the furore refused to die down, John Stalker, the deputy chief constable of Greater Manchester, was appointed to head what became generally known as the "shoot to kill" inquiry. Six months into his investigation, the team discovered to Stalker's astonishment that the hay shed had been bugged by MI5. In the end they established that that 42 tapes had been made. Tape 42, Stalker concluded, must therefore contain the answer to the vital question: was a warning given?

Stalker now felt he was searching for possible evidence of murder. He spent the next 18 months trying to get access to tape 42 and was thwarted at every turn. He was finally told that it had been destroyed. But what he didn't know was that, as a result of an extraordinary sequence of events, a copy of the tape existed.

One of the SCT personnel monitoring the device at the time of the shooting had made his own cassette copy of the master, presumably as a macabre souvenir of death captured on tape. A few days later MI5 found out about the cassette and ordered it to be handed over. The unit did as requested and the copy was stored.

When Stalker appeared on the scene, there were fears in MI5 circles that the tape would be found so one of the senior MI5 officers in the province ordered one of his MI5 colleagues to destroy it. The vital evidence was gone. By this time, several other members of the security service had heard the tape in addition to members of the SCT. The vast majority heard no warning.

Stalker was removed from his inquiry in controversial circumstances in May 1986. The dramatic denouement of the mystery of the missing tape finally came when Colin Sampson, chief constable of West Yorkshire, took over Stalker's team and the inquiry, and began to piece together the rest of the picture. Almost a year later, Sampson delivered his report to the director of public prosecutions in Northern Ireland, Sir Barry Shaw. Neither the Sampson Report nor the Stalker Report, upon which it was based, have seen the light of day.

It has always been known that Sampson recommended that police officers should be prosecuted for conspiracy to pervert the course of justice and for fabricating cover stories. What has not been known, until now, is that he also recommended that MI5 officers should face the same charge for destroying the copy of the tape.

Far from covering up what had happened, Sampson and his team were prepared to have it exposed in open court. The DPP had concluded that there was sufficient evidence to warrant the prosecutions Sampson had recommended. The team had done its homework and nailed those responsible. It was now up to the courts to judge.

The Thatcher government was in a quandary. Stalker and Sampson had done their jobs and got to the bottom of what had happened - in particular concerning the hay shed tape. Not to proceed with prosecutions would confirm the widely held suspicion that there had been a conspiracy and cover up. To go ahead and see MI5 officers in the dock being cross-examined about the destruction of the copy of tape 42 would have been political dynamite.

By the end of the 80s, MI5 had not yet taken its first tentative steps out of the shadows and the prospect of its officers facing cross-examination on any issue - let alone this - would have been unthinkable in Whitehall. Under the circumstances, the attorney-general, Sir Patrick Mayhew, told the House of Commons in January 1988 that there would be no prosecutions, "in the public interest". MPs thought the issue revolved solely around RUC officers since the fact that they had given cover stories had already been revealed. They had no idea it involved MI5 and the destruction of vital evidence.

When I asked Lord Mayhew specifically about the prosecution of security service officers, he was reluctant to be drawn. All he would say was, "a lot of intelligence matters would have been brought out that would have been very deleterious to the intelligence operation that was essential in the circumstances of the time". Remarkably, however, Sir Robert Andrew, who was permanent under secretary at the Northern Ireland Office at the time, was much more forthright. He told me he had only found out that a copy of the tape had been made and then destroyed when he read the Sampson Report.

"This, if true," said Sir Robert, "was most unfortunate. It was a very difficult one. There was an argument for saying that prosecutions should have been brought to clear the air and to demonstrate that the government was not covering up illegal activities. On the other hand, there was a fear that if police officers, and even more so, officers from the security service, were put in the dock and had to answer questions on oath, intelligence gathering methods and the identity of individuals would have become known and prejudiced the effectiveness of intelligence gathering operations.

"This is why the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Tom King, judged on balance that a prosecution was undesirable."

Sir Robert, who was present at some of these discussions between King and Mayhew, thereby confirms that the decision not to prosecute was made on political grounds. He was clearly uneasy at the decision. "It was very difficult," he said. "I think I saw it as a finely balanced case. I don't think I would want to go further than that."

Perhaps Stella Rimington will enlighten us further in her forthcoming memoirs. Somehow, I doubt it.

 Shoot to Kill, the second part of Peter Taylor's series, Brits, will be shown tomorrow night on BBC2 at 9.30pm.

There was an argument for saying that prosecutions should have been brought to clear the air and to demonstrate that the government was not covering up illegal activities. On the other hand, there was a fear that if police officers, and even more so, officers from the security service, were put in the dock and had to answer questions on oath, intelligence gathering methods and the identity of individuals would have become known and prejudiced the effectiveness of intelligence gathering operations. "This is why the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Tom King, judged on balance that a prosecution was undesirable." Sir Robert, who was present at some of these discussions between King and Mayhew, thereby confirms that the decision not to prosecute was made on political grounds. He was clearly uneasy at the decision. "It was very difficult," he said. "I think I saw it as a finely balanced case. I don't think I would want to go further than that." Perhaps Stella Rimington will enlighten us further in her forthcoming memoirs. Somehow, I doubt it.  Shoot to Kill, the second part of Peter Taylor's series, Brits, will be shown tomorrow night on BBC2 at 9.30pm.

webTitle: Psion boss fights on against share option tax bills

fields.headline: Psion boss fights on against share option tax bills
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: David Potter, the chairman of Psion, one of the country's leading hi-tech manufacturers, is to continue lobbying government for lower tax charges on stock options despite last week's softening in the Inland Revenue's stance.
fields.body:
David Potter, the chairman of Psion, one of the country's leading hi-tech manufacturers, is to continue lobbying government for lower tax charges on stock options despite last week's softening in the Inland Revenue's stance.

Mr Potter - who led the push for the recent change because he feared stifling the burgeoning e-economy - welcomed the government's response to some of the industry's concerns but said that it was still burdening entrepreneurs with a "quite onerous" tax bill.

The changes announced late on Friday would still leave employees facing a 47.5% tax charge when they exercised any options over shares, he said, which was still "quite high" in comparison with other countries.

Until Friday it was the companies themselves that faced the bill for the national insurance contribution for employees when they exercised share options - an increasingly common form of remuneration for start-up companies.

After last week's announcement, the company can now shift the tax charge to each employee, provided they agree, and each will also receive new tax relief allowing them to offset any national insurance contribution against the income tax on the share options gains, which will reduce the overall tax rate to some 47.5%.

Previously the overall tax bill would have 52.5% - consisting of 40% income tax and 12.5% national insurance.

The decision to shift the tax burden to the employee is helping to address the issue for start-up firms which have irregular cashflows, making it difficult for them to account for potential tax charges, Mr Potter said.

But he intends carrying on campaigning for an overhaul of the way the share options are treated for tax purposes.

He said that the core of his argument would be for lower tax charges which at the same time reward employees who retain their shares in the firm once the options have been exercised.

Using the situation in France as an example, Mr Potter said he would argue for a regime where employees are not taxed when they exercise the options but when they sell shares. They should then be charged capital gains tax - at rates which would reward them for holding on to the shares in the company for, say, two years after they were exercised.

webTitle: UN fears soldiers murdered by rebels

fields.headline: UN fears soldiers murdered by rebels
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: The decomposing bodies of at least six United Nations peacekeepers believed to have been murdered by rebels have been discovered in Sierra Leone.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Freetown, Michael Ellison in New York and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The decomposing bodies of at least six United Nations peacekeepers believed to have been murdered by rebels have been discovered in Sierra Leone.

The dead soldiers - wearing Nigerian, Zambian and Kenyan uniforms with UN patches - are believed to have been among about 500 peacekeepers abducted by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) earlier this month.

The apparent cold-blooded killing of some of the remaining 280 hostages in rebel hands will reinforce pressure for a military solution.

It comes on the eve of a key meeting in which British ministers are expected to agree to rearm the Sierra Leone army.

Vice admiral Ian Garnett, the chief of joint operations at the Ministry of Defence, told journalists on board HMS Ocean, one of the eight British warships off the coast of Sierra Leone: "It is very important to give them as much support as we can, to build up an effective force to take on the rebels."

He added: "We will have to consider other measures that the government of Sierra Leone has requested and see whether we can help them in the field of logistics, ammunition and perhaps other weapons."

Ministers are poised to send in 600 marine commandos to replace the 700 paratroopers who have been securing the area in and around Freetown and Lungi airport.

In London, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said the gov ernment was considering a request for arms from President Ahmad Kabbah "very carefully".

Clare Short, the international development secretary, said: "Anyone who wishes Sierra Leone a decent future with a proper democracy and security has to think about how the international community are going to help it to have properly equipped and trained armed forces so that security can be maintained."

In New York, the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, proposed strengthening the peacekeeping force to 16,500 from 13,000, and said it might have to be raised even further.

In a report to the security council, he said it might wish to consider toughening existing arms and other sanctions against the RUF to prevent them from "reaping the benefits of their illegal exploitation of mineral resources, in particular diamonds".

Mr Annan said it was clear that the RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, who is in the custody of the Sierra Leone authorities, had failed to take any action to prevent or curb the actions of his troops.

"On the contrary, there is some evidence that he may well have encouraged, if not planned, some of these acts [taking of the hostages]. The international community should hold Mr Sankoh accountable for his actions and those of [the] RUF, and for the safety and well-being of all those who have been detained," Mr Annan said.

The corpses believed to be UN peacekeepers were discovered at a UN post by government soldiers on Sunday, shortly after taking the town of Rogberi from the rebels. The fact that the victims have been dead for some time, while fighting only spread to the town in recent days, points to their killing by the RUF, which had complete control of the area beforehand.

Lying beside the skeletons was a UN helmet with a bullet hole in it.

The UN last night said it could not confirm the dead men were its peacekeepers but that it was launching an investigation. Although the RUF has used the uniforms of captured peacekeepers to try and infiltrate government lines, the discovery of a Zambian passport and an identity document points to the victims being genuine peacekeepers.

Paul Barnett, a freelance photographer who arrived at the scene with government troops, said: "It looks as if they didn't know what was going to happen. There is one body with the legs hanging in the trench as if he was just sitting there. Maybe they were taken by surprise."

fields.headline: Blairs' babe
fields.standfirst:
Premier takes two weeks off to help mind the baby

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair made a mild u-turn yesterday when he announced that he would take two weeks' paternity leave to care for his new son Leo.
fields.body:
Tony Blair made a mild u-turn yesterday when he announced that he would take two weeks' paternity leave to care for his new son Leo.

After insisting for months that he would remain on duty after the birth, Mr Blair handed over most of the reins of power to his deputy, John Prescott, who will take this week's prime minister's questions and chair Thursday's meeting of the cabinet.

Mr Blair will remain on standby for emergencies in Northern Ireland and Sierra Leone, and will return to his desk on Tuesday June 6 after the Whitsun break. He will have his weekly audience with the Queen this evening.

The announcement came as Downing Street released the first photographs of the Blairs with their baby son. They were taken in Downing Street on Sunday by Mary McCartney, daughter of the Beatle Sir Paul, who was chosen by Cherie Blair.

One photograph was made available free to the media. A further 14 were available for £500 each, with the proceeds going to two charities of which Mrs Blair is patron - Breast Cancer Care and Sargent Cancer Care for Children.

The greatest interest came from Japan, Germany and the United States. The Downing Street website crashed as people tried to view the picture of Leo.

When the Blairs leave for Chequers, possibly on Thursday or Friday, TV cameras will be allowed to film Leo for the first time.

fields.headline: Shoot-to-kill evidence destroyed
fields.standfirst:
Freedom of information: special report

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: MI5 officers destroyed a secret tape containing potentially vital evidence of murder in an episode at the centre of "shoot-to-kill" allegations in Northern Ireland, the Guardian can reveal today.
fields.body:
MI5 officers destroyed a secret tape containing potentially vital evidence of murder in an episode at the centre of "shoot-to-kill" allegations in Northern Ireland, the Guardian can reveal today.

Despite a recommendation from a senior British police officer investigating the allegations that the MI5 officers should be prosecuted for perverting the course of justice, ministers agreed to cover up the evidence in "the public interest".

Michael Tighe, a 17-year-old with no IRA connections, was shot dead and his friend, Martin McCauley, 19, was seriously wounded by RUC anti-terrorist officers in a hayshed a few miles from Lurgan, county Armagh, in October 1982.

John Stalker, Manchester's deputy chief constable, who was appointed to head an inquiry into this and other "shoot to kill" allegations, discovered that the hayshed had been bugged.

He was told the tape that would have answered the crucial question at the trial - was McCauley right in claiming he and Tighe were given no warning before they were shot? - had been destroyed.

What he did not know was that a copy had been taken by a soldier from the army's special collation team monitoring the MI5 bug.

Its existence is disclosed in Shoot to Kill, the second in Peter Taylor's series, Brits, to be broadcast on BBC 2 tomorrow night. A number of special collation team soldiers and MI5 officers heard the copy of the tape before it was destroyed. Most heard no warning, contrary to RUC claims. When senior MI5 officers in Northern Ireland found out about the tape, they ordered it to be destroyed.

Mr Stalker was removed from his inquiry in controversial circumstances and was replaced by Colin Sampson, chief constable of west Yorkshire. His report, like Mr Stalker's, is secret, though it is known he recommended the prosecution of RUC officers for fabricating cover stories.

What is not known is that Mr Sampson said MI5 officers should be charged for destroying the copy of the crucial tape. Mr Sampson and Sir Barry Shaw, Northern Ireland's director of public prosecutions, were prepared to have the evidence exposed in court.

The prospect of damning charges against MI5 activities was too much for Sir Patrick Mayhew, the then attorney general, and Tom King, then Northern Ireland secretary, to contemplate. "A lot of intelligence matters would have been brought out that would have been deleterious to the intelligence operation that was essential in the circumstances," Sir Patrick tells the BBC.

Sir Robert Andrew, permanent secretary at the Northern Ireland Office at the time, discovered that a copy of the tape had been made and then destroyed by reading the Sampson report.

He says: "There was an argument for saying that prosecutions should have been brought to clear the air and to demonstrate that the government was not covering up illegal activities. On the other hand, there was a fear that if police officers, and even more so, officers from the security service, were put in the dock and had to answer questions on oath, intelligence-gathering methods and the identity of individuals would have become known and prejudiced [their] effectiveness".

Sir Robert says his then political master, Tom King, judged that a prosecution was "undesirable".

webTitle: Gielgud exits quietly after 79 years of genius

fields.headline: Gielgud exits quietly after 79 years of genius
fields.trailText: Sir John Gielgud, the peerless verse speaker of 450 years of British theatre and one of its two greatest Shakespearean performers, has died, aged 96.
fields.body:
Sir John Gielgud, the peerless verse speaker of 450 years of British theatre and one of its two greatest Shakespearean performers, has died, aged 96.

His end came "simply of old age" at his home near Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire, on Sunday, 79 years after his first London stage appearance.

His last performance, filmed just weeks ago, was for Samuel Beckett's play Catastrophe, part of a marathon Channel Four and RTE-funded project to film all the playwright's works.

Yesterday's tributes to the actor were suffused with awe and regret at the passing of an unprecedently long-active genius, the last of a group of titanic actors who graced theatres for much of the 20th century.

The National Theatre director, Trevor Nunn, and the actor Corin Redgrave reached for epitaphs from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra to do him justice.

Nunn said: "There's a great spirit gone." Redgrave - whose father, Sir Michael, was deeply influenced by Gielgud - said: "The odds is gone/ And there is nothing left remarkable beneath the visiting moon."

Immediate reaction to the news was more profound than for his great contemporary and lifelong rival Lord Olivier's death 11 years ago.

As recently as the 1990s, he played an outstanding radio Hamlet, a part he first played on stage in the 1920s in what a critic then called "the highwater mark of acting in our time".

His former agent Laurence Evans, who also represented Olivier and Sir Ralph Richardson, said: "I suppose that, of the three, Sir John was really the greatest actor."

The stage director Peter Brook said that comparisons "could not matter less. His one aim was to reach the highest level of quality. And the word went very deep. It was in his blood. This very endearing, lovable man touched everyone by this purity in him, which was reflected in his work." The playwright Christopher Fry, 92, said the magnificence of Gielgud's verse speaking as Richard ll in 1929 "released something in me" which helped him write plays. "Olivier was the greater comedian but Gielgud was greater as a tragic actor," he said.

Cicely Berry, the Royal Shakespeare Company's voice director, said: "We live in an age when we talk minimally to each other. We have television on and the internet. Yet we still have these big feelings inside us. There is something in us which responds to cadence and makes us want to listen.

"He had the gift of entering into language and taking us into another world."

webTitle: The all-expenses paid lifestyle of union leader Roger Lyons (down to the 25p bun)

fields.headline: The all-expenses paid lifestyle of union leader Roger Lyons (down to the 25p bun)
fields.trailText: From the time Roger Lyons wakes up to listen to the Today programme to his last glass of wine at night, the expenses meter is running for his 700,000 members .
fields.body:
From the time Roger Lyons wakes up to listen to the Today programme to his last glass of wine at night, the expenses meter is running for his 700,000 members .

The extraordinary expense account lifestyle of trade union leader Roger the Dodger - the jokey name given to him by colleagues - is revealed today in a series of confidential documents obtained by the Guardian.

The papers have come to light because of a bitter internal row inside the Manufacturing, Science and Finance (MSF) white collar union over the lifestyle of Mr Lyons. At the centre are disputes with senior colleagues over nearly £10,000 of purchases on the union's credit cards and almost £4,000 of other disputed expenses. Mr Lyons - who earns £68,000 a year and gets an additional £15,000 for serving on the monopolies and mergers commission - has been accused of running up thousands of pounds of expense claims by the former assistant general secretary John Chowcatt, who left the union with a £250,000 settlement. The union's accountants investigated and cleared Mr Lyons of any wrongdoing. He was allowed to spend £6,366.70 on hotels and meals over nine months. Out of another £2,757.90, described as sustenance, £877 was spent near his Finchley home in takeaway restaurants and off licences.

One trade union colleague said: "They are not huge sums in themselves but if it happens on a daily basis it soon mounts up."

Mr Lyons has also submitted bills for office equipment - a total of £1,869.10 - which cover everything from the purchase of batteries to internet services, radios, video recorders and a briefcase.

His day begins with listening to the Today programme on a union-bought radio in his bathroom at 6.30am.

He told the Guardian: "My wife hates hearing the Today programme when we are in bed. I could listen to our own radio with earphones - but it is not very satisfactory so I go into the bathroom to hear the programme on the union's radio."

Leather briefcase

Then, if he has time, he will watch TV programmes on the union-provided video recorder (£169.99 from Curry's), recorded so as not to disturb the family. Finally, he will check the internet (installed and serviced for £777 by the union), which is also used by the family.

He then puts his papers in his leather briefcase (bought by the union from Selfridges for £89) and is driven by his chauffeur to work. (His former driver, Brian Keegan, is taking the union to a tribunal for thousands of pounds of unpaid overtime for driving Mr Lyons).

At his central London offices, the union has a strategy meeting at which tea, coffee and biscuits are normally provided. But Mr Lyons regularly claims expenses for "sustenance" - claims which reached £371.45 between January 5 1997 and September 19 1998. The unreceipted claims varied from £4 to £18.50 - and Mr Lyons justified them by saying that he might have to talk to the press afterwards.

Occasionally, meetings might be required with MSF's parliamentary colleagues - and again both food and drink are often provided by the union. But Mr Lyons also puts in claims for those, from £2.50 to £11.40. He says this is because he had to go to the Commons Strangers Bar - and pass cash to MPs to buy him a drink - which is why no receipts are available.

Meetings with Tony Blair and Gordon Brown ,who regularly supply tea and coffee and even the odd biscuit and sandwich, also led to sustenance claims from Mr Lyons. Ten meetings led to a claim of £64.15, with bills varying from £4 for seeing Tony Blair to £19.65 for a meeting with Gordon Brown.

"Of course, they do provide coffee, but if they are in the evening I would go and have a bite and a pint at the Red Lion in Whitehall afterwards," Mr Lyons told the Guardian.

On other evenings it could be an interview with the BBC at Millbank or ITN. Total unreceipted expenses for these appearances, where refreshments are usually provided, came to £174.95.

And then there were the mid-morning snacks - right down to a claim on his credit card for a 25p bun from Patisserie Valerie in Soho.

webTitle: Wetting the baby's head - not with water cannon

fields.headline: Wetting the baby's head - not with water cannon
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: It was exciting to guess which MP would get in first with a tribute to the Blair baby. In the event, surprisingly, it was Dennis Skinner who scored, just 10 minutes into the session.
fields.body:
It was exciting to guess which MP would get in first with a tribute to the Blair baby. In the event, surprisingly, it was Dennis Skinner who scored, just 10 minutes into the session.

This was rough luck on the original Blair babes (male and female), for whom the ultimate fantasy might involve Tony Blair changing their nappy.

It took some subtlety to work the subject of Baby Leo into a discussion on police numbers during Home Office questions. Both sides were massaging fake statistics with the enthusiasm of a Kobe beef farmer tenderising his cows.

Then Gerald Howarth of Aldershot got up to complain about the protest by Eritreans which has been blocking Whitehall in the past few days.

"Central London has been paralysed. We have been unable to get to work because of a whole load of foreigners who have been blocking Whitehall, and we cannot work because of the noise of the police helicopter overhead," he said.

"If you cannot find the police, perhaps you can find some water cannon to cope with the problem," he said to happy jeers from the Labour benches.

The home secretary responded mildly that he didn't think water cannon would be entirely suitable, since there were women and children involved in the demonstration.

You could see the Tories snorting. All right, why not water cannon for the men, water pistols for the children, and a bracing passion fruit and pumice douche for the ladies?

Oliver Letwin, a Tory frontbencher, heaven preserve us, wanted to know why so many violent criminals were being released early. Did Mr Straw remember a time when even the Kray twins would have thought twice about assaulting a police officer?

This maniacally sentimental notion of the Kray brothers as custodians of traditional etiquette is spreading.

"Say what you like, when the Krays were running things, you could always drive straight down Whitehall. They was good boys, they only killed each other - and them Eritreans of course..."

Then Dennis Skinner rose. "As for that violence in Whitehall, I was very seriously mistaken, because when I spotted them, I thought they were queueing up to see the baby."

Not a very gracious tribute, perhaps, but in Skinner terms as florid and emotional as the hero's proposal of marriage in a novel by the late Barbara Cartland.

Jack Straw happily picked up the lavender gauntlet. "I'm sure all of us would wish to congratulate the prime minister and his wife, and those of us of a certain age can only say that we're glad it's him and not us."

Ann Widdecombe changed the subject to asylum seekers.

The Tories have decided that this topic is a vote winner, and Miss Widdecombe has adopted the Hague technique of asking very simple questions to which she already knows the answer. How many of the 37 asylum seekers left behind after the Stansted hijacking were still here, she inquired.

"Oh, for God's sake," Jack Straw interjected. Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, barked that Ms Widdecombe knew perfectly well that all 37 were still here. Was she proposing that they should be slung out of the country without due process?

There is a certain grisly symmetry between the two front benches now. The Tories think they're winning votes by being harsh. Labour frontbenchers suddenly realise that for the first time in the past three years, the Tories now make them look caring and compassionate by comparison.

webTitle: Straw forced to defend Tyson decision

fields.headline: Straw forced to defend Tyson decision
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: The home secretary was yesterday forced to defend his decision to allow Mike Tyson back into Britain, as the promoters of the boxer's June 24th bout in Glasgow claimed it would be the biggest and most lucrative staged in the UK.
fields.body:
The home secretary was yesterday forced to defend his decision to allow Mike Tyson back into Britain, as the promoters of the boxer's June 24th bout in Glasgow claimed it would be the biggest and most lucrative staged in the UK.

Responding to criticism in the Commons, Jack Straw said he had looked at a number of issues before coming to his decision on the boxer's visa request.

"It is my responsibility to make these decisions on the law as it exists," he said. "The simple fact of the matter is that this particular immigration rule had been observed mainly in the breach rather than in the observance.

"Above all I had to take account of whether in this particular case Mr Tyson's entry would pose a risk to the public and on the basis of the history of this application and the need for fairness and consistency I took the decision that I did."

Mr Straw said he had laid before the house a consultative document proposing changes in the immigration rules and their more consistent application in the future.

Earlier Maria Fyfe (Glasgow Maryhill) used parliamentary privilege during question time to make accusations that one of the promoters of the bout has a violent criminal past.

Without naming the promoter Mrs Fyfe asked whether Mr Straw had considered the policing requirements needed for the fight. She added: "Are you aware that one of the promoters of this fight has a violent criminal past and has connections with Glasgow's criminal underworld?"

Senior Labour backbencher David Winnick urged Mr Straw to reconsider his decision.

"What sort of message is it if a convicted rapist like Tyson is allowed into the United Kingdom?" he asked. "Are you aware that it is men as well as women who are deeply opposed to allowing him in? I hope you will understand the feelings on this side at least and reconsider your decision."

Meanwhile, at a press conference in Glasgow, promoter Frank Warren said the bout against Lou Savarese at Hampden Park would probably be the biggest fight to be held in the UK in financial and audience terms.

He said it would be staged at 11pm before a sell-out audience of around 58,000 people, and would be televised to millions more in 180 countries worldwide.

Nearly 20,000 applications had come in even before the box office number had been announced, he said.

Mr Warren was accompanied at the press conference by Jimmy Wray, MP for Glasgow Baillieston, who has described Scots parliamentarians as "a bunch of cackling geese" for criticising Mr Straw's decision.

Mr Wray said he was delighted the fight was coming to Scotland. "Does Hampden not need the money? Does Glasgow not need the money?" he said.

Mr Wray also described the offence for which Tyson was convicted as "a misdemeanour" but, when questioned about that description, withdrew it and said: "It is a serious offence. If I used the word misdemeanour I did not mean to belittle it."

Women's groups will meet in Glasgow today to discuss whether to seek a judicial review of Mr Straw's decision.

fields.headline: Bringing up baby
fields.standfirst:
Little Leo is unaware of his political role but he'll notice, eventually, that his life is not like other kids'

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Oooh, isn't it sweet? The nation goes soft-hearted over the picture: don't they look exhausted? doesn't he look such a sweetie? Cherie's kohl-ringed eyes are luminous with that new mother's mixture of ecstatic relief and febrile tiredness. Tony plays the suitably modest supporting role of the new father: arms tenderly around Cherie after her ordeal. It is an iconic picture of marital harmony and fecundity which cannot but have a political resonance way beyond the intimate moment in which Mary McCartney seems to have almost accidentally disturbed the happy trio.
fields.body:
Oooh, isn't it sweet? The nation goes soft-hearted over the picture: don't they look exhausted? doesn't he look such a sweetie? Cherie's kohl-ringed eyes are luminous with that new mother's mixture of ecstatic relief and febrile tiredness. Tony plays the suitably modest supporting role of the new father: arms tenderly around Cherie after her ordeal. It is an iconic picture of marital harmony and fecundity which cannot but have a political resonance way beyond the intimate moment in which Mary McCartney seems to have almost accidentally disturbed the happy trio.

The only person who is totally oblivious to the image's significance is little Leo himself. As any parent knows, all a new baby wants to do is feed, scream and (hopefully) sleep - and that can be done as easily in Downing Street as anywhere else.

So, Leo will be shuffled about from weekends in Chequers and back to central London with the odd visit to the Sedgefield constituency, yet all he will be interested in is the proximity and frequency of his access to Cherie's breast.

And there lies the first political crisis that poor Blair junior will unwittingly provoke. Will Cherie or won't she? Given that the government launched a major advertising campaign on the merits of breastfeeding only last week, it will go down very badly with health experts if such a high-profile role model as Cherie passes up on breastfeeding.

Not only is it better for the baby's health, but many experts claim is that it is in those unhurried, relaxed breastfeeding sessions that the mother-child bond is properly developed.

But what this baby is likely to experience from the start is the hectic pace of the unusual family into which he has been born. It is hard to imagine daddy not being understandably preoccupied with the Irish peace process when Leo tentatively tries to smile. It is hard to see quite how Cherie squeezes in teenage kids, a husband worried about his collapsing position in the polls, her own work and the baby.

The sheer frenetic pace of the Blair family life cannot but affect this new arrival. He will be celebrating his first birthday close to or just after the next election: does that mean sightings of mummy and daddy suddenly shrink to a glimpse as they dash in or out of the door?

The potency permeating the Blair family and home which even a small child must surely perceive (just look at how people treat daddy) cannot but inflate the child's own sense of importance in the world. Faces they recognise from Number 10's hall - even the next door neighbour - will reappear all over the newspapers and the television.

When the child decides the best spot for a bit of indoor footie is the hall, he'll bump into cabinet ministers, not to mention Vladimir or old-time mates like Uncle Bill and Senator Hillary.

The baby's arrival is being compared with that of Princes William and Harry or that of Brooklyn in that other royal family. Yes, there is a comparable media fascination, but beyond that the similarities peter out. From the start, the two princes were surrounded by an effective wall of courtiers adept at protecting the royal family and inculcating in them an inescapable ethic of duty as part of their birthright.

This baby will not have the protection of a royal household or an elaborate system of royal etiquette. Issues such as does the media get a picture on his first day of school will have a whole set of complicated political implications - is Mr Blair trying to boost his profile?

Then there is the uncertainty of it all; William and Harry didn't have to consider the possibility of being chucked out of their childhood home by an election. From being one of the most famous four-year-olds in the world, this baby could disappear into oblivion. Suddenly, he could wake up to discover that chauffeured cars are not always waiting, that there isn't always a policeman to open the door and that crowds of tourists (or demonstrators) don't always stand around gawping at you and your family.

Of course other children have lived in Downing Street - most obviously, Leo's older siblings. In 1908, Elizabeth and Anthony Asquith aged 11 and five moved in with Pa Herbert. It didn't do them any damage; Elizabeth went on to marry a prince and wrote poetry and plays, while Anthony became a respected film director. The difference between all of them and this new baby was that at least they had an inkling of a life outside the fishbowl of Number 10 before they moved in.

Disturbingly, the closest parallel is that of the Kennedys: little Caroline and John fascinated the nation as they toddled in and out of the Oval Office. They became, along with their beautiful, clever mother, a crucial part of the political message of Kennedy's presidency.

Whether Cherie likes it or not (and there seems to be evidence of a bit of both) she and this baby are destined to play a similar role in Tony's prime ministership at the next election. We'll have to wait many years to hear this baby's verdict on his own contribution to the New Labour project.

webTitle: The folly built by our leaders that makes fools of us all

fields.headline: The folly built by our leaders that makes fools of us all
fields.standfirst:
It was going to make a statement for the nation. So how do we look?

Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome is out of sight. Down there in Greenwich, it's a long way from being in your face, even for most Londoners. For the nation, on whose children the prime minister once said the dome should confer "memories so strong that it gives them that abiding sense of purpose and unity that stays with them through the rest of their lives", it could be on another planet. But let memory speak, before the monster goes. It has been the most particular and incontestable folly of our time.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is out of sight. Down there in Greenwich, it's a long way from being in your face, even for most Londoners. For the nation, on whose children the prime minister once said the dome should confer "memories so strong that it gives them that abiding sense of purpose and unity that stays with them through the rest of their lives", it could be on another planet. But let memory speak, before the monster goes. It has been the most particular and incontestable folly of our time.

The physical distance assists the political amnesia. It's hard to find any politician who will talk about the dome now. Lord Falconer shuffles forward to mutter about an exit strategy, while Chris Smith is compelled, as a coda to the disaster the government set in train, to pour another £29m of lottery money down the Greenwich drain, the better to ensure that this exit, selling off the asset for a fraction of what was put into it, can duly happen. The announcement is as blithe as it is insulting. Otherwise, what's past is past, we're told. Time to move on. Time to talk about Tate Modern, an altogether superior monument built from the pockets of the poor who finance the lottery. The dome? Forget it.

This request I cannot meet. Somehow boredom wouldn't measure up. There was such grandeur here that slinking silently away would do an injustice to history. And history was the frame. Greenwich is the home of time, the government said. This was why Britain had a special duty to put on a millennial event that would lead the world and startle all who came from the ends of the earth to see it. The dome would "make a statement for the whole nation," said Mr Blair. It was the way for us "to take stock of ourselves". How, by that test, do we look?

The amount of lottery money consumed on the dome is closing in on £550m. Only half the expected audience have so far been willing to pay out of their own pockets for the experience. For this financial failure, they themselves, the British and global public, are to blame. Damn the punters, they inexplicably found better things to do. So the first thing we look, as a nation, is culpable. We let our prophets down. We didn't do what we were told.

But this was because we were not properly informed. The public is one scapegoat, the media are another. Asked a few awkward questions, Michael Heseltine, who can be called the dome's first begetter, was anticipating this before the money had been spent. "It's virtually impossible," he said, "to do anything in this country of any imagination without the media trying to vilify and ruin it." He was highlighting another national defect. We are apparently credulous in overlooking a brilliant creation just because a bunch of malign journalists tell us to. Or so the minister said. These are insignificant alibis for the truth. They spread the blame for the humiliating embarrassment the dome has become, so that we are all somehow guilty. Yet there has never been a project that grew so particularly and exclusively out of the preoccupations of the political class, irrespective of party, and the self-glorifying inanity in which its leaders are capable of collaborating as long as someone else pays.

The dome began as a Tory project, the last resounding belch of a dying regime. Promoted by the grandiloquent Heseltine and seized on by the cringing Mr Major, father of the lottery, it was supervised in the early stages by Virginia Bottomley and cheer-led by a variety of architects and propagandists with their own half-baked ideological, not to mention commercial, agenda for this way of proclaiming national greatness past and future - an assertion no other nation in the world felt that 2000 AD required it to make.

An additional rationale was proposed, concerning the renewal of poisoned land on the Greenwich peninsular. But it was never explained why this could be achieved only by the erection of a white elephant consuming, in all, £800m. History, and politics, were at the heart of it. Tories, when drawn into a discussion of their part, still contend that if a thousand years of history had remained the millennial motif, a triumph was guaranteed. It was New Labour's obsession with modernity, they say, that confused an otherwise flawless project.

But New Labour was on board before the Tories' fall. The consensus was all but sealed. Given the chance in May 1997 to act like a new regime, unneedful of hyperbole, Mr Blair decided he couldn't let the old, dead, corrupted one outflank him in nationalistic display, however pointless. Nobody ever answered the question about what the dome was for, except for that. Miles of verbiage and armies of consultants, up to the very millennial moment, addressed the question of content and purpose, but none was able to improve on Heseltine's best shot: "It's going to be quite wonderful but don't ask me how". They still can't. Made manifest before our eyes, the dome declared its irretrievable emptiness.

Many political projects turn out to be less than perfect. Most, indeed, can never hope to succeed in anything but a contingent and partial way. There are always more schools to build and patients to cure. For that reason the political rhetoric attaching to them is almost meant to be taken with a shovelful of salt. The level of pretension is understood to be an aspiration, the money available for its fulfilment is always inadequate. Blaming politicians for their failure is often a ritual that they can deflect with earnest remarks about the sincerity of their efforts. And besides, there's always another party, putting them to the question.

The dome is a different case. Normal lines of responsibility do not exist. It was built with funny money, for which nobody is accountable. The Treasury would never have countenanced tax money being used. No business could have defended such folly to its shareholders. Lottery money, falling outside either discipline, was made available as a plaything for egotistical wasters who invented a national purpose that did not exist. Not a little matter of a few million, either, but a donation of colossal magnitude, deployed by the same people who decided it should be handed out: people of all parties with their fingers in the trough of self-indulgence, leaving none with hands clean enough to do the ensuing scandal justice.

What one misses here is the faintest semblance of regret. No whisper have I heard, from the principals or their auxiliaries, that they may have been responsible for a mistake. Apology seems out of the question. When not whimpering a few resentful words that miss the point, they are silent. They're moving on. The dome was yesterday. Just another well-meaning blip in the awkward lives of politicians committed to national renewal. But it wasn't. It was an avoidable idiocy, which leaves Britain looking like a nation led astray by profligate, self- regarding philistines.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Delectable damsels
fields.trailText: Delectable damsels
fields.body:
Cheshire
One of the earliest damselflies to appear each year in Cheshire is the Large Red Damselfly, which can often be found close to its favourite damp habitat at the end of April. Once on the wing this species has the longest flight period of any of the county's damselflies, extending through the summer months into early autumn, being at its peak in June and July. I disturbed two of these fragile insects from some low reeds at the edge of a small marl pit on rough grassland on the early date of April 26 this year. A week later I came across more in several of the ponds and pits on the same site, fluttering weakly from stem to stem in the edge vegetation. The damselflies are a smaller, much more delicate version of the true-dragonflies, although both are in the same insect order, Odonata, meaning "toothed", which relates to their carnivorous lifestyle. Much folklore has been built up around these insects, especially the true-dragonflies with such names as "horse-stingers" - maybe because of the latters' large size, swift flight, and the occasional rustling of their wings as they swoop about. However, both are harmless and stingless, and in fact perform a great deal of good for the comfort of we humans by keeping down the numbers of mosquitoes and other small irritating flies which make up the bulk of their diet. There are a number of features that help to separate the two groups but usually close observation is required, which is not always easy to achieve. Probably the simplest guide is to watch them at rest - the damselfly will hold its wings together over its back, while the true-dragonfly spreads its wings out flat, away from the body. The fine weather during the first half of May was ideal for the emergence of the damselfly, and back in the valley, the woodlands have been looking at their best as all the spring flowers reach their peak and the tree canopy starts to filter the sunlight across a dazzling carpet of colour. At the edge of a roadside copse above the northern woods, my favourite plant of early summer has just started to open - the bogbean, a survivor of the lost flora of our drained mosslands.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Would you believe it, the Diary has carried something that may qualify as what the editor sometimes wistfully refers to as a "story". How it slipped through the net it's a bit early to say, but on Friday we reported that Andrew Fulton of Glasgow University's Lockerbie trial briefing unit had a lively career in MI6 behind him for someone interpreting a case with obvious intelligence overtones for the world's media. This unease has been shared by the unit's director Professor John Grant, it appears, who has now suspended Prof Fulton, despite declaring: "I have no personal knowledge of any connection between Andrew Fulton and the British intelligence service." Another unit member, Prof Fraser Davidson, tells us: "As far as I was aware he was a diplomat - I have to confess I didn't enquire too closely into his background." Perhaps not, but with such a sensitive case you should have done. In future, professors, you really must follow that old Diary maxim: check, check and check again ... and then go back and check some more!

On the back of "xcity", house bulletin of the City University journalism course, the Mirror woos young talent with a full page advert, headlined "A great history, a great future". Challenged to illustrate the history bit by picking four historic front pages from the 20th century, the advertising department did superbly. Picture one is the sinking of the Titanic, "Hitler dead" is the headline on the second, and the third screams "Kennedy assassinated". But what for the fourth? Man on the moon? Fall of the Berlin Wall? Death of Diana? No. "Cherie is pregnant" wins the day. You just can't beat a bit of historical perspective, can you?

Speaking of which, we return to Glasgow for news of local MP and boxing fan Jimmy Wray, who has expressed his joy about Mike Tyson's imminent visit. Jimmy, who once had a lively Labour conference encounter with my friend Dolly Draper (Dolly had had a few, and repeatedly told Jimmy to listen to what he had to say because "I'm the man who makes the policy"), is thrilled that Mr Tyson has chosen the city for his swift knock out of that huge name in world sport, Lou Saverese. The fight will, Jimmy assured listeners to Radio 5 Live, be "one of the historical events in Scottish history." Indeed, indeed.

What an amazingly natural man Mr Tony is. One minute he's in Downing Street ruthlessly invading his three elder children's privacy by parading that mug, the next he makes a point of buying the Big Issue outside Westminster Cathedral, naturally unaware that the odd camera might be following him on the day after the baby's birth. Sooooo spontaneous! Sources in Downing Street refuse to confirm, meanwhile, that a pullover specially treated with dried baby sick is being kept in the press office safe in readiness for all future media engagements.

The deconstruction of my sensitive friend Steve Glover's latest column in the Spectator is complete and the major finding is this: in a column of about 900 words, the words "I", "me" and "my" appear on 26 occasions. Amazing. Could it possibly be that Steve (or Mimi, as he may now be known ) is seeking to reassure himself that he remains a figure to be respected in this business, despite so poignantly brief a spell as editor of the Independent on Sunday? He must be helped to put that trauma behind him and achieve "closure". But how? That's the question. How?

An ironist of potential emerges at cup-winning Chelsea, home of football's best known Guardian reader, Graeme Le Saux. It is Graeme's colleague Roberto di Matteo, the Italian midfielder. "That's a very intelligent question," replied Roberto on Saturday afternoon when asked by a Sky sports reporter if it felt good to score the winning goal at Wembley. In the FA Cup final.

webTitle: Transport companies face new law of corporate killing

fields.headline: Transport companies face new law of corporate killing
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: A new crime of corporate killing is to be created by the home secretary. Jack Straw will announce today the move to make companies criminally accountable for deaths which are the result of gross negligence.
fields.body:
A new crime of corporate killing is to be created by the home secretary. Jack Straw will announce today the move to make companies criminally accountable for deaths which are the result of gross negligence.

For the first time directors of rail and shipping companies could find themselves in the Old Bailey dock if it is shown that transport disasters are the direct result of corporate conduct far below what could be reasonably expected.

It will be enough to show that there was a management failure for a company to be responsible even if the immediate cause was the act of an individual member of staff.

The decision follows years of campaigning by families who have lost relatives in disasters such as the Paddington and Southall rail crashes and repeated rulings that companies could not be prosecuted for manslaughter by gross negligence because it has proved impossible to establish the guilt of a named individual.

Mr Straw is understood to want to go further than the recommendations of the law commission which first advised the government to create the offence as long ago as 1995. The commission recommended that there should be a special offence of corporate killing which was broadly similar to the individual crime of killing by gross negligence.

It said that corporate killing could only be committed in cases where it was demonstrated that the defendant's conduct fell far below what could reasonably be expected. The commission added that, unlike the individual offence of killing by gross negligence, it did not have to be proved that the risk was obvious to the company or that the company was capable of appreciating the risk.

The commission also said it should be enough to prove the new crime of corporate killing if it is caused by "a failure, in the way in which the corporation's activities are managed or organised, to ensure the health and safety of persons employed in or affected by those activities".

The offence will be limited to disasters that happen in areas where the English courts have jurisdiction and relatives of those who die will be able to bring private prosecutions.

Earlier this month, the DPP, David Calvert-Smith, said that the current law was insufficient to deal with culpable conduct. He wanted the new offence to bear down on the negligent treatment of empoyees in the workforce. His views came on the day on which the crown prosecution service announced it would take no further action over the 31 people who died in the Paddington rail disaster last October.

webTitle: Clinton is host with the most money

fields.headline: Clinton is host with the most money
fields.standfirst:
Investigative Reporters and Editors' Campaign Finance Information Center

The Whitehouse
fields.trailText: Even by the extravagant standards of modern American campaign finance, the Democratic party gala in Washington tomorrow night is expected to break all records as the biggest cash-guzzling event in US political fundraising history.
fields.body:
Even by the extravagant standards of modern American campaign finance, the Democratic party gala in Washington tomorrow night is expected to break all records as the biggest cash-guzzling event in US political fundraising history.

Last month George W Bush came to Washington and raised no less than $21.3m (£13m) in a single night at a Republican black-tie dinner. That achievement obliterated the previous record for a hard evening's fundraising, set by his father, former president George Bush, who pulled in $14m at a Republican "tribute" dinner in April last year.

Now, less than four weeks later, the Bushes are themselves about to become history. Fittingly, the man who will set the new level of single event fundraising achievement is also the man who is poised to become the first $1bn fundraiser in US political history: President Bill Clinton.

In the gods, high above the MCI Centre at tomorrow's "salute" to Mr Clinton and the vice-president, Al Gore, there will be room for ordinary Democratic party supporters who have paid $50 each to listen to speeches from Mr Clinton and entertainment from comedian Robin Williams and musicians Stevie Wonder and Lenny Kravitz.

But the people who matter will be the 15 to 20 supporters who have either raised or pledged more than $500,000 each for the same privilege, a select group of donors whose money has not only gained them prime seats tomorrow but also places at a pre-gala dinner with Mr Clinton and Mr Gore tonight, and who knows what other advantages.

These donors are not typically the entertainment stars and movie moguls whose company Mr Clinton so often seeks out. They are lower profiled people such as Daniel Abraham, head of the Slim-Fast low calorie food company, the Virginia property developer Claire Dwoskin, and Vinod Gupta, an internet entrepreneur from Nebraska, all of whom are good for a smooth half million.

It is said that Mr Clinton does not like to ask for money himself. So, orchestrating the proceedings will be the fundraiser Terry McAuliffe, the man who raised the funds to enable the Clintons to buy their new home in Chappaqua, New York, last year.

Mr McAuliffe's record is second to none. He was the chief organiser of the Clinton legal defence fund during the Lewinsky crisis, and in his spare time he is the chief fundraiser both for Mr Gore's presidential campaign and for Hillary Clinton's New York senate race, both of which are certain to set new records in their respective categories.

The Democratic fundraiser tomorrow adds the final touch to what could be Mr Clinton's most enduring legacy to US politics - as a political fundraiser without equal. Many insiders believe he has already brought in well over $500m for personal and party causes, and that he is now within touching distance of the $1bn mark.

"It's not even close to debatable that he has raised more money than any other figure in American political history," a senior Democrat told the New York Times recently.

During his second term alone, Mr Clinton has spoken at 350 fundraising events, ranging from party extravaganzas to smaller events on behalf of individual candidates and personal encounters with rich supporters.

In addition, he has encouraged controversial ways of marketing the presidency to raise money, including allowing big donors to stay overnight at the White House and to travel in Air Force One.

At the root of these activities is the perception that modern US elections - in which the candidates sometimes disagree about very little - can only be won by expensive television advertising paid for from large campaign war chests. This has meant that any pretensions Mr Clinton may have had as a political reformer have been set aside as he exploits his position to enable his party to compete with the Republicans, traditionally the party of big business.

"This is crazy greed, and it would be shameful if there was any shame left in this city," says Fred Wertheimer of Democracy 21, a reform group.

Mr Clinton, though, is unrepentant. Speaking at an event honouring Mr McAuliffe last year, he said: "Terry and I have never been of the school that believed that we ought to act embarrassed because we ask people in the system we have to contribute so that we could get our message across."

Since George W Bush, the Texas governor and Republican candidate, set his sights on the presidency, he has raised more than $81m. Last time round, in 1996, the unsuccessful Republican candidate Bob Dole raised only half as much, $42m, in his entire campaign.

 In the early 1980s, Monsignor James Horan, the priest in charge of the Catholic shrine at Knock in Ireland, shamed the Dublin government and commerical backers to raise £12m for a local airport built on a bog.
