webTitle: Straw promises to check on Rimington role in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Straw promises to check on Rimington role in Northern Ireland
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw yesterday promised to look into allegations surrounding the role in Northern Ireland of Dame Stella Rimington, the former MI5 chief at the centre of a row in Whitehall over her decision to write her memoirs.
fields.body:
Jack Straw yesterday promised to look into allegations surrounding the role in Northern Ireland of Dame Stella Rimington, the former MI5 chief at the centre of a row in Whitehall over her decision to write her memoirs.

The new twist in the controversy over MI5's past activities emerged in the House of Commons where the home secretary was asked about allegations relating to Dame Stella and the former MI5 officer, Michael Bettaney. The Labour MP, Tam Dalyell, asked Mr Straw: "Can you give a careful and considered look at the very serious allegations contained in this weekend's Sunday Times in relation to Mrs Rimington and Mr Michael Bettaney and, in particular, whether Mr Michael Bettaney was an alcoholic who had absolutely no business to be operating in the most sensitive areas of the security services of this country?"

The newspaper reported that an MI5 informant work ing with the IRA made a "colossal misjudgment" by keeping on Bettaney as his handler. Bettaney was subsequently jailed for passing secrets to the Russians.

Mr Straw told Mr Dalyell: "I will certainly look into the matter that you raise."

The Labour MP then told him: "Unlike you, I do bear a grudge and it's against Mrs Stella Rimington for what she did to the miners in 1984, abusing the security services."

Earlier, the home secretary told MPs that he did not bear a grudge against MI5 for investigating him during the 1970s as a suspected subversive.

"Events showed at the time, as they have since, that it was, generally speaking, a waste of public money.

"I would also say that if there is a responsibility for the fact that in any period of our history the activities of the security service have ranged more widely than they would do today, then that responsibility is ultimately with one of those ministers directly involved, namely the home secretary and the prime minister of the day, and not of those who are public servants."

Richard Dearlove, the chief of MI6, and Stephen Lander, head of MI5, are understood to have reacted angrily to Dame Stella's decision to write her memoirs, fearing it could lead to a flood of books by intelligence insiders.

 A laptop stolen from a senior naval officer contained sensitive information about plans for a new stealth fighter aircraft being developed by the US with British cooperation, the Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday.

It was taken from the officer as he sat on a train at London's Paddington station two weeks ago by a thief who is believed to have had no idea of its contents.

The Mirror newspaper said yesterday that the £2,000 computer came into its possession when it was contacted by a computer specialist who said a contact wanted to wipe a laptop of "fighter plane stuff". It returned the laptop to the ministry.

fields.headline: It was Hizbullah's day
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli air force was active over South Lebanon yesterday, but this time, instead of attacking Hizbullah bases, it bombarded abandoned Israeli and South Lebanon Army outposts.
fields.body:
The Israeli air force was active over South Lebanon yesterday, but this time, instead of attacking Hizbullah bases, it bombarded abandoned Israeli and South Lebanon Army outposts.

Here at Hule, one of the 12 villages that have fallen to Hizbullah in 24 hours, no one paid much attention when an Israeli outpost on a nearby hillside went up in smoke.

They were too busy celebrat ing their sudden liberation.

"It is 18 years since I set foot here," Adel Taher said as he sipped coffee in the home of relatives who had stayed put throughout the occupation. He was one of thousands, perhaps even tens of thousands, who headed south as soon as they heard the glad tidings yesterday morning.

Traffic jams formed on narrow roads which, until last night, had led through a dangerous no man's land. Along the route they were greeted by cheering crowds and doused with rose water. A few cars flew communist flags, others those of the Shi'ite party Amal, but for the overwhelming majority the only possible emblem was the clenched fist and Kalashnikov of Hizbullah.

It was Hizbullah's day. It had always vowed to drive out the "Zionist enemy" defeated, and in its book that was exactly what it was doing.

Israel's "security zone", established in 1978, was designed to put a buffer between Israel and Yasser Arafat's Palestinian guerrillas; since the 80s it has served the same purpose against the "Islamic resistance".

The Israelis always said they would never abandon the zone without security arrangements negotiated with Lebanon, including a settlement for the SLA - its proxy army - or the force's integration into the Lebanese army.

The zone is now falling apart. Its central sector disintegrated after its militiamen sought refuge in Israel or handed themselves over to Hizbullah or Lebanon's army. Its eastern and western sectors are cut off from each other.

Overnight Hizbullah has won complete access to the Israeli frontier - Hule is barely a mile away from the border. From Aadise, which fell a few hours later, the guerrillas have direct line of sight to the northern town of Kiryat Shmona.

Residents say that the Israelis had been surreptitiously thinning out some positions in recent weeks.

This so demoralised their SLA allies that they deserted en masse, with barely of drop of blood being shed.

At Hule, about 30 of them squatted in a darkened room.

"Our situation was becoming unbearable," said Muhammad Hamdan, a Shi'ite Muslim. He served seven years in the SLA, but only "because I have a family of 10 to feed".

In all, Hizbullah says it has taken 150 prisoners in 24 hours. A hundred or more are reported to have surrendered to the Lebanese army at one of the former crossing points into Israeli-occupied Lebanon.

"We shall hand ours over to the Lebanese state," said a Hizbullah guard.

But inside newly liberated Lebanon there is no Lebanese state to receive them. The regular army has not advanced from the edge of the zone. Nor have Unifil troops - the UN interim force in Lebanon - moved in to fill the vacuum.

As the hordes descended on the south, Unifil checkpoints waved everyone through: the human tide was clearly too overwhelming to resist. For the foreseeable future only Hizbullah's writ will run here.

This has alarmed Israel, and the deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, warned that if Hizbullah moved into border villages Israel might have to return to Lebanon.

fields.headline: Rail row
fields.standfirst: Legal threat angers Prescott
fields.trailText: Railtrack is proposing legal action to prevent it having to reveal timing and cost details about the upgrade of the west coast main line to the rail regulator, Tom Winsor.
fields.body:
Railtrack is proposing legal action to prevent it having to reveal timing and cost details about the upgrade of the west coast main line to the rail regulator, Tom Winsor.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, believes that Railtrack is pursuing a running battle with the regulator over an issue where Mr Winsor is merely doing his duty.

Government sources made it clear that in the week of the first industry rail summit for 15 months it was unfortunate that two of the summit's main participants are arguing in public again. The Department of Transport has been asking summit participants to present a united front in the face of considerable problems following the Paddington rail disaster.

Mr Prescott's sympathy appears to lie with Mr Winsor, who has given Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, the opportunity to provide the regulator with details.

"To suggest that Mr Winsor is acting inappropriately is to misunderstand his position. He is obliged under railway legislation to vet Railtrack's actions," a government source said.

Railtrack agreed yesterday that "strictly speaking" it had been unable to meet the terms of the regulator's enforcement order on the upgrade of the line between Glasgow and London.

It said that it sent a letter to Mr Winsor last night informing him that it did not have all the information he required and that it would not be available for some weeks. It confirmed that it was set to take legal action to stop Mr Winsor from proceeding. This follows a decision by Railtrack's board to adopt a "deliberate culture of defiance" against the regulator to prevent action through the courts.

Mr Winsor has expressed concern that Railtrack will not be able to deliver the line on time, a situation which would upset the chances of Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Trains to start running 125mph tilting trains by May 2002. Upgrading the tracks and signalling is crucial to Sir Richard's plan to cut the journey time between London and Manchester to less than two hours, and Birmingham-London to little over an hour.

Mr Winsor says that simply exposing Railtrack through the courts would be a deterrent and there would be no fine.

webTitle: We're ready to sell Orange, says Gent

fields.headline: We're ready to sell Orange, says Gent
fields.trailText: VodafoneAirTouch's chief executive, Chris Gent, signalled yesterday that his group was prepared to sell Orange to another company rather than spin it off through a stock market flotation.
fields.body:
VodafoneAirTouch's chief executive, Chris Gent, signalled yesterday that his group was prepared to sell Orange to another company rather than spin it off through a stock market flotation.

His stance could trigger a £20bn-plus battle among a number of top international telecoms companies for con trol of Britain's third largest mobile phone group.

But it could put Mr Gent on a collision course with the top management at Orange, which wants the company to regain its independence through a return to the stock market.

Vodafone, which is Britain's biggest mobile phone operator, agreed to demerge Orange in exchange for clearance from the European commission's competition authority for its takeover of Mannesmann, the German telecoms company.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Britain jumps to EU directives
fields.body:
Britain jumps to EU directives

Britain's track record on implementing EU legislation is better than most, a European commission report showed yesterday.

Britain is ranked sixth in the commission's "single market scoreboard" which indicates how quickly EU legislation has been introduced in member states in the last year.

Four countries - Greece, Portugal, France and Luxembourg - account for over 40% of the delays while Finland is the most efficient country at adopting EU directives.

Of the 1,489 internal market directives which should have entered into force by April 15, the commission says 194 have not been taken on board by member states.

Gold back in demand

Demand for gold in Britain rose by 18% during the first quarter of this year, boosted by surging Christmas and new year jewellery sales, the industry reported yesterday. Worldwide, demand for the metal during January-March totalled 795.2 tonnes, up on the 787.7 tonnes sold during the same period last year. The increase came despite a drop in demand for bullion as an investment. Gold held its own despite a price bounce in the latter half of last year that took it well above the 20-year lows seen in the summer of 1999.

CAT's losses are cut

Drug development company Cambridge Antibody Technology reduced its half-year losses by 68% to £2.1m, helped by payments from licensing partners. The biggest contribution was from the German group BASF, which paid a fee when CAT began phase-three trials of its product for rheumatoid arthritis. CAT's chairman, Peter Garland, said a Nasdaq listing was likely during the second half. CAT's shares fell 37.5p to £24.25. They peaked at more than £49 this year, valuing the business at more than £1bn.

Iceland in cold war with Tesco

Iceland is taking the war of the freezer cabinets to the office of fair trading after a market blitz by Tesco which claimed frozen food was cheaper in its stores. Iceland claimed to possess an internal memo from Tesco in which it said it was taking an "anti-Iceland" stance to "attract customers who usually shop at Iceland". This weekend, Iceland said, volunteers from 760 stores had been affixing stickers over Tesco posters saying "Psst . . . I'm cheaper at Iceland". Tesco said: "We've taken £18m off the price off frozen food and these are permanent price cuts."

webTitle: Israel leaves its security zone to the guerrillas

fields.headline: Israel leaves its security zone to the guerrillas
fields.standfirst:
Settlers ordered into bomb shelters as speed of proxy army's rout catches Barak unprepared

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's 22-year occupation of south Lebanon was marching towards a chaotic and inglorious end yesterday, with its proxy army fleeing in disarray, and Hizbullah guerrillas sweeping towards its border.
fields.body:
Israel's 22-year occupation of south Lebanon was marching towards a chaotic and inglorious end yesterday, with its proxy army fleeing in disarray, and Hizbullah guerrillas sweeping towards its border.

As Hizbullah moved into villages abandoned by the South Lebanese Army, taking control of a third of the territory occupied by Israel and its allies and slicing the so-called security zone in two, it was impossible to escape the conclusion that Israel was no longer dictating the terms of its unilateral withdrawal.

Almost all the dozen villages that have passed into the hands of the guerrillas since Sunday have fallen without the SLA firing a shot in resistance. The speed of events leaves the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, with an unpalatable choice: either to speed up the withdrawal or to attempt to hang on and restore order; an unpopular option with most Israelis.

Mr Barak was deliberating on those choices an an emergency meeting of his security cabinet last night. But earlier yesterday a senior defence official in Tel Aviv admitted that Israel was advancing its self-imposed July 7 deadline for the exit by five weeks, and that the few hundred soldiers still in south Lebanon could leave any time after June 1.

Israeli residents of the border area say they have seen signs that the last soldiers might be out of Lebanon even sooner. "The full withdrawal will be sooner than you and I think - not in June but in the next few days," said Hanan Rubinski, secretary of Misgav Am kibbutz, which is on the border. With the SLA's flight from its outpost at Taibehon Sunday, the kibbutz is now just over a mile from Hizbullah's guns.

In northern Galilee, tens of thousands of Israelis were ordered into underground shelters yesterday for fear of reprisal rocket attacks after three Lebanese civilians were killed by Israeli helicopter gunships. But many settlers simply drove south rather than spend the night in shelters.

Mr Barak had badly wanted the UN to approve an expanded peacekeeping force to stabilise the south Lebanon situation, but that prospect appeared to be evaporating.

Israel's SLA allies, who face execution or long prison sentences for collaborating with a foreign occupier, are streaming towards the border to seek refuge. Defence officials said four trucks and two jeeps carrying about 30 members of the SLA and their families had crossed at the Tourmos border post, and that they would be given asylum.

Israeli army radio said another 100 Lebanese were asking to enter at the Biranit crossing in western Galilee. Journalists in the border town of Metullah said scores more were waiting on the Lebanese side and had reportedly been turned back.

There are also fears of an exodus from northern Israel. Mr Rubinski said that with Israeli schools breaking up for the summer holidays soon, many northern families would see this as a good time to leave. "If this tension keeps on in the days ahead, people will have to come to a decision," he said.

In the past few days Mr Barak has tried to distract people in the north from the prospect that the withdrawal will lead to a rise in rocket attacks, and guerrilla infiltration. But the acceleration of events has undermined his efforts. Defence officials admitted yesterday that a sophisticated new fence to keep out guerrillas had yet to be completed, and that the army had yet to install promised anti-missile walls around the most exposed settlements.

Almost all the dozen villages that have passed into the hands of the guerrillas since Sunday have fallen without the SLA firing a shot in resistance. fields.headline: Whitehall war on bribery
fields.standfirst: Paying sweeteners to win foreign contracts to be made a criminal offence
fields.trailText: The government is to announce new laws aimed at cracking down on companies paying sweeteners to win lucrative foreign contracts after strong international pressure forced a change of heart in Whitehall.
fields.body:
The government is to announce new laws aimed at cracking down on companies paying sweeteners to win lucrative foreign contracts after strong international pressure forced a change of heart in Whitehall.

Bribing corrupt foreign officials is to be made a criminal offence in a move designed to bring Britain into line with other leading industrialised nations. The UK is the only country out of 20 which have ratified the OECD's anti-bribery convention not to have adapted its domestic legislation, repeatedly arguing that existing legislation is tough enough to comply.

But after lobbying from fellow cabinet ministers and foreign governments the home secretary, Jack Straw, has accepted that a new statute is required.

The proposed change in the law - which goes against the advice of civil servants - will make it an offence for a British citizen to offer, promise or give a bribe to a foreign public official to obtain or retain international business deals, irrespective of where the offence is committed.

Other OECD members have accused Britain of shielding corrupt firms from prosecution by repeatedly failing to acknowledged that existing legislation is inadequate. The US administration, in particular, has been dismayed by the UK government's recalcitrance.

Until now, the government has been arguing that existing laws, based on the Prevention of Corruption Act 1906, are sufficient, but there has never been a successful prosecution under that piece of legislation.

Threatened with publication of a highly critical report by an OECD peer review group at June's ministerial meeting, Clare Short, the international development secretary, and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, have been pressing Mr Straw to ignore his officials and take urgent action to ensure Britain abides by the convention.

Mr Straw's decision will also tidy up other aspects of the laws on corruption, including payments to MPs.

For the first time, corruption laws will embrace the concept of extra-territoriality, whereby it will become an offence for British citizens to offer bribes for business contracts anywhere in the world, not just within UK jurisdiction.

Transparency International (TI), a non-governmental organisation which campaigns against corruption, welcomed the decision to update the law but expressed concern about the time it will take to enact new legislation which bundles together all aspects of the law on bribery.

"We don't know how long such a bill will take but it's been suggested that it's unlikely to be in the lifetime of this parliament," said George Moody-Stuart, the president of TI UK.

The OECD convention, signed by Britain in December 1997, is the centrepiece of anti- bribery efforts across the world. Most rich industrialised countries have amended their laws that criminalise bribery of domestic officials to cover foreign bribery. Others, such as Korea and Australia, have a stand-alone law. Even the US, which has had the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act for more than 20 years, amended that law to reflect some principles of the convention.

British companies were ranked among the least corrupt in a TI survey but of 53 firms on the World Bank's bribery blacklist at the end of February, 36 were in the UK.

fields.headline: 'Hawk' raises rates hopes
fields.standfirst: New MPC member sees no necessity for tighter policy
fields.trailText: Fears that the Bank of England could raise interest rates eased yesterday when an important new member of Threadneedle Street's rate setting committee said there were few signs of wage inflation, even though unemployment has fallen to a 20-year low.
fields.body:
Fears that the Bank of England could raise interest rates eased yesterday when an important new member of Threadneedle Street's rate setting committee said there were few signs of wage inflation, even though unemployment has fallen to a 20-year low.

Professor Steve Nickell, a labour market expert, told members of the Treasury select committee that he would have to see evidence of rising wage inflation before voting for higher rates.

"At the moment I would not see the necessity on this particular score to tighten monetary policy," Prof Nickell added.

Some City analysts had expected Prof Nickell to side with the hawks on the Bank's monetary policy committee because of his view that there is an equilibrium rate of unemployment - and if the jobless rate falls below this level, it puts pressures on prices.

However, Prof Nickell said the equilibrium rate had fallen in recent years and that in any event, it was only a guide to setting policy. "Precisely where unemployment is relative to the equilibrium rate today is not known," he said in his written evidence to the committee.

"It is almost certainly fairly close but to judge precisely where it is can only be done by looking closely at the evidence for excess demand in the labour market."

Asked how he would judge this, Prof Nickell said: "I'd watch the wages; that seems to me to be the key to this."

The MPC has been closely watching the level of average earnings, running at an annual rate of 5.8%, well above the 4.5% rate which the Bank estimates is consistent with keeping inflation in check.

Prof Nickell said the level of pay settlements which have remained steady at around 3% was a better guide than the average earnings index which has been dogged by problems of reliability.

The Bank's key rate-setting committee is widely expected to leave rates on hold next month because of the strength of sterling. Prof Nickell and his fellow new entrant to the MPC, Chris Allsopp, agreed that sterling's level was well above any long run estimate of its equilibrium rate. However, Mr Allsopp said there was little policymakers could do to massage sterling down. "I would be particularly worried about intervening at the moment, as it seems to me that probably the main problem is a dollar-euro problem, with sterling caught on one side," he said.

Sterling has slumped against the dollar in recent weeks after holding steady at around $1.60. It finished yesterday at $1.49, slightly up on Friday's low point of $1.47. "Sterling has had a little bit of a bounce today, but it still looks vulnerable," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC World Markets in London.

fields.headline: Nascent renaissance
fields.standfirst: Silver Cross rolls out new pram
fields.trailText: The Rolls Royce of British prams returned to the market yesterday - only a matter of hours post-Leo - with its first new line since receivership and rescue by private investors a year ago. But the Blairs, who joined the Queen and Madonna in buying the celebrated Silver Cross brand for their first three children, may baulk at the name of the six £400-500 models to be sold as the Blue Room range.
fields.body:
The Rolls Royce of British prams returned to the market yesterday - only a matter of hours post-Leo - with its first new line since receivership and rescue by private investors a year ago. But the Blairs, who joined the Queen and Madonna in buying the celebrated Silver Cross brand for their first three children, may baulk at the name of the six £400-500 models to be sold as the Blue Room range.

"We were a bit perplexed about how to put it to Cherie Blair," said Robert Bruce, product manager of Silver Cross. "But blue became a theme; the new range all have a tint of it.

"Our designer, Jane Churchill, thought long and hard and decided that blue was the colour."

The Blue Rooms will be the test of Silver Cross's revival, which has seen the company rehire more than 70 of 130 staff laid off last May. The Yorkshire firm, founded 123 years ago, sells 35,000 of the 700,000 prams and buggies bought annually in Britain. But a relaunch by previous owners Venture Finance failed to successfully modernise its tank-like heritage range.

The Blue Room prams are designed to bridge the gap, with a more contemporary carrycot which can be fixed either flat, as a pram, or sloping as a baby buggy.

webTitle: Scottish Radio still on buy trail

fields.headline: Scottish Radio still on buy trail
fields.trailText: Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday said it remained on the acquisition trail after Border Television slipped from its grasp at the end of last month.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday said it remained on the acquisition trail after Border Television slipped from its grasp at the end of last month.

Richard Findlay, the Scottish Radio chief executive, shrugged off the suggestion that Border was one of the last few opportunities to expand the company's radio business by acquisition, and said there were still "plenty of opportunities." Rival Capital Radio delivered a knock-out blow in the battle for Border when it produced a £151m cash offer.

Mr Findlay said the decision to withdraw from the battle had not given him any sleepless nights. "We are a business, not a hobby or an ego trip.

"We haven't had an iota of criticism from shareholders - all I've heard is relief that we weren't prepared to bust the wallet and overpay.

"There are further opportunies - and there always are in this business because the sands are always shifting. I'm pretty optimistic that we will be able to expand the radio business," he said.

Acquisition opportunities are also being assessed across the outdoor advertising and local newspaper sectors, in which Scottish Radio has built a presence. It is also looking at further new media opportunities - it is sitting on a cash pile of £26m after earmarking a rights issue to fund the Border deal as well as arranging a debt facility of £116m.

The company reported a 39% rise in revenues for the first half of the year to £34m, although pre-tax profits slipped by 11% to £6.4m. Radio remains the biggest part of the business, with revenues running at £17.4m in the first half, newspapers accounting for £9.2m and outdoor advertising £7.3m.

Scottish Radio shares, which were as high as £18.75p during the bid for Border, slipped 15p to £13.35p. The firm has applied for the second London digital multiplex licence in partnership with GWR and GMG, publisher of the Guardian.

fields.headline: PhD study costs Antisoma £44m
fields.trailText: A maverick postgraduate student has wiped £44m off the market value of Antisoma, the drug development group, by suggesting in a paper that its flagship treatment for ovarian cancer does not work.
fields.body:
A maverick postgraduate student has wiped £44m off the market value of Antisoma, the drug development group, by suggesting in a paper that its flagship treatment for ovarian cancer does not work.

The student, Steven Nicholson, stunned Antisoma by producing his negative findings at a medical conference in New Orleans yesterday.

His work was based on a 20-patient study at a south London hospital which Antisoma had no idea was under way.

Antisoma immediately announced it was halting recruitment of patients for its phase three clinical trial of Theragyn, causing its shares to dive 60.5p to 90p.

Chief executive Glyn Edwards said: "We're not sure whether this is a statistical fluke or a genuine effect. But we're not taking this lightly - in clinical research you can't afford to take any risks."

Theragyn is an antibody-based treatment which is supposed to deliver medicine accurately to tumour cells. It has been dubbed a "magic bullet" because of this targeting.

The product was licensed to Antisoma by the Imperial Cancer Research Fund where Dr Nicholson, a mature student, used to work.

It emerged yesterday that Dr Nicholson with the approval of the charity had taken the same antibody to carry out trials for his PhD thesis.

In his study more people died among those using the treatment than among a contol group. Mr Edwards said: "I'm not trying to denigrate his work, but he's used a small number of patients and the study hasn't been followed up and checked."

He said Antisoma's studies showed Theragyn to be highly effective. Antisoma is said to be furious with the charity, which owns a 7.9% stake in the company, for not passing on information about the trial.

Max Herrmann of Charterhouse Securities said: "There's something strange about this - the company's own studies were very encouraging."

fields.headline: 'Worst' armed robbers get 30 years
fields.standfirst: Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Two notorious armed robbers who headed a gang called the Wild Bunch were jailed for 30 years each yesterday after three trials which cost £7m.
fields.body:
Two notorious armed robbers who headed a gang called the Wild Bunch were jailed for 30 years each yesterday after three trials which cost £7m.

After Charles Tozer, 47, and Francis Pope, 49, were sentenced at the Old Bailey, Detective Superintendent Jon Shatford described them as utterly ruthless villains. "On any scale of armed robbers, these two would be the worst."

Tozer, of Kentish Town, north London, and Pope, of Wapping, east London, had records stretching back to the 1960s, the court was told. They would celebrate their robberies by singing Pennies from Heaven at champagne parties in expensive hotels. They planned to retire eventually to a villa in Spain.

The men, described as desperate, dangerous and evil, were arrested in September 1997 after an operation involving 60 officers from Scotland Yard's flying squad.

On Saturday they were convicted of attempting to rob a security guard, Stephen Sturgeon, at a Safeway's store in Bow, east London, in August 1997 and causing him grievous bodily harm. Tozer had shot and wounded him.

Giving evidence, Mr Sturgeon, 40, said: "I was punched so hard it knocked my helmet off. There was a gun to my head. I was dragged out of the store to the security van. I said there was no money. One grinned to the other and said 'shoot him anyway' and his partner fired. A bullet went through my hand and into my thigh."

Tozer and Pope were also convicted of robbing the Nationwide building society in Kentish Town a month later.

In the first trial, in October 1998, they said they had been "set up" by police. That trial was abandoned when they sacked their legal teams. The jury in a second trial failed to agree on verdicts. One juror was discharged after he was seen gesturing to the defendants.

Jurors in the third trial were given 24-hour police protection.

Tozer and Pope repeatedly disrupted proceedings during the trials, staging "sit in" strikes in their cells and refusing to enter the dock.

Judge Peter Beaumont QC told them yesterday: "The time has come for the public to have a long rest from your activities."

Mr Shatford said: "Most other criminals wouldn't go near them. They were regarded as being out of control."

fields.headline: 'MI6 man' dropped by Lockerbie panel
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: A Glasgow University law professor is being dropped from an expert panel on the Lockerbie bombing following allegations that he was a high-ranking MI6 officer. Andrew Fulton will be asked today to stand down from his role as deputy director of the university's Lockerbie trial briefing unit.
fields.body:
A Glasgow University law professor is being dropped from an expert panel on the Lockerbie bombing following allegations that he was a high-ranking MI6 officer. Andrew Fulton will be asked today to stand down from his role as deputy director of the university's Lockerbie trial briefing unit.

The unit was set up by the university to give foreign and UK journalists "impartial and objective" advice on Scottish legal procedures used in the trial of the two Libyans accused of causing the 1988 explosion on Pan Am flight 103. Professor Fulton joined the unit last year after he retired from a 31-year career in the Foreign and Commonwealth Office.

Last Friday, the Guardian raised questions about his links with MI6, and over the weekend a series of reports claimed Professor Fulton had been one of Britain's most powerful MI6 officers, acting as head of station for the intelligence service in Washington.

He is said to be on holiday on Skye and cannot be contacted, but he is expected to attend a meeting at the university today to discuss the revelations. Asked to comment on the claims last week, he neither confirmed nor denied them, saying only that he had worked as a diplomat for 30 years.

A university spokesman said Professor Fulton was being asked to stand down because of the risk of publicity overshadowing the unit's work, regardless of the truth or otherwise of the allegations.

No decision had yet been taken on his post as a visiting professor at the university's law school. "We are not in a position to confirm or deny Professor Fulton's status but it will be put to him that as he has become the story, rather than the work of the unit, he should stand aside in the interests of the unit."

The unit had avoided commenting on "rumours or speculation" about the Lockerbie evidence, instead confining itself to explaining Scottish legal principles, procedures and terminology. John Grant, director of the unit, posted a notice on its website saying: "I am disappointed that we have become the story when a major criminal trial is trying to determine who is responsible for the deaths of 270 people.

"The unit has consistently offered impartial advice and assistance to those with an interest in the trial. The news organisations throughout the world who have spoken to members of our team can bear testimony to our impartiality.

"I have no personal knowledge of any connection between Andrew Fulton and the British intelligence service. I cannot contact Andrew at the moment, but I shall be speaking to him during the week from Camp Zeist, where I am covering the restart of the trial.

"Our independence and impartiality are articles of faith with us. Any prejudice to that independence and impartiality is, of course, of great concern to us."

The trial of the two men accused of the bombing resumes today in Holland under Scottish law but before three judges instead of a jury.

He is said to be on holiday on Skye and cannot be contacted, but he is expected to attend a meeting at the university today to discuss the revelations. Asked to comment on the claims last week, he neither confirmed nor denied them, saying only that he had worked as a diplomat for 30 years. A university spokesman said Professor Fulton was being asked to stand down because of the risk of publicity overshadowing the unit's work, regardless of the truth or otherwise of the allegations. No decision had yet been taken on his post as a visiting professor at the university's law school. "We are not in a position to confirm or deny Professor Fulton's status but it will be put to him that as he has become the story, rather than the work of the unit, he should stand aside in the interests of the unit." The unit had avoided commenting on "rumours or speculation" about the Lockerbie evidence, instead confining itself to explaining Scottish legal principles, procedures and terminology. John Grant, director of the unit, posted a notice on its website saying: "I am disappointed that we have become the story when a major criminal trial is trying to determine who is responsible for the deaths of 270 people. "The unit has consistently offered impartial advice and assistance to those with an interest in the trial. The news organisations throughout the world who have spoken to members of our team can bear testimony to our impartiality. "I have no personal knowledge of any connection between Andrew Fulton and the British intelligence service. I cannot contact Andrew at the moment, but I shall be speaking to him during the week from Camp Zeist, where I am covering the restart of the trial. "Our independence and impartiality are articles of faith with us. Any prejudice to that independence and impartiality is, of course, of great concern to us." The trial of the two men accused of the bombing resumes today in Holland under Scottish law but before three judges instead of a jury.

fields.headline: Marines face unknowable enemy
fields.standfirst:
This war is still an enigma to the soldiers who may have to fight in it

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: There are eight British warships sailing around an imaginary box off the coast of Sierra Leone. It can hardly be called a show of force, because most of the ships are deliberately kept so far offshore, to prevent more accusations of "mission creep", that no one in Freetown can see them.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal on board HMS Ocean off Sierra Leone
fields.body:
There are eight British warships sailing around an imaginary box off the coast of Sierra Leone. It can hardly be called a show of force, because most of the ships are deliberately kept so far offshore, to prevent more accusations of "mission creep", that no one in Freetown can see them.

But their Sea Harrier aircraft come tearing over the city each day and across the jungle toward rebel territory. What they do there remains unclear to all but those who give the orders.

We are told that the hundreds of young Royal Marines on board HMS Ocean are itching to get to the shore they have yet to glimpse. Their wish will be granted within a week or so when they are sent into Sierra Leone to take over from the Parachute Regiment.

What the young foot soldiers will be doing there is only marginally less of a mystery to them than who it is they may end up fighting.

Whitehall continues to maintain the line that British soldiers are not being used as combat troops. Perhaps not, but they are now as close as you can get without looking the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) in the eye.

On Sunday a British officer was giving orders to Sierra Leonean troops as they took the town of Rogben at a crucial T-junction which opens the way to the rebel headquarters at Makeni. The SAS barely bothers any more to hide its presence immediately behind the government army.

But for all that, Sierra Leone's war remains an enigma to those who may soon have to fight it: the young marines - some of whom look startlingly like schoolboys with guns - do not know what to expect.

No one has held back in painting the RUF as a barbaric enemy, given to murder and mutilation. But what motivates them, and who they are, remain as unexplained to the marines as Sierra Leone itself.

The marine commander on HMS Ocean is Colonel Andy Salmon. He has served in Bosnia and Belfast, but the question of who he may be fighting in west Africa - and how he may fight them - makes him twitchy.

"Clearly it does make a difference when you are not in a conventional situation with regular forces," he says. "We already know that the pathfinders were up against the rebels. That's very much on our minds."

The pathfinders - a branch of the Parachute Regiment - shot dead at least four rebels last week when the RUF assaulted a joint British and Nigerian post. But the British response suggested a lot more than mere defence.

Helicopter gunships and hot pursuit by the pathfinders probably claimed a lot more lives than those of the four rebel corpses recovered. The RUF got the message the British are keen to convey, at least to Sierra Leoneans: the UN troops may surrender, but the British will fight.

Col Salmon searches for a comparison in his 20 years as a marine, but gives up. "The streets of Northern Ireland perhaps, with people throwing bricks and petrol bombs at you. But it is very different. There is no template."

There is another difference from conventional war that hardly anyone cares to discuss. The RUF is an army heavily reliant on child soldiers. Many are abducted, force-fed hallucinogenic drugs and herded into combat.

The Nigerian troops who saved Freetown from the RUF last year were disturbed to find themselves killing nine-year-olds. But these were the children who were hacking the arms off of babies and old men.

Circumstances forced the Nigerians to harden themselves to killing children to save children, but it is a daunting prospect for any regular army. And not one on which the British care to dwell.

"I don't think it makes a difference if you're life is being threatened by whoever. There's a job to be done," said Col Salmon. But some of his young soldiers were not quite so firm. No one had told them there were children in the RUF, they said. No one has told them very much at all.

webTitle: Labour predicts £20bn hole in Hague plans

fields.headline: Labour predicts £20bn hole in Hague plans
fields.standfirst: Backbench team hunts for evidence to use in election campaign that Tory pledges on tax cuts and spending are irresponsible
fields.trailText: Labour has set up a Treasury- supported team of backbenchers to look for the financial black hole in the Conservatives' tax and spending plans.
fields.body:
Labour has set up a Treasury- supported team of backbenchers to look for the financial black hole in the Conservatives' tax and spending plans.

Labour hopes to use the same techniques deployed with devasting effect by successive Conservative governments - such as the "double whammy" campaign in the 1992 election campaign - to prove that the Tories' tax cuts and spending promises are profiligate and irresponsible. The group, led by backbencher Christopher Leslie, MP for Shipley, has been monitoring every statement from Conservative frontbench politicians, ranging from subsidies on pig offal to abolition of capital gains tax, to assemble a figure for the Tories' financial black hole which Labour predicts will exceed £20bn.

In a foretaste of the Labour attack in the run-up to the general election, the group hopes to substantiate the claim that William Hague has become a new breed of animal - a tax cut and spend politician. The group claims the Tories "have yet to identify any credible specific savings whilst continuing to make a stream of unsustainable spending pledges and tax promises".

Downing Street believes the Conservatives are especially vulnerable because Mr Hague has committed himself to cutting tax as a proportion of national income over the next parliament, even though he has also promised to match Labour spending on health and education.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, has countered by claiming Gordon Brown, on page 200 of the Treasury red book, also commits himself to cut tax as a proportion of national income.

So far, the Conservatives have claimed they can cut £7bn from welfare spending and £2bn from excessive central government spending.

The work compiled by Mr Leslie - parliamentary private secretary to cabinet minister Lord Falconer - and his team suggests the £7bn figure can only be reached if it includes all irregularities in the system, such as estimating the number of people who would miss one interview at a benefits office and lose state support.

The Leslie team also says the Tory savings in the DSS budget include "the complete nonsense" of assuming that all lone parents whose youngest child is over 11 could immediately find work at high enough pay levels to exclude them from in-work benefits.

Labour claims the £2bn of excess spending on the cost of government is also a deeply suspect figure since it represents cash, rather than real terms. The costs of central gov ernment have not risen in real terms, Labour claims, and are falling in real terms from the levels inherited from the Toires.

Other Tory spending commitments costed by the Leslie group include a right to transfer tax allowance (£4.25bn), tax relief for private health insurance (£500m), abolition of capital gains tax (£3.9bn), pledge to cut the top rate of tax (£690m), and scrapping of stamp duty on share sales (£3.7bn).

In addition Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, has broadly costed her law and order package at £260m, including stiffer sentences and more prisons.

She concedes this excludes the cost of her commitment to restore police numbers to the levels at the time of the last general election. This may require a big increase in police pay.

Ms Widdecombe has also claimed her plan to put 100,000 asylum seeekers in detention centres will bring financial savings, since asylum seekers will be deterred from coming to Britain, although on other occasisons she has said it will take years to get rid of the backlog of asylum claims.

Other Tory spending commitments include building 1,000 new parks and greens, restoring spending on road maintenance, and restoring tax concessions for the elderly who choose to have private healthcare.

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, has also said transport needs billions of pounds of investment, but has not specified whether this could be raised from the private sector.

webTitle: Peers inflict defeat over war widows

fields.headline: Peers inflict defeat over war widows
fields.trailText: A cross-party coalition of peers defeated the government last night over Ministry of Defence rules which deprive war widows of their pensions on remarriage.
fields.body:
A cross-party coalition of peers defeated the government last night over Ministry of Defence rules which deprive war widows of their pensions on remarriage.

The peers ignored ministerial pleas to await the outcome of an MoD review to back the amendment to the child support, pensions and social security bill by 143 to 117. The amendment would allow war widows to keep their pensions if they remarry. Lady Strange, who moved the amendment, said she knew of 10 widows who cannot remarry because of the rules.

The government also came under fire in the Lords last night over plans to take benefits away from offenders who disobey community service orders. The human rights lawyer, Lady Kennedy QC, said that courts should decide how to deal with offenders, rather than benefit offices. "It is an attack against the poor because it is a punishment that can only apply against people on benefit," she earlier told Radio 4's Today programme.

She was denounced on the same programme by the social security minister, Jeff Rooker, who said: "Helena Kennedy is swanning around the salons of Islington and has no idea of the terror that these youngsters strike into the heart of people on estates."

webTitle: Crime assets seizures open to abuse, warns liberties group

fields.headline: Crime assets seizures open to abuse, warns liberties group
fields.trailText: Civil liberties groups warned last night that government plans to set up a new agency to seize the assets of all criminals, not just drug dealers, could be open to abuse if it is self-financing.
fields.body:
Civil liberties groups warned last night that government plans to set up a new agency to seize the assets of all criminals, not just drug dealers, could be open to abuse if it is self-financing.

The cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, yesterday recycled proposals first announced in a Home Office consultation paper by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in 1998. Ms Mowlam gave few new details about the plans to create a national investigation agency to implement court confiscation orders except to indicate they are not likely to be acted upon until after the general election. The level of confiscated assets from convicted drug dealers, which Tony Blair has promised will be used to fund drug treatment programmes, has never risen much beyond £3m a year.

It is claimed that the proposals to extend the power of the courts, including reversing the burden of proof so that the police do not have to prove that the assets involved are ill-gotten gains, would boost this figure to £40m a year. But civil libertarians worry that if the new agency is self-financing there will be problems.

"Customs officers already have very wide powers to seize assets, and to look into people's lives and bank accounts. While organised crime is clearly a serious problem, extending such powers more widely is not the way forward. There are particular concerns that if such an agency were partly self-funding, these powers would be open to abuse," said Liberty's director, John Wadham.

Ms Mowlam yesterday held out the prospect that the extra funds seized could be used to fund the measures to tackle homelessness.

"Why should millions of law-abiding people work hard for a living, whilst a few criminals live a life of luxury built on the misery of others?" she asked.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Coronation Street actress Liz Dawn, who plays Vera Duckworth, was installed as lady mayoress of Leeds. Ms Dawn, 60, was picked for the post by her friend and Leeds' new bachelor lord mayor, Bernard Atha. A home care assistant and a town hall cleaner have been chosen as deputy consorts when Ms Dawn is busy with her TV work.

Bad day

For Eritrean demonstrators protesting yesterday outside Downing Street calling for Britain and the UN to intervene after Ethiopia's invasion of their homeland. Despite their banners and chants they appear to have failed to get their mesage across. Beast of Bolsover Dennis Skinner told the House of Commons: "I thought they were queuing up to see the baby."

Good day

Downing Street PC Ian Sheeran, has hung up his bobby's hat and truncheon and hit the high seas. The 39-year-old, who has regularly guarded the PM's official residence since 1992, has been chosen to take part in an around the world yacht race. Ian's skipper Manley Hopkinson said: "Ultimately the team that wins will be the one that pulls together the most." A lesson perhaps for the Labour party?

Today

Commons: Crown prosecution service inspectorate bill, second reading. Lords: Terrorism bill, committee.

fields.headline: Minister's brother 'appeared in porn films'
fields.trailText: The brother of Lady Blackstone, the education minister, yesterday admitted in the high court in London that he once performed in pornographic films.
fields.body:
The brother of Lady Blackstone, the education minister, yesterday admitted in the high court in London that he once performed in pornographic films.

Tim Blackstone, 54, a father of three, of Shepherd's Bush, west London, has launched a libel action over an article in the Sunday Mirror which he says made him out to be "violent and a criminal".

Asked by Ronald Thwaites QC, representing the newspaper, which denies libel, whether he had performed in pornographic films, Mr Blackstone, a public relations consultant, said he had, in about eight or nine, before becoming a journalist in the early 1980s.

He accused Mr Thwaites of "raking over something that happened in the 1970s in a period of my life when I was a bit part actor and a model. I was in my twenties. You are muck-raking all this."

He said he stopped "doing those things" when he became a journalist, but had a "lapse" in 1991.

Mr Blackstone is seeking damages from the Sunday Mirror over an article last March which said he had been arrested "after a slanging match with his estranged wife Sarah" and held at a police station for more than six hours.

He denied there was a slanging match, or that he was held for six hours.

He said the only reason the story was used was because his sister was a minister. "It was a cheap shot that her brother had been arrested."

The hearing continues today. Press Association

webTitle: Infection lurks at the touch of a phone or tap

fields.headline: Infection lurks at the touch of a phone or tap
fields.trailText: Infectious diseases can be passed from one person to another by such simple actions as turning on a tap or picking up the telephone, according to new research.
fields.body:
Infectious diseases can be passed from one person to another by such simple actions as turning on a tap or picking up the telephone, according to new research.

Scientists from Arizona said yesterday that viruses could linger for days on hard surfaces, while the dose needed to cause an infection was low. A member of a family with a bad cold who blew their nose and then turned on the tap could easily leave more than 1,000 viruses on the handle, many of which could be picked up by the next person who touched the tap. If that person then touched their mouth, nose or eye they stood a good chance of infection.

Patricia Rusin, Charles Gerba and Sheri Maxwell at the University of Arizona, Tucson, looked at the degree of transfer of Serratia rubidea, a bacterium which causes diarrhoeal disease, and PRD-1, a bacterial virus similar to a human virus, from common household articles to the hand. Telephone re ceivers passed on 39% of the bacteria and 66% of the viruses, while taps passed on 28% and 34%. Further studies showed that 34% of the bacteria and viruses could be transferred to the lower lip if it was touched by an infected finger.

These results were coupled with published information regarding the infective dose (the number of microbes required to cause an infection) and levels of disease-causing microbes called pathogens found in human fluids such as stool and nasal secretions.

Reporting their results to a conference of the American Society for Microbiology, they described several infection scenarios. There were large numbers of salmonella, a common bacterial cause of diarrhoea, in the stool of an infected person. If only a tiny amount of stool were transferred from a contaminated hand to a telephone receiver, the next user could have 107,104 salmonella cells on the fingertip.

If that finger were placed in the mouth, they calculate, the person would receive a dose of 36,383 cells, which could easily result in disease.

If a telephone receiver were contaminated with a low concentration of rotavirus agent - they suggest 10,000 viruses - then 6,580 of these would be transferred to the hand during normal use of the phone, with 211 of them found on the fingertip. "Our results show that 72 viruses could be ingested by the user, which would very likely result in disease."

In previous work they showed that the household sponge might contain 320m disease causing germs. Based on a transfer efficiency of 0.0009%, just under 3,000 bacteria could be transferred to the hand and 32 passed from the fingertip to the mouth.

"This work shows that everyday activities in a contaminated household or workplace could easily result in the transmission of disease," said a spokesman for the society.

"Disease can probably be transmitted in the home more often than these studies suggest, because many of these articles are used repeatedly in the home."

Based on a transfer efficiency of 0.0009%, just under 3,000 bacteria could be transferred to the hand and 32 passed from the fingertip to the mouth. "This work shows that everyday activities in a contaminated household or workplace could easily result in the transmission of disease," said a spokesman for the society. "Disease can probably be transmitted in the home more often than these studies suggest, because many of these articles are used repeatedly in the home."

webTitle: Tobacco firms fight ban on ads

fields.headline: Tobacco firms fight ban on ads
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Lawyers for four leading UK tobacco companies asked the House of Lords yesterday to stop the government introducing a ban on tobacco advertising before the European court of justice rules on their challenge to the ban in Luxembourg. That ruling is not expected till late this year or early next year.
fields.body:
Lawyers for four leading UK tobacco companies asked the House of Lords yesterday to stop the government introducing a ban on tobacco advertising before the European court of justice rules on their challenge to the ban in Luxembourg. That ruling is not expected till late this year or early next year.

Gallaher, Rothmans UK, British American Tobacco and Imperial asked five law lords to overturn an appeal court ruling last December that UK regulations implementing the ban could go ahead in the meantime.

Ministers had hoped the regulations would come into force last January, with phased withdrawal of advertising. But an injunction imposed by the appeal court pending the Lords hearing has stopped them going ahead. The law lords are expected to deliver their judgment next month.

webTitle: A job still to be done

fields.headline: A job still to be done
fields.standfirst:
It is too early to bid farewell to Freetown

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: The British military intervention in Sierra Leone has, so far, gone as well as anybody in the government could have hoped. The UN peacekeeping mission, which officials in Freetown now concede was only days away from collapse, has been resuscitated and is being heavily reinforced. The threat of a new coup has receded as RUF rebels have retreated. Their feared leader, Foday Sankoh, has been captured.
fields.body:
The British military intervention in Sierra Leone has, so far, gone as well as anybody in the government could have hoped. The UN peacekeeping mission, which officials in Freetown now concede was only days away from collapse, has been resuscitated and is being heavily reinforced. The threat of a new coup has receded as RUF rebels have retreated. Their feared leader, Foday Sankoh, has been captured. Many UN hostages have been freed, although fears are growing for the remaining captives' safety. The British forces, supporting Sierra Leone's army and its militia allies, have not been drawn into the sort of all-out combat which many on the mission-creepy right predicted. The evacuation of British and other foreign nationals, the initial justification for the deployment, has been undertaken without incident. In all this, there is much to be thankful for.

The clear temptation now facing the government is to declare victory and set in train a rapid withdrawal. The cabinet committee which is overseeing the operation is expected to examine this week a timetable for a pull-out and a request for weapons from the Sierra Leone government. The idea that President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah's forces, better armed, and assisted by remaining British advisers, can finish the job by themselves has obvious attractions for London. This rosy view is rendered all the more pleasant by UN chief Kofi Annan's determination, spelled out yesterday, to raise the UN's strength to 16,500 or more. It all points to a swift, painless British exit.

This would be short-sighted. The RUF insurgency is far from over and key diamond-producing areas remain outside government control. As UN officials and Liberia's president point out, a political dialogue with the rebels, under regional auspices and underpinned by region-wide guarantees, is necessary and desirable if there is to be any chance of rebuilding civil society over the longer term. But none has yet begun. The augmented UN force, meanwhile, will need time to become wholly effective. To pull out with so many loose ends dangling would be irresponsible. Britain quit colonial Africa in a windy hurry; many of Africa's problems stem from that era. Having made an exceptional decision to return in force, Britain must be prepared to stick around for as long as it is wanted - and until success is as certain as ever it can be. As we said at the outset, there can be no quick fix in Sierra Leone.

webTitle: EC takes legal action against 'tardy' Oftel

fields.headline: EC takes legal action against 'tardy' Oftel
fields.trailText: Britain's claim to be one of Europe's most competitive telecommunications markets appeared shaky last night after the European commission said it had started legal proceedings against the British government for the inefficient way it is regulating the multibillion-pound sector.
fields.body:
Britain's claim to be one of Europe's most competitive telecommunications markets appeared shaky last night after the European commission said it had started legal proceedings against the British government for the inefficient way it is regulating the multibillion-pound sector.

The EC claims that Oftel is dragging its feet over crucial regulatory decisions and taking too long to decide under what conditions mobile telephone operators can access rivals' networks.

It argues that Oftel has taken too long to resolve a price dispute between small mobile phone firm INMS and BTCellnet and Vodafone. Although INMS told Oftel at the end of 1998 that its commercial efforts to access the two groups' networks had failed, Oftel is still deliberating over how much INMS must pay for network access now.

EU rules give regulators six months to take this kind of decision. A formal letter of warning has been dispatched to the DTI, and if the EC does not receive a satisfactory explanation for the delays within two months Britain could find itself before the European court of justice over the issue.

"We have received complaints from several mobile phone operators who allege that Oftel is taking too long to make these kind of decisions," one EU official explained.

"Our aim is to get the UK position on these allegations and to speed up the process for new market entrants. We will then consider what to do next. Whenever there is a violation we will not fail to act."

Oftel admitted it was taking time to resolve the row but said it was a test case which would have implications for all operators wanting access to two of Britain's largest mobile networks. "The reason it's taking so long is because we need to formulate policy," an Oftel spokesman said.

fields.headline: London's airports 'near crisis'
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Runway capacity will be exhausted at London's airports within 10 years, a report by the capital's Chamber of Commerce and Industry warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Runway capacity will be exhausted at London's airports within 10 years, a report by the capital's Chamber of Commerce and Industry warned yesterday.

Passenger numbers at airports serving London could rise by 200% by 2030, while those at regional airports could increase fivefold in the next 30 years, said the chamber. This would limit the amount of air traffic that could be diverted from London to other UK airports.

The chamber's chief executive, Simon Sperryn, said London was already suffering from capacity constraints. "These will reach a crisis point by 2010 if urgent decisions are not taken to expand airport runways and terminals." But the chamber feared ministers would delay any decision until well after the next general election, he added.
Press Association

fields.headline: Trouble at the big top
fields.standfirst:
Blair's popularity has waned with the Dome's

Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Despite the arrival of little Leo, 2000 has not been a banner year in the life of Tony Blair. Politically, it has been a headache: with defeats in local elections, a slide in the opinion polls and two enormous industrial closures all serving to strip the prime minister of his aura of invincibility. Looking back, it is clear when the trouble began. The very moment the clock struck twelve to herald the new millennium, things turned ugly.
fields.body:
Despite the arrival of little Leo, 2000 has not been a banner year in the life of Tony Blair. Politically, it has been a headache: with defeats in local elections, a slide in the opinion polls and two enormous industrial closures all serving to strip the prime minister of his aura of invincibility. Looking back, it is clear when the trouble began. The very moment the clock struck twelve to herald the new millennium, things turned ugly.

The next day's papers did not sing a song of jubilee - instead they rubbished what was meant to be the symbol of the Blairite new Britain: the Millennium Dome. There had been a monumental cock-up on the opening night, as the London elite were kept waiting for hours. In a way, the dome never recovered from that first blast of negative publicity. The word of mouth kicked in immediately: the Dome was a turkey.

Despite management changes, multiple relaunches and discounts for latecomers, the Greenwich fun-palace has simply failed to draw the crowds it needed. Half a million have been coming in each of the most recent months, but it is not enough: the Dome needed to bring in twice that number. Now it has revised down its estimates, from the initial 12m visitors expected throughout the year to the 7m hoped for today. If this was the private sector, the plug would probably have been pulled by now.

But this is not the private sector and some very big political egos are on the line. The PM invested personal capital in this project (remember the photos of Mr Blair in a yellow hard-hat?): he could not let it die a failure. And so yesterday the Millennium Commission did its duty. Mo Mowlam doubtless acted for her boss in voting to give this apparent turkey a blood transfusion of £29m. The commission insisted on tying the new cash to yet more improvements in the New Millennium Experience - but, tellingly, it did not rule out doling out even more money later on. That brings to £538m the total amount of lottery money the Dome has sucked up: £60m of it in another emergency hand-out in January.

Was this a good decision? It has only one thing to commend it: now the Dome will have a chance to prove itself in the one period when it might score - the school summer holidays. Otherwise it looks like bad politics and bad economics. After all, this is a government which has made a sacred principle of minimal intervention to help ailing industries. Dagenham and Longbridge were struggling, too; but Labour made it clear that financial hand-outs to keep those factories alive were off the table. Suddenly that iron law is waived for the Dome.

It is bad politics because it makes Labour's priorities appear out of kilter: help will not come for manufacturing industry, but it will for what is fast looking like a vanity project in the south-east of England. Yesterday's decision also risks hurting, albeit indirectly, the much more popular New Opportunities Fund - which organises small-scale projects: after-school activities, nature walks and help for the countryside. They were due to get Millennium Commission money next year: now they risk getting less - or at the very least a long wait for it.

This newspaper supported the idea of a grand British project to see in the millennium. We even liked the notion of a big Dome. But like many others we wanted something of real, enduring value to go inside it. That did not come. Now the best course is probably an early sell-off to someone else who might do a better job - and a serious attempt to learn some lessons from what has been a shambolic, disappointing experience.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Crane dead named
fields.body:
Crane dead named

Three men killed when a crane snapped in two and fell 400ft on to a building site while they were working on offices for the HSBC bank in docklands, east London, were named yesterday as Peter Clark, 33, of Southwark, south London, Martin Burgess, 31, of Castleford, West Yorkshire, and Michael Whittard, 39, of Leeds. Postmortem examinations were carried out yesterday and the health and safety executive examined the wreckage.

Hot air attempt over Arctic

Explorer David Hempleman-Adams will take off today from Svalbard, Norway, in his attempt to become the first man to cross the Arctic by hot air balloon. The 44-year-old from Box, Wiltshire, is expected to spend five days in a wicker basket measuring 6ft by 4ft on the 1,000-mile flight before touching down in Ellesmere Island in Canada.

RUC finds guns in forest

Guns and ammunition were discovered yesterday during a search in Garry Forest near Ballymoney, Co Antrim. The discovery was made after the RUC found balaclavas, gloves, two-way radios and lengths of pipe in the forest earlier in the day.

webTitle: India to rescue Sri Lankans trapped by Tigers

fields.headline: India to rescue Sri Lankans trapped by Tigers
fields.trailText: India was preparing a large-scale evacuation plan last night to rescue thousands of civilians trapped in the town of Jaffna, and the beleaguered Sri Lankan troops in the town.
fields.body:
India was preparing a large-scale evacuation plan last night to rescue thousands of civilians trapped in the town of Jaffna, and the beleaguered Sri Lankan troops in the town.

Around 15,000 Indian troops have been moved to Trivandrum, the capital of the southern state of Kerala, as a prelude to a humanitarian operation. People in the neighbouring state of Tamil Nadu have reported nightly aircraft movement between Trivandrum and Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital.

Speculation was growing last night that India was on the brink of intervening in the war as part of a wider negotiated settlement involving a ceasefire between the Sri Lankan army and the Tamil Tigers. A Norwegian peace mission began three days of talks with Sri Lankan leaders yesterday aimed at arranging a deal.

Although Indian ministry of defence officials denied reports of big troop movements, a spokesman at the headquarters of its southern air command said: "We are on a six-hour alert. We are in constant touch with the army headquarters in New Delhi."

No evacuation plan is likely to be put into effect without a formal request from both the Sri Lankan government and the Tigers. The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, still insists that the 40,000 troops marooned on the Jaffna peninsula can hang on.

But her claim seems increasingly untenable. The Tigers are on the outskirts of Jaffna, and captured the strategic town of Chavakachcheri at the weekend. They have started shelling Palali air base and Kankesanthurai harbour - the army's only supply routes.

India has already offered Sri Lanka humanitarian assistance. It is not clear whether the evacuation plan would include a commitment to transport only civilians, or troops as well. "We are ready for action. The details will be worked out at a later stage," an Indian diplomat said last night.

the Sri Lankan foreign minister, Lakshman Kardigamar, hinted last week that Sri Lankan troops might qualify for humanitarian assistance if they were disarmed before evacuation. "It is a hypothetical scenario," he added.

Diplomats said yesterday that India was not going to involve itself directly in the war. Any relief operation was likely to go ahead only with the consent of the Tigers, who had the means to shell departing government troops.

webTitle: Fijian coup plotters raise the stakes

fields.headline: Fijian coup plotters raise the stakes
fields.trailText: The gunmen holding the Fijian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, in an attempted coup dragged him on to the lawn of the parliament building yesterday and held a gun to his head, witnesses said.
fields.body:
The gunmen holding the Fijian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, in an attempted coup dragged him on to the lawn of the parliament building yesterday and held a gun to his head, witnesses said.

Coup leader George Speight, a failed businessman who says he is acting on behalf of indigenous Fijians, has threatened to shoot the ethnic Indian prime minister and other hostages if the security forces attempt to retake parliament.

The Fijian president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Maru, said he could not guarantee that he would retain Mr Chaudhry's government, which has been held hostage since Friday. It was the first serious crack in support for the South Pacific island's first ethnic Indian prime minister from the president.

"If Mr Chaudhry wants to resign he can resign but it must come from him," Sir Kamisese said. But he called again for Mr Speight and his gunmen to lay down their arms. Several hundred people milled around the grounds of parliament house yesterday, many of them supporters of Mr Speight.

Dissatisfaction with the abrasive Mr Chaudhry's style of government has been growing since he took power a year ago on Friday. Tension has risen between ethnic Fijians, who make up the majority of the 800,000 population, and the Indian community.
Reuters

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
As the rows continue about the state of London's underground, Parisians are marking the centenary of one of the world's best urban railways. In the first of five celebratory programmes, Philip Sweeney recalls the doom and gloom which greeted the idea of the Métro (9.30am, Radio 4). Now its trains trundle six million people a day along a 15-line network. Passengers pay a flat fare of about 50p a trip and the government stumps up a vast subsidy to meet the inevitable deficits.

Mark Radcliffe recalls one of the great entertainment partnerships, created when a lad from Ulverston in Cumbria met one from Harlem, Georgia. Me And My Pal (11.30am, Radio 4) is the story of Hollywood's most enduring comic team, Laurel and Hardy (pictured). They originally appeared separately in the same films until producer Hal Roach realised how much better they performed together. Archive interviews recall their personal lives and the 80-odd films they eventually made.

webTitle: Chelsea Flower Show opens to accusations of bad taste

fields.headline: Chelsea Flower Show opens to accusations of bad taste
fields.trailText: The Chelsea Flower Show, the start of the London summer season and a mecca of English gardeners, opened yesterday to accusations of bad taste and selling out to the global garden industry after swapping its ancient six acre canvas marquee for two massive plastic industrial sheds.
fields.body:
The Chelsea Flower Show, the start of the London summer season and a mecca of English gardeners, opened yesterday to accusations of bad taste and selling out to the global garden industry after swapping its ancient six acre canvas marquee for two massive plastic industrial sheds.

"Too utterly ghastly," said Lady Frances Smith, who has been coming to Chelsea for the past 38 years and was not amused by the £4m, 50ft high structures which the Queen visited yesterday. "They're like those dreadful DIY sheds you see on roundabouts. But at least they smell better".

"Just shows that gardening is a growth industry and the Royal Horticultural Society is cashing in," said John Sturrock, who has been exhibiting cottage style plants for 20 years.

But others rushed to the defence of the plastic sheds which 160,000 garden lovers are expected to visit in the next three days with up to 30,000 people indulging in an orgy of petal peddling on the last day.

"This is fantastic," said a sweet pea salesman sipping red wine. "There is much more light ... much more ventilation."

Sir Simon Hornby, president of the RHS, admitted that many people would miss the old tent but said the new pavilions would add a "fresh feel". Meanwhile the old marquee has been recycled into limited edition pinafores, snips at £84 each.

Chelsea may have rooted out its old world charm but its eccentricities are thriving. Yesterday's visitors were puzzling over how high fashion and hi-tech could mix it with sculptors, Arab sheiks, dot.com companies and the prison sevice - all of whom have sponsored show gardens. Where Laurent Perrier had produced a spiral labyrinth in celebration of a 17th century French natural philosopher and Shaikh Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan had commissioned a cool "garden of the night" in dark marble, the Leyhill open prisoners of Gloucestershire had recreated a derelict family coal mine in the Forest of Dean and planted it out with just about every rampant English weed and bits of old junk.

It struck a chord with Peter, a carpenter laying acres of decking nearby. "That's what I call a garden. Nice stinging nettles. Reminds me of home."

Elsewhere, between giant orchids, the first Jill Dando roses, armies of military style tulips and and forests of bonsai, Commonwealth countries were exhibiting the sort of hallucinogenic sub-tropical flowers which global warming might one day allow to be grown in Britain.

Not to be outdone by the Caribbean, South African or Australian exhibits, a US botanical garden had air-freighted in a quarter of an acre of tropical rainforest, complete with acrylic waterfalls but minus ants and wildlife.

But Barbados won the unofficial vote of passers-by with a selection of demented-looking scarlet asparagus plants, surreal heliconia rostratyas and nature's equivalent of the late Dame Barbara Cartland - an outrageously vivid curcuma plant.

"It's all very exciting," said Lady Arabella Lennox-Boyd, who has designed a garden of olive trees, sculptures and canals. "People have much more money and courage today. Gardening used to be exclusive. Everyone's experimenting now. "

Gardening is now an £11bn a year industry, one of the most popular and fast growing leisure sectors and the prices of everything from conservatories to pergolas have rocketed. Getting in on the boom times are artists and sculptors with painted Italian stone and effigies of animals and children.

"I am appalled at some of the quality here," said Alan Wilson, who was selling limited edition otters for £1,250 and men with their private parts covered by lizards for £20,000, and inscriptions in Latin. "It is easy to get out a credit card and put a deposit on a weasel if the mortgage is paid, the kids have left, you have got the yacht."

"This year, it is all water and reflections, hi tech and the millennium," says designer Geoff Whitten whose marsh garden looks back to the days when you could pick up an old ruin for a few hundred pounds. Now, made in false stone but muddied with real dirty water, his ruined cottage with a half-sunk boat has a reserve price of £40,000.
