fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle  continues his trek through the highlights of the world's biggest modern art museum  This week: Head of a Hostage (1943-44), by Jean Fautrier, in the Nude/Action/Body section of Tate Modern
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle continues his trek through the highlights of the world's biggest modern art museum This week: Head of a Hostage (1943-44), by Jean Fautrier, in the Nude/Action/Body section of Tate Modern
fields.body:
A head. Almost a head, something like a head. Jean Fautrier's Head of a Hostage, 1943-44, is a strange, molten, gobbetty lump of glistening lead, sheared by a piece of slate, which provides the central axis, the vertical of the nose, the sole division of the face. The piece of slate appears to have healed over. It gives Fautrier's head a kind of keel. It gives this near-formless lump its balance and its anonymous human presence.

There are several versions of this work. Another - perhaps a cast taken from this version (the form is reversed) - is a virulent green patinated bronze, and when I first saw it I thought of Ariel's song from the Tempest, hence the image of the sea, and thought of drowning. It is a drowned face, a head without eyes. When I look at it I think of how heavy one's own head feels in the moment before sleep. Walk around this leaden head, and the profile emerges, the keel of the face again, or perhaps its prow, cleaving the air. Seen front on, the head looks asphyxiated.

Fautrier, born in 1898, was bought up in England by his mother, was gassed at the end of the first world war, and detained by the SS in the Occupation in Paris in 1942. I think he made this work just after he left a sanitorium in Chamonix, in 1943. At about this time he also illustrated Georges Bataille's Madame Edwarda. Bataille talked of the formless as like spit. The lead of Fautrier's head is like spit too, solidified.

The other head by Fautrier in the room, the Grand Tragic Head from 1942, is more pained, one side of the face clawed flat, the other misshapen but alert. But the leaden lump is so much better - or worse. Like Medardo Rosso's heads, it is stuck between emergence and submergence, affectiveness and disappearance. It is drowning in its own base material.

webTitle: Best of the lot? Two mangled mallards

fields.headline: Best of the lot? Two mangled mallards
fields.standfirst: The works and the hang are as absurd as ever, but that doesn't stop  Adrian Searle having a soft spot for the Royal Academy summer exhibition
fields.trailText: The works and the hang are as absurd as ever, but that doesn't stop Adrian Searle having a soft spot for the Royal Academy summer exhibition
fields.body:
The Royal Academy summer exhibition is anachronistic; a toe-curling embarrassment. It is an essentially silly exhibition, drawn from a send-in of more than 10,000 works, and selected by a group of Royal Academicians, a motley body of mutually antithetical and incompatible temperaments.

I am rather fond of the summer show (I was even in it once, hung so high up I could barely be seen, of course), but only in those years when I am not obliged to review the thing. I enjoy its collisions and its disasters, the daftness of it, even the pervasive mediocrity. Painted plants in the potting shed, sunsets over the Venice Lagoon, nice views of even nicer places - why not, I ask. Girl on a Shady Terrace? Beehives and a Yellow Cat Set Among the Lavender, Provence? Often, the title is enough. Actually seeing the work is somehow superfluous. You can construct entire holidays and meals from the titles - Red Leicester and Pickled Onions; Granny Smith and Knife; Redcurrants. And you can be sure that there will be a picture of Ken Livingstone here somewhere, among the Morrises and Vanessas. There is.

You know things are getting a bit more serious when titles like Obelisk Drift, Encounter, Divided #84 and Circle Series (Interaction) start coming along - this, assuredly, is the kind of modern art that deserves a twangy counterpoint of 50s musique concrete and a voice-over explaining the crisis of the modern condition. I much prefer Adrian Berg's flaring, unchanging painted gardens; Norman "Knackers" Ackroyd's tenebrous etchings, Anthony Green's enthusiasm, and his wonky depictions of his life, or Freddie Gore's unexpected annual wildness. The novelty sculptures and Sunday conceptualist gags always take the biscuit - surely they are here only to remind us that every bad idea can have a good day, that for every vanguard, there has to be a rearguard. And when all else fails there's always Eduardo Paolozzi and Howard Hodgkin.

It is somehow warming to discover that there are still artists who pop in on Varnishing Day to do a spot of varnishing, or to craftily touch in an extra bit of colour, setting their works off against their accidental neighbours. Another bit of me takes perverse delight in the invariable awfulness, the one-upmanship, the hubris, the low horizon of it all. As works are numbered rather than labelled, one is constantly wrong-footed: gosh, look at that fake Anselm Keifer, you say, but then turn to the catalogue and see that these pastiches of German heavyweights like Keifer and Baselitz really are by the men themselves, conned into becoming honorary RAs. Cy Twombly sends in a scribbled note every year, and that weedy homage to Balthus - nude floppy-limbed girl on bed in languorous crumbly yellowing afternoon light - really is a Balthus.

It is when the exhibition tries too hard to be hip and with-it that things go wrong. Lewis Biggs, director of Tate Liverpool, and one of the judges of this year's Wollaston Award - a prize of £25,000 for the "most distinguished work" in the exhibition - raves about being "knocked out" by the standard and variety, and asks, "What other exhibition this year will combine the most cutting-edge, conceptual work with the utterly accessible?" I am afraid that the dread cliche "cutting-edge" signals that the man has been driven to desperation.

We might like to see the summer exhibition as the ultimate in radical pluralism, but somehow it never feels like that. Admittedly, the shortlist of artists selected for the Wollaston Award is a bit mind-boggling, going as it does from a small screenprint by Basil Beattie to a gargantuan hi-tech acrylic painting by Frank Stella, Hon RA, but it is a meaningless roll call. Gerard Hemsworth is on the shortlist with a painting of a rabbit, in schematic outline, that failed to win any kind of prize in last year's John Moores exhibition. My favourite contender is Georgia Hayes's Birds in the British Museum, a picture of two mangled mallards done in a style reminiscent of New York painter Donald Baechler: he used to get Bowery drunks and guys in prison to make drawings for him, which he then enlarged, very roughly, on big, dirty canvases. Hayes renders her touchingly pathetic ducks in overcooked, jaunty oil paint. It is still funny though. The ducks are definitely challenged by something or other.

Frank Stella gets an entire room to himself, which, at the end of last week, was crammed with two vast paintings and two huge scrap-metal sculptures. Apparently, a third sculpture is yet to be added. Born in 1936, Stella's career has run backwards - in that the work he made in his 20s was his best. For the past 30 years, things have gone steadily downhill for Stella. His severe, sober early works gave way to lunking drivel, neo-baroque arrangements of French curves, and now layered patches of fluorescent spray , spirals, computer-generated lattices, blats, staves and writhing forms derived from the shapes cigar smoke makes when photographed in a glass box. The sculptures, like the paintings, are big, cumbersome, overcomplicated grungy hulks.

There is something ogre-ish, maniacal and desperate about Stella's room at the Academy, but it hardly matters, as the summer exhibition is so utterly strange. Tony Cragg - himself an RA - has tried to make the room for which he was responsible look cool and sparse, with works by Richard Deacon, Cragg himself, Barry Flanagan and - another Wollaston Award contender - Brian McCann. Peter Blake, on the other hand, has made a sort of spoof Academy hang in an adjacent gallery, lining the walls with hundreds of smallish works. Some of these are so pointedly bad, that it is quite clear the gallery is more about Blake himself than the exhibits he has chosen to include. Stella's is one kind of insufferable egoism, Blake's another.

The new president of the RA, Phillip King, is, like Cragg and new recruit William Tucker, a sculptor. He is also having to come to grips with the politics of an institution that has been far too clubbable for far too long. Some Royal Academicians are barely worth the letters after their name, and many of those who resigned over the inclusion of Marcus Harvey's portrait of Myra Hindley, in the Sensation show in 1997, are, I notice, sloping back. But do we really want a more relevant academy? Do we care?

The Academy is weird, and there's nothing weirder than the summer exhibition. It would be terrible if the RA turned itself into a replicant of all the other contemporary galleries and art spaces in London, lauding the same artists, vaunting the same dubious pantheon. I, for one, don't mind a bit of old-fashioned aesthetic conservatism - and where, in current art-speak, would the cutting edge be without the existence of a rearguard? Whence challenge without old-style values? But no one really believes all this. The whole thing is a charade. With the appointment of Phillip King and mutterings abroad, it appears that there is an attempt to re-jig the summer show for once and for all, and to entice our better younger artists into the fold. This may be the last time to see the summer exhibition in its present form. But then they always say that, and it always stays more or less the same.

 The summer exhibition opens at the Royal Academy, London W1, on Monday. Details: 020-7300 8000.

fields.headline: Outside the tent
fields.trailText: Larry Elliott's recommendations for public investment in the north (2.5m reasons for radical regional policies, May 22) are compelling. But if northern cities are to compete with London, investment should start with cultural policy.
fields.body:
Larry Elliott's recommendations for public investment in the north (2.5m reasons for radical regional policies, May 22) are compelling. But if northern cities are to compete with London, investment should start with cultural policy.

In the same issue, we read of "Lottery bail-out for sinking Dome". Last week, Tate Bankside opened; a week before, new galleries at the National Portrait Gallery; recently the London Eye, and renewed Royal Opera House. Next week, the refurbished Dulwich Gallery opens. Barely a month passes without a new cultural facility in London, each with public money. This amounts to billions in regional aid to the UK's wealthiest area. Yet there are as many people living within 90 miles of Piccadilly Manchester as Piccadilly London. The dome failed because it was put in an already overprovided yet, for most people, remote south-east corner of Britain.
Brian Hatton
London

 The total granted to the dome, including the latest "donation", equals approximately £2.7m per local authority in the UK. We are finding it difficult to raise the £1.25m we need to build an innovative and fully accessible centre to provide a wide range of services for people with disabilities. What represents better value - a tent in the suburbs of London or providing every town and city in the UK with proper facilities for disabled people?
Andy Berry
Chair, Gloucestershire Disability One-Stop Shop
andy@tof.co.uk

 I cannot remember a Monday morning when my anger has been so compounded with cynicism and frustration. As I was interviewing young Asians in Bradford with a view to recommending Millennium Commission grants of £3,000 or so which will benefit them and their local communities, the government was asking the commission to bale out the dome with another £30m.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford, W Yorks

fields.headline: Weblines
fields.trailText: Sites we like
fields.body:
'Thinking women' (is there any other type?) are the target for new website United Women's Voice. This e-paper features a daily digest of home and international news, a soapbox section and arts reviews to "inform, enlighten and amuse". Figures from Joan of Arc to Sylvia Plath are profiled in its regular glance at women in history. Online polls and a contributors' section encourage women to have their say, on everything from business to babies. An interactive salary checker tells you what you should be earning. A thoughtful and welcome contrast to the current trend for ad-led women's sites.

 Cyberspace displays a bizarre amount of interest in women's hair this month. Attitude-laden ChickClick plays host to a debate about 80s styles in which an alarming number of hair don'ts appear, from horror stories of crimping and frizzy perms to the confessions of a side ponytail owner. Meanwhile online current affairs magazine Salon reviews a new, 238-page history of hair politics. Author Diane Simon draws parallels between women's rights and hair flair - the 20s trend for bobs as feminism reared its head, the braiding parlours frequented by African-American women as they rediscovered their roots etc.

Political party workers disappointed by poor turnouts at the recent London mayoral and local elections could learn a trick or two from US women's supersite ivillage. This well-established women's portal includes an election 2000 sub-site to demystify this year's US state primary and presidential voting. Visitors can register online to vote or take part in "town hall Tuesdays", a weekly interactive forum for women to chat with candidates, which has so far included Al Gore and Hillary Clinton. "Fishy" or "flabby" responses are forbidden.

Pomoting her new book on Beme this month, The Fast Show's Arabella ("Does my bum look big in this?") Weir celebrates the joys of growing up in the 70s. Not content with playing truant, smoking dope and fancying Les out of the Bay City Rollers, Weir admits the best thing was not worrying about sexually-transmitted diseases: "It's not that I wish my own daughter could shag around in the way we all did. It's just now I hope girls have been taught that they are entitled not to have sex if they don't want to."

Author Diane Simon draws parallels between women's rights and hair flair - the 20s trend for bobs as feminism reared its head, the braiding parlours frequented by African-American women as they rediscovered their roots etc. Political party workers disappointed by poor turnouts at the recent London mayoral and local elections could learn a trick or two from US women's supersite ivillage. This well-established women's portal includes an election 2000 sub-site to demystify this year's US state primary and presidential voting. Visitors can register online to vote or take part in "town hall Tuesdays", a weekly interactive forum for women to chat with candidates, which has so far included Al Gore and Hillary Clinton. "Fishy" or "flabby" responses are forbidden. Pomoting her new book on Beme this month, The Fast Show's Arabella ("Does my bum look big in this?") Weir celebrates the joys of growing up in the 70s. Not content with playing truant, smoking dope and fancying Les out of the Bay City Rollers, Weir admits the best thing was not worrying about sexually-transmitted diseases: "It's not that I wish my own daughter could shag around in the way we all did. It's just now I hope girls have been taught that they are entitled not to have sex if they don't want to."

fields.headline: No: 1640 Quasimodo
fields.trailText: "Morning in Paris, the city awakes/To the bells of Notre Dame/The fisherman fishes, the bakerman bakes/To the bells of Notre Dame/To the big bells as loud as the thunder/To the little bells soft as a psalm."
fields.body:
"Morning in Paris, the city awakes/To the bells of Notre Dame/The fisherman fishes, the bakerman bakes/To the bells of Notre Dame/To the big bells as loud as the thunder/To the little bells soft as a psalm."

Very nice. But "psalm" doesn't really rhyme with "dame", you know. What are you singing? A song from the 1996 Disney adaptation of The Hunchback of Notre Dame.

I see. Isn't there a musical adaptation of Victor Hugo's 576-page novel Notre Dame de Paris by Richard Cocciante and lyrics by Luc Plamondon coming to the London stage tonight, fresh from great success in Paris where 600,000 people saw it, but translated into English? No.

There is, isn't there? Yes.

There have been lots of adaptations of Hugo's Quasimodo story, haven't there, ranging from an 1836 opera with libretto by Hugo to films including one starring Lon Chaney (above) in 1923? Yes.

Story please. Deformed bell-ringer (Quasimodo) fancies Gypsy girl (Esmeralda). Evil priest (Frollo) fancies her, too. E fancies captain. F kills captain. E suspected. Q shelters E in cathedral. F finds E and, when E rejects F, leaves E to executioner. Q throws F from cathedral tower. Later two skeletons found in E's tomb - one of a hunchback embracing one of a woman. QED.

Thanks. I've got a hunch this new musical will be a success, like the one by that other bloke, Les Miserables. Geddit? Get what?

Never mind. There are a lot of deformed Frenchmen in London at the moment, including one in Charles Aznavour's musical about Toulouse-Lautrec. But why no musical about Richard III? Good point. I can imagine it starting like this: "A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!/I'm known as a hunchback, but there's more to me of course/Everyone seems to think I'm a total chump/Which, to be honest, can give a boy the hump."

It'll never happen. Let's hope not.

fields.headline: Image of IT
fields.trailText: Ann Swain (Letters, May 20) may believe that the IT industry has to "change its image" to attract more women, but in my experience it is women who have a problem with IT. The problem is simply that, to quote various female friends, IT is "boring", and the people who work in it "sad". Better a shop assistant than a geek, whatever the perks and pay.
fields.body:
Ann Swain (Letters, May 20) may believe that the IT industry has to "change its image" to attract more women, but in my experience it is women who have a problem with IT. The problem is simply that, to quote various female friends, IT is "boring", and the people who work in it "sad". Better a shop assistant than a geek, whatever the perks and pay.

The same attitude is apparent in studies showing that female undergraduates will avoid course modules with a maths or computing content, let alone whole degrees, despite superior maths results at GCSE level. Various "science is cool and sexy" campaigns have done little to change this. Quotas for female students often remain unfilled through lack of applicants.

It is difficult to imagine what sort of image change would work - perhaps one that pretended IT was cool and programming wasn't important. I think it's called e-commerce.
Julian Lawton
Leeds
julian.lawton@virgin.net

fields.headline: A child of our time
fields.trailText: On the day Tony Blair came out of Downing Street to herald the arrival of baby Leo (Leo brings pangs of old labour, May 22), Denis Wise hoisted his five-month-old boy along with the FA Cup. Both moments were hugely touching (though not without anxiety: Denis narrowly avoided braining his baby). Both babies undoubtedly enhanced their fathers' aura of success.
fields.body:
On the day Tony Blair came out of Downing Street to herald the arrival of baby Leo (Leo brings pangs of old labour, May 22), Denis Wise hoisted his five-month-old boy along with the FA Cup. Both moments were hugely touching (though not without anxiety: Denis narrowly avoided braining his baby). Both babies undoubtedly enhanced their fathers' aura of success.

Meanwhile, I am applying for work for which I am qualified, yet felt compelled to quote back at the employer their claim to invite applications "from all sections of the community, particularly from people with disabilities", adding that hopefully, then, they'd consider a part-time applicant with one child still pre-school. I am delighted at the prospect of a baby in the seat of power, of a new family dimension to the male preserve of football, but can't help noting this: a child crowns a man's success, but to a mother in the job market, it is still a serious disability.
Sophie Kersey
Tunbridge Wells, Kent sjkersey@supanet.com

 We are two working women, who breathed a sigh of relief on reading Joan Smith (Enough Already, May 22). Media obsession with designer babies born to a life of privilege has nothing to do with most people's lives. It deflects attention from serious political debate about child poverty and the reality of being a parent in Blair's New Britain. Enough is enough.
Helen Shaw and Deborah Coles
London

 Even a www link. So what about the tens of thousands of babies born the world over on the same day into a life of abject poverty? A comparison of the life Leo is likely to have with that of a child born in Sudan would have made much better reporting.
John Bissett
Hebburn, Tyne & Wear
johnbissett@cableinet.co.uk

 Glad to see you didn't go over the top this morning with the neonatal Blair - just the front page, an editorial and G2 showed remarkable restraint. I suppose a pull-out, all-colour christening edition is out of the question?
Dr Robert Court
Weston-super-Mare, Somerset
court@hemscott.net

 Did Tony and Cherie pick the name Leo for the reasons we did? Leo McGree was a distinguished post-war communist and labour leader; Leo(pold) Bloom the literary hero of the 20th century in Joyce's Ulysses; and Leo McKern the best character in the 60s TV series The Prisoner. Great choice.
Natalie Seeve-McKenna
Liverpool
nataliem@liverpool.ac.uk

 It is a shame the baby was not called Eric as a tribute to the author who epitomised true socialist ideals.
Daniel Colover
London

 Shouldn't the baby have been called Lionel? I suppose one all-singing, all dancing male in the family is enough.
Mark Walker
London

 My children are very impressed that the Blairs have named their new son after the Red Power Ranger.
Anne Salter
Balquhidder, Perthshire
Anne@geomantics.com

 Leo should have no problem attending prime minister's questions... after all, no unseemly breast-feeding.
Sue Negri
Norwich
sue.negri.socs@norfolk.gov.uk

 Surely Taurus? But then Taury Blair wouldn't have sounded quite right, would it?
Mike Atkinson
Nottingham

 Leo Blair is an anagram of I bore all.
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes, Bucks

fields.headline: Dear John
fields.standfirst: In a letter to the immortal memory of an 'irreplaceable' friend,  John Mortimer reflects on the inspirational life and career of John Gielgud, who has died
fields.trailText: In a letter to the immortal memory of an 'irreplaceable' friend,  John Mortimer reflects on the inspirational life and career of John Gielgud, who has died
fields.body:
I always thought you were immortal. Ten years ago, when you were well over 80, we were in Tuscany and you were playing the disreputable, lecherous old journalist who insists on going on a summer holiday in order to embarrass his family, in a filmed version of Summer's Lease. You went home, had a small operation and came back a week later still chain-smoking, gossiping, talking endlessly, acting with a faultless touch, as though there had been no interruption.

I remember a long night shoot with you talking in a dark garden. We got on to your great comic creation, John Worthing and your memory of Bosie. "Lord Alfred Douglas was a beautiful young man who ended up sour and ugly. Can you believe this? He was at the first 'The Importance' and he couldn't remember whether it was played as farce or comedy. He was Wilde's closest friend and he couldn't remember a single thing about the production."

I suppose I was not much more than 10 when I saw your first Hamlet, an intelligent, witty, sensitive and poetic prince, for me the Hamlet of all time. "I played other characters," you said, "but I always thought of Hamlet as me." I can still see you as Richard of Bordeaux, a spoiled king, bathed in a golden light. I wrote for a signed photograph of you wearing a trilby hat and the star of the Good Companions. I never dreamed that I'd grow up to sit with you in the canteen of Thames Television and have you tell me that you learned more from your failures than your successes. When you were at the Old Vic, playing all the great roles in your youth, James Agate came round to congratulate you in the interval on Macbeth because, he said, "I might have changed my mind by the end of the play". As you talked your hands moved to the rhythm of your speech. "Ken Tynan said I only had two gestures, the left hand up, the right hand up - what does he want me to do? Bring out my prick?"

The pre-war theatre was dominated by two great stars. You and Olivier. You were the master of the poetry, easily moving the audience because you were so effortlessly in tears yourself. You told me that your mother cried "almost constantly like a wet April". Olivier, with the clipped delivery, was the physical actor, dropping from a great height to kill Claudius and rolling down a long staircase as Coriolanus. The rivalry became a collaboration when you and Olivier alternated as Romeo and Mercutio in an unforgettable production.

Shakespeare hadn't been played in the West End since the days of Irving and Tree, but you made him a box office hit on Shaftesbury Avenue and then, in the 50s, the theatre changed, Look Back In Anger came to the Court and poetry seemed to be no longer wanted. Luckily, it was Tony Richardson, also from the Court, who cast you as Lord Raglan in the Charge of the Light Brigade and a great player of film comedy was revealed.

You said that you had three besetting sins, on and off the stage, impetuosity, self-consciousness and "a lack of interest in anything not immediately connected with myself or the theatre". This lack of interest extended to horses. You played the King of France on horseback during the filming of Becket. The director told you to say the line and the horse would move one pace forward. At the first take you said the line, of course impeccably, but the horse remained immobile. By the seventh take the horse had still not moved on cue, or at all. Then, extremely puzzled, you asked the director: "Do you think the animal knows?"

It was true that you took a somewhat vague view of matters not connected with yourself or the theatre. One night in wartime you were seen to look sadly up at the barrage balloons which protected London and said: "I do feel so sorry for our poor boys up there. They must be terribly lonely." I remember a dinner long ago at Tony Richardson's house. My actress daughter Emily was a baby then, and we had brought her with us in a carrycot and left her in a spare bedroom. We were lugging this pink plastic box out of the front door when you saw us and said: "Why on earth didn't you leave your child at home? Are you afraid of burglars?"

You were also, of course, the most famous brick dropper of all time. Having directed Richard Burton in Hamlet, you went into his dressing room meaning to say, "We'll go to dinner when you are ready" but your critical subconscious made you come out with, "We'll go to dinner when you're better". Your classic dropped brick came when you were having lunch in the old Ivy with a pre-war playwright whose name, curiously enough, was Edward Knoblock.

A man came in at the door and waved to you and Knoblock asked you who he was. "That," you said with great confidence, "is the second most boring man in London." "So who's the first most boring man in London?" the playwright asked, to which you unhesitatingly replied, "Edward Knoblock, of course". And then, realising you had said exactly the right thing, you tried to mend matters by adding, "Not you, of course, I mean the other Edward Knoblock".

Apart from Summer's Lease you did a radio play of mine and you were unforgettable as Charles Ryder's father in a television adaptation I did of Brideshead Revisited. The scene in which, with barely concealed malice, you mock your son's unwelcome need of money must rank among the great comic performances of all time. You had that essential quality of all comedy performers. The scene must always be played absolutely seriously, and the actor must never think he is being funny.

So I have been extraordinarily lucky. You introduced me to Shakespeare on the stage, and you said lines I have written. More than that you were, as everyone who knew you or worked with you can testify, an inspiration to all of us and a constant, unexpected, unpredictable joy to be with. I suppose we must accept the idea that you are not immortal, but irreplaceable you most certainly are.

fields.trailText: A panel about national tests faced by schoolchildren, page 5, May 20, was headed Britain when it applied only to England and Wales. Scotland has a separate education system and a different testing regime.
fields.body:
A panel about national tests faced by schoolchildren, page 5, May 20, was headed Britain when it applied only to England and Wales. Scotland has a separate education system and a different testing regime.

In an interview with the leader of the British National party, Weekend magazine, May 20, we said that given Britain's population of 60m and an annual average of 50,000 asylum-seeker applications, the Home Office was being asked to consider one refugee case for every 12,000 UK citizens. We should have said one case for every 1,200 citizens.

The author of an article about competition among television channels for Asian viewers, page 8, Media Guardian, yesterday, is Paran Balakrishnan, not Palan Barakrishnan.

fields.headline: Robots and religion
fields.trailText: You say (The unhappy prince, May 18) there may be a "growing backlash against science". It is wrong to see this debate as pro or anti science - legitimate concerns about possible applications of new scientific knowledge are shared by many scientists.
fields.body:
You say (The unhappy prince, May 18) there may be a "growing backlash against science". It is wrong to see this debate as pro or anti science - legitimate concerns about possible applications of new scientific knowledge are shared by many scientists.

For example, Bill Joy, co-founder of Sun Microsystems and creator of internet systems such as Java, wrote recently: "The 21st century technologies - genetics, nanotechnology, and robotics - are so powerful that they can spawn whole new classes of accidents and abuses." Echoing the concerns of environmentalists about the haphazard release of GM crops, he says these technologies will give us "the possibility not just of weapons of mass destruction but of knowledge-enabled mass destruction; this destructiveness hugely amplified by the power of self-replication".

Human values and concerns, and their expression through political processes, are required to enable us to make civilised choices about the future. The constant parroting (often by non-scientists) of the "sound science will decide the outcome" mantra will not help.
Peter Melchett
Executive director, Greenpeace UK

 Jonathan Porritt (Comment, May 20) argues scientists are responsible for the destruction of the environment because they have "taught us to see ourselves as random, purposeless bipeds, with an inherently destructive nature".

The implication that prescientific cultures preserved the environment because of their religious beliefs does not stand up. Easter Island, the abandoned city of Petra and the deserts of the southwestern US are just a few examples of how ancient peoples degraded and destroyed their environments. It is the ability of rational science to measure and predict environmental destruction and to prescribe solutions that offers the best hope of saving the planet. The myth of the noble savage living in harmony with nature is a distraction.
Niall Dillon
London

fields.headline: No vote for democracy
fields.standfirst: Italian apathy affects the rest of Europe
fields.trailText: Once again, the Italians have endorsed the way they are governed despite its manifest failings. That is to say some 70% of them did not turn out for a referendum on replacing proportional representation with first past the post and the vote was therefore invalidated. There are reasons for apathy.
fields.body:
Once again, the Italians have endorsed the way they are governed despite its manifest failings. That is to say some 70% of them did not turn out for a referendum on replacing proportional representation with first past the post and the vote was therefore invalidated. There are reasons for apathy. Sunday was a rerun of last year's failed referendum and people tire. The Italian economy is looking up at last, which might have encouraged complacency about the political system. Alternatively, abstention was a way of endorsing the prospect of the right wing coming to power for the first time since 1994. Silvio Berlusconi told his supporters not to bother and a lot of other Italians seem to have joined them.

Even so it is a deplorable result (which, incidentally, has few implications for the UK case for election reform). Under the system voters failed to change, Mr Berlusconi is likely to take power, but dependent on neo-fascists and northern separatists. They might push him into an even more extreme position on entry into Italy, where he has talked about firing on vessels in the Adriatic on suspicion of their carrying refugees and immigrants. What price diplomatic isolation of Austria by the European Union when a coalition not so dissimilar to that in Vienna takes power in Rome?

Inside the EU the outcomes of domestic elections have long since ceased to be national business alone. Italian economic underperformance in part explains the euro's weakness. Structural reforms were promised by the centre-left governments led by Romano Prodi then Massimo D'Alema; they have both joined the deep ranks of short-lived Italian prime ministers. Present incumbent Giuliano Amato will be lucky to get by until the election that has to take place by next May. Changing the basis for elections to the chamber of deputies would not have guaranteed either strong government or the centre-left's prosperity, but it would have helped.

fields.headline: Eritrea's war
fields.trailText: Lord Avebury asserts that Ethiopia's offensive contravenes international law (Letters, May 19). It is a pity he and others were reluctant to speak out against Eritrea's invasion of Ethiopia in May 1998, the direct cause of the conflict.
fields.body:
Lord Avebury asserts that Ethiopia's offensive contravenes international law (Letters, May 19). It is a pity he and others were reluctant to speak out against Eritrea's invasion of Ethiopia in May 1998, the direct cause of the conflict. Avebury has extended extraordinary latitude to Eritrea, which by its aggressive behaviour (four countries invaded in four years) has provoked an arms race in the Horn. Before the Eritrean invasion Ethiopian defence spending was 2% of GDP and its army a third of the size of Eritrea's. The authorities in Eritrea have held no elections since coming to power nine years ago and minority ethnic groups such as the Afar and Kunama are persecuted.
Tony Hickey
Addis Ababa, Ethiopia

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer flirted with levels it last experienced at the start of the previous decade yesterday as investors braced for news expected this morning of an unprecedented cut in its dividend.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer flirted with levels it last experienced at the start of the previous decade yesterday as investors braced for news expected this morning of an unprecedented cut in its dividend.

The 5% fall in its shares to 220.75p, off the day's low of 218p, looked meagre, however, in comparison with the woes experienced by Psion, which fell 78p - nearly 15% - to 484p, and Baltimore, which ended the day 51p lower at 368p.

In a continuation of a loss of favour in the hi-tech stocks, many of which only joined the FTSE 100 three months ago, Arm Holdings was lower at 550p, down 65.5p, while Misys fell 47p to 488p.

But, the sharp falls in technology stocks, as well as some of the telecoms and media groups, were mitigated by rises in "old economy" stocks which left the FTSE 100 index just 9.9 points lower at 6,035.5.

The same could not be said of the Techmark for technology shares, however, which continued its slide to end at 2,925, down 126 points or 4%, and ever closer to the 2,300 level at which the market made its debut in November.

Inside the FTSE 100, telecoms company Kingston Communications, based in Hull, fell 63p to 535p as it unveiled plans to go national but suffered a dent its profits as a result of investment spending. Like other "new economy" stocks, it risks being catapulted from the blue chip index at the quarterly reshuffle next month. Colt Telecom, its FTSE rival with which it is building the national fibre optic network, also lost ground, ending 50p lower at 1,862p.

British Airways was another loser, down 10.5p to 374.25p ahead of the maiden results for chief executive Rod Eddington. Yet Barclays, which is also expected to make an announcement, about its e-commerce strategy, gained 48p to 1.622p. Other banks gained some ground: Abbey National rose 29p to 814p and Halifax was up 5.5p to 608p.

Other gains in the FTSE 100 came from BP Amoco, up 5.5p to 614.5p, and British American Tobacco, one of the tobacco companies trying to stop the government's move to prevent them advertising, which rose nearly 9% to 416.5p, up 34.75p.

Dealers said investors were tending to take their money and hold it in cash, a sentiment that appeared to be echoed in a survey conducted by US investment bank Merrill Lynch which showed that fund managers in the US were planning to raise their holdings of cash to the highest for six years.

webTitle: Blue Circle plays down US talks

fields.headline: Blue Circle plays down US talks
fields.trailText: Shares in Blue Circle Industries have gone off the boil. They reached 450p before French building materials group Lafarge was sent packing with its 420p per share - £3.4bn - hostile bid. Yesterday they were in the doldrums at 420p as management played down the importance of another potential deal, this time with Southdown, the second-biggest cement manufacturer in the United States.
fields.body:
Shares in Blue Circle Industries have gone off the boil. They reached 450p before French building materials group Lafarge was sent packing with its 420p per share - £3.4bn - hostile bid. Yesterday they were in the doldrums at 420p as management played down the importance of another potential deal, this time with Southdown, the second-biggest cement manufacturer in the United States.

Blue Circle chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite, who has had a baptism of fire since taking the helm last summer, was keen to emphasise that a strategy which had kept Lafarge at bay was still in place: "Our priority remains the delivery of our performance improvements and return of capital."

He is aware that investors are touchy about big acquisitions because a spate of deals, such as the takeover of Alexandria Cement, followed soon after an October profits warning.

But insiders said that talks with Southdown were well advanced and City analysts were enthusiastic about the benefits of a deal being struck, noting there were good synergies between the two.

Certainly there would be tactical advantages in a deal for Blue Circle management. An enlarged group would dilute the power of Lafarge, which has a 29.6% stake that will rise to 34% once an £800m share buyback is executed at the British group.

Southdown has a reputation for being well run and could help Blue Circle achieve its aim of reduced costs. Analyst Mike Betts of JP Morgan noted that Blue Circle's margin on earnings before interest depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) margin was 18% while Southdown's was almost double this.

The two companies would fit together neatly. Both are under pressure to play a part in the consolidation that is sweeping the sector and are poised to construct new facilities in the US.

Southdown could help steady Blue Circle's balance sheet which will be stretched by its share buy-back commitment. And apart from the state of Georgia, there is little overlap between the businesses that would worry competition regulators in North America.

Rising interest rates will put a squeeze on the US cement market. That means Southdown could accept a lower takeover price than the one that stopped Blue Circle in its tracks before.

Other predators are circling Southdown but well-placed sources ruled out Britain's RMC.

Blue Circle is a good bet for investors whether the Southdown talks come to something or not. There is the share buyback to look forward to, a chance that Asia will return strongly and hopes that the company's internal recovery programme will come up trumps.

fields.headline: Arjo Wiggins Appleton
fields.trailText: The Agnelli family, the force behind Italy's Fiat group, yesterday bid £1.3bn for full control of Arjo Wiggins Appleton, the Anglo-French paper company.
fields.body:
The Agnelli family, the force behind Italy's Fiat group, yesterday bid £1.3bn for full control of Arjo Wiggins Appleton, the Anglo-French paper company.

The bid, which values the whole of the high quality paper maker at £2.2bn, is being recommended by AWA's independent directors.

The cash offer of 255p a share is being made through Worms & Cie, a Paris-based investment company controlled by the Agnelli family. Worms already owns a 40% stake as a result of a complex deal in 1990 in which Wiggins Teape Appleton bought the paper making assets of Arjomari Prioux, part of the Worms empire, to form AWA.

Ken Minton, AWA's executive chairman, said the deal would give the company greater financial firepower to make acquisitions in already identified growth areas. These included very fine, high added value branded papers, drawing and art papers, and banknote and security papers.

Mr Minton, who will remain executive chairman of AWA, said Worms fully endorsed the restructuring programme already under way at the group.

He did not expect further job losses beyond the 2,000 already announced. The bulk of those were in in France, Britain and the United States.

The AWA board is recommending the bid on the grounds that the present share price does not fully reflect the company's prospects. The bid includes the payment to AWA shareholders of a 5p special dividend, effectively valuing the shares at 260p each.

Worms' main investments are a 47% stake in St Louis Sucre, France's second largest sugar producer, 4.2% of the French-based Danone food group, and 1.3% of the Accor hotel, travel agency and restaurant group. The 1990 deal creating Arjo Wiggins Appleton was criticised because it was not clear who benefited and where control lay.

Arjomari Prioux was 40% owned by St Louis Sucre, which was 47% owned by Worms; Worms now owns the 40% stake in AWA and will end up with 100% if its bid is successful. Worms itself is 53% owned by the Agnelli family and 23% by French financier Nicholas Worms.

webTitle: US supreme court eases restrictions on cable TV sex

fields.headline: US supreme court eases restrictions on cable TV sex
fields.trailText: The US supreme court has decided by a narrow margin that congress went too far when it acted to restrict sex-oriented programming on cable television.
fields.body:
The US supreme court has decided by a narrow margin that congress went too far when it acted to restrict sex-oriented programming on cable television.

The court's ruling is certain to revive the debate about broadcasting explicit sex scenes and discussions on television, a potent issue in an election year.

It stems from complaints by Playboy Television, part of Hugh Hefner's resurgent Playboy empire, that government action has inhibited the rights of broadcasters enshrined in the first amendment, part of which guarantees free speech.

By a majority of 5-4, the court ruled yesterday that the government had not explored every alternative course of action available to it when it imposed the law restricting sex shows on cable television, as allowed by the Communications Decency Act of 1996.

"If television broadcasts can expose children to the real risk of harmful exposure to indecent materials even in their own home and without parental consent, there is a problem the government can address," Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote in his summary of the judgement.

However the government decided to deal with the problem, "it must do so in a way consistent with first-amendment principles," he continued.

The court concluded: "Here, the government has not met the burden the first amendment imposes."

The court upheld a lower court's decision that the government had options other than imposing the restrictions available to it.

The ruling throws back on the government the burden of coming up with a way of controlling the output of cable channels, which have been showing increasingly explicit sex programmes.

The 1996 decency act, introduced after complaints from church groups and conservative family lobbies, restricts sex-oriented channels to operating at night unless they "scramble" their signal, making it impossible for anyone but a subscriber to receive what they offer.

There had been complaints that even when the signal was scrambled adults and children could still hear the sex channel.

Cable channel operators object to the night-time restriction because they know that many of their potential audience are likely to watch during the day and the restrictions have meant a loss of advertising revenue.

Sex-oriented programming on cable television is now worth many millions of dollars a year and programme-makers have made it clear that they will fight any attempts to slow down its growth.

The subject of sex on television has become a big election-year issue. Candidates have to tread the line between appearing to condone sexually explicit programming and being labelled as opposed to free speech.

While cable channels such as Bravo delete even common swear-words - all were removed from a showing of of Mike Leigh's Secrets and Lies last weekend- others have pushed the medium to its limits, showing explicit material.

The shock radio jockey and television personality Howard Stern is currently running a parody of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in which scantily clad women compete to win new body parts for themselves. The explosion of such programmes has led conservative groups to organise boycotts of advertisers associated with lewd programming.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Monitors in poll plea to Mugabe
fields.body:
Monitors in poll plea to Mugabe

Free and fair elections are unlikely in Zimbabwe because of the political violence and unfair electoral practices, an international election-monitoring group said yesterday.

The National Democratic Institute delegation, led by the former Nigerian vice-president Alex Ekwueme, urged President Robert Mugabe to take immediate steps to end the violence, which has claimed 23 lives, and to establish the basics for free and fair polls.

The report, dismissed by a government spokesman as "senseless", criticised Zimbabwe's leaders for restricting essential voter information and promoting biased reporting. Parliamentary elections are due in late June.
Andrew Meldrum, Harare

Lawyers ask for Ocalan move

Lawyers for the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan said yesterday that their client was having breathing problems due to allergies .

Ocalan, who was sentenced to death last year, is the sole prisoner on Imrali island. Turkey has postponed the decision whether to carry out the death sentence until the European Court of Human Rights reviews his appeal.

The lawyers say Ocalan should be moved from his cell, or at least allowed more outdoor exercise.
AP, Ankara

500 given drugs pardon in Dubai

Dubai's crown prince, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, has pardoned 500 people - including 300 foreigners - convicted of drug abuse, newspapers said yesterday.

The foreigners will be deported, while those from the United Arab Emirates will be placed in a rehabilitation centre or given treatment at home, the attorney general, Ibrahim Boumelha, was quoted as saying. He said his office was considering decriminalising drug abuse, which he said had reached dangerous levels.
AP, Dubai

Czechs give gold to Slovakia

A symbolic gold bar passed from the hands of the Czech prime minister, Milos Zeman, to his Slovak counterpart, Mikulas Dzurinda, ending a property dispute between the two countries, which were once the two halves of a federation.

The gold brick, weighing 14kg (31lb) and worth £66,000, is part of 4.1 tonnes of gold the Czech authorities refused to turn over to the Slovaks when Czechoslovakia broke apart in 1993.
AP, Prague

Astronauts fix space station

Two spacewalking astronauts sped through a first set of urgent repairs to the international space station yesterday, fixing several exterior problems well ahead of schedule.

webTitle: UK hopes to win carbon credits deal with China

fields.headline: UK hopes to win carbon credits deal with China
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The government is encouraging British Nuclear Fuels to build nuclear power stations in China so Britain can claim credit under an international treaty to curb global warming.
fields.body:
The government is encouraging British Nuclear Fuels to build nuclear power stations in China so Britain can claim credit under an international treaty to curb global warming.

Part of the Kyoto protocol is that developed nations can claim carbon credits if they help developing countries install clean technologies which do not add carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. These credits can count towards the donor countries' reduction in carbon dioxide emissions.

Most of Europe wants nuclear power excluded from climate change negotiations because the problem of nuclear waste has not been solved. The UK argues that nuclear power can be classed alongside wind and solar power as it does not produce carbon dioxide.

Detailed negotiations on the Kyoto protocol under which developed nations are legally bound to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 begin next month in Bonn. It is hoped an agreement will be signed at a 150 nations meeting at the Hague in November.

British Nuclear Fuels, through its subsidiary companies Westinghouse and ABB Combustion Engineering, are competing with France and Canada to sell nuclear power stations to China using the carbon credits idea as a selling point. China has said it will not make a decision until it knows how it can sell the carbon saved back to the west.

Gilbert Vaughan, for Westinghouse, confirmed the company was hoping to sell reactors to China. "We regard nuclear power as a green technology, an essential part of a country's energy mix, particularly one anxious not to add any further carbon dioxide into the atmosphere."

In the treaty negotiations the UK, France and Canada are combining with China and India to get nuclear power included in the "clean development mechanism" or CDM. The rest of the EU and a large number of developing countries object, mainly because they believe that heavy investment in new nuclear stations will starve solar and wind power of funds.

The 35 countries which make up the alliance of small island states, which will be the first to be swamped by rising sea levels, say that if nuclear power was allowed in the CDM the climate talks would just become a subsidy for nuclear power.

Denmark's environment minister, Svend Auken, said: "The CDM is about clean development and nuclear energy has no place."

The environment lobby is also opposed to nuclear power. Greenpeace calculates that if China built nuclear instead of coal it could claim saving 4.5m tonnes of carbon a year. With carbon likely to trade between £7 and £20 a tonne this could net the Chinese between £300m and £900m over 10 years. Carbon credit would cut the capital cost of nuclear stations by between 10% and 40%, according to Greenpeace.

The Department of Environment said: "The aim of the CDM is to reduce emissions and promote sustainable development in developing countries, as well as allow for a cost effective way for developed countries to meet their Kyoto targets.

"The UK government believes that developing country governments should have the final say about which CDM projects they accept .

"We are encouraging British business generally to think about potential CDM projects, particularly in the fields of renewable energy and energy efficiency."

fields.headline: Soccer dry zones 'not the answer'
fields.standfirst: More about recent football violence
fields.trailText: Police yesterday cast doubt on claims that the closure of bars in Belgium and Holland during next month's European football championships could thwart hooliganism.
fields.body:
Police yesterday cast doubt on claims that the closure of bars in Belgium and Holland during next month's European football championships could thwart hooliganism.

Earlier the Home Office minister, Lord Bassam, said that turning cities where matches will be played into dry zones could help to maintain order.

However, a spokesman for the national criminal intelligence service said such a move might generate greater problems because large crowds with nowhere to go would be out on the streets.

Those intent on drunken violence would still find a way.

"Closing every alcohol outlet would not stop violence because fans would still manage to smuggle in alcohol if they were hellbent on it." Press Association

fields.headline: Lenny's Atlantic adventure
fields.trailText: Comedian Lenny Henry and yachtsman Tony Bullimore set sail from Plymouth yesterday on a transatlantic voyage to Jamaica.
fields.body:
Comedian Lenny Henry and yachtsman Tony Bullimore set sail from Plymouth yesterday on a transatlantic voyage to Jamaica.

The 6ft 5in tall self-confessed landlubber and the world class sailor will spend three weeks together on a 53ft trimaran, the Nootka. Their 5,000 mile journey to Montego Bay will be filmed from another boat and they will record a video diary for a BBC show, Lenny's Big Atlantic Adventure.

Henry has undergone intensive survival training with the Royal Navy and has been out three times on training runs with Bullimore.

"I've managed not to throw up by taking deep breaths as if giving birth to a small elephant," he said.

Bullimore hit world headlines in 1997 when he was rescued from his upturned catamaran after five days in the southern ocean.

fields.headline: Prison for internet paedophile
fields.trailText: A computer worker who used the internet to feed his "evil" fantasies for young girls was caught after an operation by Californian police and Scotland Yard.
fields.body:
A computer worker who used the internet to feed his "evil" fantasies for young girls was caught after an operation by Californian police and Scotland Yard.

Kenneth Lockley, 28, was the first person to be charged in this country for inciting an undercover officer to procure a girl aged nine for sex using the internet.

Lockley, a £50,000-plus high flier once employed by Core Design, a British subsidiary of the computer games company Eidos, was jailed for 18 months at the Old Bailey yesterday.

Lockley will be freed after serving only half his sentence, as the other half is suspended under the law.

Judge Peter Fingret called on parliament to review the gap in present laws. Acts of parliament limited the sentences he could pass. "The law clearly does not deal with the type of conduct perpetrated by the defendant in this case."

Lockley had admitted inciting an undercover police officer to procure a girl for unlawful sexual intercourse and distributing indecent photographs. The first charge carries a maximum of two years and the second three years.

Lockley, from Ashbourne, Derbyshire, had also faced charges of attempting to have unlawful sexual intercourse with a girl under 13 and attempted buggery. But they were dropped after the judge ruled there was no evidence that a jury could consider.

The defence had submitted there was no actual attempt as no child was ever involved in the "sting" operation. Andrew Campbell-Tiech, prosecuting, said the crown had no choice but to offer no evidence on the attempt charges.
Press Association

fields.headline: Loaded withdrawn in Ireland
fields.trailText: The British "lads' magazine" Loaded has been withdrawn from shops in the Irish Republic on police orders because it contains advertisements for Dublin based escort agencies.
fields.body:
The British "lads' magazine" Loaded has been withdrawn from shops in the Irish Republic on police orders because it contains advertisements for Dublin based escort agencies.

Distributors were ordered to collect all unsold copies of the publication last week because of its content, a Garda spokesman said.

The May edition featured two adverts for agencies, one promising "beautiful top class escorts" who offered a "call in or call out service".

The other offered the chance to "relax in our luxury apartment with our large selection of beautiful and friendly model like girls". One agency also advertised that it had work available.

The June edition, which has been withdrawn, contains three similar adverts.

A spokeswoman for Loaded, which has a circulation of more than 370,000 in the UK and Ireland, said similar adverts would not appear in future editions on sale in the republic.

"As soon as Loaded magazine was alerted to the fact that escort agencies are illegal in Ireland its classified advertising department withdrew and destroyed all of the offending advertisements," she said.

"Unfortunately this discovery was not made in time to withdraw the adverts from the June edition."

The magazine would continue to carry adverts for "reputable escort agencies" in the UK.

The Irish magazine In Dublin, which carried similar adverts for several years, was banned for six months in August 1999.

Last Thursday its publisher, Mike Hogan, was accused on 53 charges relating to the adverts. He faces a maximum fine of IR£30,000.

webTitle: Auctions for sex: Europe's thriving slavery industry

fields.headline: Auctions for sex: Europe's thriving slavery industry
fields.standfirst: Women tell of being sold to pimps by the Balkan mafia and beaten if they resist or fail to earn enough on the streets
fields.trailText: Angela always liked attention, but the day she was forced to stand naked on a block for men to poke, pinch and haggle over her worth ended that.
fields.body:
Angela always liked attention, but the day she was forced to stand naked on a block for men to poke, pinch and haggle over her worth ended that.

Now she sells herself every night, but sometimes she hovers just beyond the streetlamp so that motorists may whizz by without noticing her.

Six months on Via Salaria, a motorway just north of Rome, has sharpened her memory of walking with her boyfriend to the outskirts of Tirana, the Albanian capital, to meet a contact. Their future had arrived, he told her.

It was a posh house with a long drive and inside groups of men were waiting for her and a dozen other girls. "Strip," her boyfriend whispered, and she didn't know what else to do, so she did.

The wooden block was the size of a railway sleeper, too low to make her visible to the whole room but enough to give a sense of occasion. It was, after all, an auction. Inspection was allowed before bidding.

The buyers were not rough. Some checked her veins, rolled her tummy between forefinger and thumb, counted her teeth, felt her breasts. Some did not bother and just looked. The opening bid was £400. It seemed like an awful lot, but the price went up. To be blond and 19 was to be in demand. Within minutes she had fetched £900. Another girl was guided to the block and Angela stumbled away.

That was in November. Tonight she is wearing a black miniskirt, grey T-shirt, green nail polish and brown lipstick. "This is my work outfit," she says, gazing out of the car window and fretting about returning to her street lamp.

Angela is a false name, but her ordeal is becoming the reality for an increasing number of young women from south-eastern Europe. Albanian gangs have taken over prostitution and rewritten the rules to make it an industry that is bigger, bolder and more brutal. Porous borders and lawlessness in former Yugoslavia and Albania have created ideal conditions, according to the United Nations.

Bulk orders

Such is the industry's scale and confidence that gangs in Italy send bulk orders for the number and type of women. Colleagues in the Balkans oblige by rounding up women, not always against their will, and holding auctions, says Miriam Lani, who helps former prostitutes for the charity Caritas in Rome.

"Auctions usually take place in source countries, in areas controlled by the local mafia. They are well protected. They are efficient ways of doing business."

But the auctions are moving to Italy, where about half of the estimated 50-70,000 prostitutes are foreigners. Two years ago auctions were held only in the Balkans, says a Rome detective, but the need to rotate prostitutes around different cities to elude the police creates a market. Typically, the bidders gather in motorway lay-bys or service station carparks. The business is unchallenged, since the Italian mafia melted away in the face of the Balkan onslaught. Last month the police in Matera, in southern Italy, rescued two Romanians, aged 19 and 22, who were exhibited nude to Serbian, Montenegrin and Albanian gangs.

Back in the Via Salaria in Rome, Angela is beginning to panic. She has been away from her post for 20 minutes - too long - and she is not supposed to talk. It is only two hours to her midnight deadline and since 6pm she has made less than £100, mostly from £15 sessions of oral sex. "It's not enough. What will I tell him?"

Some nights, when she cannot face the work, she lurks in the shadows beyond the streetlight. Just a few years of prostitution and then they would have enough money to marry, her boyfriend had told her, but she has not seen him since the auction. The man in her life now is her buyer, and she must earn back his £900 purchase money and endless costs. He pays for her food, rent, clothes, condoms and make-up. Though she speaks good Italian, her pimp is virtually the only person she knows in Italy. Her documents were left in Albania.

Police cars cruise past, but Angela refuses to seek help. Shouting and shaking, she insists on being returned to her spot. Twelve minutes later she vanishes into a red Audi.

Frightened

By midnight Angela is gone from Via Salaria, but other prostitutes know of her. "She tells clients she's 24 but she's 19. She's always frightened but there are others a lot, lot younger," says Tanya, a 28-year-old Russian. The auctions are churning out too many girls, she complains. "Two years ago there were two or three of us on this stretch. Now look at it, there's at least 30."

A Ukranian, also 28, says the Albanians and Romanians tend to be younger and more pliable. "They never work for themselves, they're like sheep." Escape can be as easy as hailing a police car, but they are inhibited by fear of retaliation against their families back home, says Miriam Lani of Caritas. Others have told their families that they are waitresses or dancers, and fear blackmail.

Jailed pimps have been known, upon release, to track down the girl who betrayed them. "These men are extremely violent, and they keep discipline by making examples of those who step out of line," says Ms Lani. Virtually every week two-paragraph stories in Italian newspapers report the discovery of a streetwalker's corpse, often burned. Biba Merita, a 17-year-old Albanian, was beaten to death in Treviso after being diagnosed with a brain tumour. She had been bought and sold many times during her four-year career.

This new generation of streetwalker is different, says Nicola Maria Pace, a prosecutor in Trieste. "My personal observation is that they have neither the look nor the mentality of prostitutes. They are often very young. They're usually resold after being on the streets for a certain time, and taken to a different area."

Most prostitutes are volunteers fleeing poverty, the police say, though if arrested, the girls tend to claim that they were coerced. What the women do not anticipate are the beatings and auctions. Being sold to strangers must be terrifying for those who expected to be managed by their boyfriends or relatives, says Father Piero, who makes weekly prayer and counselling visits to Via Salaria's prostitutes. "Knowing who they'll be working for, that's their only real safety."

webTitle: US youths on trial for murder in Germany

fields.headline: US youths on trial for murder in Germany
fields.trailText: Three American teenagers accused of killing two women drivers and injuring four other people in cars by throwing stones from a bridge have been charged with murder and attempted murder, the prosecution authorities said yesterday.
fields.body:
Three American teenagers accused of killing two women drivers and injuring four other people in cars by throwing stones from a bridge have been charged with murder and attempted murder, the prosecution authorities said yesterday.

The three, sons of US soldiers stationed in Germany, will be tried by a German juvenile court at Darmstadt, outside Frankfurt, Ger Neuber said. No trial date has been set for the youths, who are being held in a German prison.

The unnamed youths, aged 14, 17 and 18, are accused of throwing large stones from a bridge on to a busy motorway in Darmstadt on the night of February 27.

Two women, aged 20 and 41, were killed when the stones crashed through the windscreens of their cars, which were travelling at around 50mph.

The youths also were charged with endangering traffic.

The deaths caused wide spread outrage in Germany, where incidents of random youth violence, although increasing, are still relatively rare.

The defendants lived at the US army's Lincoln housing area, near the motorway where the alleged offences were committed.

The prosecution accuses the teenagers of "malice" and says they acted knowing that their actions could kill people. Several of the stones they threw narrowly missed other cars.

Mr Neuber said the accused had been throwing smaller stones at cars for some time before the night of February 27, when they hurled cobbles and other large stones weighing up to 8.4kg (18lb 8oz) from the 9-metre (30ft) high bridge.

They took the stones from a nearby school yard and agreed to throw them at the cars, hiding behind a screen on the bridge so they could not be seen by the motorists, Mr Neuber said.

The defendants lived at the US army's Lincoln housing area, near the motorway where the alleged offences were committed. The prosecution accuses the teenagers of "malice" and says they acted knowing that their actions could kill people. Several of the stones they threw narrowly missed other cars. Mr Neuber said the accused had been throwing smaller stones at cars for some time before the night of February 27, when they hurled cobbles and other large stones weighing up to 8.4kg (18lb 8oz) from the 9-metre (30ft) high bridge. They took the stones from a nearby school yard and agreed to throw them at the cars, hiding behind a screen on the bridge so they could not be seen by the motorists, Mr Neuber said.

fields.headline: Meals on wheels
fields.trailText: Today, children are more likely to study the techniques behind mass biscuit production than roll up their sleeves and make them.
fields.body:
Today, children are more likely to study the techniques behind mass biscuit production than roll up their sleeves and make them. Concerned about the long-term effects of children no longer being taught how to prepare food, the Royal Society of Arts launched its Focus on Food campaign specifically to raise the profile of hands-on cookery. That was three years ago; now it has two thousand schools taking part. The independent and state sector primary and secondary schools are involved.

As its director Anita Cormac explains: "It is like training to be a doctor but never seeing a patient. How can youngsters learn about food and healthy eating if they are not shown how to prepare food? If you can't cook, you are putting your nutrition in the hands of the manufacturers of ready meals. We need to engage our young people in a culinary culture and show them that cooking is fun."

Few schools can afford the expensive teaching facilities and extended kitchens necessary to teach practical cookery. So the RSA's Focus on Food campaign takes the kitchen out to them.

Its Cooking Bus - a "culinary pantechnicon" housing a state-of-the-art kitchen and classroom area - has visited nearly 200 schools in Britain. It provides practical food teaching for thousands of pupils and training for teachers. Fresh ingredients are provided by the supermarket chain Waitrose, which is putting millions of pounds into the campaign. The RSA can call upon the free services of a line-up of celebrity chefs to teach. Last week Anthony Worral-Thompson helped out, and other regular participants include Sophie Grigson and Rick Stein. Schools receive materials to support their teaching, which this year focuses on the variety and qualities of food eaten in Britain today.

The campaign is underpinned by a three-year academic study based at the University of Reading researching the effects of a sustained food education upon youngsters. It also explores the strong links between the making of food and social issues.

As Anita Cormac points out, young people traditionally learned cooking at their mother's knee. But the demands on working parents and the advent of the microwave age have led to a dependence on ready-meals. "One of the key messages to get across is that meals using fresh ingredients can be prepared quickly and easily at relatively low cost," she says. Fancy gadgets and top-of-the range cookers are also not necessary.

Cormac, a home economics teacher by training, recalls a cookery lesson in which pupils were taught to make a "fruit crumble" using a tin of prepared pie-filling topped with a packet of crumble mix. Youngsters involved in the RSA's campaign are taught basic skills, such as how to prepare fresh fruit and vegetables. Some ready-made ingredients such as filo pastry, low in fat, are used.

Watch out for the Focus on Food week starting on 26 June in England (5 June in Scotland), culminating with the Tastebud Challenge, where pupils will compare a ready-made meal such as pizza with its home-made equivalent.

fields.headline: Welsh
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about Welsh on the web
fields.body:
BBC Wales
****
Aimed at: everyone

An English version of BBC Wales sits at bbc.co.uk/wales but the Welsh version puts more emphasis on news and entertainment. A great deal is made of the BBC's Welsh soap, Pobol y Cwm, and you can also listen to radio in Welsh. There's also a useful guide to learning Welsh for older learners.

Snapdragon
***
Aimed at: everyone

The bilingual red Snapdragon originated as a radio series. He now has a site of his own where key stage 1 and pre-school children can play simple counting games, identify animal sounds, set an alarm clock and colour in pictures. The taught phrases appear (and are spoken) in English and Welsh. To see all the activities, visitors need to download Flash.

Welsh Language Board
**
Aimed at: teachers

The board promotes the use of Welsh and provides basic background information and news on its site. The contacts list may be helpful, but there could be more for teachers and learners.

Welsh Informationary
****
Aimed at: everyone

Gwybodiadur is a directory of Welsh-language resources, including CD-Roms, books and tapes. The author reviews new publications with considerable verve and enthusiasm. Those looking for a sense of Welsh culture will be disappointed, but anyone who appreciates language learning for its own sake should visit the site.

S4C
**
Aimed at: everyone

Another completely bilingual site, this time from Welsh-language TV channel S4C. Learners won't be stuck with a translation, but equally they may not try very hard if they know the English version is one click away. Plenty of rugby, S4C schedules and a chatroom, but little else.

Searching Lexicon
***
Aimed at: everyone

A growing online Welsh-English and English-Welsh dictionary and spell-checker containing over 22,000 entries. The site, however, is showing its age and doesn't appear to have been updated since 1996.

A Welsh Course
**
Aimed at: everyone

From the same author as the Lexicon, this site is also rather primitive in terms of design and layout. Idiosyncratic and not readily adaptable for use in the classroom, it's still worth looking at if, say, you want to help your child learn Welsh.

Order a Welsh book
***
Aimed at: teachers and parents

Although the navigation could be improved, this is a useful site for anyone who can't find Welsh or bilingual books easily. Recommended Key Stages and brief plot outlines are available.

Welsh Learner's Links
**
Aimed at: everyone

A couple of language lessons, a freeware vocabulary builder in .zip format, links and a few pages in Welsh make for an amateurish site which, in time, could become a useful resource.

webTitle: Rhodes to build a new Colossus

fields.headline: Rhodes to build a new Colossus
fields.trailText: Greece is to invite international artists to recreate one of the seven wonders of the ancient world, the Colossus of Rhodes.
fields.body:
Greece is to invite international artists to recreate one of the seven wonders of the ancient world, the Colossus of Rhodes.

No one knows exactly what the statue looked like, or even where it stood, but Nelson Mandela and other celebrities have already been asked to join a committee to choose the winning entry. "We want to build a monument equal to the legendary Colossus of Rhodes in both brilliance and historic significance," the island's mayor, Giorgos Yiannopoulos, said. "It will, just as in ancient times, be an anti-war landmark, a symbol of peace, friendship and reconciliation."

To emphasise that point, the competition will be formally announced to the Greek and Turkish media on Friday.

Unlike the original statue, which took Chares, one of antiquity's greatest sculptors, 12 years to carve, the Greeks want the Colossus to be erected in time for the Olympic games in 2004. "Applications will have to be submitted by the end of the summer," the mayor said.

The Colossus, believed to have been about 30.5 metres (100ft) tall, stood over Rhodes for almost 70 years before it was destroyed by an earthquake in 226BC and its huge bronze parts were carted off by Arab merchants. Although historians have spent years arguing about its exact location, artists have always depicted it straddling Rhodes' harbour.

Where the new monument will stand is anyone's guess, officials say. "The winning entry will be as much about the ability of the design team to locate it well," Spyros Pangas, a town hall official, said. Where Chares' work was made of melted-down weapons abandoned by the successive armies that tried to invade Rhodes, the new Colossus will be made from melted-down coins of currencies soon to be replaced by the euro.

"We would like to have ships passing under its feet, as in ancient times, but we don't want to commercialise a myth," said Mr Yiannopoulos. "The new Colossus will not be a replica of the original as we imagine it to be, it will simply be inspired by it. The last thing we want to do is create something kitsch."

fields.headline: French minister sorry for 'Nazi' jibe
fields.trailText: Responding to howls of outrage from left and right, the plainspeaking French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, apologised yesterday for saying that Germany had not recovered from its Nazi past.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
Responding to howls of outrage from left and right, the plainspeaking French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, apologised yesterday for saying that Germany had not recovered from its Nazi past.

"My comments were compacted, as is often the case for television," Mr Chevènement, no stranger to controversy, told French radio. "I am truly sorry for what has happened. I like Germany and I see Europe's future based on the Franco-German relationship."

His remarks sparked a storm of embarrassed protest in France. The Green party, a member of the coalition government, called for an official explanation and the opposition Gaullist RPR accused him of throwing to the winds years of post-war reconciliation.

In Berlin, officials shrugged off his comments, saying that last week's high-level Franco-German meeting at Rambouillet had secured "the most intense co-operation" between the two countries. One said: "The Franco-German motor is not stalling."

But the remark was an indication of the discord in the French government on the future of Europe.

"There is a tendency in Germany to imagine a federal structure for Europe which fits in with its own model," Mr Chevènement told French television on Sunday. "Deep down, it is still dreaming of the Germanic Holy Roman Empire. It hasn't cured itself of its past derailment into Nazism."

Germany, he continued, "has a conception of the nation that is one of das Volk [the people], in other words an ethnic conception. It must be helped to form another idea of the nation, the nation of citizens, in order to have a better dialogue with France".

Mr Chevènement was commenting chiefly on a controversial speech 11 days ago by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer.

Mr Fischer's "personal vision" of a federal Europe was broadly welcomed by pro-Europeans in France and Germany as a step towards reviv ing the European debate.

The French Socialist party secretary, François Hollande, repeated his support for Mr Fischer yesterday, but Mr Chevènement did not entirely withdraw his comments, hinting that Germany might be eyeing a rather bigger role for itself than France would like.

"The Franco-German relationship is fundamental," he reiterated, "but in order for it to be healthy, it must recover its balance."

 Joschka Fischer will step up his drive for a federal Europe at a conference in Berlin today from which British official representatives will be conspicuously absent.

A keynote speech by Mr Fischer will open the meeting, which will bring together leading figures, including the European commissioner for enlargement, Günter Verheugen.

British embassy officials in Berlin knew nothing of the meeting and the signs were that the Germans were giving London a foretaste of their plans to press ahead with a "core group" of European states committed to closer ties.
