fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: My son has been revising methodically for his GCSEs. How can I help him to make the revision process more effective?
fields.body:
My son has been revising methodically for his GCSEs since before Easter. He's made a revision timetable and copious notes for the eight subjects he's studying, but he's now overwhelmed by the prospect of trying to take it all in. How can I help him to make the revision process more effective?

Jane Florsham was a senior teacher, and now works as an educational consultant.

Your son needs to distil the information he has learned into more manageable chunks. He needs to go through his notes and reduce them into topic areas, and then key notes. These form the "pegs" on which you can hang your wider knowledge. Working out how to remember these depends upon what type of learner you are: visual, auditory or kinesthetic.

Visual learners use flowcharts, spidergrams, charts or mnemonics. These take a large quantity of information and then present it in a simplified, but memorable, form. Put them up on the walls in your bedroom to memorise them.

There are revision aides on tape/CD-Rom for auditory learners, but it's also worth making your own. As well as listening to it, the process of selecting the narrative for your revision tape will help to fix ideas into your subconscious.

Kinesthetic learners learn best by doing. The very act of writing down revision notes is a form of active learning, as is watching videos. The BBC broadcasts the Bitesize revision series, which is extremely useful regardless of which form of learning suits you. It's produced with GCSE revision in mind, and gives a great deal of visual stimulus that will help to trigger remembered learning.

The same is true of using computer software, such as CD-Roms or internet revision sites, such as the Guardian's own website, www.learn.co.uk . On the Channel Four website students can contact teachers for help.

Think about the context in which you first learnt something: for example, visualise the science experiment, the methods you used and the results recorded.

Practice by doing timed past papers and get them marked with feedback. To find out what examiners are looking for, dig out their marking schemes. Schools also offer revision classes in GCSE subjects. These will explain how to get certain grades and provide the opportunity to seek individual guidance. You might need something explained again or helped to identify what to revise to get the highest marks possible. You may feel as if you've left school, but your teachers will still view you as their pupil until after your exams.

Plan your revision timetable to follow your exam timetable. Spend 30 minutes revising, take a 10-minute break, and then test your self on what you've just learned. Ask someone to test you, you do actually learn more by "teaching" someone else.

A good revision programme should leave you time to unwind. Don't try to sleep straight after revising - your brain will be too active and stop you from getting to sleep. Never cram immediately before an exam, it will just make you anxious about all the things you don't know. Make sure you've got everything ready and have a good breakfast. Give yourself plenty of time to get there, you cannot perform at your best if you're stressed before you start.

Never begin writing straight away in the exam. Make sure you know which parts are optional, which parts are compulsory, and which don't apply to you at all. Take time to read the paper carefully, and plan your answers. Try to leave time to read through your answers, you will lose marks for poor spelling and grammar.

The key to any exam success is confidence. If you feel happy that you know all you can be expected to know, and how to apply that knowledge, you will be fine. Make the revision process useful for you and resist comparing yourself to others. Use all resources available to you to give it your best shot. And last of all, good luck!

Next week's query: We have just received information about the work experience fortnight that our son's school runs. What exactly should we tell him to expect and what can he hope to get out of it? We didn't do work experience in my day!

fields.headline: Exam stress
fields.trailText: Is it possible to avoid exam stress? Ros Taylor finds out how
fields.body:
Anyone who thinks the BBC doesn't take its public service role seriously should visit the Bitesize Screech talkboards, where almost 5,000 anxious messages had been posted by the time GCSE language orals were underway last week.

"Think I have failed my German oral and my Drama exam went horribly wrong and I have got my prom on Wednesday and my dress is still being altered," reads a typical entry.

Could it ever be otherwise? Yes, according to study counsellor Eileen Tracy, who advises parents on how to deal with their children's exam stress. "Revision skills are not adequately taught in schools." Teachers do not have the time to understand how each of their pupils learn, says Tracy, and the need for mental stamina is often overlooked.

Tracy, a former teacher who runs her own website, believes that children tend to adopt two types of behaviour when confronted by exam pressure. At one extreme, the "swot" works incredibly hard, often because of parental pressures, but chiefly because they regard exams as a convenient measure of self-worth. At the other, the "rabbit" loses all confidence in their ability and stops studying altogether.

Revision websites like Bitesize and the Guardian's learn.co.uk are, Tracy says, a positive development when they boost pupils' confidence. (A score of 8 out of 10 on a French exercise on Bitesize won the comment: "Very well done, you are revising incredibly well.")

Some children mistakenly believe that their teacher holds a grudge against them and deliberately plays down their efforts. A computer, on the other hand, is impartial and won't punish them unfairly.

Unfortunately, like the books that preceded them, revision websites can also perpetuate what Tracy calls the "Gradgrind approach to learning", where study becomes a means to an end. That may not keep 15-year-olds awake at night, but about a fifth of the parents who contact her via the BBC site are more worried about their child's welfare than their grades.

"Maybe websites will start to provide the function that schools should," says Tracy, somewhat sceptically. "But it would be good to have study skills counsellors dotted round schools.

"Often children will resist seeing a school counsellor because they don't think they have mental difficulties."

"Maybe websites will start to provide the function that schools should," says Tracy, somewhat sceptically. "But it would be good to have study skills counsellors dotted round schools. "Often children will resist seeing a school counsellor because they don't think they have mental difficulties."

fields.headline: Zoo-keeping
fields.trailText: Zoo-keeping
fields.body:
Uncanny! What is?

A talking gorilla! Whadyamean?

You look almost human... I am human, you idiot.

What you doing in the gorillas' cage then? I'm their keeper.

Yes, I know. Just kidding. Very droll.

Magic job! It has its moments.

Much sought after, I suppose. There are about 300 zoos, safari parks and specific animal collections in the UK and Ireland, but you're right. There's a lot of competition.

So, how do you get in? Any would-be keeper should be able to prove experience with animals. Volunteer work in kennels, stables or on a farm, if not a zoo, would count.

Do they keep you busy? Not half! The modern zoo-keeper's job is never done.

Give me a flavour. Well, there's all the traditional stuff: cleaning out animal pens and cages.

Can't you train them to be tidy? I'll ignore that. Plus, there's all the food preparation. Some animals need special foods and some need to be fed by hand.

Some think you're food. True. That's worth remembering. We're also responsible for ensuring the animals are kept in a comfortable environment at the correct temperature and humidity

They have a cushy time. Rightly so. Most zoos play important roles in animal conservation. We've got to keep the animals in environments as close to the natural habitats as possible.

Anything else? I've barely started. We have to keep accurate medical records. That includes observing their diets and behaviour. And we help the vet if any animals need treatment.

What do you do if they get a bit rough? We've got to ensure the safety of the public and of the animals. Should animals get aggresive with one another, keepers may need to intervene.

Do the lions ever pretend to fight to lure you in? And we answer questions from the public - even the stupidest ones.

What qualities are needed? Physical fitness is essential, and no allergies to fur or hair. A keeper could work in many environments during the course of a day, from cold, smelly, muddy outdoor jobs to humid internal stuff. And the work is physically hard, especially preparing and mucking out cages. Obviously when working with dangerous animals, vigilance is vital.

What about entry requirements? There are no minimum qualifications, although three to five GCSEs at grades A-C are desirable, including maths, English and science.

Is training provided? Yes. Practical training is given on the job. There is a City & Guilds zoo animal management qualification for which employers ideally allow time off to study. It can also be done by correspondence course via the National Extension College. There are also NVQs at levels 1, 2 and 3 in animal care. Some organisations may offer national traineeships.

 Association of British Wild Animal Keepers (ABWAK) c/o Lukes Gate, Chessington Zoo, Leatherhead Road, Chessington Surrey KT9 2NE

 Federation of Zoological Gardens in Great Britain Email address fedzoo@zsl.org

 Job opportunities are advertised in Cage and Aviary Birds and International Zoo News magazines

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: What about the kids?
fields.standfirst: Our system of childcare for working parents is chaotic and new state help may not be enough
fields.trailText: Our system of childcare for working parents is chaotic and new state help may not be enough
fields.body:
Pity the poor mums and dads of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. They want to be good parents, but juggling jobs and children can be hard. The government is eager to help and is spending billions developing better childcare across the country. However, some people worry that thousands of families may continue to miss out despite the politicians' promises.

Why is childcare in the news now?

This week is National Childcare Week. By coincidence, the prime minister's wife, Cherie, has just given birth to her fourth baby. People wonder if Mr Blair will take time off from his job to help look after baby Leo.

What sorts of childcare can parents choose?

First, you can care for your children at home. If a mother is working, the law allows her 18 weeks off work directly before and after her baby's birth. But in some countries, such as Sweden, both mothers and fathers are allowed to take time off for longer than 18 weeks.

In Britain, fathers do not have a legal right to take paternity leave, although some employers allow them time off. If parents want to return to work, they may be able to get family members to help out or pay for a nanny or an au pair.

Second, children too young to go to school may be cared for outside their home while their parents work. They might go to the home of an officially checked (registered) childminder, or attend a playgroup or a nursery paid for and/or run by other parents. Children can also attend after-school clubs and holiday playschemes. All of these have to be paid for by parents. Paying for a place at a private nursery can be very expensive.

Third, there are nursery classes that are based at school though they are only for two and a half hours in the morning and the same in the afternoon. Often, more children want to attend a nursery than there are places.

How can you tell if childcare is good?

Babies, toddlers and school-age children all need different types of care. To check if someone is offering good childcare, a parent needs to find out if the care meets all a child's needs. This is important - over half a child's physical and mental development takes place before he or she is five years old. Children who get good nursery education tend to do well at school later.

Why is the government so worried about childcare?

Families now depend far more on official forms of childcare. Many family members live a long way away from each other. In the past, families often lived in the same town and cared for children of working relatives.

The government also fears that if it does not provide affordable childcare, the children of poorer, working parents will be left to come home to an empty house after school and may get into trouble.

The National Daycare Trust explains as many as 600,000 children under three live in poverty in Britain. Giving parents access to better-paid work is a major way to improve a family's fortunes. However, without good childcare many adults do not have the time or the money to train for a better job or to take up a job at all.

What is the government trying to do?

It is developing the National Childcare Strategy to increase the availability of high quality, affordable childcare. Its Sure Start scheme aims to create well-organised childcare in some of our poorest areas. It is also allowing some parents to pay less tax so that they can afford to pay for childcare.

What problems remain?

Many of the poorest families live in areas not covered by the Sure Start scheme. The situation is improving but it has a long way to go.

Further information: This week the National Day Care Trust (tel 020-77392866 is launching a guide to surviving half term. See also Maternity Alliance factsheets on key childcare issues (please send £1 and an A4 stamped addressed envelope to the Maternity Alliance, 45 Beech Street, London EC2P 2LX).

 First Edition is a current affairs series for schools on C4 presented this week by Jon Snow and produced in association with Guardian Education. It is transmitted every Tuesday morning at 11am and repeated on Wednesday at 11am.

fields.headline: Dreaming of spires
fields.standfirst: College lecturers must drop their prejudices about Oxbridge, if students are to get the best, says  Ann Limb
fields.trailText: College lecturers must drop their prejudices about Oxbridge, if students are to get the best, says Ann Limb
fields.body:
My college's most illustrious alumnus is Prince Charles. Back in the late 60s, whilst taking his degree at Trinity, the heir apparent whiled away his leisure time doing a part-time evening course in pottery at the local tech. Quite how much of this experience of further education he took back to the ivory tower is lost to the annals of time, but we do know that it has taken Oxbridge colleges over 30 years to realise what they have been missing in further education.

The recent initiative taken by seven Oxford colleges to woo students from further education, although long overdue, is to be warmly welcomed by the sector. So how will our students and staff respond to their wish to achieve a big increase in the numbers of working class and mature students they take from further education colleges?

The sixth-form colleges (still thought of as state schools in my own university town) will doubtless rally to the call, along with the tertiary colleges, one of which recently made a bold, although ultimately unsuccessful, challenge to the established recruitment procedures of a Cambridge college admissions tutor.

But where do the general further education colleges stand on this issue? If the ambitious targets set by Mansfield College (to take three quarters of its students from the state sector in five years) are to be achieved, then collaboration on a massive scale with the further education sector nationally will be required. My concern is that many of us in the sector will firstly have to overcome as much prejudice on our side about what happens in the quads and at high table, as the dons will have to about their belief in the unlikelihood that anyone from Motor Vehicle 2 can ever get an Oxbridge degree.

I wonder how many lecturers in general further education colleges positively encourage their students to think about applying to Oxford and Cambridge? Do we dare admit (since most of us did not go there ourselves and it is not part of our culture to be seen to be promoting elitism) that we are not really sure how to work their system to the benefit of our students?

I hope that we shall not let our ignorance, fear or arrogance intimidate our common sense and reason. I've not met a lecturer yet who is not motivated by the desire for students to have the very best. If an Oxbridge education is the right route for a student from a further education college, it is our duty to ensure that we do all we can to support the applicant and help confront outdated assumptions about student life in the colleges.

The Oxford consortium's project must be engaged with wholeheartedly and by the entire further education sector. I urge my colleagues to respond. Every general further education college in the land should throw open its doors and invite the admissions tutors in to learn about what we do. Over the last two years, Cambridge Regional College has undertaken a project with the University of Cambridge to do precisely this and the numbers of students entering Oxford and Cambridge has risen dramatically (60%).

Oxbridge dons do not inhabit a parallel universe - in fact a surprising number of them are married to lecturers who work in further education and increasing numbers of them are parents of students studying in our colleges.

As we celebrate Adult Learners Week, here in Cambridge, another more recent, but less famous, alumnus from Cambridge Regional College will take centre stage locally. Jackie Reeves started with us as a mature student. She said people like her didn't go to Cambridge University - but she did. She got a first in medicine, went on to do her clinical training with great success and is now a qualified doctor undertaking her first residence at Addenbrooke's NHS Trust - perhaps Prince Charles knew something about further education after all!

 Ann Limb is principal of Cambridge Regional College.

fields.headline: Ever vigilant
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  finds that exams can be fun for invigilators
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock finds that exams can be fun for invigilators
fields.body:
Bliss. Nothing more demanding to do than to stand in a packed sports hall and count the number of breeze blocks in the walls. Oh the pleasure of knowing that there are nine rivets to every roof truss, or that you can make up dozens of words out of the phrase "Centre Number". Yes, it's invigilation time once again.

There are several ways to pass the time. Of course, walking the length of an aisle slowly in squeaky shoes is mildly diverting. Responding to a raised arm with brio is satisfying. Often the anxious questioner poses a painfully helpless comment like:

"Do I have to answer all the questions?"

"Well, have you read the instructions?"

"Yes, but it's all different from the mock exam."

"Well it would be, wouldn't it."

But it turns out that the student was expecting a maths paper and the one they are staring at is economics. The fact that the paper started half an hour ago is another matter. People do funny things under examination pressure. Or rather, they do the wrong thing.

And then there is the bladder moment, when the urge to rush to the toilet sets in. Once you have dealt with one student another one wants to go. This is not a problem. If you are lucky you can kill a good 20 minutes with trips to the loo. Even if this means skulking outside the toilets pretending to find the fire notice interesting.

It is much the same domino effect with rulers, rubbers and any other piece of equipment that a question demands and the student has failed to bring. Trying to remember who has borrowed what from whom and where keeps the mind active. Helping yourself to a student's last Rolo is a fair reward for this service.

In calm moments when your eyelids grow heavy, surveying the number of mascots on desks can pass an amusing few moments. Last year miniature teddy bears were popular, along with other fluffy members of the animal kingdom.

However, when Roxanne, one of my own students, seated herself and then tipped something out of a jam jar I felt obliged to comment.

"You can't bring that in here," I whispered.

"But it is dead." She poked the rabbit's foot.

"And the rest of the rabbit?"

While Roxanne stared at me I understood what it feels like to be withered by a look. I retreated to my temporary torpor only to spot my mate Colin from maths lurking by the door. Colin has a reputation for organising boredom-relieving games in an exam hall. People who know this look to see when he is invigilating and then do a swap just to be on duty with him.

One of Colin's favourites is to stand at the back where he can't be seen by the candidates and do a mime. He is fond of performing film titles. No student has ever asked why "Deep Throat" or "Basic Instinct" was added to the list of exams written on the whiteboard.

But it doesn't need Colin to organise a round of "Hunt the Phone". It is the regulation that everyone has to leave their bags at the front of the exam hall. This is fine, until a mobile phone goes off. And, of course, it's always the last one you tear open that contains the offending item. Last time that bag turned out to be a tatty looking briefcase with a combination lock. It was mine.

fields.headline: A college is born
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on the newest arrival in the Yorkshire Dales
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on the newest arrival in the Yorkshire Dales
fields.body:
By sunset today the folk of the Yorkshire Dales will have acquired their very own college. There will be nothing obvious to the casual passer-by. No campus to tip a cap at. No new smudge on the sublime skyline.

Nor will any grand outsiders be gracing today's event with their presences. In Whitehall they're largely ignorant of the new arrival although a letter was winged to David Blunkett notifying him of this addition to his domain.

The College of the Dales, which is being formally opened by Hannah Hauxwell, a local celebrity, is not some Yorkshire act of defiance, a sort of UDI. It will actually be an offshoot of Craven College, Skipton, situated on the southern margin of this 600 square-mile region of outstanding beauty.

It will consist of a network of learning centres, access points with computer facilities for individual study, and information points, explains Craven college's principal, Alan Blackwell.

They will be in places like Settle, Malham, Ingleton, Askrigg and Aysgarth.

The College of the Dales will boast its own stationery and all the other badges of institution, but it won't have its own pipeline to the Further Education Funding Council, nor to its Learning and Skills Council successor. It will get its cash from its parent.

Why, then, didn't Craven College simply boost its operations in the Dales? After all, it and other providers have been running courses in various locations there.

"It's a sum of the parts. There'll be a new sense of cohesion," says Blackwell. His deputy, Barry Turner, who has been the driving force behind the new concept, adds: "It's very difficult to serve a rural area from the sidelines. What works at the moment as a series of individual centres, we want to pull together and and give an overall sense, a culture of a college of the Dales."

And it doesn't mean sprinkling computers around and flogging distance learning.

"There's a very strong feeling in areas like this," says Turner. "People tell us they want to learn together. There's an important social element."

The new college has obeyed - is ahead of, even - the government's call for a new spirit of partnership in post-16 provision, they say. The other partners are the Yorkshire Dales national park authority, the local library services and the community education service.

There is no doubt, both men say, that among the 50,000-odd population covered by the new college, there is a strong demand for new skills, not least among beleaguered farmers wanting to diversify, and the plethora of tiny businesses wanting, for instance, basic marketing. They estimate that in the first year or two the college will pull in 2,000 students.

Up until now, only viable courses - those which can attract at least 10 students - have been possible. Soon there will be all the exotic wares of the typical metropolitan college: in Bentham, for instance, one of the remotest locations, they want aromatherapy, reflexology, alternative medicine, Indian head massage, and healthier lifestyles courses.

"Businesses keep telling us of an emerging skills gap," says Blackwell. "People in the rural areas are not getting upskilled. There's a slow divide happening."

Firms in the Dales looking for relevant skills are having to recruit from the surrounding urban areas, and further afield in Leeds or Burnley.

"Now Dales people are not just going to have some flower arranging in the morning or a computer course if they travel 20 miles," says Turner. "They are going to have a vast army of courses as good as in urban centres, that's our goal."

"We want to take education and training to the community, we have to make it physically accessible to them," says Alan Blackwell, Craven College principal.

"We're hoping this will change slowly and surely the economic fabric of the Dales.

"We need a rebirth of the Dales."

What works at the moment as a series of individual centres, we want to pull together and and give an overall sense, a culture of a college of the Dales." And it doesn't mean sprinkling computers around and flogging distance learning. "There's a very strong feeling in areas like this," says Turner. "People tell us they want to learn together. There's an important social element." The new college has obeyed - is ahead of, even - the government's call for a new spirit of partnership in post-16 provision, they say. The other partners are the Yorkshire Dales national park authority, the local library services and the community education service. There is no doubt, both men say, that among the 50,000-odd population covered by the new college, there is a strong demand for new skills, not least among beleaguered farmers wanting to diversify, and the plethora of tiny businesses wanting, for instance, basic marketing. They estimate that in the first year or two the college will pull in 2,000 students. Up until now, only viable courses - those which can attract at least 10 students - have been possible. Soon there will be all the exotic wares of the typical metropolitan college: in Bentham, for instance, one of the remotest locations, they want aromatherapy, reflexology, alternative medicine, Indian head massage, and healthier lifestyles courses. "Businesses keep telling us of an emerging skills gap," says Blackwell. "People in the rural areas are not getting upskilled. There's a slow divide happening." Firms in the Dales looking for relevant skills are having to recruit from the surrounding urban areas, and further afield in Leeds or Burnley. "Now Dales people are not just going to have some flower arranging in the morning or a computer course if they travel 20 miles," says Turner. "They are going to have a vast army of courses as good as in urban centres, that's our goal." "We want to take education and training to the community, we have to make it physically accessible to them," says Alan Blackwell, Craven College principal. "We're hoping this will change slowly and surely the economic fabric of the Dales. "We need a rebirth of the Dales."

fields.headline: Cordon blues
fields.standfirst: Despite chefs' new celebrity status, youngsters are shunning catering careers.  Simon Midgley  asks why
fields.trailText: Despite chefs' new celebrity status, youngsters are shunning catering careers. Simon Midgley asks why
fields.body:
Are all the violent tantrums of chefs, familiar from fly-on the-wall telly, putting youngsters off catering? This is one explanation for a serious, not to say slightly mysterious shortfall of applicants to one of the UK's top training programmes.

This autumn's intake to the specialised chefs course at Bournemouth and Poole College of Further Education, which trains professional cooks for Britain's leading hotels and restaurants, is 15 trainees short. The programme which can take up to 30 students has only managed to attract 15 would-be trainees to date. Last year the programme started with 28 students.

David Boland, the course's tutor, believes that there may be several reasons for the shortfall of applicants. He says that the number of 16-year-olds leaving school this year is lower than it has been for some years, so fewer young people are entering further education college courses generally.

More worringly, however, he believes that young people are no longer prepared to work the long hours with no overtime that the catering industry has traditionally expected of its kitchen staff.

And, while much of the media coverage of cooking and chefs in recent years has been favourable, some TV programmes showing chefs bullying and threatening kitchen staff will not have encouraged young people to opt for a life in the kitchen.

The Bournemouth and Poole course, which has been running since 1989, trains chefs for leading hotels and restaurants, such as the Savoy, the Ritz, Claridges and Langan's Brasserie.

The prestigious three-year course of work-based training is arranged in partnership with the Academy of Culinary Arts, an association of Britain's top chefs and restaurant managers, and Waitrose, the supermarket chain.

Leading chefs such as Anton Edelmann at The Savoy, Michel Bourdin at the Connaught and Richard Shepherd at Langan's restaurants sponsor students to study on the course. Unusually students are paid a minimum wage of £55 a week by their sponsor who also pays for the cost of their accommodation with local families.

There is, says Boland, a serious shortage of quality chefs in London hotels and restaurants.

"We are our own worst enemy. We have developed a philosophy that to be a good chef you have to work 16 hours a day, which is absolute nonsense. Very few establishments pay overtime, or double time for bank holidays or weekend work. You are expected to work Saturdays and Sundays.

"You work under immense pressure all the time. You get your holidays, if you are lucky, in January or February. It's archaic. In Australia chefs work for 37.5 hours a week, are paid overtime and given days off in lieu. If it can be done in other parts of the world, why can't it be done in this country. The industry has got to change its approach if it wants to attract young people."

Jaxon Keedwell, Sir Paul and Lady Getty's personal chef and a graduate of the course, said: "The problem is that school-leavers can quite easily find jobs in the IT and computer industry, which pay high wages from the start. Whereas in catering, high salaried jobs are hard to come by. It is possible that the top end of the catering industry will be affected by a shortfall in trainee chefs but perhaps it will force the industry to review salaries and working hours for young chefs."

fields.headline: Held captive
fields.standfirst: Cheap and cheerful or posh and pricey?  Helene Mulholland reports on the effects of privatising student housing
fields.trailText: Cheap and cheerful or posh and pricey? Helene Mulholland reports on the effects of privatising student housing
fields.body:
John Moffat knows a thing or two about learning curves. His first important lesson at the Southampton Institute was in the housing market. His second was doing something about it.

Soon after his arrival, John realised that at £76 a week, the rent set by the institute was far more expensive than private arrangements with local landlords. "I thought halls would be cheap and value for money, but it turned out that in the private sector you were paying for a lot better accommodation with a lot more room," says John. Although he had to wait until somebody could take his place in halls, John was eventually able to move into a shared house, 15 minutes walking distance from campus, for a weekly rent of £45 - bills included.

His friend and fellow student Nick Ponniah was not so lucky. Unable to transfer out of halls, he struggled to pay the rent. The institute held back his exam results and Nick had little choice but to abandon the course and work to pay off his arrears. He plans to start again next September, this time at a different university.

A recent NUS survey listed Southampton Institute as having the third most expensive student accommodation in the country, second only to two London universities. Southampton Institute is also one of the early pioneers of an arrangement which is now known as the Private Finance Initiative (PFI), or Private Public Partnership (PPP).

Institute spokesperson Robyn Mills explains: "We have built seven halls of residence over four or five years using private developers. The reason for high prices is that we built on 1990s prices in a city centre. We didn't own our own land, and we had to go to a private company."

Mills justifies the high rents by pointing out that the accommodation is fully maintained, managed and also secure for the students. "That is one of the reasons that parents, in particular, like them," she adds.

One thing the institute doesn't admit is that it is charging students a top-up fee to cover future risks. A source confirmed that the institute was charging at least £40 per month over the odds to build up reserves for times when the student occupancy may drop.

Bill Paytee is director of development at Servite Houses Housing Association, which in the early 1990s built and now manages an 800-capacity accommodation hall for the institute. Southampton's contract with Servite guaranteed occupancy, effectively binding the university to paying rent on rooms whether or not they are occupied.

Paytee confirms that the institute has effectively passed on this risk to its students: "Southampton are loading a supplement onto the money they have to pay us so they have to cover their risks and voids."

With students already spending more than four-fifths of their income on accommodation, the growth area of PFI deals for higher education accommodation might be worth watching. The idea behind private/ public partnerships is that the private sector will bear the risks in return for a guaranteed income stream.

Tim Russell, head of procurement and PFI advice at Higher Education Funding Council for England, says: "You have to determine who takes which aspect of risk. It entirely depends on the sort of deal that the university actually makes. It is up to the university to say what they want. But if they want to make a deal with the private sector, then it will want to feel adequately rewarded."

Hertfordshire, Luton and Sheffield are just some of the universities at various stages of PFI. Olivia Brown. welfare officer at Sheffield University, says "The university wants to privatise all of its accommodation. They're well aware that we don't like it as an idea, but they are involving us in their discussions. They're saying it's the only way forward."

A very vocal opponent of such schemes is the public service union Unison. Christine Lewis, national officer for education, says: "It is not a good option. It is more expensive, it involves long contracts, and management for the halls goes out of the hands of the people that are publicly accountable. We have argued this long and hard, but it is seen as the only show in town for providing public buildings."

Lewis also points out that student accommodation has become the most common form of PFI in higher education because it is such a safe bet. "The attractiveness for a company is that they will get the rent for 20-25 years. The risk is supposed to be passed on to the private sector, but if it is underwritten it is hard to see how much risk they are actually passing on," she says. The private companies bidding for these type of contracts range from big property developers like Jarvies to the individual housing associations like Servite.

Tim Russell believes that this growth area reflects shrewd business acumen. "We are seeing more interest from the private sector in doing PFI deals because they can see the potential commercial opportunity."

The idea of profit being made on the back of university accommodation might seem odd to some, but for now, the National Union of Students seems fairly relaxed about the whole thing. Spokesperson Simon Kemp says: "The situation would depend on whether prices do increase without there being sufficient amenities to go alongside. Students may be happy to pay higher prices if they get closer and better facilities. It is not just who is doing it, but value for money."

Quality does not seem to be in question. Current trends in PFI show that private organisations are keen to provide top-of-the-range accommodation in halls.

The reason is simple: contractors are having to keep their eyes on two different markets. Bill Paytee explains: "Students are only in halls for 38-39 weeks in the year. We have to find occupancy for the rest of the time. We are trying to ensure that the accommodation is also suitable for visitors. It's not quite a hotel-type trade, but that is why we have included the ensuite."

Nice room if you can get it, but for students like Nick Ponniah, such a luxury remains a pipe dream. Whether PFIs will elevate the country's residential halls to pricey and posh, rather than cheap and cheerful, remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Is small still beautiful?
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod asks what future there is for Oxford's elite but fruitful colleges
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod asks what future there is for Oxford's elite but fruitful colleges
fields.body:
It was over coffee in the senior common room that the germ of a new approach to tackling Alzheimer's disease emerged. Susan Greenfield and David Vaux were not in the same department at Oxford University and there was no particular reason for them to meet and swap ideas - but as fellows of the same small college, it was perfectly natural to end up discussing the finer points of mechanisms involved in neuro-degeneration. The result was a major scientific collaboration and a spin-off company, Synaptica Ltd.

That conversation in a dark oak-panelled room at Lincoln College was an example of the Oxbridge college system working well - top-class academics from different disciplines sparking ideas off each other in civilised surroundings, but still being engaged in the tutorial teaching of undergraduates. (Professor Greenfield has since moved on to head the Royal Institute, and is now to be seen giving tutorials at Number Ten to the Blairs and distinguished guests.)

But as a way of educating students and supporting academics, colleges are outrageously expensive compared to the rest of British higher education; and the question is being voiced more loudly now - are they worth it? It is not just the cost of one-to-one teaching, but of operating in medieval buildings and the diseconomies of scale - each college has its own library, its own domestic and clerical staff and bursar.

The government has certainly decided that their subsidy from the taxpayers should be less lavish: the £2,000 premium that every student at Oxford and Cambridge receives is to be reduced by a third over the next ten years. It is a very gentle let-down, agreed after intense lobbying of Tony Blair - an alumnus of St John's College, Oxford - to soften the original proposal from education ministers. But it is a challenge to the colleges.

Even more threatening to the sedate-looking college world is the cut-throat race to keep up with international research. These days a university has to be quick on its feet and well resourced to stay with the American and, increasingly, the Asian competition - can Oxford afford a ponderous federal decision-making process involving 36 colleges?

A forthcoming book, Oxford and the Decline of the Collegiate Tradition, poses the question of how long colleges can survive as autonomous institutions choosing their own students and academics. The buildings, of course, will remain; but they could become little more than halls of residence with the principal reduced to an "academic concierge" and the bursar a "toilet-roll distributor", suggest Ted Tapper and David Palfreyman (himself bursar of New College).

For the first time the book will provide an accurate estimate of the wealth of these secretive bodies - £1.58bn in endowment capital. Their joint endowments bring in more than £63m a year. Add to that academic fees, residential and catering charges, conference trade and tourism and fees for filming Inspector Morse and the like and their combined income is £136m a year. That is at least as much as the central University of Oxford receives from the funding council in grants and fees for teaching 16,300 students. It is more than the £115m the University of Sheffield gets for teaching 20,300 students.

With money comes influence, although the rich colleges (like St John's with an income of £6.8m) have to subsidise the poorer ones. Palfreyman, a drily humourous man whose office is as strewn with errant papers and books as any don's, admits colleges have been slow to adopt efficiency savings like joint purchasing.

While the outside world suspects that too much money goes on high-table port, he argues that the college fee from the taxpayer all goes on teaching and library resources, and indeed that tutorial teaching is subsidised by college endowments - in the case of New College, set up by the founder William of Wykeham. (Income from the endowment also has to pay for a £500,000 replacement lead roof, which weighs heavily on the bursar's mind.) And student rooms in these old buildings now need internet connections as well as plumbing. ("Baths?! But they're only here for eight weeks," as a 19th-century college head is supposed to have expostulated during a previous modernisation.)

The fact that the academics in a college still choose their own students makes them more committed to teaching them, he suggests.

"From the outside Oxford looks hopelessly uneconomic, but we seem to be rather effective," he says. He adds that although on average better endowed than their Cambridge equivalents, Oxford colleges are undercapitalised compared to Harvard (£5bn endowments) or Yale (£3bn).

His co-author, Ted Tapper, professor of politics at Sussex, is less committed to the college ideal. "There is a tension in the book," he admits. "Do 18-year-olds want to live in colleges anyway and stand on the towpath cheering their rowing team?"

Plenty do, says Jane Minto, admissions officer for Oxford - 9 out of 10 applicants go for a named college rather than an "open" application to the university. "The opportunity for sport and drama in an informal atmosphere is an enormous plus. You get a chance to know students across all the disciplines."

Both Tapper and Palfreyman see the college system under pressure from the "three Ms" - massification, managerialism and marketisation - and having to change substantially in the next 20 years. Their nightmare scenario is the decay of colleges as they are increasingly starved of income and influence - even the university abandoning its medieval buildings to Disney and operating from cyberspace.

More likely, they say, is Oxford becoming more like Cambridge - where the central university has more control, where the vice-chancellor is appointed for a seven-year term, and where staff feel their main loyalty to the university rather than a college: "The core of the academic faculty at Oxford will continue to wear the two hats of college and university but, as at Cambridge, there will be an increasing tendency for the university hat to assume greater significance. Within this framework the colleges will retain their independence, perhaps becoming more fissiparous, prepared to operate within the confines of university-established parameters, but less respectful of inter-collegiate constraints."

A future where the richer colleges asserted more autonomy would be intensified if, as the authors believe is most likely, colleges start to charge differential top-up fees. The rich colleges would get richer, the poor perhaps go to the wall, and the universities would become more diverse: "There will be several Oxfords as there will be several Cambridges."

In this scenario Oxford and Cambridge universities are moving towards a Harvard model where research and teaching are more separate. "The colleges will provide upmarket high-quality undergraduate teaching and increasingly the central university is the research centre," says Tapper.

The colleges are still inefficient, not only in their domestic arrangements but in the way they organise their teaching, argues Chris Goodall, a local software company director, who offended the dons of Oxford by suggesting that colleges could make huge savings by pooling resources. He asked if each one of them really needed a bursar and a library.

More radically, Goodall said that it was time each college gave up trying to teach virtually every subject. Since he made those comments in 1997 nothing much has changed, he feels. "Nobody has really begun to address that crucial challenge that Oxford has to face - how to make sure students from poor families do not find it more difficult to go there."

It would be wrong to underestimate the money-raising powers of the Oxford colleges, however, and at least some of that is being built up for scholarships, as well as to replace the college fee from the government as it is phased out over the next decade.

The intense loyalty of former students to their colleges rather than to the larger university stems from their human scale, believes Sir Christopher Ball, a former warden of Keble College (and former bursar of Lincoln College). All the colleges have development offices which tap into this sentiment to raise large sums of money - nobody knows how much, but while the university raised £139m in an appeal between 1988 and 1994 on the back of its international reputation, a small college like Lincoln receives commitments of more than £2m a year from old members. The former women's colleges tend to be less well endowed and their ex-members less wealthy.

Sir Christopher outraged Oxbridge when he said that universities had secured excessive increases in college fees from the government "like taking candy from children". In the long term, one-to-one tuition could not be a proper use of public funds when the country was trying to extend higher education to half of all young people.

He is confident that colleges, with their human scale, will adapt and survive by reverting to being privately funded, as they were for the best part of seven centuries. Today they could no longer try to have it both ways by taking state money: "They are brilliant at surviving. They have outperformed almost anything else you can think of - where are the Tudors and Stewarts now? They have outlasted most private enterprises and many state institutions. Some will go to the wall as they have in the past - where is Gloucester College now, or St Albans Hall? But there is nothing worrying about a few Oxford colleges disappearing or merging."

There is no doubt that college days leave their mark. Ask Greenfield. Over dinners at high table, romance with her fellow fellow Peter Atkins blossomed. Reader, she married him.

 Oxford and the Decline of the Collegiate Tradition will be published by Woburn Press later this year.

Idle fellows

The historian Edward Gibbon remembered his college days in the 1750s without affection.

"I speIt fourteen months at Magdalen College; they proved the most idle and unprofitable of my whole life: the reader will pronounce between the school and the scholar; but I cannot affect to believe that nature had disqualified me for all literary pursuits. The fellows [of Magdalen] of my time were decent easy men, who supinely enjoyed the gifts of the founder; their days were filled by a series of uniform employments; the chapel and the hall, the coffee house and the common room, till they retired, weary and well satisfied, to a long slumber. From the toll of reading, or thinking, or writing, they had absolved their conscience; and the first shoots of learning and ingenuity withered on the ground... Dr ----- [his own tutor] well remembered that he had a salary to receive, and only forgot that he had a duty to perform."

 Edward Gibbon, Memoirs

But they're only here for eight weeks," as a 19th-century college head is supposed to have expostulated during a previous modernisation.) The fact that the academics in a college still choose their own students makes them more committed to teaching them, he suggests. "From the outside Oxford looks hopelessly uneconomic, but we seem to be rather effective," he says. He adds that although on average better endowed than their Cambridge equivalents, Oxford colleges are undercapitalised compared to Harvard (£5bn endowments) or Yale (£3bn). His co-author, Ted Tapper, professor of politics at Sussex, is less committed to the college ideal. "There is a tension in the book," he admits. "Do 18-year-olds want to live in colleges anyway and stand on the towpath cheering their rowing team?" Plenty do, says Jane Minto, admissions officer for Oxford - 9 out of 10 applicants go for a named college rather than an "open" application to the university. "The opportunity for sport and drama in an informal atmosphere is an enormous plus. You get a chance to know students across all the disciplines." Both Tapper and Palfreyman see the college system under pressure from the "three Ms" - massification, managerialism and marketisation - and having to change substantially in the next 20 years. Their nightmare scenario is the decay of colleges as they are increasingly starved of income and influence - even the university abandoning its medieval buildings to Disney and operating from cyberspace. More likely, they say, is Oxford becoming more like Cambridge - where the central university has more control, where the vice-chancellor is appointed for a seven-year term, and where staff feel their main loyalty to the university rather than a college: "The core of the academic faculty at Oxford will continue to wear the two hats of college and university but, as at Cambridge, there will be an increasing tendency for the university hat to assume greater significance. Within this framework the colleges will retain their independence, perhaps becoming more fissiparous, prepared to operate within the confines of university-established parameters, but less respectful of inter-collegiate constraints." A future where the richer colleges asserted more autonomy would be intensified if, as the authors believe is most likely, colleges start to charge differential top-up fees. The rich colleges would get richer, the poor perhaps go to the wall, and the universities would become more diverse: "There will be several Oxfords as there will be several Cambridges." In this scenario Oxford and Cambridge universities are moving towards a Harvard model where research and teaching are more separate. "The colleges will provide upmarket high-quality undergraduate teaching and increasingly the central university is the research centre," says Tapper. The colleges are still inefficient, not only in their domestic arrangements but in the way they organise their teaching, argues Chris Goodall, a local software company director, who offended the dons of Oxford by suggesting that colleges could make huge savings by pooling resources. He asked if each one of them really needed a bursar and a library. More radically, Goodall said that it was time each college gave up trying to teach virtually every subject. Since he made those comments in 1997 nothing much has changed, he feels. "Nobody has really begun to address that crucial challenge that Oxford has to face - how to make sure students from poor families do not find it more difficult to go there." It would be wrong to underestimate the money-raising powers of the Oxford colleges, however, and at least some of that is being built up for scholarships, as well as to replace the college fee from the government as it is phased out over the next decade. The intense loyalty of former students to their colleges rather than to the larger university stems from their human scale, believes Sir Christopher Ball, a former warden of Keble College (and former bursar of Lincoln College). All the colleges have development offices which tap into this sentiment to raise large sums of money - nobody knows how much, but while the university raised £139m in an appeal between 1988 and 1994 on the back of its international reputation, a small college like Lincoln receives commitments of more than £2m a year from old members. The former women's colleges tend to be less well endowed and their ex-members less wealthy. Sir Christopher outraged Oxbridge when he said that universities had secured excessive increases in college fees from the government "like taking candy from children". In the long term, one-to-one tuition could not be a proper use of public funds when the country was trying to extend higher education to half of all young people. He is confident that colleges, with their human scale, will adapt and survive by reverting to being privately funded, as they were for the best part of seven centuries. Today they could no longer try to have it both ways by taking state money: "They are brilliant at surviving. They have outperformed almost anything else you can think of - where are the Tudors and Stewarts now? They have outlasted most private enterprises and many state institutions. Some will go to the wall as they have in the past - where is Gloucester College now, or St Albans Hall? But there is nothing worrying about a few Oxford colleges disappearing or merging." There is no doubt that college days leave their mark. Ask Greenfield. Over dinners at high table, romance with her fellow fellow Peter Atkins blossomed. Reader, she married him.  Oxford and the Decline of the Collegiate Tradition will be published by Woburn Press later this year. Idle fellows The historian Edward Gibbon remembered his college days in the 1750s without affection. "I speIt fourteen months at Magdalen College; they proved the most idle and unprofitable of my whole life: the reader will pronounce between the school and the scholar; but I cannot affect to believe that nature had disqualified me for all literary pursuits. Dr ----- [his own tutor] well remembered that he had a salary to receive, and only forgot that he had a duty to perform."  Edward Gibbon, Memoirs

fields.headline: It's never too late
fields.standfirst: It's Adult Learners Week and awards are going to those who have transformed their lives with new knowledge and skills.  John Crace went to meet one of the winners
fields.trailText: It's Adult Learners Week and awards are going to those who have transformed their lives with new knowledge and skills. John Crace went to meet one of the winners
fields.body:
Seven days of celebrity jollies and activities got under way last Saturday to mark Adult Learners Week. Jon Snow, Phil Redmond and Anthea Turner will be lending their names and time, while the Bishop of Tewkesbury, the Rt Revd. John Went will be picking up the odd blister as he attempts to learn some ballroom dance steps. Hopefully the bishop won't have to dance alone, as the National Organisation for Adult Learning (NIACE) is organising a series of events up and down the country in colleges, schools, libraries, museums, supermarkets, shopping malls, pubs and even on the bus to get people involved in some kind of learning.

For roughly 100 people, though, the highlight of the week will be the awards to celebrate the inspiring stories of those who have beaten the odds and turned their lives around through learning. It's not often you come across a competition that stipulates a minimum age limit of 85, but in reality you don't stand a prayer of winning the oldest learner category unless you're at least 100. Fred Moore is 107, looks 30 years longer, and appears a dead cert to pick up the award for the forseeable future.

Picking up the award for England's most inspiring learner was Emily May Butterfield, 94, known to everyone as Aunt May. She left school before she was 12. "The teacher didn't believe I had done something right," she says. "So I walked out and refused to come back." She taught herself to read and write and took jobs waitressing and running a cafe, before joining the Auxiliary Fire Service at the outbreak of the second world war. After the war she devoted 40 years to fostering over 100 children at her home in Devon. "I bought a dictionary for the children so they wouldn't be at a disadvantage with their homework," she adds in acknowledgment that her own lack of formal education created limits to the amount of help she could give.

Aunt May now lives in sheltered accommodation in Taunton. Four months ago she got a form through the post which she could barely understand. She filled it in as best she could, only to get a reply saying she had done so incorrectly and could she please fill in a further four forms. This was the last straw.

"I was fed up with feeling out of my depth," she says, "so I went and registered for English and maths classes at the Somerset College of Arts and Technology." Which is where you will now find her each week between 10 and 12 on Monday mornings and between 1 and 3 on Friday afternoons.

"I feel much more confident and I've refound my self-respect," she explains with justifiable pride.

But you don't have to be an octogenarian or older to get something out of adult learning. Tracey Carruthers, aged 35, began a basic English class in 1999. She had no reading or writing skills and had to identify goods in the supermarket by the colour of the tins. She attended a basic skills summer school and is currently working towards an Open College English certificate and plans to write a book. Robert McKittrick-Gallaher spent five years on the street when drink dominated his life. He is now working towards an NVQ in television and radio.

There are any number of similarly inspirational stories to be found and they all make great photo opportunities for Malcolm Wicks, Minister for Lifelong Learning. But without wanting to take anything away from the achievements of all these adult learners, you can't help concluding that the lifelong learning initiative has been far from an unmitigated success. This is the ninth year of Adult Learners Week and the divide between those who get back to some form of learning and those who don't is as wide as ever.

According to a participation survey published by NIACE last year only one in four adults are currently engaged in education and those who left school without any formal qualifications are the least likely to get involved in adult learning in later life; a staggering 87% of people who have done no learning since school say they are unlikely to do so in the future. All of which rather suggests that the adult learning message just isn't getting through to those who could benefit most from it.

The picture looks bleaker still when you discover that, despite the fact that it is widely accepted that older people are one of this country's most valuable untapped resources and that a recent study by the Institute for Employment Studies for the DfEE confirms that older people in learning feel better about themselves and their health and tend to lead active lives, there has been a 20% fall in participation by retired people in adult learning in the past three years.

So what can be done to dislodge these entrenched cultural attitudes and get people to view learning as a valuable resource rather than a waste of time?

The short and depressing answer may well be nothing; and that all you can hope to achieve is to make sure the opportunities are there for those who want to take them. Which is why Adult Learners Week is still important as a means of keeping the message alive - even if it actually makes little difference to the numbers engaged in adult learning.

And you can always hope. After all, as Aunt May herself would admit, if she can learn to use a computer, anyone can.

fields.headline: Future hopes
fields.standfirst: Richard Bourne  reads a new report on universities and socioeconomic development
fields.trailText: With the growth of the knowledge economy, a new report puts universities at the forefront of development
fields.body:
When development judders to a halt, as in Sierra Leone or Zimbabwe now, where are the universities? Trying against all the odds to keep going.

In Sierra Leone, whose Fourah Bay College dates back to 1827, concerned students have been playing their part - amid ravaged towns and amputated limbs - in the National Forum for Human Rights. In the University of Zimbabwe (whose chancellor is Comrade R Mugabe) students were teargassed at the time of the famous Harare Declaration in 1991. They and their academics have been steadily widening the political space in a de facto one-party state, in spite of economic rundown and physical intimidation.

"A country whose universities are allowed to decline is opting out of the development process at the start of the 21st century." This is the uncomfortable conclusion of a new report on the future of universities in developing countries, published by the Association of Commonwealth Universities (ACU). It is uncomfortable because, in the wake of the Dakar conference on the elusive target of education for all, cash-strapped governments may feel they are being pulled in impossibly contradictory directions. But the team put together by the Commonwealth Policy Studies Unit, and chaired by Paul Davenport, vice-chancellor of the University of Western Ontario, also offers hope: universities in developing countries can do a lot to help themselves.

The team's thesis is that universities and their graduates are critical to the knowledge economy now driving socioeconomic development. This is true for Bangalore and Hyderabad in India, two of the IT hotspots in South Asia. At the other extreme, the sorry state of campuses in Nigeria and several other countries in sub-Saharan Africa is one reason for the decades of African development lost.

In the 1960s the leaders of independence, themselves usually graduates, had no doubt that universities were crucial to nation-building and growth. But over the next 30 years academic stocks fell: brain drain, campus dissent, the seeming expense of tertiary education when set against demands for other tax-financed services and the 1990s preference for basic education at all costs undermined the universities. Underpaid staff and decaying facilities created a vicious circle in much of the Third World, and in countries like South Africa a huge range of private institutions of varying standards tried to fill the breach.

The group chaired by Davenport included seven nationalities and a high-powered mix: among them were Goverdhan Mehta, director of the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, Andrew Downes, director of the Institute of Economic and Social Research at Cave Hill, Barbados; Ruth Pearson, Director of the Centre for Development Studies at Leeds; and Derrick Swartz, acting vice-chancellor at Fort Hare, Nelson Mandela's alma mater. The group met once, with support from the British Council, and then deliberated by email.

The members do not challenge the importance of basic education, but they want a recognition, by political leaders and academics themselves, that universities are becoming increasingly crucial. Universities need to demonstrate accountability and have more flexible academic packages for students; they need to involve more stakeholders, benchmark their achievements, and do more to generate income from outside government. Special efforts will be needed to recruit good science and technology students by talent searches and scholarship schemes. Brain drain should be confronted, with firms in developed countries stimulating IT jobs in developing countries, and joint appointments straddling universities in developing and developed states.

The group acknowledges that there is no simple, linear connection between higher education and development, but Downes quotes recent research from Ghana, South Africa, Tanzania and Uganda to show that the rate of return for education at university level is higher than rates for primary and secondary education. The average tertiary gross enrolment for the five wealthiest Commonwealth countries (Singapore, UK, Australia, Canada and New Zealand) more than doubled from 27.2% in 1980 to 62.8% in 1996. However, among the lowest-income countries there were serious drops in tertiary enrolment in Zambia, Bangladesh and the Gambia in the same period.

There is also an increasing awareness that universities in developing countries can be direct actors. And not only by setting up science parks or stimulating agricultural improvement. The famous Grameen Bank, the microcredit agency founded by Professor Mahammad Yunus of the economics department at Chittagong University, Bangladesh, resulted from fieldwork in neighbouring villages.

When university research does bear fruit, however, it can be hard to ensure that the developing country itself reaps the rewards. One case in point involved a discovery by one of Mehta's Bangalore research colleagues that enhanced the scope and memory of silicon chips. The publication of his results sparked immediate commercial interest from Intel in the US, which contacted the researcher and offered to protect the intellectual property of his discovery and to take him under its wing. He reported at once to Mehta, who moved to protect the interests both of the researcher and of the Indian Institute of Science. As Mehta points out, however, it can be hard to get a fair deal because the US has a head start with its intellectual property lawyers.

Other useful inputs come from students on sandwich courses, who spread best practice rapidly in institutions and communities. Pearson cites the master's course in international child welfare, run by the University of East Anglia in the UK, for people with social-work qualifications from the Third World. Its second semester is a unit of supervised professional practice in the student's own country, often in their original place of work.

The report does not suggest that it will be easy to correct some of the problems. With the US, Germany and the UK all offering fast-track entry to IT personnel, especially from South Asia, the issue of brain drain remains serious. In 1990 almost a quarter of a million people with tertiary-level education from India lived in the US. Data shows that brain drain has seriously affected Fiji, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Gambia, Ghana, Sierra Leone, Uganda, Jamaica and Trinidad.

The Commonwealth study is a call to arms, one which has interesting parallels to a recent World Bank/Unesco publication Peril and Promise: Higher Education in Developing Countries. The Commonwealth Policy Studies Unit, a new thinktank attached to the Institute of Commonwealth Studies at London University, is working with the ACU to ensure that there is widespread discussion and follow-up. The report suggests universities could re-emphasise their social purpose with a Commonwealth University Charter for the new century.

Already Ministers of Education and the Commonwealth Secretariat are working on a new, aspirational Education Declaration, to come out of a meeting of ministers at Halifax, Nova Scotia in November. It is hoped there will also be a special meeting in South Asia, and a presentation to next year's Commonwealth Business Forum in Australia, focused on the role of universities in development.

Three years ago, in Edinburgh, the Commonwealth leaders signed up to the goal of halving the number of people living in absolute poverty by 2015. With the growth of the knowledge economy that goal cannot be achieved without universities.

 Richard Bourne is head of the Commonwealth Policy Studies Unit. Copies of Universities and Development may be obtained from the ACU at 36 Gordon Square, London WC1H 0PF

fields.headline: Golden hellos all round
fields.standfirst: A scheme to lure trainee teachers is set to include lecturers too
fields.trailText: A scheme to lure trainee teachers is set to include lecturers too
fields.body:
The government looks set to introduce salaries to lure graduates to train as further education lecturers. The Department for Education and Employment is urgently trying to reckon the cost of matching the proposed bursary scheme, which will pay graduates between £6,000 and £13,000 to train as schoolteachers.

The schools scheme, announced by the education and employment secretary David Blunkett after this year's budget, is intended to avert a looming teacher recruitment crisis.

But the combined effect of paying trainee schoolteachers golden hellos and of the growing gap between teachers' and lecturers' salaries is bound to make the crisis in lecturer recruitment even worse, according to Natfhe, the lecturers' union.

The union's general secretary, Paul Mackney, raised the issue when a Natfhe delegation recently met Blunkett. The education secretary reportedly replied: "We'd better make a policy decision. We'll do it as a matter of urgency, but we just need to get the costing."

Since then civil servants have emailed the Universities Council for the Education of Teachers (UCET) asking for "urgent" statistics on the numbers currently doing postgraduate certificate in education (PGCE) for further education. The Council estimates there are about 1,000 graduates on further education PGCEs and probably more non-graduates on further education "CertEd" courses.

At the same meeting with Natfhe, Blunkett allegedly indicated a desire to step into the long-running pay dispute between lecturing and support staff unions and further education employers. One Natfhe official said: "He said a line had to be drawn under the situation where 'silver book' lecturers aren't getting pay increases."

This theory will be tested out when unions and employers jointly meet Baroness Blackstone in early June. More cash from government for pay, they reckon, must be a non-starter before the new comprehensive spending review is completed, since so much of the cash for further education announced last November has been earmarked for specific projects.

Pay will be uppermost at Natfhe's national conference this weekend in Blackpool. The union's claim for a flat £2,500 for everyone, to bridge the 8% gap between average teachers' and lecturers' salaries, was turned down by the Association of Colleges.

The association is offering a 3.3% increase on all salaries or £330, whichever is greater. This matches the percentage increase school teachers will receive and so does nothing to narrow the pay gap.

The Natfhe leadership is stressing that although the figures are disappointing, the accompanying package is a giant leap forward. This includes a deal not to use the bottom two bands of the main grade lecturers scale, roughly between £13,000 and £15,000, development of a long term approach to pay in the sector, and a continuing joint approach to government.

The offer is to go out to Natfhe branches for consultation, and they will be urged to ballot members after conference.

 Andrew Murray, Natfhe's southern region branch secretary, has lost claims for unfair dismissal and victimisation for trade union activities against his former employers at Cricklade College near Andover after a 12-day industrial tribunal hearing.

Natfhe's general secretary Paul Mackney said: "We would certainly take the case again and will look to see if there are grounds for appeal."

Cricklade's principal Elizabeth Blakemore said: "Cricklade College believes it has been fully vindicated by the judgements of the tribunal... and welcomes the tribunal's rejection of the allegations of victimisation of trade union activists."
