Since then civil servants have emailed the Universities Council for the Education of Teachers (UCET) asking for "urgent" statistics on the numbers currently doing postgraduate certificate in education (PGCE) for further education. The Council estimates there are about 1,000 graduates on further education PGCEs and probably more non-graduates on further education "CertEd" courses. At the same meeting with Natfhe, Blunkett allegedly indicated a desire to step into the long-running pay dispute between lecturing and support staff unions and further education employers. One Natfhe official said: "He said a line had to be drawn under the situation where 'silver book' lecturers aren't getting pay increases." This theory will be tested out when unions and employers jointly meet Baroness Blackstone in early June. More cash from government for pay, they reckon, must be a non-starter before the new comprehensive spending review is completed, since so much of the cash for further education announced last November has been earmarked for specific projects. Pay will be uppermost at Natfhe's national conference this weekend in Blackpool. The union's claim for a flat £2,500 for everyone, to bridge the 8% gap between average teachers' and lecturers' salaries, was turned down by the Association of Colleges. The association is offering a 3.3% increase on all salaries or £330, whichever is greater. This matches the percentage increase school teachers will receive and so does nothing to narrow the pay gap. The Natfhe leadership is stressing that although the figures are disappointing, the accompanying package is a giant leap forward. This includes a deal not to use the bottom two bands of the main grade lecturers scale, roughly between £13,000 and £15,000, development of a long term approach to pay in the sector, and a continuing joint approach to government. The offer is to go out to Natfhe branches for consultation, and they will be urged to ballot members after conference.  Andrew Murray, Natfhe's southern region branch secretary, has lost claims for unfair dismissal and victimisation for trade union activities against his former employers at Cricklade College near Andover after a 12-day industrial tribunal hearing. Natfhe's general secretary Paul Mackney said: "We would certainly take the case again and will look to see if there are grounds for appeal." Cricklade's principal Elizabeth Blakemore said: "Cricklade College believes it has been fully vindicated by the judgements of the tribunal... and welcomes the tribunal's rejection of the allegations of victimisation of trade union activists."

fields.headline: On the right road again
fields.standfirst: Helen Carter visits an alternative school offering hope to kids who slipped through the net of mainstream education
fields.trailText: Helen Carter visits an alternative school offering hope to kids who slipped through the net of mainstream education
fields.body:
When Michael Nicholls was in a mainstream school, he used to fight and throw chairs at teachers. But now he is a student at Oaktree Education Trust, a unique initiative in Liverpool, set in a sprawling Edwardian building overlooking Sefton Park.

Michael no longer throws furniture and instead takes his aggression out in the boxing ring. "I was fighting one day in my mainstream school and I just flipped," he says. "I started throwing chairs around and one of the chairs hit a teacher, so I was excluded.

"I was told by a teacher that I was never going to go anywhere with my life. Last year I went back to the same school and told the teacher what I was doing with my life. To see the look of shock on his face was brilliant."

Michael, now 16, has blossomed at Oaktree. "I have been here nearly four years," he adds. "When I first came here, one of the students offered me a cup of tea and made me feel welcome. It was very important to feel that way."

All 30 students, aged between 11 and 16, are in similar positions. They have slipped through the net of mainstream education; some have been bullied, others were persistent truants, or have had behavioural problems at school.

The trust aims to offer them a lifeline by providing an exciting and alternative education in a stimulating environment. The students have a say in which teachers are appointed and what subjects they learn. If they don't like a teacher's style, he is unlikely to get the job. The school has a student council, with elections that were held on the same day as the local elections.

The candidates had to write their own campaign catchphrase and to design their campaign posters. They then had to deliver a speech in front of their fellow students before the vote.

Each day at Oaktree is divided into five sessions interspersed by breaks and circle meetings - where students hand in their homework and also thrash out any problems. Students are invited to comment on their end-of-term reports next to their teachers' comments and they are always realistic about their shortcomings.

The curriculum incorporates themed weeks. One week, the students could be learning about Spanish history, culture, art and language, the next week about Clause 28, democracy and Bloody Sunday in a politics-themed week.

They are also taught about human rights, self defence and how to become streetwise and a range of sports and martial arts are on offer. At lunchtime, the students sit alongside their tutors and they eat and talk together.

James Kinsella is another typical student. A few months ago his ambition was to drive tug boats. Now he plans to go to university. He had refused to go to secondary school because he wasn't offered the schools he wanted and was taught by home tutors.

"I got fed up with that," he says. "I was reading the local paper and I came across Oaktree and gave them a call. At first I didn't come into Oaktree because I had been away from school for so long so I could catch up with my work."

James was involved in positive outreach - because of his disaffection with mainstream education. He was visited at home by staff from Oaktree and gradually integrated into the trust.

Sarah Haves was bullied at her school and was a persistent truant for 16 months. "I was really bored," she says. "The teachers used to say that the only place I was going to was the dole queue. Now I am looking at becoming an architect."

Fiona Watts, the education co-ordinator at Oaktree, has re-mortgaged her house so that it can stay open. The trust has also been awarded funding for every pupil from Liverpool education authority for the first time in its 10-year history.

The trust was originally set up by Sister Marie Fillingham, a nun, who wanted to provide an alternative holistic method of education.

Watts says: "We are not criticising teachers here - it goes higher up than that and it is the system that creates ogres out of people. Mainstream education is too much about force-feeding and dictating to students but young people learn more if they discover it themselves.

"Our curriculum between Monday and Thursday is the opposite of what David Blunkett is talking about with longer school days and bigger terms."

When she applied for the job of education co-ordinator just over a year ago, her teaching skills were assessed by a panel of students before she was interviewed by the board of trustees.

"Because we are such a small place I know the names of students' mums, dads and all the people in their wider circle of friends," she says. "This would not happen in a mainstream school. For those students who find mainstream schools a hostile and oppressive environment, we offer a friendly, nurturing environment."

 The trust is currently looking for volunteers, mentors and teachers to help them. Anyone interested can contact Oaktree on 0151-727 7231.

fields.headline: Under cover
fields.standfirst: Using supply teachers is a thorny issue. Phil Revell finds some schools with answers
fields.trailText: Using supply teachers is a thorny issue. Phil Revell finds some schools with answers
fields.body:
Keith Hollins is taking a class at the Westwood High School in Leek. It's an RE lesson and the group is getting on with some coursework. Keith helps where he can, but his speciality is geography and he found out he would be teaching this group less than half an hour ago. It's a cover lesson.

Government statistics released last week show that sickness-related absence in schools amounts to more than 2.5 million days a year. More than half the workforce took time off through illness, an average of five days for each teacher at a cost of £300 million a year.

But sickness is only half the story. The cover list at Westwood has only one teacher off ill. The A4 sheet has nine teachers out of lessons for all or part of the day. One is out of school with a sports team, two are supervising language exams and five are involved in an interview for a new staff member. Keith Hollins is covering for Dave Lyons, whose responsibility for newly qualified teachers means he needs to meet candidates to explain the school's induction procedures.

Cover is the bane of many schools. In theory schools simply contact supply agencies, but many teachers see supply as a last resort; schools like Westwood use their own staff if they can. "It's very difficult to come into a school and pick up the system," says Westwood's Keith Hollins.

"Supply teachers don't know the policies. They don't even know where the rooms are. When a class perceives that you know far less than them about what's going on in a school, it places you at a disadvantage."

And cover is a real source of stress for teachers. "It's the last-minute nature of it," says Hollins. "I have a team of six tutors, five of whom have taught for three years or less. They find cover extremely stressful. You plan your marking, you plan your lesson preparation... and then you suddenly find you can't do either because you're on cover. It impinges on everything, you're always pushing things back."

Parents are also concerned about a system that often leaves their children without proper teaching. "It just seems to be an expensive baby-sitting service," said one, whose teenage daughter was following an exam course. "The teacher was away and they were given a colouring-in exercise." Another reported that her child had been given the same history lesson four weeks running because the regular teacher had been on a course.

Dorit Brown, the chief executive of the advice agency Parentline, argues that supply teachers often create problems because they're not aware of school policies or the background of the class they are taking.

In secondary schools children may find their entire day managed by cover teachers. "There are well-recorded instances of pupil tracking," says Robin Casson at Prudhoe Community High School in Northumberland, "where pupils have had a succession of cover and supply teachers. They haven't seen a specialist teacher all day."

And the supply of supply is drying up. In the late 80s and 90s, supply teachers were often those who had been given early retirement but still wished to keep in contact with the job by working occasionally. Restrictions on early retirement have cut off that source and in cities heads may have to spend hours on the phone searching for a stand-in teacher.

In March Ruth Harker, the head of Bournville School in Birmingham, was unable to find anyone to cover an absence. "There was no supply teacher at any agency in the city available for the absence we wanted to cover," she said.

Heads in London are concerned about the situation in September, when many of the Australian supply teachers will return home for the Olympics.

Some schools have imaginative answers to the problem. Brooke Weston school in Corby is one of the most successful state schools in the country, but uses no supply teachers. "We don't use supply," says its headteacher, Peter Simpson. Absence at Brooke Weston is covered internally.

"Classes are small, 25 or under, and we team teach," he says. "It's well structured, well organised team-teaching. If one teacher is away the lessons can continue with the remaining member of staff managing both groups."

For three years the Beacon Community School in east Sussex ran a system based on its computer suites. These learn centres were a place for children to go for individually focused education when their teachers were away. The system involved teachers preparing work in advance which would be available for the children to do. "A bête noir of mine for many years," says Beacon's principal Alison Banks, "was the wasted curriculum time caused by cover lessons and seeing the frustration of colleagues losing their free time to cover a class, often at the very time when they needed the time for marking and preparation."

An alternative solution could be for the government to fund schools to cover absence internally. After the election David Blunkett asserted that training in school time must stop because it disrupted children's education, but the flow of initiatives requiring teachers to take time out has continued.

This kind of training is funded by the government's huge standards fund, whether it's for literacy and numeracy initiatives, or as preparation for performance-related pay. Westwood School in Leek received £34,000 of standards funding last year, much of it to pay supply teachers.

The deputy head Mike Gledhill would like to see the government allow the school to use the money to hire full-time staff - to eliminate the need for supply and to allow absence to be covered internally. He's not alone.

"The issue of non-contact time affects everyone from the head down to the newest teacher," says David Hart, the general secretary of the National Association of Headteachers. "The government has got to understand that its initiatives have thrown up enormous training demands."

Hart would like to see more money available for non-contact time in schools and a start could be made with standards funding, with schools given the freedom to spend it on mainstream staffing.

"At the moment in my staffroom the talk isn't about performance-related pay," says Northumberland's Robin Casson. "It's about time - how will we find the time to do things. If money could be found to protect non-contact time, the quality of teaching would improve in all areas. My most pressing need is to give my staff some quality time."

fields.headline: A great meeting
fields.trailText: The summer term is here and so we're starting to plan enthusiastically for our Parents Annual General Meeting and the associated report to parents.
fields.body:
The summer term is here and so we're starting to plan enthusiastically for our Parents Annual General Meeting and the associated report to parents. This will come as a surprise to some who see the annual meeting and report as chores imposed by the Department for Education, so I would like to explain why we are enthusiastic and what we do to try to get our pupils' parents and guardians enthusiastic, too.

At our school we value our relationship with parents or guardians greatly and the staff spend a lot of time working on this. One example is to encourage parents or guardians to come to parents' evenings. Since we as a governing body wholeheartedly support this strategy, it's only logical for us to play a real part in it too.

Our annual report is for the parents and guardians, but is produced by the governors. This means it covers the things we think parents want to hear about and is presented in a way that invites them to read it. It also means that it says what the governors have been doing and plan to do. We talk about things like the new hot meals service, which governors were heavily involved in, but not about school events, such as school trips, in which we governors have little involvement.

Getting a full hall of parents to the annual meeting is the easy part. A typical agenda starts with presentations by pupils, has a talk by me on the past year and plans for the future, includes talks by guest speakers, and ends with more entertainment by the children. We then have an open session with soft drinks and nibbles where parents can have a quiet word with governors if they wish. We also invite every important person we can think of to our annual meeting, including local education authority officers, local councillors and former staff, as we see it as the ideal occasion to promote what we are doing within the school.

The feedback we get from parents on both the report and the annual meeting is always very positive. It is also one of the most fun and rewarding things I get to do as chair of governors.

 Matthew Rees is chair of governors at a primary school in Kingston upon Thames and can be contacted at eesinham@netscapeonline.co.uk

fields.headline: Back to their roots
fields.standfirst: Scottish Month has enabled pupils to focus on their own nation and learn about its rich culture and heritage
fields.trailText: Scottish Month has enabled pupils to focus on their own nation and learn about its rich culture and heritage
fields.body:
In a world where we are able to communicate across great distances and peek into the lives of people in other continents via a satellite, it's easy to forget your own history. However, pupils at Sighthill Primary school, Edinburgh, have the opportunity to positively bask in the rich heritage of their home nation, thanks to "Scottish Month".

As part of environmental studies, the pupils are required to gain an understanding of the people in their area: their past and heritage. This is where Scottish month comes in.

The youngest pupils in the school begin their cultural induction with a taster of famous Scots, but it is not until the middle and upper years that this jumble of characters are put into the context of key events and important dates. Topics covered include a roll call of what Sassenachs think they know about Scottish history: Robert the Bruce, Mary Queen of Scots, the Acts of Union, Bonnie Prince Charlie (before and after the Skye boat song), and Culloden.

But it's not just historical figures that provide interest. There is also an immediate resource in the form of an exhibition entitled Shaping a Nation. The exhibition aims to debunk stereotypes and myths about Scotland, and to leave behind a lasting impression of the immense contribution this country has made upon the way we live in the 21st century.

Through interactive technology and audiovisual displays, visitors gain an insight into why Scotland is renowned for its innovation in science, engineering and design.

June Henderson, deputy headteacher at Sighthill, took a group of pupils to the exhibition earlier this year. She wasn't sure what the pupils would make of it all, but they loved every minute. "It definitely raised awareness for them of the country as a whole and their culture in particular," Henderson says. "It's a really fun way to learn about Scotland and helped to give pupils a sense of the chronology and context of what they'd learned in school, a bit like the parts of a jigsaw puzzle fitting into place."

The teachers at Sighthill were pleasantly surprised at just how much information the pupils had retained, and the excitement it generated back in the classroom.

Henderson is well aware that many pupils at Sighthill come from economic backgrounds that make such trips difficult, and feels that schools should be able to provide these opportunities.

Scottish month culminates in an evening of words and music for parents or guardians, performed by pupils.

 Shaping a Nation is at Fountainpark, Dundee Street, Edinburgh.

fields.headline: Second chance to shine
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot finds the Ishango club is overcoming prejudice and raising black children's ambitions
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot finds the Ishango club is overcoming prejudice and raising black children's ambitions
fields.body:
Straight off the bus from school, the kids bound up the stairs, throw down their bags and buckle down to the day's second set of lessons. There are around 20, aged 15 and 16, split between two attic rooms in a spacious, Victorian building once occupied by an advertising agency.

Today it's the headquarters of the Ishango Science Club and the hub of the expanding African-Caribbean Network for Science and Technology. From its beginnings here in the north-west five years ago, Ishango now has outposts in Birmingham, Nottingham, Leicester and, most recently, Peckham, south London. Another is planned for Sheffield.

Although under no obligation, the network was confident enough about the standards to invite Her Majesty's inspectors to view the Manchester and Birmingham operations at the end of last year. Ofsted's recently published report praises the attitude of the pupils and the commitment of the teachers.

Teaching ranged from satisfactory to good. Inspectors, though, felt there was room for improvement in assessing pupils and monitoring their progress. Also, there should be better links between Ishango and its feeder schools, primary and secondary.

Each after-school club takes in around 180 children a week. They're aged between eight and 16, and different age-groups attend on different evenings. These are children, remember, who have already spent a day at school. So have the Ishango teachers, for that matter. Yet here in Manchester is Farrah Iqbal, back at the chalk-face, patiently explaining the difference between protons, neutrons and electrons. Across the landing Sandra Brown from Styrtford High School is going through some past GCSE maths papers in a room decorated with posters on quadratic sequences, speed and density and, rather incongruously, the prologue to Chaucer's Canterbury Tales.

Downstairs is an information technology suite with 18 computer terminals, supplied though a one-off grant from Lloyds-TSB. Grants have also come from the Nuffield Foundation and Trafford's local education authority, but not Manchester's. There's funding from local education authorities in Birmingham, Nottingham and Southwark but not Leicester (nor Liverpool where the Ishango club was forced to close down at the end of last year through lack of resources).

"I think we're an embarrassment to some local education authorities," says the director Liz Rasekoala. "It's an admission that their schools are failing Afro-Caribbean pupils."

She first became aware of the problem when she arrived in this country from Nigeria in 1984 with a first in chemical engineering. There were other black graduates on her masters degree course in Manchester, but all had been educated abroad.

"As for undergraduates, there was not one doing science and engineering," she says. "When I mentioned it to my supervisor, he talked about the hypocrisy of a British education system which purports to offer third-world countries help with education but can't seem to bring on British-born black children to become doctors, scientists and engineers.

"Perhaps the British Council should sort out kids in areas like Moss Side before trying to spread science and technology in Uganda."

Rasekoala founded Ishango in 1995 with a few fellow black professionals who shared her frustration. More than 10 years on from her arrival from Africa, she felt nothing much had changed. Black children, she maintains, are "under siege" on three fronts - the home, the class room and the media.

"Look at hospital dramas here and in America," she says. "You find black doctors in ER, but not in Casualty or Holby City. Nurses or paramedics, yes, but not doctors. It's difficult to appreciate what it means to grow up in a society where your only positive role models are in music and sport.

"And there's still an insidious stereotype, prevalent among teachers. Too many don't seem able to look at a black child and think about anything else but sport and music. Academic expectations are still pitched too low. It's very difficult for a black child to challenge a teacher's assumptions. That's true of parents, too. They're largely ignorant of the education system because they've had a devastating experience from it themselves."

Some - invariably mothers - have recovered enough to realise that their children need a second chance which they never had. "But it needs to be a real second chance," says Rasekoala, who is dismissive about Saturday morning classes in black history and culture. "There are a lot of good intentions, but the academic rigour's not there. We live in a western technological society and these children need pieces of paper.

"The black community must work with the mainstream. We invited Ofsted because we're running a hard-edged programme with qualified teachers working with no more than 10 children at a time. And we're already addressing the criticisms put forward."

"Meanwhile, we want to get the message back to local education authorities and headteachers in mainstream schools that there must be a better way of doing things."

fields.headline: Burger battles
fields.standfirst: School dinners may not mean boiled cabbage and pie but  John Crace finds it is still a fight to get the little darlings to choose cauliflower cheese instead of chips
fields.trailText: School dinners may not mean boiled cabbage and pie but John Crace finds it is still a fight to get the little darlings to choose cauliflower cheese instead of chips
fields.body:
It's the calm before the storm. The cavernous, brightly-coloured hall of the Central Foundation boys school echoes to the sound of food trays being laid out on the hot counter. In five minutes, the first of nearly 400 human locusts will swarm through the dining-room, munching their way through mountains of pizza, burgers and chips. Within 40 minutes the onslaught will be over and all that will be left for the caterers to do is decide how to dispose of the salads, the baked potatoes and the lamb noodles that will have remained virtually untouched.

School dinners have always come in for flak as few remember with affection the taste, or smell, of boiled cabbage and steak and gristle pie. But the debate has moved away from matters of taste to one of nutrition, amid fears that children are turning into junk-food addicts. Average sugar consumption has risen in Britain by more than 30% since 1980 and, according to the National Audit Office, Britain is the proud holder of the title for the fattest European nation, with 17% of men and 20% of women considered clinically obese.

Of more concern to schools is the alarming rise in obesity in children, confirmed by a recent report from the Medical Research Council. It concludes that today's children are more at risk of developing osteoporosis, heart and respiratory diseases and some forms of cancer than their more deprived parents and grandparents. Eating habits are learned primarily at home, but research by Mintel on behalf of Iceland has found most parents believe schools should be doing more to teach children about healthy eating.

But how do you convert that knowledge into practice? How do you get the little darlings to say no to chips? The simple answer is, you don't. You can put as many salads on the menu as you like, but given a choice of eating healthily or bingeing on junk, most children will opt for the latter. Caterers dare not take junk off the menu because they know kids will vote with their feet and head for McDonald's.

There are no easy victories in the burger battle and most schools have reconciled themselves to a long war of attrition. Central Foundation is trying a different approach - stealth. Derek Powell, the deputy head, has been in charge of the school's catering makeover, involving a switch to new caterers. "We have 840 pupils and only 300 or so were eating on site. Of these, roughly 250 were on free dinners. We looked at other schools and reckoned it was possible to get more boys in and make the food healthier and more appetising."

So the doughnuts and pies have gone and a coat of paint, slicker service and a more appetising main course and pudding have come in. Powell has got it right on one count. Two weeks into the new regime and an extra hundred boys are using the dining-room, but they're nearly all packing in the saturated fats.

Jesse is first through the door, making straight for the pizza, burgers and chips. "I always eat pizza," he says, amazed that I should challenge him about his diet. Daniel and Bobby are on meal tickets, and for their £1.25 allowance they choose pizza and chips. "You used to be able to get a drink as well, but they've put the prices up," they chorus in outrage. So why not go for the main meal and pudding if you feel you're being ripped off? They look at me in disbelief, as the idea has clearly never crossed their mind. "I need to feel filled up," says Daniel.

The need to feel full is a common response among the boys when asked about their meal choice. But none associate feeling full with healthy eating. I only come across one boy who admits to thinking about his diet and eating salad. A couple have a go at the lamb noodles and cauliflower cheese and only one boy, Jake, opts for the ham sandwich. "I actually wanted a slice of pizza, but they'd sold out," he confesses.

Powell admits it's an uphill struggle to improve diets as there's a fine balance between a healthy menu and an empty dining-room, but he hopes to gradually ensure that chips are not a daily option. David Marney, senior operations manager for Chartwells, the caterers, appears unconvinced, but tries to reassure me that pizza is not that unhealthy before adding, "we do make sure that the healthier options are the best value on the menu".

But price is not really the issue. There is a certain correlation between low-income families and poor diet but these boys aren't stupid. They know what is and isn't healthy. They just don't give a damn one way or the other. They are still young enough to feel immortal, untouched by adult concerns of obesity and heart disease. In any case, they find the appeal and marketing of junk food specialists, McDonald's and KFC, infinitely more attractive than a few government directives.

So what can be done? For the boys at secondary school the answer is almost certainly not very much - unless parents take more responsibility and stop expecting schools to deal with the problem in isolation. At primary school it may be a different matter. The department of social medicine at Bristol University, in conjunction with the health promotion division of the National Assembly for Wales, has been piloting a fruit tuck shop project in 28 schools in the west country.

"The aim is to get nine and 10-year- olds to eat more healthily," says Dr Joanna Moe, a researcher on the project. "We targeted schools where there was no tuck shop, and asked them to set one up, to be run by the children, which only sold fruit. The idea was that if children had money that could only be spent on fruit, they would rather do that than not spend it all." The results will not be available till later this year, but Dr Moe is happy with the results so far. But will these children take their good habits on to secondary school? "Ah," she sighs, "that's the big unanswered question." Watch this space.
